HEADLINE: Bush's Debt?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "When the Economy Slows" (editorial, Dec. 20): 
 Whether or not a recession is truly looming, a $1.3 trillion tax cut is ludicrous, especially when one considers that 40 percent of that tax cut would be enjoyed by the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers.
In view of all the challenges that face a new president, that George W. Bush's priorities lie primarily with those of immense wealth tells us that perhaps this is simply part of his "debt" to those who helped put him in office.
 
PATTY ADJAMINE
New York, Dec. 20, 2000

HEADLINE: November Factory Orders Up 2.3%, Led by Aircraft

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Commerce Department reported today that factory orders rose 2.3 percent in November after a 6.5 percent drop during October.
A surge in aircraft orders led the increase. Excluding transportation equipment, orders rose 0.4 percent in November after falling 3.1 percent during October. 
 Spending on durable goods, unadjusted for inflation, fell 1.2 percent in November, the same as October. General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler sold fewer new cars and trucks in November, and trimmed production to reduce inventories. The appliance manufacturer, Whirlpool, plans to cut as many as 6,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its worldwide work force, because of sluggish sales.
Spending on nondurable goods was unchanged after rising 0.4 percent in October. Retailers' same-store sales rose 3.5 percent in November as the chains cut prices on clothing and other items to attract holiday shoppers. Ann Taylor Stores said earnings in the fiscal fourth quarter would miss forecasts because of the early markdown of prices on velvet clothing and other holiday items.
Consumer spending rose in November, led by higher utility costs, while incomes recovered from the previous month's decline, the department said.
The 0.3 percent increase in spending on goods and services last month followed a 0.4 percent rise during October, the report said. Adjusted for inflation -- the result largely of rising energy prices -- spending rose 0.1 percent, the weakest performance since a similar increase in March. Incomes rose 0.4 percent in November after a 0.1 percent decline in October, when farm subsidies dropped. Even with the rise in incomes, consumers cut back their spending on automobiles and other expensive products.
The personal savings rate fell to a negative 0.8 percent during the month, the lowest on record, from a negative 0.7 percent during the previous month. The savings rate weighs current income from wages, salaries, businesses and government payments against spending. It does not account for borrowed money, income from investments, or withdrawals from prior savings.
Meanwhile, disposable income, or the money left over after taxes, rose 0.3 percent in November after dropping 0.3 percent in October.
Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic output, and the Federal Reserve's efforts to combat inflation with higher borrowing rates have restrained the pace of growth. On Thursday, Commerce Department figures showed economic growth was the slowest in four years during the third quarter.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Canada Strengthens Internet Privacy

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 22

 BODY:
A new law to protect personal information disclosed through electronic transactions will take effect in Canada on Jan. 1, and it will eventually affect all domestic companies and those in the United States that have Canadian subsidiaries.
Initially, the new law, the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act, will cover only companies that are federally regulated -- mainly banks and airlines. But by 2004, anyone doing business in Canada must comply. 
 Under the law, the consent of consumers would be required if their personal information was used commercially -- and it would be illegal to use data gathered in the past without that consent. Consumers will also have the right to review any information about them that is on file.
A privacy commission is being set up to investigate violations, while protecting whistle-blowers, and to take law-breakers to court if necessary.
"Canada is committed to the digital economy, and it is important to build trust in it," said Brian C. Keith, a lawyer at Borden Ladner Gervais in Toronto. "I'm telling clients that even if the legislation doesn't apply to you now, don't go to sleep. If this legislation doesn't apply, other laws will."
Elizabeth McNaughton, a lawyer at Blake, Cassels & Graydon, another Toronto law firm, agrees. Companies have not thought through the full range of privacy issues, she said. "It's not limited to electronic means of commerce," she said. "It's as much an issue for people who fill out ballots at the supermarket."
According to a survey by Michael Geist, a law professor at the University of Ottawa, half of the commercial World Wide Web sites in Canada do not have a privacy policy, and many of the existing policies are weak. Of 259 sites surveyed this summer, 40 percent did not indicate whether personal information could be given to a third party.
Canadians have been more reluctant than Americans to buy goods or make other financial transactions on the Internet. Although Canadians spend more time online, a 1998 study found that only 12 percent with Internet access had made an electronic purchase, compared with 39 percent in the United States. Canadians were more concerned about disclosing personal information, and not being able to examine goods.
Companies must not only set up procedures for disclosure and consent, but also name someone responsible for privacy matters.
Mr. Keith of Borden Ladner said he did not think foreign subsidiaries would find it difficult to meet the new standards, although it could be a big undertaking for, say, a financial company.
There has been plenty of warning. The American Express Company of New York is among those that have already complied with the new Canadian law. Ms. McNaughton of Blake Cassels said she thought that other companies in the United States that have well-developed privacy policies would have no problem meeting the Canadian standards.
European companies already operate under similar rules. Canada's legislation has been pushed ahead partly to protect the trans-Atlantic flow of commercial information.

HEADLINE: Tbilisi Journal;
Where It's Dark and Cold Outside, and Inside, Too

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: TBILISI, Georgia, Dec. 21

 BODY:
This was not supposed to be yet another bitter winter in the gracious and fraying capital of this lovely and distressed country.
An American energy company, the AES Corporation, bought the city's electric system last year and promised that Tbilisi's 1.2 million residents would no longer spend most of their winter days in darkness and their nights shivering without heat. 
 But overcoming the obstacles, from a broken-down power generating system and vast corruption to the effects of a summer drought and Russian meddling, proved too difficult. The electric system -- tweaked, massaged, seemingly held together with baling wire -- meets little more than half the demand.
So people persevere through another winter with five or six hours of electricity a day, even less than in previous years. Essential services like hospitals, government offices and the subway have steady supplies; everyone else must improvise.
One government official admitted that he runs a line from his office to his nearby apartment. Restaurants, hotels and businesses of any size rely on gasoline-powered generators, and some have switched to natural gas for heat, despite the expense.
The three-fourths of the population who cannot afford gas huddle around wood-burning stoves and sleep beneath layers of blankets. Shop owners who do not have generators sit glumly in ice-cold stores illuminated by candlelight.
Outside the capital, things are grimmer. Many places have gone without any electricity for weeks, a condition described by an official at the state Energy Ministry as "full darkness."
Vazha Javakhishvili, who lives in Natakhtari, a village 12 miles north of Tbilisi, said people grew so angry after two months without electricity that they blocked the main street.
"Now we have electricity a few hours most nights, so it's better," Mr. Javakhishvili said as he stood outside the small apartment where he and his wife, Sopiko, live with their 6-month-old daughter, Nino, and a tiny electric coil for heat.
The perennial shortage has political implications for President Eduard Shevardnadze, the West-leaning veteran of the Soviet era who has guided Georgia through a civil war and transition to independence but who has been unable to halt the economic slide. So far the opposition has remained muted, but there have been signs of unrest.
Last winter, protests did not start until February or so. But early this month, about 100 people took to the streets in the center of Tbilisi for several nights, blocking intersections with burning tires and chanting antigovernment slogans.
"It reminded me of the chaos during the civil war," said Ekaterine Khvedelidze, a translator and Tbilisi native. "It was very frightening."
The demonstrations stopped after the minister of internal affairs warned that the authorities had videotapes of the demonstrations and that leaders could face punishment.
The unrest also carries implications for foreign investors, who are badly needed but remain wary of the deep economic troubles.
AES, by far the largest outside investor, bought 75 percent of Tbilisi's electric company, acquired power generators and refurbished a system neglected since the collapse of the Soviet Union a decade ago.
The company is the target of populist anger here, but Mr. Shevardnadze praises it and reminded Georgians last week in a radio address that the country could not have afforded the $224 million invested so far by AES. "Had it not been for the above-mentioned investments," he said, "the Georgian energy sector would have collapsed completely."
AES, based in Arlington, Va., operates electric power systems in 24 countries, including others in the former Soviet Union. Its officials knew they were in for a rough ride in Tbilisi, but there have been a few surprises.
"This is the toughest business we've got," said Michael Scholey, the general director here. "You don't see the combination of problems anywhere else."
Mr. Scholey ticked off the list: The state-owned utility was collecting only about 10 percent of its bills from its 400,000 customers. Its only computer was used for payroll; customer accounts were kept in hand-written ledgers. Sometimes ledgers for entire apartment blocks disappeared, along with any possibility of billing the users.
A quarter of the customers did not have meters, and the meters that did exist were often faulty after years of neglect. Transformers sprouted illegal connections by the dozen.
And some thieves were more brazen. Mr. Scholey said a deputy minister in the government, whom he declined to name, had a personal transformer to heat his swimming pool and was never billed. Untold other people and businesses bribed collectors to look the other way.
Even Mr. Shevardnadze conceded that widespread corruption contributed to the crisis. He said several former officials had been arrested and others were under investigation.
As new meters are installed as part of a $45 million project, payment rates are rising, topping 80 percent in some districts. At the same time, people are learning to conserve because now they pay for what was once free.
But new meters will not generate electricity, and efforts to increase the amount of power have been hampered by poorly operating generators. The supply has also been hurt by a summer drought, which left hydroelectric stations without enough water to operate at full capacity.
Matters were not helped when Russia, which sells gas to the AES for its generators, halted the service for four days this month in a price dispute. AES was about to run out of gas and shut down the system when the flow was resumed after high-level talks in Moscow.
Mr. Scholey is optimistic that the company is making progress, and he said he expects to meet Tbilisi's demands next winter, a claim that evokes skepticism in some quarters.
"That's what AES said?" asked a woman who works in a hotel that relies on expensive generators. "That would be funny, if it weren't so sad."

HEADLINE: Figuring Dues: From Each According to Its G.N.P. (Back in '46)

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
The scale of assessments for member countries to finance the United Nations was set up in 1946, in theory according to each nation's ability to pay.
But Edward C. Luck, who has written about the history of the organization, said, "The ink wasn't dry on the charter before the U.S. and other countries started complaining" about what should be their fair shares, which were calculated according to each member's contribution to the world's gross national product. 
 Because of Europe's postwar devastation, Washington initially consented to pay slightly more than 39 percent of the regular budget, but just for a year. It was agreed that the United States' assessment would be pegged at 33 percent thereafter, in part so the United Nations would not have to depend for financial survival on a single country.
In those early days, the United Nations had only 55 members, compared with 189 today.
In fact, it took nearly a decade for the United States' assessment to fall to 33 percent. This was because experts at the United Nations kept insisting the United States ought to pay more, according to Mr. Luck, who is the executive director of the Center for the Study of International Organization, which has links to New York Law School and Princeton University.
In 1972, the General Assembly reduced the American share to 25 percent, and the minimum charged to the poorest countries was cut in half, to two one-hundredths of 1 percent. In 1978 this minimum was halved again, and was recently cut to one-thousandth of 1 percent, a share paid by struggling countries like Burundi, Cambodia and Equatorial Guinea.
China, a permanent member of the Security Council, pays slightly less than 1 percent.
The debate over who owes how much has been complicated by the cost of United Nations peacekeeping, which began with a one-time assessment of members for a mission in the Sinai in 1973. But far from being a one-time cost, "it locked into position for 27 years and never moved," said the United States representative, Richard C. Holbrooke, who described today's agreement as the first reform of peacekeeping.
While Washington has been at odds with the United Nations over the exact amount it owes, the United States' assessment has been less than 30 percent of peacekeeping expenses since 1973, said Steven Dimoff, vice president of the United Nations Association of the United States, a research and support organization.
The United Nations calculates that the United States is now about $1.3 billion in arrears, after its payment of $217 million earlier this week. Washington calculates a lower figure.
While the United States has been accused of being the most conspicuous debtor, other countries have been reluctant to pay up. In the early 1960's, Russia, France and other countries refused to pay for peacekeeping in Congo, and were taken by the United Nations to the World Court, which ruled against them.
Britain, Canada and the Scandinavian countries have been among the few members habitually scrupulous about paying their share of the operating costs of the United Nations.

HEADLINE: Rich Nations Will Forgive Debts of 22 Of the Poorest

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The United States, Japan and European and other industrial powers have agreed to forgive loans to 22 of the world's poorest countries this year, fulfilling a promise to accelerate debt relief and to give a token of the West's unprecedented prosperity to the poor.
The debt-relief program, announced today by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, is a victory for an eclectic coalition of religious organizations, celebrities and watchdog groups that put pressure on wealthy nations and international lenders to help the poor nations cope with globalization. 
 Many of the people in the countries granted debt relief -- all in Africa and Latin America -- live on $1 a day or less. Charity groups have argued that it is both economically inefficient and morally wrong to require the governments of such countries to devote large shares of their revenue to paying back foreign lenders.
The push for debt relief began in Europe in the mid-1990's and grew steadily through this year, when a worldwide protest campaign persuaded nearly all rich nations to move far more quickly than they had in the past. People as diverse as Pat Robertson, the religious broadcaster, and Bono, the rock star, lobbied to advance the cause.
President Clinton and the Republican-led Congress competed to claim credit for providing the $435 million required to fulfill the United States' obligation under the global forgiveness program this year, an amount that was fully financed in the budget for 2001.
Wealthy nations have devised a rigorous program of granting, distributing and monitoring debt relief to ensure that money no longer used to pay off debts will be employed in constructive ways to improve education, health care or economic development.
The effort to guard against waste has meant that debt relief comes only after a nation completes a long process. To date, only one of the 22 nations that have been granted relief, Uganda, has received all the benefits promised.
International finance officials have said they will wipe out two-thirds of the total debt the poorest nations owe to foreign governments and multilateral lenders, a debt stock that is estimated to have a value of $125 billion if it was paid today. So far, some $20 billion of that amount has been forgiven. At least a dozen more nations are considered eligible for relief in the future.
The World Bank and the I.M.F. had raced to complete cumbersome reviews and provide relief to at least 20 nations by the end of this year, doubling the number they had reached in September. The goal has had symbolic value for religious organizations in the year 2000, a Jubilee year for the Roman Catholic Church.
The goal of 20 was set by European nations in September and initially met with skepticism from the Clinton administration and some I.M.F. officials, who doubted that so many nations could complete the necessary applications in time.
In fact, the bank and the fund relaxed some requirements and eliminated a few hurdles to meet and then surpass the goal, bank officials have said. But officials stressed that the main conditions imposed to ensure that the money was used well remained in place.
"To ensure that the relief is translated into poverty reduction, the beneficiary countries must continue with their economic, social and governance reforms," James D. Wolfensohn, the World Bank's president, and Horst Kohler, the I.M.F.'s managing director, said in a joint statement.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers welcomed the news that 22 nations had been granted relief. But he warned that it was just one element of what wealthy nations must do to help the poor. He warned that health problems like AIDS and inadequate education reduced poor countries' ability to take advantage of money they saved in debt payments.
"Our challenge now is to build on the momentum of the extraordinary coalition that came together around debt relief to help every country seize the opportunities that global economic integration affords," Mr. Summers said.
The 22 nations receiving debt relief are Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Gambia, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Niger, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Tanzania, Uganda and Zambia in Africa; and Bolivia, Guyana, Honduras and Nicaragua in Latin America.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Soars To Finish Off Brutal Week

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index jumped 7.6 percent yesterday as bargain-hunting investors snapped up technology stocks that had dropped sharply in recent weeks.
It was the Nasdaq's fifth-best daily percentage gain ever. But because of the hard hit that technology stocks took earlier in the week, including a 7.1 percent loss Wednesday, the Nasdaq was still down 5.1 percent for the week. 
 Cisco Systems, which plunged 12.6 percent on Wednesday after it was downgraded by Merrill Lynch, rose for a second day, climbing $2.63, to $41.50. Qualcomm, which had fallen 11.3 percent since Monday, rose $9.19, to $85. Microsoft, which had dropped 28.5 percent in the last week and a half, jumped $3, to $46.44. And I.B.M., which was off 14.1 percent in the last week and a half, jumped $7.44, to $89.
Among other technology stocks helping lift the three major indexes were Hewlett-Packard, Sun Microsystems and Oracle.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 148.27 points, or 1.4 percent, to 10,635.56. The technology-heavy Nasdaq surged 176.90 points, to 2,517.02. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 31.11 points, or 2.4 percent, to 1,305.97. The gains came in relatively heavy volume for the last trading day before Christmas, with 1.09 billion shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange.
I.B.M. rose after a Salomon Smith Barney analyst said speculation that the computer company would miss its sales or profit forecasts was off the mark. But the Ford Motor Company dropped $1.38, to $22.81, after it said Thursday that its fourth-quarter profit would come in about 10 cents below forecasts of 74 cents a share because of slowing economic growth and consumer spending.
Yesterday's rebound, however, cannot be read as a signal that the stock market has finally hit bottom. That still depends on how much more the economy slows and how quickly the Federal Reserve moves to stimulate growth by cutting its short-term interest rate target.
"I don't believe that we have seen the bottom," said Thomas McManus, equity strategist at Banc of America Securities. "The news on earnings is still very negative, surprisingly negative for an earnings bear, which I have been for eight months. My numbers are probably too high."
Mr. McManus also said that President-elect George W. Bush's comments about the possibility of a recession and disagreement from the Clinton White House are not helpful for consumers or stocks. "It is not encouraging to see politicians arguing over the state of the economy," he said.
In addition, investors still have to get through another week or so of fourth-quarter earnings preannouncements in the first part of January. If the negative tone of this month's announcements continues, stocks could be pushed lower.
For the week, the Dow was up 1.9 percent, and the S.& P. 500 index fell 0.5 percent. With just four more trading days to go in the year, the Dow is down 7.5 percent, which would be its worst performance since 1981. The Nasdaq is down 38.2 percent, on the way to its worst performance in its history. And the S.& P. 500-stock index is off 11.1 percent, its worst year since 1977.
While Fed policy makers unexpectedly shifted their bias to cutting interest rates from raising them at their Tuesday meeting, they have not yet cut their benchmark federal funds rate from 6.5 percent. The sell-off in the stock market on Tuesday after the Fed said that it would not change the rate and again on Wednesday indicated that many investors were hungering for a cut.
Given the recent signs of the economy's slowing, more economists and analysts are saying the Fed will cut interest rates when policy makers meet at the end of January.
But Mr. McManus said there was talk in the stock and bond markets now that the Fed would reduce rates before its scheduled session at the end of January, given the rapidity of the economic slowdown. The Fed rarely moves on interest rates between formal policy-making meetings. But it has done so, most recently in the fall of 1998, during the Russian financial crisis.
"I think the market will definitely be extremely disappointed if the Fed does not cut rates by Groundhog Day," Mr. McManus said.
Several government reports yesterday added to the portrait of an economy that has slowed sharply from the 5 percent growth pace of 1999 and the first half of this year. Orders for durable goods rose 2.3 percent in November, after a 6.5 percent drop in October. Although the increase was a little larger than the 1.5 percent expected, it still reflects how wary consumers have become.
The Commerce Department also reported yesterday that consumer spending rose 0.3 percent in November. But much of the increase went to pay for higher utility bills, which analysts say have been cutting into spending for household and other goods and holiday gifts.
The Commerce Department reported Thursday that economic growth in the third quarter slipped to 2.2 percent at an annual rate, the weakest quarterly growth in four years.
The slowing growth and the prospect of a Fed rate cut before the end of January helped drive Treasury interest rates lower in a trading session shortened by a holiday. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note rose 7/32, to 105 21/32, as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 5 percent, from 5.03 percent on Thursday. That is its lowest yield since February 1999, when longer-term interest rates were rising after reaching 30-year lows in October 1998. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.39 percent, from 5.41 percent on Thursday.
Clearer signs of a slowdown in the United States and the sharp decline in the stock market also helped the euro to rise against the dollar. From the inception of the euro in January 1999 until last month, the currency had fallen as investors preferred to put their money into the United States.
But now the euro has jumped almost 12 percent against the dollar since its record low in October, including an increase yesterday to 92.52 cents from 91.43 cents on Thursday. At this level, the euro is already as high as some forecasters predicted it would rise in 2001.

HEADLINE: A Voice of Protest Rises for Itself;
WBAI Resists Superiors Who Say It's Stuck in the 60's

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The trouble began late last month when the out-of-town brass showed up in the offices of the venerable radio station WBAI in Manhattan for what was assumed to be a routine performance evaluation, then proposed unceremoniously that the general manager take a new job elsewhere that did not then exist.
When the general manager declined, she was told that after 20 years at the station, she would be unemployed as of Dec. 31. Most of the staff quickly vowed to fight her firing. Demonstrations and petitions ensued. Now WBAI-FM (99.5), and its parent, the Pacifica Foundation, are on the brink of civil war. 
 At a time of consolidation in the radio industry, WBAI is a defiant exception -- a throwback to a time when community radio flourished, a holdout against homogenization, on intimate terms with its listeners (who might even want to hear an exclusive five-hour broadcast of a speech by Fidel Castro).
Now it is embroiled in what is simply the latest in a series of confrontations between Pacifica, which pioneered listener-sponsored broadcasting in the United States, and staff members at its five stations, which have served for a half-century as what one historian called the voice of the left on the radio.
Underlying the conflict are two forces: the foundation's desire to broaden Pacifica's audience and ensure the network's future, and programmers' suspicions that what the foundation really wants is to trade in the old audience and become a slightly more liberal version of National Public Radio.
"The national office believes that we represent an outre politics; let's put it that way," said Matthew Finch, the director of arts and cultural programming for WBAI, which gets a small percentage of its $3 million budget from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. "That we are too far out on the fringe and too negative. That is something that I do know has been said in those halls."
Kenneth A. Ford, vice chairman of the foundation's board, insisted in an interview that no one on the board had ever suggested giving "a milquetoast appearance" to Pacifica's programming. But he also said, quoting an industry guru he would not name, that Pacifica "had a mission at one time and had a credible voice but now it has gone from being insignificant to irrelevant."
"That says we need to change the way we're doing things," Mr. Ford said. "It's bad enough when you're insignificant; but when you're irrelevant, you're nonexistent. You must ask the question: Do we serve just a few people and their interests? Do we serve people who are locked in time in the 60's, or do we try to stay current and expand and grow to bring in new people under the Pacifica umbrella?"
Pacifica was conceived in 1946 by a group of conscientious objectors as a network of grass-roots, alternative stations free of corporate control and dedicated to peace. It introduced the Beat Generation to the airwaves, challenged McCarthyism, held on-air debates on the arms race and was investigated by the House Un-American Activities Committee.
WBAI, which joined the network in 1960, became one of the first stations in the country to interview a former agent about life in the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said Matthew Lasar, a historian and author of "Pacifica Radio: The Rise of an Alternative Network" (Temple University Press, 1999). That broadcast, Mr. Lasar said, earned Pacifica its own F.B.I. investigation.
Later, WBAI reporters were the first to cover the Vietnam War from North Vietnam. The station was a leader in the free-form radio movement, a spontaneous broadcasting style that became popular in the late 1960's. Yoko Ono was once the station's record librarian, one staff member said. In the station's heyday, Richard Avedon photographed the staff.
"If it wasn't for Pacifica's five stations, the left wouldn't have been on the radio," said Mr. Lasar, a visiting assistant professor at the University of California at Riverside and a former reporter for a Pacifica station. "It's really the voice of the left. For many people in the network, the struggle is whether it will continue to be the voice of the left."
The foundation owns the licenses to stations in Berkeley, Calif., Los Angeles, Houston, Washington and New York. Dozens of affiliates also take some of Pacifica's national broadcasting -- its network news and "Democracy Now!," a public-affairs program produced at WBAI that Mr. Lasar said was the most successful venture in alternative-radio history, reaching some 700,000 people a week.
In the years since the 60's, the number of WBAI subscribers has declined to 17,500 today from about 30,000. But the station continues to pride itself on serving as an "early-warning system" for what members of its staff witheringly call the corporate media, aggressively covering issues like police brutality and the shortage of affordable housing in New York.
In recent weeks, some staff members have wondered what set Pacifica's executives off. Was it that exclusive broadcast of Castro's speech last September at Riverside Church? Or the Saturday afternoon special on a march for the Palestinians in Washington? Or the extraordinary half-hour grilling given President Clinton when he called WBAI on Election Day to get out the vote?
On Nov. 28, Bessie M. Wash, executive director of the Pacifica Foundation, arrived in New York to meet with Valerie Van Isler, WBAI's general manager, who has told others she expected a performance review. Instead, Ms. Wash offered her a job in the Pacifica national office in Washington with the title of executive producer of national programming.
When Ms. Van Isler turned it down, Ms. Wash told her she would be out of a job, according to Bernard White, the WBAI program director. He said he called Ms. Wash the next day to object, then met with her several days later. She agreed to explain her actions on the air the following Tuesday, Mr. White said, but did not appear on time. She finally met with the station's staff that afternoon.
At that meeting, it became apparent that some staff members had complained about Ms. Van Isler to Ms. Wash, Mr. White and others said. But, he said, Ms. Wash had never discussed the matter with him or others in the station's management. If Ms. Van Isler was to go, Mr. White and others said, the station, not Pacifica, should have the right to determine when and how.
Ms. Van Isler has been general manager for 10 years.
"The issue is not whether this is the best general manager this station has ever seen," Mr. Finch, the arts director, said. "It's the process by which they made this move and the timing of it that are alarming."
Ms. Van Isler would not discuss her situation, saying only that she had filed a grievance against Pacifica. Ms. Wash did not respond to repeated requests for an interview. Instead, the foundation on Dec. 14 issued a four-paragraph announcement of a "reorganization of key positions," stating simply that Ms. Van Isler had been offered the new job "as part of Pacifica's vision to restructure the organization and bring in some new leadership."
The statement said Pacifica would begin a search for a new general manager.
Meanwhile, most of the staff members are said to have signed a statement refusing to honor Ms. Van Isler's firing or cooperate with a successor. A petition is circulating among listeners. There have been on-air discussions, anguished meetings, plans for a broadcast teach-in and talk of a vigil at the offices at 120 Wall Street if Pacifica tries to move Ms. Van Isler out.
At a meeting on Dec. 12, dozens of members of the station's staff, racially diverse but mostly middle-aged, jammed a conference room in the office. In the crush, a table loaded with people collapsed. Various staff members, a dissident Pacifica board member and a lawyer for Ms. Van Isler spoke about their dealings with Pacifica's management and board.
"Many of us believe that the intention of Pacifica is to consolidate all the radio stations and then begin to change systematically the programming," Mr. White said at the meeting. He added: "This is not a joke. They are serious about what it is they want to do. We've already seen how at some radio stations they've already done what it is they want to do."
In March 1999, Pacifica fired the general manager of KPFA, the Berkeley station, two weeks before its 50th-anniversary celebration. When protests followed, Pacifica warned employees not to discuss the firing on the air. When they did so anyway, one was fired and another was pulled off the air in midsentence. Eventually, Pacifica temporarily shut down the offices.
More recently, Amy Goodman, a "Democracy Now!" host, filed grievances against Pacifica's program director alleging harassment and censorship -- charges Pacifica denied. Among other things, she says Pacifica withdrew her show's credentials to cover the Democratic National Convention after she took Ralph Nader onto the floor of the Republican National Convention to offer commentary.
Some WBAI staff members insist they are not opposed to change. The problem, they said, is how the change has come.
"Many of us for years have been saying we must adjust to survive," said Sidney Anthony Smith, WBAI's operations director. "The notion that we are 60's fossils who are intransigent to any rational change is simply untrue. But this change must be done humanely and with patience, since these have always been our traditions."

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Plunges, Especially Among the Affluent

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence plunged in December, but not evenly across the population. The nation's more affluent families are turning out to be the most pessimistic, apparently because of the sinking stock market. The less affluent, not as heavily invested in stocks, are not yet so directly affected by the slowing economy.
Those are the latest findings of the Consumer Research Center at the University of Michigan. Released yesterday, the survey is the most authoritative reading so far of how Americans are reacting in the Christmas season to the slowing economy -- and, in reacting, contributing to the slowdown. 
 "Not many people have yet personally experienced the slowing economy except through the stock market," said Richard T. Curtin, director of surveys for the Consumer Research Center. "But they are getting negative signals in the workplace, from their neighbors and in the mall. Then they listen to the news and hear someone confirm what they are concerned about."
That more or less describes Nancy Ward, a 47-year-old paralegal interviewed while shopping at Faneuil Hall Marketplace in Boston. The slowdown for her is apparent in the workplace. "My husband and I do real estate law, so we do a lot of closings, and we are seeing closings slowing down," she said, explaining that she is more price conscious now when she shops. "I've also been reading in the papers that there are a lot of layoffs in the bigger companies, so it is just a matter of time."
For all the signs of a slowdown, there are strengths, too. While the University of Michigan reported the fall-off in confidence, the Commerce Department said yesterday that personal income was holding up, as was consumption, despite a slowdown in Christmas sales. Personal income rose 0.4 percent in November, and consumption expenditures increased 0.3 percent. Although outlays for merchandise fell, spending on services more than offset the decline.
The confidence index fell to 98.4 this month from 107.6 in November, the fourth-largest one-month drop since the survey went monthly in 1978. The three larger drops came before the 1980 and 1990 recessions. While the pessimism was broad-based in those years, this time it is mainly among households with annual incomes of more than $50,000 -- the households, in sum, with much of their wealth invested in stocks. These are America's biggest spenders, and cutbacks on their part because of declining confidence could indeed hurt the economy.
Households with less than $50,000 in annual income, on the other hand, are just beginning to turn pessimistic. "Their strong income and job prospects led them to overlook rising gasoline prices," Mr. Curtin said, "but now they are beginning to feel threatened at work" and the news media reports amplify their worries.
Trying to talk an economy up or down is hardly a new phenomenon. Franklin Roosevelt's fireside chats during the Depression were a famous attempt to lift spirits and encourage economic activity. Until they did an about-face this fall, corporate executives, Wall Street forecasters and Federal Reserve policy makers were publicly bullish. The Clinton administration never missed an opportunity to point proudly to the booming prosperity, and now it says the Bush camp is making matters worse by calling attention to the slowdown and to the risk of recession. The Bush camp wants to suggest that a recession would be President Clinton's fault.
Mr. Bush said Thursday that he was simply being a realist in considering the dangers ahead, "and if there are warning signs on the horizon, we need to pay attention to them." But Gene Sperling, President Clinton's economic adviser, said the Republicans were "creating anxiety" unnecessarily.
"As one moves from a campaign to running the government," Mr. Sperling said, "part of the transition is understanding that you are not just an outside commentator but what you say can itself have an impact on confidence and stability, and talking down your own economy is a serious mistake."
Can an economy in fact be talked down? Can pessimism publicly expressed be self-fulfilling? Neither Mr. Curtin nor Lynn Franco, his counterpart at the Conference Board, which also surveys consumer confidence, finds much evidence yet that people are responding to pessimistic talk. What is more, random interviews yesterday with shoppers in Seattle and Boston turned up little evidence that people were altering their behavior as a result of pessimistic news media reports.
"I honestly believe there is a downturn, but it is at the beginning so it does not really affect you yet," said James Simpson, 32, a real estate developer in Phoenix, visiting in Seattle. He added that he sold all his stocks six months ago, which is why he is not feeling an effect.
Still, if bad news persists, the impact will come, according to Thomas Smith, a director of the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago. "What we are hearing has the potential for weakening consumer confidence," he said. "But I don't think the message has been taken into the hearts and minds of the American people so far."
The impact from talking down an economy comes gradually; it takes time for the pessimistic talk to be measurable in the consumer confidence numbers, but eventually it has an effect, said Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of DYG, a polling firm.
Norbert Schwarz, a University of Michigan psychologist, describes the process. "It is impossible," he said, "to consider all the information that is relevant; so people truncate the information search early, as soon as they have a few bits of information that seem relevant." That makes them vulnerable to pessimistic media reports. "The reports increase the accessibility, as we call it, of pieces of similar information already in memory," he said.
Much depends on the eye of the beholder. "You can tell two different stories about this economy," Dr. Schwarz said. "You can emphasize the sharp slowdown, as we are doing, or you can say that while growth has slowed, the economy is still strong. I am from Germany where they consider 2 or 2.5 percent growth like we have here very good. Depending on which aspect you are focusing on, people's confidence comes out very differently."
The economy is in fact hurting, no matter what the perspective. Indebtedness hangs over consumers and corporations. Capital spending is weakening, loans are harder to obtain and defaults are rising. But even after sharp declines, car sales and home construction -- two economic pillars -- are as high as they were in the 1980's. And while layoffs abound, so do jobs; the unemployment rate is a very mild 4 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Factory Orders Rise 2.3%; Consumer Spending Climbs
The Commerce Department reported that factory orders rose 2.3 percent in November after a 6.5 percent drop in October. A surge in aircraft orders led the increase. Excluding transportation equipment, orders rose 0.4 percent in November after falling 3.1 percent in October.
Consumer spending also increased in November, led by higher utility costs, while incomes recovered from the previous month's decline, the department said. Page C4. 

Canada to Adopt Privacy Standard
A new law to protect personal information disclosed through electronic transactions will take effect in Canada on Jan. 1, and it will eventually affect all domestic companies and those in the United States that have Canadian subsidiaries. Initially, the new law, the Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act, will cover only companies that are federally regulated -- mainly banks and airlines. But by 2004, anyone doing business in Canada must comply. C2.
 
Korean Banks Near Formal Merger
Two of South Korea's largest and strongest banks, Kookmin and Housing and Commercial, moved closer toward a formal merger despite a union walkout that shut many branches. The merger would form South Korea's largest bank, with assets of 167 trillion won ($136.1 billion). C2.
 
Major Powers to Forgive Debt
The United States, Japan, Europe and other industrial powers have agreed to forgive loans to 22 of the world's poorest countries this year, fulfilling a promise to accelerate debt relief and to give a token of the West's unprecedented prosperity to the poor. A6.
 
A Dysfunctional Utility Deregulation
California's great experiment with utility deregulation relies on the wisdom of the marketplace to keep things running, but as the threat of utility bankruptcies, sharply rising electric rates and dimmed Christmas lights grip the state, the marketplace has no clear idea of what to do. Worse yet, it seems, neither does anyone else, from political leaders who have every incentive to keep California's economy humming, to the agencies charged with keeping the lights on. A1.
 
Real Media Dismisses Executive
Real Media, a New York-based Internet advertising sales and technology company, replaced its chief executive and laid off 10 percent of its work force after a major investor objected to the company's recent performance and ordered a restructuring in return for any additional financing, company officials said. C3.
 
C. I. Fund Ends Takeover Bid
C. I. Fund Management has scrapped a $2.5 billion hostile takeover attempt of a larger rival, the Mackenzie Financial Corporation, along with its hope of combining the two Toronto companies to form Canada's largest mutual fund empire. C2.
 
Egghead.com Cites Loss of Data
Egghead.com, an Internet retailer of computers, electronics and sporting goods with 3.62 million registered users, said customer credit-card data may have been stolen by a hacker earlier this week. Egghead.com asked the F.B.I. to investigate and said it had notified credit-card companies as a precautionary step. C3.
 
Clinton Pardons Tyson Executive
President Clinton pardoned 59 people including Archibald R. Schaffer 3rd, a longtime friend of President and Mrs. Clinton from Arkansas. Mr. Schaffer, an executive with Tyson Foods, was sentenced in September to a year in prison for his role in a scheme to illegally influence Mike Espy, the former agriculture secretary. A12.

HEADLINE: Last Noel for Some Dot-Coms;
Traditional Chains Making Inroads in the Online Market

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
For Internet merchants, this holiday season is bringing little joy, and not much comfort, either.
Online retail sales are up again, with estimates of the increase over last year varying from 50 to 100 percent. Visa says 3.5 percent of the spending on its credit cards over the holiday season has been done online, double the share last year, and almost five times that of 1998. 
 Still, online spending, like holiday sales over all, is falling short of many predictions. And the number of people shopping online is leveling off, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll, indicating that Web merchants looking to get big fast are having to wring more revenue from existing customers.
Moreover, Internet shoppers have flocked increasingly to affiliates of conventional stores -- Wal-Mart Stores, Kmart, Toys "R" Us, J. C. Penney and Best Buy -- compounding the difficulties of the increasingly endangered Web start-ups that led the way last year.
The most prominent casualty has been eToys, the phenomenon of last year's holiday season, which reported last week that its quarterly sales would fall 50 percent short of expectations. The company, whose value has fallen to $25 million from $11 billion in 14 months, put itself up for sale.
After conceding the lead to start-ups, traditional retailers have built Web sites this year with the sort of broad inventory they offer in stores. The Internet accounts for a small part of their sales -- perhaps 2 to 3 percent in the case of Toys "R" Us -- and like most Web start-ups, they are losing money at it. But the retailers consider it an important and profitable part of their long-term business.
Meanwhile, as dot-com companies heavily cut advertising to conserve cash, or close altogether, the Web addresses of the traditional companies have become the most visible Internet promotions -- on television and in their stores -- and seemingly the most stable.
"There has been a flight to quality," said Chuck Davis, the chief executive of BizRate, an online research company. "For the bricks-and-clicks companies," he said, referring to store chains with online operations, "this is their first real holiday. For the dot-com pure plays, this is their last holiday."
Amazon.com has continued to thrive (if not profit), with sales expected to be $1 billion for the quarter, 58 percent more than last year and far and away the largest on the Net. But even after a $300 million spending spree to build five automated warehouses, Amazon has not been able to keep up with the demand as pockets of customers -- it will not say how many -- discover that their orders are weeks late and may not arrive in time for Christmas.
"Usually, they are as fast as Chinese food in New York," said Barry Bryant of Brightwaters, N.Y., a high school teacher who still has not received half the items he ordered from Amazon on Dec. 9 despite the promise of immediate shipment. "I think they booked far more business than they can handle."
Whatever gains Web merchants are experiencing this year, in fact, appear to be coming largely from people like Mr. Bryant, experienced online shoppers who are spending more this year, rather than from first-time buyers.
In the New York Times/CBS News Poll of 1,048 adults conducted Dec. 14-16, 19 percent said they had or would buy gifts online this year. That is not meaningfully more than the 17 percent who gave that response a year ago. More broadly, those who say they have ever bought something on the Internet increased to 31 percent from 25 percent a year ago. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
BizRate, similarly, found that only 10 percent of Web shoppers this month are making their first purchase online.
Measuring how much money was spent online is an imprecise art, especially because most online stores do not release sales figures. And even now there is a wide range of estimates of last year's online spending.
This year, Visa estimates that $2.5 billion was spent online with its cards from Nov. 24 to Dec. 20, up 103 percent from a year ago. Since Visa has 54 percent of the card market and nearly all online purchases are billed to credit or debit cards, that implies total spending of about $5 billion.
BizRate estimates that total online spending was about $5 billion from Nov. 20 to Dec. 18. But that represents only 50 percent growth from BizRate's calculation of last year's sales, less than the 81 percent increase it expected.
The biggest drag on online sales, BizRate found, came from computers. Online sales of computers, BizRate's largest category, rose by only 40 percent from a year ago.
The Internet-only retailers that appear to be doing the best are those that reflect the Web's role as the nation's flea market. EBay, the auction site, continues to thrive (although its best month is typically January, when people unload unwanted gifts). And Half.com, an eBay unit that sells used merchandise at fixed prices, has become the No. 2 online store in its first year.
Online retailers, like their shopping mall counterparts, blame the uncertain economy, the falling stock market and even the endless election for dampening shopping enthusiasm.
The online stores have far more trouble than a few dimpled chads, however. Once investors decided they wanted to see profits rather than growth, the money that had fueled the dot-com boom simply dried up. Many sites shut their doors, and others have cut back sharply, at a cost.
"We spent half a year spending zero dollars on marketing," said Michael Krupit, chief executive of CDNow, the online music store recently purchased by Bertelsmann. "We lost tremendous momentum." Holiday sales at CDNow will be lower than last year, he said.
Other sites have dealt with the tough times by raising prices.
"Last year we were selling thousands of Palm Pilots at cost," said Katherine N. Vick, president of Cyberian Outpost, an online computer dealer. "We are not in that business any more." Over all, the company expects to double its gross margin from last year's holiday season while increasing sales by 60 percent.
That said, not all the online promotions have disappeared this year. A number of online retailers, including Amazon, offered free shipping for much of the holiday season, at least for larger orders. Some analysts say eToys' reluctance to match these offers contributed to its shortfall.
In any case, even for the Web retailers left standing, the demise of former competitors is not an unmixed blessing.
"We would love to have thriving competitors because their advertising drew more people online," said Jeff Bezos, the chief executive of Amazon.com.
Indeed, to counter the skepticism from customers (and investors), Amazon took the unusual step of placing an up-to-the-minute count of how many items it had shipped on its home page. (To date, Amazon's Delight-o-Meter has counted 31 million shipments, up from about 20 million last year.)
"We wanted to show people in a very real way that lots of people are doing this and that Amazon.com is reliable," Mr. Bezos said.
Reliability was a problem for other Web sites last year, especially toysrus.com, then Amazon's rival and now its partner. This year, it is Amazon itself that has fallen behind.
"We have a collection of orders we are running a little slow on," Bill Curry, an Amazon spokesman, acknowledged. He declined to quantify that collection. He cited a variety of causes, like late shipments by manufacturers.
Planet Feedback, a site that passes consumer complaints and compliments to companies, said that reports of problems of delayed shipment at Amazon have increased from an average of 23 percent of the comments on that company to 40 percent, a much faster increase than at other online stores.
Indeed, the rest of the industry appears to be doing better than last year. BizRate finds that 87 percent of online shoppers say they are satisfied with the timeliness of their shipments, up from 74 percent a year ago.
In fact, overall satisfaction is higher at Internet-only stores than at the bricks-and-mortar affiliates that are doing so well online this year, according to a joint study by BizRate and Robertson Stephens, the brokerage firm. Most notably, Walmart.com, which has had a 490 percent increase in traffic to become the fourth-most-popular online store, scores significantly below average on the study, said Lauren Cooks Levitan, online retail analyst for Robertson Stephens.
"Maybe it is because they are attracting newer online shoppers, but Wal-Mart's customers are less satisfied and say they are less likely to shop there again," she said.
But customer satisfaction, Ms. Levitan said, does not seem to predict success. EToys, she noted, topped her satisfaction polls and many others.
"They had built a better mousetrap," she said. "What we understand now is the consumer didn't care."

HEADLINE: AFTER LONG FIGHT, U.N. AGREES TO CUT DUES PAID BY U.S.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 22

 BODY:
After weeks of bitter negotiations, members of the United Nations agreed in principle today to reduce American dues for the first time in more than a quarter century. If accepted by Congress, the deal will remove the primary irritant between the United Nations and Washington just as a new administration prepares to take over.
The immediate reaction in Congress was positive, and diplomats said that only a few details remained to be settled before the General Assembly formally approved the accord. 
 "This is a tremendous achievement for the United Nations," said Ambassador Richard C. Holbrooke, who has spent almost all of his 16 months as representative here fighting to get two scales of dues -- one for the regular United Nations budget and another for peacekeeping -- realigned by 188 other nations. Some of those nations would have to pay substantially more to make up for American cuts.
In Washington, Senator Jesse Helms, the leading Congressional critic of the United Nations, welcomed the development. "I consider it a real leap forward," he said, singling out Mr. Holbrooke for praise.
Relations with the United Nations had worsened when a Republican Congress was elected in 1994. By 1995, Congress was actively legislating against American involvement, reducing payments in violation of treaties and demanding that the United Nations reform.
The American debt to the organization mounted to a level nearly twice the annual operating budget. Anger grew among other member nations, which watched Americans expect support for their policies while the organization faltered under the debt.
Sir Jeremy Greenstock, Britain's ambassador, called the deal a "huge breakthrough" and said that if it had not been for Mr. Holbrooke's determination, there might have been "shards on the ground" and no deal.
Mr. Holbrooke changed the terms of the debate, arguing that all nations should have their assessments revisited because the world had changed since payment scales were reviewed in the 1970's and changing economic realities had to be reflected.
The peacekeeping scale of assessment had not been changed since 1973, though periodically the United Nations' regular operating budget had been adjusted. But Mr. Holbrooke did not get everything Congress demanded.
He did win approval of a cut to 22 percent of the United Nations regular budget, from 25 percent. As to other payments for peacekeeping, the American share was cut to 27 percent from 30 percent, but still exceeds the 25 percent level set by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. To make their point, the senators had tied up payment of American debts, which the United Nations calculates at more than $1.3 billion now. Under an agreement that the committee struck with the Clinton administration in 1997, arrears could not be released until the 25 percent level was reached. Two years earlier, Congress passed a law saying the United States would not pay more than 25 percent for peacekeeping. This has added an automatic increase in arrears ever since. That law would have to be repealed.
When the shape of today's deal became apparent last week, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, the committee's ranking Democrat, said he would fight for acceptance, despite the shortfall in the peacekeeping budget demand. He said the reduction in regular budget assessments to 22 percent was crucial to the committee.
The final resolution of the General Assembly did not include a European proposal that would have made the continuation of lower American dues conditional on Washington's payment of all arrears by 2003. In any case, Congress and the United Nations disagree on the amount of arrears. But member nations did leave open the possibility of reversing today's decision if there was reason to do so at the next review.
"If things go wrong in the next three years," Mr. Greenstock said, "then the General Assembly will come back to the question."
With the United States and the European Union locked in firm positions, concessions from a variety of nations, many of them prospering, were the key to striking a deal. They included Thailand, Singapore, South Korea, Brazil, Argentina, Chile, the Czech Republic, Poland and Persian Gulf oil states.
On the regular budget, the United States made the transition to higher assessments easier to swallow by offering to pick up the $34 million that other nations would have to make up during the first year of lower American payments.
The money was made available to the State Department by Ted Turner, the founder of CNN, through his United Nations Foundation. In 1997, Mr. Turner stunned the organization with a pledge to give $1 billion over 10 years to a variety of United Nations programs, with emphasis on the environment, health and aid to women and girls in developing nations.
The grant to the State Department is in addition to that $1 billion gift, and had to be made through the State Department because individuals cannot pay a country's dues.
Mr. Holbrooke said today that opposition to United States demands in the United Nations had been fierce for months. "As the year drew to a close, resistance became more and more intense," he said.
Other diplomats said that while many countries would have been willing to reduce American payments even further as a way to weaken the fiscal influence of the United States, they were defiant about making any adjustments under an ultimatum from Congress.
Mr. Greenstock said today that a number of larger developing countries like India and prosperous nations like Canada thought it was "politically unwise to have one power holding such a whip over the U.N." But the Europeans argued that it was naive to think that the United Nations could readily make up for a large financial gap.
"Into the mix stepped Ted Turner," Mr. Holbrooke said. "Six weeks ago, after I had briefed him and some of his associates on the problem, Turner, with his characteristic combination of vision and energy, and a profound understanding of the leveraging effects of a dramatic bequest, said if the $34 million difference that this amounts to is the make or break, I will contribute that money on a one-time-only basis."
"As the year grew on, country after country passed its national budget, based on the assumption we would still pay 25 percent," Mr. Holbrooke said. "And so countries all over the world came to us and said, we've already budgeted the money, and we can't pick up the extra. So Ted Turner's offer in hand, we began to talk to individual countries and then two days ago the group. Then came the brutal discussion about how to distribute the money."
That slicing of the Turner sweetener was still going on at the last minute today.
In addition to the American reduction, Japan asked for and got a cut of one percentage point, to 19.5 percent of the regular budget. That means that the United Nations will have to find new sources to provide 4 percent of the operating budget. Russia and China voluntarily increased their payments, though marginally. When complicated calculations were made of nations' capacity to pay based on economic strength, Britain, Denmark, Greece and Ireland all saw their regular dues go up, although in total the European Union added only 0.3 percentage points to its bill.
Regular budget assessments form the base for calculating peacekeeping bills, a system that has now become even more complex, by introducing a sliding scale of discounts depending on ability to pay.
A number of countries -- among them Israel, Cyprus, Malta, Hungary and Slovenia -- voluntarily gave up discounts immediately. Others agreed to give them up in the future.

HEADLINE: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: THE REGULATIONS;
Bush Aides Plan a Hard Look At Clinton's Final Regulations

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Aides to President-elect George W. Bush put the Clinton administration on notice today that they would scrutinize the many regulations being issued by President Clinton on his way out of office, and they said they might alter rules with which they disagreed.
At the same time, lawyers and lobbyists sympathetic to the Clinton administration said Mr. Bush would have many tools available if, as expected, he wanted to delay, modify or rescind some of the regulations after he took office on Jan. 20. 
 In the last few weeks, the administration has issued a blizzard of rules, dealing with everything from the privacy of medical records to the pollution spewed by diesel-powered trucks and buses to the prevention of repetitive-stress injuries in the workplace.
Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for the president-elect, said today that the Bush transition team was "carefully reviewing each and every regulation that is issued here in the waning days" of the administration.
"They've been busy beavers in the administration with these last-minute executive orders and last-minute regulations," Mr. Fleischer said.
Without commenting on the merits of any initiative, Mr. Fleischer said Mr. Clinton's executive orders could be "undone at the stroke of the pen" of the new president, while "regulations can be undone through regulation."
William Kovacs, vice president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, said Mr. Clinton was "trying to put the next administration into a regulatory straitjacket." In most cases, the new administration must show cause and invite public comments before rescinding regulations issued in final form by Mr. Clinton.
Conflicts of this sort have occurred in the past. Soon after Ronald Reagan succeeded Jimmy Carter in 1981, the Reagan administration rescinded a rule that required automatic seat belts or airbags in new cars. In 1983, the Supreme Court ruled that the action of the Reagan administration was arbitrary and capricious.
In revoking a rule, the court said, a federal agency must follow the same procedures that applied when it issued a new rule. It must supply "a reasoned analysis for the change" and "must articulate a satisfactory explanation" for its decision, the court said in the 1983 case, Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association v. State Farm Mutual.
Linda Ricci, a spokeswoman for the White House Office of Management and Budget, said: "Our rules are a product of serious, substantive work with lots of scientific analysis. We believe they will stand up in court."
In effect, the Supreme Court set criteria for new presidents to follow in rewriting regulations. But even without formally changing the rules, a new president can take many steps to switch course.
Gary D. Bass, executive director of O.M.B. Watch, a consumer group that monitors the Office of Management and Budget, said: "If the new president wants to undermine regulations that protect public health, safety and the environment, he can do it. He has many levers to pull -- so many, it would amaze the public."
Here are some examples:
*A new president can declare a moratorium on new rules for two or three months, as President Reagan did.
*A new president can place a low priority on enforcement of rules with which he disagrees.
*The president can give states more responsibility for enforcing federal health, safety or environmental standards, without providing much additional money.
*A new president can set new standards for cost-benefit analysis, so federal officials pay more attention to the costs of new regulations.
*A federal agency can postpone the effective date of new regulations that have been challenged in court. The United States Chamber of Commerce and other business groups, for example, have sued to block the ergonomic rules and to overturn a new rule that denies federal contracts to companies that have violated labor or environmental laws.
*Under a 1997 law, agencies must send their rules to Congress for review 60 days before they take effect, and Congress can kill the rules. Congress never did this under Mr. Clinton, who could have vetoed any "resolution of disapproval."
But Mr. Bush as president might cooperate with Congress to kill certain regulations he opposes.
Mr. Bush said this week that he wanted "less regulation" as part of his program to head off any recession. And in the campaign, Mr. Bush said he wanted to reduce the burden of federal regulations in education, health care and the environment.
David C. Vladeck, a lawyer at the Public Citizen Litigation Group, a nonprofit law firm, said the new president would probably issue an executive order establishing a framework for all federal regulation, as Mr. Reagan did in February 1981 and Mr. Clinton did in September 1993.
Mr. Vladeck said he expected Mr. Bush to establish a standardized method of analyzing the costs and benefits of new regulations. Agencies like the Food and Drug Administration, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration now use somewhat different techniques.
Robert W. Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, said: "Bush will take cost-benefit analysis more seriously than the Clinton administration has. He will ask for a more careful accounting of the costs and benefits of proposed rules and alternatives. Cost-benefit analysis now is often a charade."
Mr. Bush has vowed to shift regulatory power from the federal government to the states.
In educating children, he said, "states will be offered freedom from federal regulation, but will be held accountable for results." On health care, he said, he will "remove federal regulations that restrict state flexibility in designing programs for the uninsured." On environmental issues, he promised to discard "the 30-year-old federal model of 'mandate, regulate and litigate.' "

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk
