HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
The Floor Under Wages: How Low Can It Fall?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE Clinton years are almost gone, and with them the best hope for strengthening the minimum wage. Not that he had much success. The minimum wage today helps fewer people than when President Clinton took office in 1993. And George W. Bush's team seems willing to let the dwindling continue. Employers, not the government, would once again decide how low pay could fall, as they did until the Depression. 
 All this is happening almost sub rosa. No politician openly challenges a New Deal law that has put a floor under wages for two generations, lifting millions of people out of poverty. An outright repeal is not a political option. Instead, the death blow is coming through inaction. Even stingy employers no longer balk at paying a minimum wage stuck at only $5.15 an hour, the present level.
The Clinton administration had been pressing since 1998 for a $1 increase, to $6.15 an hour, in 50-cent installments over two years. The Republicans resisted, but finally agreed to the increase in late August, if the Democrats would accept various tax cuts as a quid pro quo -- particularly for small business. That is where most minimum-wage workers are employed. The Democrats consented, but in the end the Republicans insisted on more quid pro quo than President Clinton would accept, and Congress adjourned without raising the minimum.
"We are coming back next year and we will ask for a larger increase," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who has pushed to raise the minimum. The senator would not say how much more than $1 the next bill would request. "We will run the numbers over Christmas," he said.
It is painfully evident that $1 is no longer enough. Even among economists like Kevin Murphy of the University of Chicago, who worry about the impact on hiring, a $1 increase no longer risks making low-skilled workers too expensive to hire. "You are simply ratifying what has already happened in the marketplace," he said.
The statistics illustrate how quickly the minimum wage is drifting toward oblivion. Adjusted for inflation, it has declined steadily in value from a high of $7.66 an hour in 1968 to today's $5.15. Nearly half the deterioration came during the Reagan years. Measured another way, when the Democrats proposed the $1 increase in 1998, the benefit would have gone to 10.1 percent of the work force. That was the percentage earning between $5.15 and $6.15 that year. This year, only 6.8 percent would have benefited directly from the same increase.
A booming economy has moved many people's wages above the minimum, and this trend continued in the third quarter despite a slowing economy. But 6.8 percent of the work force is still nearly nine million workers, and these are the people the minimum wage was intended to protect, particularly when the economy turns down. "The whole point of minimum-wage policy is to make sure that no one is paid a privation level wage," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute.
A single mother of two who is leaving welfare, for example, must earn $6.45 an hour at a full-time job simply to reach the official poverty level of $13,423 for a family of three. That $6.45 is also the maximum pay for the bottom 10 percent of the work force, and Mr. Bernstein would set the minimum wage at this 10th percentile level. Until the early 1990's, the minimum wage often tracked the 10th percentile, without a measurable effect on hiring. Then it fell again, despite a 90-cent increase in two steps, in 1996 and 1997, to the present $5.15.
Getting back to the 10th percentile in 2002 means raising the minimum next year by roughly $1.50 an hour. That is a popular number among Democrats, according to Gene Sperling, director of the National Economic Council in the Clinton White House. Such a proposal in the next Congress, he said, "would put a strain on many moderate Republicans who won't want to be seen as unwilling to give hard-pressed workers in their districts a needed raise."
Conservative Republicans are more resistant. "They are more of the view that when you increase the minimum wage, you hurt unskilled people trying to get into the work force and certain industries that rely on these people," said John Feehery, a spokesman for House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert.
Mr. Bush shares these sentiments. He would sign a bill increasing the minimum wage, says Ari Fleischer, a spokesman. But he would require that the bill include a radical "opt out" provision. Any state would be allowed to opt out of the federal minimum and substitute its own, lower minimum if the legislature and governor decided that an increase in the federal minimum would be a "barrier to employment."
That would be a huge breach. A national standard 65 years old would be cracked, and the minimum wage would disappear.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Why Banks Can Avoid A Hard Landing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THE volume of problem corporate loans is rising. Individual debt levels are at record highs. And the economy is slowing. So why are investors so sweet on bank stocks?
From a trough in early March, the Keefe Bruyett & Woods Banks index is up more than 30 percent. Since the end of last year, it has risen more than 13 percent. 
 James K. Schmidt, lead portfolio manager of the John Hancock Financial Industries fund and the John Hancock Regional Bank fund, took time last week to discuss expectations for the new year. Following are excerpts from the conversation.
 
Q. Last week, the Federal Reserve said it was more concerned about the risks of a slowing economy than a rise in inflation. Would rate cuts in 2001 help banks?
 
A. Most investors overestimate how important interest rates are to banks. A long time ago, changes in rates used to be important, but now banks can balance their sensitivity to rate changes by matching assets and liabilities. That said, a drop in rates should be a slight help to earnings.
 
Q. There is talk that the economy could do more than just slow a bit, that it may even fall into recession. Do you share that view?
 
A. I am looking for a slowdown in growth to around 1.5 percent to 2 percent. That slowdown will lead to higher problem loans than we have had, but the numbers will not be draconian, so profitability will continue.
 
Q. How rapidly are problem loans rising? Are they likely to be as much of a risk as they were in the late 1980's and early 1990's?
 
A. There has been a lot of news lately about higher nonperforming assets and cuts in bank earnings estimates. The Fed numbers for the third quarter show the ratio of nonperforming assets to total assets increased from 0.67 percent to 0.7 percent. Over the course of my career, the average for that ratio has been 1.5 percent. This number is still very good, even though it will probably go up in the fourth quarter.
 
Q. What was that ratio in the early 1990's, with those problem real estate loans?
 
A. In 1990, the ratio was 2.94 percent. It rose to 3.02 percent the following year. It was worse for savings and loans: in 1991 the ratio was 3.96 percent.
 
Q. Are banks overextended in any particular area of the economy?
 
A. There is no obvious severe loan area that would correspond to the energy, farm, real estate and developing-country loans of the 1980's. People thought credit card loans would be a problem, but they have held up.
To date, the biggest problem has been large, syndicated, shared credits to large, highly leveraged companies.
 
Q. If the economy slows but doesn't stall, what sort of profit growth do you expect from banks next year?
 
A. Some people are estimating that profits will be up 10 percent to 12 percent. In the aggregate I think that will be hard for most banks to do. I don't anticipate big credit problems, but they will be worse than this year. So profit growth of 6 to 8 percent is probably a better range. That range might go up to 9 to 12 percent in 2002.
 
Q. Bank stocks did well from 1995 to 1998, in part because of mergers. The pace has slowed. Do you expect it to pick up again?
 
A. To me, the arithmetic for mergers looks good. But it only works for a handful of major banks. The stocks of premier banks, Wells Fargo, Firstar, Fifth Third, sell at substantial premiums to some medium-sized and smaller banks. That means they could pay a substantial premium and still have the deal be accretive to earnings.
 
Q. Are there other bank stocks that you like?
 
A. I like Commerce Bancshares in Kansas City. Barring a severe recession, they will not have credit problems. Seacoast Banking Corporation, in Stuart, Fla., has a very attractive franchise. I also like Cascade Bancorp in Bend, Ore.
Cuts in interest rates probably make savings and loans a better play than the banks. Of the thrifts we like Astoria Financial in Lake Success, N.Y.
 
Q. In addition to your regional bank fund, you manage a broader financial industry fund. Are there brokerage or credit card company stocks that you like?
 
A. Brokerage earnings can go away quickly, but they can also come back quickly. Right now, conditions in the stock market are about as bad as they can be. Even if the Nasdaq isn't any higher in 12 months, at least it isn't going down any further.
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, which is down from $110, is worth a look. And Merrill Lynch is a big holding. Among regional brokerages we like Tucker Anthony.
Our favorite credit card company is MBNA. They are quite sophisticated in their underwriting and their ability to model losses and delinquencies. But if the economy were to fall into recession and the unemployment rate had a big jump, my attitude would be different.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM;
Sharing the Bounty: How Much Is Enough?

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE pastor of my church called last month and asked if I would be willing to get up in front of the congregation to discuss, as he put it, "my journey" to increased charitable giving.
My first thought was, "Don't we hear enough on that subject from you?" My second was, "You've got the wrong guy." I decided not to give that talk, although I did agree to play one of the three kings in the Christmas pageant. 
 I figured that the pastor had noticed the bigger checks my wife and I started putting into the collection basket earlier in the fall, and that he was hoping that I would inspire others to do the same.
Indeed, our giving had gone way up, but not because I wanted it to. My wife, Christine, had insisted on it. She noted that our stock holdings and 401(k) plans had appreciated, that our suburban house had jumped in value and that the two of us were working. We had much to be thankful for, she said, and we could certainly afford more than the 2.4 percent of our income that we had been giving for the last three years.
Frankly, 2.4 percent sounded fine to me. After all, we still have to pay for the college educations of our four children, and our own retirement is less than 20 years away. In my opinion, now is not the time to be giving away money. Let's talk again, I said, after the children are out of college.
Besides, when I checked two years ago, I had found that baby boomers contributed, on average, just 1.9 percent of their incomes to charity. We were doing better than average, I told Christine smugly. What else could she want?
The answer was 10 percent. "Net or gross?" I asked in horror. "Your choice," she answered, probably thinking she was offering a compromise. I chose net.
Of course, we are not the only people writing bigger checks to charities. Financial planners and charitable organizations say many boomers are rethinking their charitable giving, with the older ones, those in their late 40's to early 50's, now giving 2.2 percent of their incomes. Until recently, at least, the stock market and the economy have been robust, and planners say boomers are telling them that they want to give something back.
"I'm not seeing more people giving, but the same people are giving more because their incomes have increased," said Chris Cooper, president of his own financial planning firm in Toledo, Ohio. "Their giving has increased 50 percent over a 10-year period. Some are up as high as 15 percent of their income a year. Some have 20 to 60 charities on their list."
Many people aren't finished saving for their retirements or children's educations, either. Bill Ludwig, 45, a pharmaceutical sales representative in Sylvania, Ohio, has two young sons and is counting on his 401(k) plan and other savings to eventually pay their bills and otherwise finance his retirement. He writes quarterly checks to a list of charities and refuses to let those worries stop him from doing what he sees as his responsibility.
"I've been able to give more as I see that I can," said Mr. Ludwig, who contributes about 6 percent of his net income. "There are people in need, and I feel blessed that our family has been able to have a good life and there are certain causes that have touched my heart. If I can make their lives a little bit better, I'm happy to do that."
John Fletcher, 42, of Perrysburg, Ohio, who works for the Ohio Turnpike Commission, said he had increased his giving by about 25 percent over the last four years. "I'm fortunate, and a lot of people out there are not fortunate," he said. "I should be giving something back."
Sara Melendez, chief executive of Independent Sector, an association of nonprofit groups in Washington, said that boomers were indeed having an impact.
"The number of small family foundations in the last few years has mushroomed," she said. "I would have to think that part of that is the baby boomers."
But, sounding a lot like my wife, she also thought that boomers could be doing better.
"I think the average American is very generous to be giving 2 percent of their income, but the very wealthy people can afford more than 2 percent," she said. "People who have reached the conclusion that they are well off should be giving 5 percent."
She may have to wait. The decline of the stock market could slow charitable giving. "I think that the people who are very wealthy and got their money out in time, they're still giving," said Greg Daniel, the owner of Creative Financial Solutions, a financial planning company in Manhattan. "People who don't even want to hear about giving, they're not going to fund any of these foundations any more."
Does that mean he is getting calls from clients asking him to delay their charitable plans?
"No, there's no phone call," he said. "I just don't hear from them again."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Living Without the Treasury Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE pace of the long goodbye to the trusted Treasury market will pick up under the new Bush administration. So next year, investors will really have to learn to live with the rapid shrinkage of this venerable $3.4 trillion market.
"Investors are going to have to go to non-Treasury instruments -- to high-grade corporate bonds and the agencies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac," said James R. Capra, chairman of the Treasury borrowing advisory committee of the Bond Market Association, which provides Wall Street's view on how to scale the Treasury market down. 
 Before the new administration is dry behind the years, some old standbys are going to vanish while others become less visible -- and probably more expensive.
By the second quarter of 2001, if not earlier, the one-year Treasury bill will be retired. Legislation to make that possible was recently approved. Also by then, issuance of the popular two-year note will be curtailed sharply, possibly to $40 billion a year, or just $10 billion a quarter, from $120 billion a year, or $10 billion a month, now.
Officials are also considering ending the issuance of 30-year bonds, whose sales have already been slashed to a mere $15 billion a year from $47.2 billion in 1991. "That is a live possibility," Mr. Capra said. And the Treasury is likely to curtail, if not eliminate, Treasury inflation-protected securities, known as TIPS, that it began to offer just four years ago.
The government is also likely to buy back more outstanding Treasury securities. It bought $30 billion this year and could increase that to $40 billion next year.
To those who think that a recession and a $1.3 trillion, 10-year Bush tax cut would shrink government surpluses enough to save these cherished Treasuries: Think again. Almost no matter what happens in the next year or two, the surplus forecasts are still stacked in favor of a smaller Treasury market.
The surplus is projected by the Congressional Budget Office to be $268 billion for fiscal year 2001, which began in October. It could rise to $345 billion in fiscal year 2002 and to $685 billion in 2010. Even after John Youngdahl, senior economist at Goldman Sachs, updated those projections to reflect a full Bush tax cut and zero economic growth for the next two calendar years, there would still be a lot of surplus sloshing around: $245 billion in fiscal year 2001, $203 billion in 2002, $180 billion in 2003, $178 billion in 2004, $183 billion in 2005 and modest increases from there in the next five years.
"It would take exceptionally pessimistic economic assumptions relative to the current consensus to cut the surpluses by much over the next few years," Mr. Youngdahl said.
Adding to the squeeze on Treasuries is the declining total of maturing government debt, simply because the Treasury issued less as deficits shrank and surpluses grew. The last three-year note, issued in 1998, matures in May. Five-year note sales were cut back to quarterly, from monthly, in June 1998; the sale of two-year notes was reduced last May to $10 billion a month from $15 billion.
Paying off maturing debt will not absorb all of the surplus. So new debt sales will be curbed and more existing securities will be bought back.
"Market participants do not think that the bond market will disappear," said Lewis A. Sachs, assistant secretary of the Treasury for financial markets. "But over the course of the next year or two, even if the economy slows down, there is an increasing recognition that there will still be a meaningful paydown of government debt."
The changes expected next year should not be as disruptive as the announcement early this year of the cut in 30-year bond issues. That seemed to have caught investors by surprise, even though the growing government surpluses signaled that Treasury borrowing had to decline. In just two days, the yield on the 30-year bond plunged to 6.14 percent, from 6.42 percent, as investors finally realized that this bond, once a benchmark, would become scarce.
But because the reductions are concentrated in short-term Treasury bills and notes, Mr. Youngdahl said, there could be enough extra downward pressure on these Treasury yields to surprise some investors.

LENGTH: 1319 words

HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE;
The Team Spirit At Work (Rah, Rah)

BYLINE: By FRED ANDREWS 

 BODY:
THESE four gents from New Zealand must have enjoyed themselves.
Over the course of two years, they met, among others, Michael Jordan, Mia Hamm, Joe Torre and Franz Beckenbauer, whom German soccer fans call the King. They sailed with Team New Zealand aboard Black Magic, twice winner of the America's Cup. They went through the paces with the American women's national soccer team, from buffet breakfast to chilling out with late-night pizza. Williams F1, the world's pre-eminent Formula One racing team, welcomed them into the pits at the Canadian Grand Prix. 
 Their odyssey delivered a book, "Peak Performance: Inspirational Business Lessons from the World's Top Sports Organizations" (Texere, $27.95), by Clive Gilson, Mike Pratt, Kevin Roberts and Ed Weymes. Except for Dr. Roberts, who is worldwide chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi, the advertising empire, the authors are professors at the Waikato Management School at the University of Waikato in New Zealand.
The authors say businesses can learn a lot from sustained excellence in sports. They looked at nine of today's most successful franchises, from the women's soccer team, still fresh in the limelight, to the All Blacks, New Zealand's national rugby team and an international force for more than a century. Great players come and go, the authors say, but excellence rests on building a "peak performance" organization that in its totality is more powerful than any player, even Mr. Jordan.
Almost none of their lessons come from the playing field. Nor does the book explain the new economics of sport or how a cunning general manager plays his cards in the confusion of college drafts, costly free agents and payroll ceilings. There are no trade secrets here.
Rather, the authors look at the shapes and styles of organizations, from secretaries and ticket punchers to presidents, vice presidents and -- today's stars -- the people in charge of marketing.
The elite organizations all turn out to be small and informal, most fielding only a few hundred employees. The authors find them overflowing with secure, intelligent people who are free to do their jobs. Almost invariably, the employees say that they feel like family and laugh a lot. With thousands of applicants, the elite teams prefer loyal retainers and long-serving professionals. The San Francisco 49ers finally retired a 95-year-old usher at the insistence of his family.
The prose is visual and nicely descriptive, amazingly so for a management book by a team of authors. Anyone would be thrilled to sail with Team New Zealand, and the book brings an exciting afternoon to life. The engines roar in the Formula One pit. One wonders which author (or who else) applied the final polish.
The book would be more persuasive, however, if it were not such a valentine. These glowing profiles are all self-portraits. The authors say they accumulated 4,000 pages of interview transcripts. If they spoke with a single critic, or even an independent expert, it is not apparent. So these sports tourists troop through the locker rooms with their mouths agape. They are true believers, as reverential as NFL Films.
WHAT they offer is big-time sports through rose-colored glasses. They describe the United States Soccer Federation campaign to build up the women's team, but not the gross favoritism toward the men's. Even after winning the World Cup, the women's team went on strike over their woeful pay.
The authors admire the feeling of family that Edward J. DeBartolo Jr. created by treating every 49er as a prince. They never mention his guilty plea in failing to report a felony in a gambling fraud and extortion case. That episode forced him to turn over the team to his sister, Denise DeBartolo York.
Nor do they mention Carmen Policy, the team's president from 1991 to 1999. His genius at stretching the salary cap was considered a key to the 49ers' peak performance. This month, the National Football League fined Mr. Policy $400,000 for violating the salary rules in those years.
A weak chapter about the New York Yankees reads like a single day's visit. The authors describe Yankee Stadium and the streets around it. They talk in the dugout with Joe Torre. In the clubhouse, Roger Clemens has no time to chat, so they talk with Ed Yarnall, a left-hander coming back from an injury who would later be traded.
They delight to find a former receptionist's photograph among a display of Yankee greats and to discover a half-bust in the dugout honoring an equipment manager who served 58 years. Just the right message, they say.
But their book includes this howler: "Allowing people to do their job without unnecessary interference is undoubtedly a trademark of the Yankee organization."
Saccharin aside, the book offers an insider's clinic on how sports are embracing big-time marketing the world over. The United States Soccer Federation orchestrated the "Road to Pasadena" matches to lift the profile of the women's team before the World Cup. The German soccer titan FC Bayern Munich mails a million copies of its master catalog.
The Atlanta Braves, described as "an entertainment brand second to none in sports," are ever inventive and never content. The Braves were pioneers with Turner Field, a dazzling ballpark with banks of video games, a Braves museum, a retail store and a life-size baseball playground on the upper-deck roof.
Not all teams pursue the same box-office strategy. In plush times, the Chicago Bulls forcefully pushed season tickets, against the day when Mr. Jordan would depart. Only 4,000 of 22,000 seats went on nightly sale. Now in the N.B.A.'s basement, the Bulls play before thousands of empty but presumably profitable seats.
FC Bayern Munich, in a soccer stadium that is much larger, limits its season tickets to 20,000 to give millions of fans a better chance of attending a match (and, not incidentally, to sell more trinkets to a fresh audience).
THE strongest chapters may be two from home, on Team New Zealand and the New Zealand Rugby Union, parent of the vaunted All Blacks.
In 1995, after a century of amateurism, potential competitors forced the rugby union to add professionals to its edifice. It created the Super 12's league, a jazzier version of rugby, to attract new fans, particularly women, and it added the National Provincial Championship, for small-town, smash-mouth rugby played the old-fashioned way. With the All Blacks, the Super 12, the National Provincial Championship, the Black Ferns women's team and the New Zealand Maori Team, the staid rugby union reinvented itself as a "house of brands."
In winning the 1995 and 2000 America's Cup, Team New Zealand went for an informal, cohesive unit that brought together all the sailors, designers, sailmakers and others, a varied lot who usually stuck to their own cubicles. Where once the cup challenge was driven by the genius who designed the boat, designers and sailors now listened to one another, the sailors clearly the customers. Instead of requiring the crew to jockey for starting berths until the last minute -- which had proved very divisive -- Team New Zealand announced its lineup 18 months before the event.
The book closes with a theory: Peak performance begins with focus, which rests on an inspirational dream and on accepting "the greatest imaginable challenge." Peak performance also means "sharing the dream" with employees and fans. It implies an organization that feels like family, imbued with harmony, passion and flow. The final hurdle is attending to the smallest detail, inventing "game breaking" ideas and striving constantly to better the organization's previous best.
Those virtues would transform any business. The unanswered question is how to nurture them in a business setting. These elite organizations are propelled by the joy and excitement of sport. Where does ordinary business find the equivalent?
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo

SECTION: Section 4; Page 9; Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1022 words

HEADLINE: The Nuts and Bolts of Bipartisanship

BYLINE: By Richard Darman; Richard Darman served, in the Reagan and Bush administrations, as assistant to the president, deputy secretary of the treasury, and director of the Office of Management and Budget.

 BODY:
With the election now settled, it is time to turn from the pursuit of power to its constructive use. It is unrealistic to expect a new era of bipartisanship. But is it too much to ask for one good year?
Conventional wisdom suggests that bitterness about Florida, a weak electoral mandate, and a closely divided Congress will make stalemate likely and the presidential victory hollow. Yet this possibility is so obvious it creates an opportunity to avoid it. Past examples of bipartisan success may suggest how. 
 Of course, stalemate has been the norm for much of the past decade; and it may continue. At least as likely, however, is the prospect that politicians will rise to calls for mutual accommodation merely by giving each other a little of this and a little of that -- tokens of ephemeral cooperation and a modest bipartisan mush.
But in the current context, neither stalemate nor tokens nor mush will do. Serious policy reform is needed. In a world where intellectual capital is increasingly important, America's education system is lagging. Our tax system, with higher rates and proliferating special-purpose provisions, risks a return to economic inefficiency and public alienation. Our health system, though superior in quality, remains costly and inequitable. Our Social Security system, in its present form, will not survive the retirement of the baby boom generation. And this is just the start of a long list of pressing challenges.
In the past two decades, despite divided government and polarized politics, our system has managed to produce bold bipartisan reform in four noteworthy cases: the 1981 Reagan economic program, the Social Security rescue of 1983, comprehensive tax reform in 1986, and the 1990 budget agreement. What these substantively very different cases have in common can help provide a guide toward a more productive future.
In all four cases, key parts of the political establishment were initially opposed to what was ultimately enacted. Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill and the Democratic House majority were adamantly opposed to the Reagan program in 1981. And they were not alone; much of the Republican leadership opposed the size of the Reagan tax cuts. On Social Security, neither Democrats nor Republicans would take the lead. They tried to pass the problem to a bipartisan commission; but the commission could not agree on a solution. On tax reform, the tax-writing committees of the Congress were highly skeptical. Almost every special interest lobby was organized to prevent reform. And on deficit reduction, Democrats opposed spending restraint and entitlement reform; while Republicans either opposed tax increases or conditioned them upon just what the Democrats opposed. How, then, in the face of conventional wisdom that said it couldn't be done, was historic legislation enacted? Four common elements are striking.
First, in none of the cases was the legislative process left to business as usual. Presidential staff invented and actively managed special processes to reach agreement and accelerate action. They negotiated side-by-side with key legislators. They did not accept -- nor did legislators enforce -- the separation presumed by the dictum "The president proposes and the Congress disposes."
Second, the executive branch developed, in advance, an explicit concept of its core coalition. For the Reagan revolution, conservative Democrats were linked with Republicans. For Social Security, the core was a centrist majority of the commission, President Reagan, Senate Majority Leader Howard Baker, and the Democratic speaker, O'Neill. For tax reform, the initial core involved a left-right linkage of reformers and President Reagan, which forced the bipartisan middle to join. And for deficit reduction, the strategy assumed that if the bipartisan leaders of the House, Senate, and executive branch would agree, the necessary majority would follow. Each coalition was adapted to its historical circumstance. All were bipartisan.
Third, most of the negotiating and coalition building was done in private -- often secret -- meetings at which trust could be built and built upon. These private trust-building sessions did not displace the open legislative process; they allowed it to function constructively.
Fourth, an outline for a policy bargain was developed in advance. In each case, the bargain was strong enough in substance to produce significant reform, while balanced enough in its politics to hold the coalition together.
And so, what might this mean for the current circumstance? Clearly, a bipartisan coalition will be necessary to govern. If a modest number of swing Democrats proves to be available, the coalition need not include the Democratic leadership. But one way or another, Democrats must be included. And to avoid the usual mush, special bipartisan negotiating procedures will have to be created -- bringing together groups of Congressional and executive leaders outside the conventional protocol. This much is straightforward.
 The harder issue is the substantive bargain. One variation might involve this trade: the Republicans would give a bit on the size of government in return for the Democrats allowing more market-oriented governmental action. This might mean, for example: a smaller tax cut than that proposed by President-elect Bush in the campaign, but one that emphasized across-the-board rate cuts; a larger education budget, but one that allowed more decentralization, accountability and use of vouchers; broader Medicare coverage, but through greater use of insurance premium subsidies; and the preservation of Social Security, but with a modest set-aside for individually controlled investment accounts.
If a superior bargain can be implemented, so much the better. But some such grand bargain should be pursued. Without it, the protracted contest for the presidency will have proved hollow. With it, the Florida fiasco could be left behind as a fitting close of an era of partisan excess. Having given the public sufficient reason for dismay, might not politicians conclude they owe the voters at least one good year?

HEADLINE: The End of the Party, or Is It?

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
DON'T panic.
The United States economy has gone from scalding to ice cold faster than a tenement shower. Every day brings another earnings warning, or 10. Despite a strong rally on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average is on track for its worst year since 1981. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is on track for its worst year since 1974. And the Nasdaq composite index, its worst year ever. 
 Last week, Charles Schwab, noting that assets and trading at his brokerage firm were shrinking, cut his base pay by 50 percent and encouraged his employees to take as many as 20 days of unpaid vacation in early 2001. And Lucent Technologies just issued its fifth earnings warning this year.
But investors need not panic. Really.
Yes, the shocking decline in information technology and telecommunications stocks this year -- by more than 90 percent in many cases -- has vindicated the skeptics who called the Nasdaq's 86 percent climb last year unsustainable. Yes, investors put money into too many untested technology and telecommunications companies. Yes, earnings do matter, and slowing economic growth does affect technology spending. And, yes, even after the plunge, many technology stocks remain expensive by historical measures.
But beyond the technology sector, the stock market no longer looks so precarious. By a crucial valuation measure, the broader market is cheaper than it has been in two years, and many highly regarded strategists expect the S.& P. 500 index to have strong gains next year. Even some technology stocks may be bargains, although they are harder to find.
"The market is today undervalued, the S.& P. on the order of 15 percent or so," said Abby Joseph Cohen, the chief United States investment strategist at Goldman, Sachs. "The valuations are the best we've seen them in a long time." Ms. Cohen expects the S.& P. 500 to be at 1,650 at the end of next year, a gain of almost 30 percent from its close on Friday of 1,305.97.
Several other top strategists are also bullish, including longtime bears like Byron R. Wien, the chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. The overall market, which was 40 percent overvalued at the beginning of 2000, is now 10 percent undervalued, Mr. Wien said.
"The market has gone through a process of rationalization," he added. "I can do my job now -- people were encouraging me to retire at the beginning of the year."
This optimistic view, of course, plays down one danger advanced by a vocal minority: a recession in the United States. "We don't think this is an environment for an aggressive investment stance," said Douglas Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan. "It looks like the first part of next year is going to be even weaker than what we've got right now."
Mr. Cliggott thinks that many of his counterparts are underestimating the risk of a recession. He predicted that the S.& P. 500 companies would have flat earnings next year, and his year-end 2001 target for the index is 1,400, markedly lower than that of most of his peers.
IF Mr. Cliggott and the bears are right, the market could be in for another long year. But their view fails to account for the measures that both the Federal Reserve and the federal government are likely to take to stimulate the economy next year, bulls say. Both monetary policy (a k a short-term interest rates, which are controlled by the Fed) and fiscal policy (the government's tax and spending manipulations to achieve a surplus or deficit) have been very tight this year. The Fed has kept real short-term interest rates high, and the federal government is running the largest surplus in its history.
Those policies have worked all too well in recent months to slow the economy. Early in 2001, they will be loosened, giving the economy a crucial lift, predicted Mary C. Farrell, senior investment strategist at PaineWebber. That move is even more likely because inflation remains low, productivity growth is still strong, and oil prices, an important contributor to inflation, are dropping.
"This is the longest expansion in our history," Ms. Farrell said. "It's maturing, it's slowing, but we should still get some reasonable growth next year. She predicted growth in the gross national product of 2.6 percent next year and global economic growth of 3.3 percent.
Those gains should translate into an earnings increase of 7 to 8 percent for the S.& P. 500 during 2001. That would be less than half the pace this year, but in line with historical averages, she said. Other bulls offer similar estimates for economic and earnings growth.
If they are correct, stocks should perform very well next year, said Donald G. Berdine, chief investment officer of PNC Advisors, which manages $65 billion in stocks and bonds. The decline in stock prices during the fall, combined with the climb in bond prices and the corresponding drop in yields, means that stocks are as cheaply valued as they have been since 1998, Mr. Berdine said.
At the beginning of this year, the 10-year Treasury bond yielded around 6.5 percent. The average S.& P. 500 stock, meanwhile, had a price-to-earnings ratio, based on projected 2000 earnings, of almost 30, or an "earnings yield" of about 3.5 percent. The earnings yield is the inverse of the price-to-earnings ratio.
Usually, the 10-year bond yield and the S.& P. 500 earnings yield are about the same, and many analysts viewed that gap as a signal that stock prices were dangerously overvalued.
Now, earnings have risen and stock prices have fallen, so the average big stock has a P/E ratio, based on projected 2001 earnings, of 21, or an earnings yield of about 4.8 percent. And the yield on the 10-year Treasury bond has dropped to 5 percent. With the gap between stocks and bonds virtually gone, stocks are no longer expensive, said Ms. Cohen at Goldman, Sachs.
"It's a very interesting contrast as to where 2001 starts and where 2000 started," she said.
MR. BERDINE offered another reason for optimism -- the sheer amount of money available for investing. The cash holdings of stock mutual funds crept up to 6 percent of total assets in October, from a low of 4 percent in March and a recent average of around 5 percent, according to the Investment Company Institute, an industry trade group. That may look like a small difference, but because stock funds have about $4.3 trillion in assets, each percentage-point difference represents $43 billion in cash. Barring steep withdrawals by investors, managers will put some of that built-up cash into the market as this fall's nervousness subsides, providing additional buying pressure, Mr. Berdine said.
Still, no one is expecting a return to the wild markets of 1999 and early 2000, when technology stocks without earnings -- and sometimes without revenue -- would double in a few days and rise tenfold in months. "New bull markets always establish new leadership," said Fred Kobrick, one of the few money managers around who can draw on firsthand experience of the 1973-74 bear market. "The theme players are going to be very disappointed."
Mr. Kobrick, who manages almost $1.5 billion in assets, has had a miserable year. After gaining 86 percent in 1999, his emerging-growth fund, the Nvest Kobrick Investment Trust Emerging Growth Fund, which is focused on technology companies, has fallen 42 percent this year. He said investors had panicked and sold good and bad technology companies alike this year, just as they had bought them en masse in 1999. Next year, investors will resume distinguishing winners from losers, he said.
"Classic bull technology markets over history meant that some technology stocks were going up, some were going down," Mr. Kobrick said. "That's why, historically, technology has been hard to invest in." He expects semiconductor and semiconductor equipment manufacturers, which are off 50 to 80 percent from their highs, to begin the technology rally.
"Semiconductors led the market down, and they'll lead it back up," he said.
Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, also says technology has more strength than many investors believe. "The business really hasn't slowed down much," he said. Personal computer sales will rise 20 percent worldwide in 2000, despite weakness among American consumers, he said.
"There is a flat spot here, but it's difficult to say things are actually going to go down," Mr. Murphy said.
Still, many other investment professionals are not so sanguine about technology; they contend that the sector as a whole remains overpriced despite its slide and that the remainder of the market offers better values.
"We've just thrown way too much money into the technology sector," said Ralph Wanger, chief investment officer at Liberty Wanger Asset Management. "Stocks got wildly priced, too much enthusiasm, and now we're all sobering up. You roll over in bed, and look at your portfolio and say, 'Hey, I brought that home?' "
Many big technology stocks remain expensive on a price-to-earnings basis despite their plunges this fall, especially because earnings estimates for the technology sector are coming down, said Charles L. Hill, research director for First Call/Thomson Financial. First Call tracks corporate earnings and analysts' forecasts.
Cisco Systems, the leading manufacturer of networking equipment, trades at 50 times its projected earnings for the fiscal year ending July 2001. EMC, which makes huge data storage systems, trades at 80 times its expected earnings for this year.
At the earliest, "the bottom for earnings growth for the tech stocks is going to be the second quarter" of 2001, Mr. Hill said. "There are some stocks where the multiples are too high."
SO what sectors are worth investors' attention?
Both Mr. Berdine and Mr. Wanger favor energy. Mr. Berdine likes independent electric power producers like AES, which is based in Arlington, Va., and operates power plants worldwide, and oil services companies like Schlumberger, which help oil companies find, develop and operate new fields.
"We have a substantial weighting in energy stocks, and we think that's going to be all right," Mr. Wanger said. "They're burning a lot of gas out here in Chicago." He expects oil prices to stay between $20 and $40 a barrel over the next several years, considerably higher than the $10-to-$20 range where they spent most of the 1990's.
A couple of veteran investment managers, meanwhile, advise investors not to worry even if there is a recession.
As long as individual investors have a reasonably long time horizon, they may not want to spend too much rejiggering their portfolios to find recession-resistant stocks, said Mark Greenberg, manager of the $550 million Invesco Leisure fund."Every company is affected by the economy," he said.
Instead, people should look for companies that can increase their earnings faster than the overall market or their peers in the same industry, no matter what the economy does, Mr. Greenberg said. Marriott International, the hotel company, is an example, he said. Because Marriott is expanding aggressively and has solid management and a strong brand name, he said, he expects the company to have above-average earnings growth over the next three to five years whether the economy is strong or weak.
Then there is Mr. Wien, who has been a strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter for years. "Buy old economy," he growled. "The only technology you buy is truly distressed. You don't buy any stocks that don't have positive cash flow. Buy value versus growth. Buy small and medium versus large. And I think you'll do well."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
A Strategy Built on Loaves Throughout the Land

BYLINE: By GRAHAM GORI 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
EVERY morning, in the working-class neighborhood of Diez de Abril, where unfinished concrete is the dominant decor, a sparkling white truck emblazoned with the name Bimbo stops at almost every corner.
A deliveryman wearing a Bimbo tie unloads loaves of white bread and carries them into a tiny mom-and-pop store. He greets the owner, stocks up the Bimbo bread display, collects the money, drives another block and repeats the process. 
 Grupo Bimbo is Mexico's largest baking company and the third biggest in the world, with sales of $3 billion last year and profits of $210.5 million. It has succeeded by lavishing attention on the smallest retailers in nearly every nook of Mexico for the last 55 years.
In Mexico City, with a population of 18 million or more, there are twice as many Bimbo delivery trucks as city police cars. Nationally, the company's 17,250 trucks deliver to many areas that lack running water or plumbing. It now controls nearly 95 percent of Mexico's packaged-bread market. In the minds of many customers, Bimbo bread is as Mexican as a corn tortilla.
Having conquered Mexico, Bimbo began looking abroad about seven years ago. It now sells bread, snacks and candy in almost every South American country, plans to buy a bakery in Brazil and has opened operations in Texas and California.
Now, having brought white bread to Mexico, Bimbo wants a bigger slice of the market where white bread has long been a grocery-store fixture: its executives are preparing to spend billions on a major acquisition in the United States.
In a way, Bimbo's aspirations north of the border represent a belated recognition of the Bimbo name -- a derivative of Bambi, which was a popular American cultural icon in Mexico when the company was founded.
It is not clear whether Bimbo has the experience to succeed in such a large expansion outside of its own country. But in the United States, where the market for white bread is barely growing and where small bakeries are routinely gobbled by larger ones, Bimbo has made it clear that it will be predator, not prey.
"We are always looking at opportunities to increase our presence in the Americas, where we are concentrating at the moment," said Daniel Servitje, Bimbo's president. "We are open to looking into ways to strengthen our position in the United States."
In 1993, Bimbo began buying bread bakers all over the Americas, including 4S Bakeries in California and Mrs. Baird's in Texas. In terms of size, Bimbo and its subsidiaries are the dominant players in most of the markets they have entered. But Bimbo executives have found difficulty in turning a profit outside of Mexico.
THE company's Latin American operations, excluding Mexico, will have operating losses of about $7 million this year on sales of about $250 million, the third consecutive year of losses. In the United States market, Bimbo is only expecting to break even this year.
"Their secret of success in Mexico has been market dominance," said Damian Fraser, an analyst at UBS Warburg in Mexico City."They don't have that outside Mexico. They've already bitten off more than they can chew. If they expand further, it will only make it more difficult for them."
Responding to rumors that Bimbo was preparing to buy a large bakery in the United States, Deutsche Bank published a report recently suggesting that any such decision would be a mistake. Its authors argued that Bimbo had become significantly bigger in the last three years, but not necessarily more profitable. They said it would be "challenging for the Mexican company to gobble up such a large company in the U.S. at a time when it is still transitioning towards stability itself."
Doubts about Bimbo's future expansion plans have not been lost on investors. The company's stock price has been in a general decline for more than a year.
The skepticism partly reflects the decreased popularity of white bread in the United States. Once the choice of the upper class, white bread has lost favor with health-conscious consumers, making bread shelves a highly competitive space at groceries. But Bimbo says it has the ingredients to survive in the United States.
Mr. Servitje countered every criticism aimed at his company, calling its poor performance in Latin America a result of strategic mistakes and a faltering economy, and attributing the drop in profits in the United States to a recent restructuring in California. Both markets, he predicted, will show earnings gains next year as Latin America continues to industrialize and its consumers turn to the convenience of packaged bread.
While he acknowledged that the United States market is far different, Mr. Servitje said his company has strong brand recognition among Hispanic consumers. An estimated 20 million Mexicans and Mexican-Americans now live or work in the United States; in Mr. Servitje's opinion, that means 20 million consumers with memories of Bimbo bread on their breakfast tables at home in Mexico. In addition, the Latino food market is growing robustly, at around 6 percent a year.
"What differentiates us from our competitors is that we are a Mexican-based company that will add products geared to Hispanic markets alongside Anglo products, or general market products," Mr. Servitje said. "One strong difference of our company is that we do have a special interest in the Hispanic market, and we are providing more products geared toward that segment."
Bimbo is already selling its bread and line of tortillas in Latino markets in the United States. Bimbo's wheat-flour tortilla, Tia Rosa, is the fastest-growing tortilla brand in the United States.
BIMBO'S strategy, Mr. Servitje said, is to buy a company with an extensive, well-developed distribution system, to continue producing the acquired company's existing brands, and to use the distribution channels to promote its own products in Latino markets.
"There's a greater recognition of Bimbo in the U.S. market," said Alberto Bercowsky, investor relations officer at the company. "We've already gained the two largest Hispanic markets, in Texas and California, and we're planning on moving on."
Mr. Bercowsky said Bimbo, which has $450 million to invest, is looking to buy one of the largest bakeries in the United States: Interstate Bakeries, the maker of Wonder bread and Hostess Twinkies; Earthgrains; Flowers Industries, which controls Keebler and Nature's Own (but recently agreed to sell its Keebler stake to Kellogg); or Bestfoods Baking, whose brands include Entenmann's and Oroweat.
For months, securities analysts thought that Bimbo was planning to buy Interstate, the largest bakery in the United States, with a distribution system that reaches more than 90 percent of the population. Both companies denied that there had been talks, but Interstate's recent announcement of its 12th consecutive quarter of losses reinvigorated speculation that it could fall into Bimbo's hands.
"Bimbo's desire to approach companies in the United States has continued to mature," Mr. Bercowsky said. "But it's undecided which of the four it will be. At this point I'd say that Interstate would be an error."
Whatever happens, Mr. Bercowsky said, "Bimbo is taking an aggressive stance and is looking to acquire, instead of being acquired."

INDUSTRY: NAICS311812 COMMERCIAL BAKERIES (57%); SIC2051 BREAD & OTHER BAKERY PRODUCTS, EXCEPT COOKIES & CRACKERS (57%);

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for LARRY COHEN;
Renewing a Union in the New Economy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
LARRY COHEN, executive vice president of the Communications Workers of America, is one of the labor movement's chief strategists in trying to unionize high-technology workers. He wants to develop models for new-economy unionism.
His union is seeking to organize hundreds of customer service workers at Amazon.com. It is involved in the first unionization vote at a dot-com company, Etown.com, a Web site that sells electronics. Most customer service workers there asked for the election, scheduled for next month, saying they wanted to join the communications workers. 
 His union has led an effort to organize workers at I.B.M., after the company angered employees with a plan to reduce pensions. The union has not won the right to bargain for I.B.M.'s workers, but the unionization drive helped persuade I.B.M. to reverse itself on much of the unpopular pension overhaul. STEVEN GREENHOUSE
 
Q. Considering that high-technology workers earn more than most other workers and are so highly skilled, why should they be interested in a union?
 
A. People involved in high-tech want more of a voice on work-related issues, like the kind of customer service they provide on the Internet or the phone. Many high-tech workers are also concerned about job security. When Amazon is moving customer service work to New Delhi, customer service workers in Seattle, many of whom have been at Amazon since the beginning, are worried that management is ignoring their concerns.
High-tech workers are aware that there's not a single high-tech C.E.O. or high-level manager who doesn't have a contract, detailing their country club membership, stock options, health care and salary of $1 million or $10 million. High-tech workers are smart, and they don't understand why they shouldn't also have a contract.
 
Q. High-technology companies are usually entrepreneurial, innovative and flexible, but unions usually resist entrepreneurship, innovation and flexibility. How do unions fit into the high-tech economy?
 
A. Unions usually take a different approach when it comes to high-tech workers. You don't try to bargain everything. When unions negotiate contracts for high-tech workers, they usually set just a floor, and most of the room is from there on up. Maybe just 30 or 40 percent of the compensation will be based on that floor. That leaves a lot of flexibility.
 
Q. With a lot of dot-com companies struggling, many managers fear that unionization will hasten the demise of their companies. What do unions bring to the party?
 
A. What unions bring is support for people at a company who feel they have a stake and don't want to be treated like a commodity. We're trying to build structures so that workers can interface with their managers with more confidence. People working at these companies are entitled to a voice, and companies are much more likely to succeed if their employees have a voice. Unionization absolutely should not increase the chances of a company's demise.
 
Q. Why have unions had so little success in organizing high-technology workers?
 
A. Six years ago, our union did not represent a single worker in cell phone communications, and now we represent 10,000 of them as members.
In terms of I.B.M., it has very traditional issues, relating to job security, pension and benefits, and of course there are concerns about cost-cutting. At I.B.M., many employees, working with us, have established the Alliance at I.B.M., to help give workers there a voice. The Alliance at I.B.M. has 1,000 members and 3,000 subscribers.
In the Amazon campaign, it's not easy. There, management is operating in a 1930's style. It's responding with fear. This is supposed to be a new economy but we have old-economy-thinking managers in terms of employee rights. Amazon is willing to accept workers if they have piercings or tatoos, but it's not willing to accept workers if they have a mind of their own.
 
Q. With so many high-tech workers jumping between companies or working as freelancers, how can unions help the high-tech work force?
 
A. At our affiliate, the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, what sustains people is not collective bargaining, but creating a community of people. Maybe half these workers are freelance. Unions can provide a mix of social and educational activities, including hard-core training. We're providing classes in advanced Java script to improve people's skills.
Unions can provide information on job referrals and partnering for new people at a company. It's a matter of how do we create virtual and actual communities with other people like us.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
A Lightning Rod in California

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
WHEN a water shortage gripped California in the mid-1990's, Stephen L. Baum took to showering in a bucket. He would stand in the bucket under the shower, get wet, shut off the faucet, soap up, rinse and flush the toilet with the accumulated water.
Mr. Baum, the chairman of Sempra Energy, has asked his customers to take the same kind of conservation steps in response to the the current crisis gripping California -- spiraling natural-gas prices, coupled with an unprecedented shortage of electricity that has been widely attributed to a chaotic deregulation of the state's utility industry. 
 "I'm a persistent spokesman for addressing the demand side of the equation," he said in an interview early this month, when Californians were confronting the prospect of rolling blackouts for the first time. The blackouts remain a threat.
If Mr. Baum is looking to his consumers for help, it is hard to blame him. Sempra Energy, the parent of San Diego Gas and Electric and Southern California Gas, has been hit hard by California's energy crisis. During the summer, Sempra's customers were the first in the nation to pay free-market power prices: wholesale electricity costs skyrocketed and homeowners' bills doubled or tripled. And now Sempra's gas customers are facing winter bills that are likely to be 60 percent to 100 percent higher than last year's.
Mr. Baum, a former Marine and a career power industry executive, is under intense pressure, even if he does not show it. Sempra serves 21 million people in California and is one of the country's largest utility companies. Sempra employees have been harassed by outraged bill payers. The state has temporarily limited what Sempra can charge for power regardless of what the company must pay to buy it.
Mr. Baum, 59, has acknowledged that his salary, with bonuses, is likely to exceed $2 million a year, so he will not have any trouble paying his utility bill. Still, he has sought to practice what he preaches about conservation. In his La Jolla home, he has installed energy-saving fluorescent bulbs, timers on the dehumidifier and wine cooler and a special meter that lets his family save money by using electricity during off-peak hours.
But Mr. Baum also acknowledges that power conservation alone cannot solve California's energy crisis. He has been a leading proponent of changing the way deregulation works.
He wants temporary limits on what electricity wholesalers can charge the utilities. He wants the state to permit a rate increase. And he has suggested ways to help consumers buy the so-called time-of-use-meters -- the type he has in his home -- so they can benefit from using energy at off-peak times and through "negawatts," or credits for not using power. "Everyone talks about building new power plants, and everyone talks about price caps, but none of these things address the end user," he said.
Although Sempra has been forced to buy electricity at high prices, its problem is not as severe as that of California's two biggest utilities, Southern California Edison, which is a unit of Edison International, and Pacific Gas and Electric, a unit of the PG&E Corporation. Last Tuesday, Edison warned that it might have to seek bankruptcy protection. And Gov. Gray Davis has acknowledged that bigger electricity bills are inevitable because consumers must "bear some of the burden" of saving the utilities.
Sempra is in relatively good shape, partly because the company sold its California generating plants in July 1999, making San Diego Gas and Electric a distributor.
Under deregulation, that cleared the way for the company to raise consumer rates; Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas and Electric could not because they still own plants.
"We lifted the rate cap and nothing untoward happened for over a year," Mr. Baum said. "At which point, and this is my take on it, the generators and the other market participants figured out how to optimize their profits in the market."
Mr. Baum has seen the utility business from all sides. He started in the late 1970's as a lawyer for the Orange and Rockland Utilities in New York. He later became general counsel of the New York Power Authority, the state regulatory agency. In 1985, he moved to California and held a range of managing posts at San Diego Gas and Electric. He had been Sempra's vice chairman, president and chief executive before he was named chairman in September, succeeding Richard D. Farman, who retired.
Perhaps Mr. Baum's most notable achievement has been the diversification of Sempra, which has six subsidiaries besides its utilities. Among them are Sempra Energy Trading, an energy marketer, and Sempra Energy International, which develops projects abroad.
Sempra's non-utility businesses now provide about 30 percent of the company's earnings, compared with 1 percent or less a few years ago.
The diversification has earned Mr. Baum respect, not only from shareholders but also from employees. "When he arrived we were kind of laid back, doing business as a utility and not venturing into anything else," said David A. Moore, business manager of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers local 465, which represents field workers at the San Diego Gas and Electric unit. "We were known as the small little utility to the south," said Mr. Moore, who has known Mr. Baum since his arrival. "He basically turned this company around."
But if the company is proud of its expansion, consumer advocates express concern that the company is putting its own interests before those of customers. "I was very supportive of changing around the economics of the industry," said Michael Shames, executive director of the Utility Consumer Action Network, a San Diego group that is critical of Mr. Baum and Sempra. "But I have a lot of difficulties with the way it's been done. These megaholding companies exercise way too much authority over the customer."
Mr. Shames said he believed that Mr. Baum was positioning the company to be sold -- something that Mr. Baum has denied.
Mr. Baum, who finds relaxation in the kitchen preparing gourmet meals, said he had no regrets about running Sempra at such a difficult time.
"I don't pine for going off and playing golf," he said. "I'm an adrenaline junkie. This is actually fine."

HEADLINE: An Interview With Bill Clinton

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview of President Clinton in the Oval Office by The New York Times:
 
Q. The thing that seems to be a common thread that all your senior aides have said over time is that your greatest strengths are inexorably, I suppose as all human nature is, bound up in some of your potential weaknesses, and that the same aptitudes and appetites that have made you the most formidable political person of your generation have sometimes got you in trouble. I just wonder if you think there is any way that, over the last eight years, somehow America could have had the best of you without getting the worst of you, or is it all sort of wrapped up in one package? 

A. Oh, that's a judgment for somebody else to make.
 
Q. You don't want to take a ----
 
A. Yes. You guys were wrong about Whitewater. I wish we had the -- that Gertz sic Gerth piece was ridiculous, absurd on its face. I wish we could have had the great New York Times without that. It was like Wen Ho Lee, Chapter 1. I wish we could have had it. But we couldn't. So we still got The New York Times. Is the country better off for having The New York Times? Absolutely it is. Are we better off having The New York Times? Of course we are. I'll let -- the American people will have to make that judgment.
 
Q. Is it ever a kind of thing that you would like to take a good crack at some day in your own writings or your own thinking about this, some day when there's perspective? Because I sense it's ----
 
A. I might. I might. I've been -- nobody has any -- most people have no idea about what, personally, I've gone through for the last couple of years -- and I might do that. But I did the right thing not to do it -- this point, because the people hired me to do a job, and I got up every day and did it.
The price I paid for my personal mistake was, believe it or not, more than anything else, a profound personal price. I'm glad that I saved my family. I'm glad that my life is happy and in good shape, and I'm glad my country is still in good shape. But that whole episode was fundamentally a political move. It was not rooted in any established principles of Constitution, or law, or precedent. And so, you know, I didn't have time to be as personally reflective or harshly judgmental of myself, except for once, as I would otherwise have been inclined to do, because I was finding it too hard to save what we had worked for and the direction the country had taken.
And I just think that one of the things I hope -- and I saw it in this election -- I noticed that there was much less appetite for the politics of personal destruction in this election than there had been in many others, and I hope that maybe that's one of the consequences of all that I did, and maybe -- I mean, what we all went through, and maybe that will be something that's really good for the country over the long run. Maybe nobody else will ever have to go through this. . . .
 
Q. Is health care your biggest regret?
 
A. Well, I regret the fact that there are a lot of people in this country who still don't have health insurance. But we finally got the number of people without insurance going down again, for the first time in a dozen years, because of the Children's Health Insurance Program triggering in. So we're moving on it.
And I suppose on a policy front, that certainly ranks right up there. I wish we'd gotten -- I wish we'd been able to do more. But we got the number of uninsured people going down, and now we know how to do it, interestingly enough.
I think in the next year, I think the Congress ought to let the parents of the CHIP kids buy into it. I think they ought to let people over 55 buy into Medicare, as I proposed. There's three or four things you could do to dramatically reduce the number of people without health insurance in a piecemeal basis.
But let me say -- people say, well, why didn't you do that back in '94. The reason is, we didn't have the money to. If you want to provide health insurance, universal health insurance, there's only two ways to do it. It's not rocket science. You've either got to require the employers to offer the health insurance and then give a little financial -- a tax break to the people who have a hard time providing it, or you have to pay for it with tax money. And we had just raised taxes in the economic plan of '93 to get the deficit down. And we didn't have any money, so we couldn't raise taxes and we didn't have -- and the economy was not strong enough for the Congress to feel comfortable putting the employer mandate on it.
So I think -- that was my mistake. That wasn't -- I've always thought that my wife took too big a hit on that. That was -- I asked her to come up with a universal plan that maintained private health providers. And there aren't any other options, and neither option, frankly, in 1994 was politically doable in that Congress, and maybe not in the country by the time the interest groups got through mangling on it. So that was my mistake and it's one I have to live with -- like all my other mistakes. 
http://www.nytimes.com
