HEADLINE: New Sprouts, Old Doubts for A.D.M.

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: DECATUR, Ill.

 BODY:
AT the sprawling headquarters of Archer Daniels Midland here, just beyond the rumbling and rattling of some of the world's biggest corn and soybean processing plants, top executives speak in glowing terms about the company's future.
A new A.D.M. is emerging, they say. It is a company that offers not just bulk grain but also a growing array of health and nutritional products like veggie burgers, soy milk, natural vitamin E and isoflavones, a soy extract that may reduce the risk of osteoporosis. It is also a company that will use its huge stocks of corn to produce renewable resources like biodegradable woods, plastics and fibers that could be an alternative to petrochemical products. And it is one that is willing to experiment with giant fish farms and specialized foods like hydroponic cucumbers. 
 What the executives do not want to talk about, though, is the past. They would like to bury talk about criminal investigations, F.B.I. tapes and Mark E. Whitacre, the former executive who blew the whistle on a huge price-fixing scheme at A.D.M. in the 1990's. That is history, the company says.
Although the company's stock price has jumped in recent weeks, few on Wall Street appear convinced that the new A.D.M. is all that different from the old one. The company, the self-proclaimed "Supermarket to the World," is still in the bulk commodity business, and its board and executive ranks are still believed to be controlled by the Andreas family, which owns less than 8 percent of the stock.
Five years after the price-fixing scandal and two years after the retirement of Dwayne O. Andreas, the legendary chairman who built A.D.M. into one of the world's most powerful corporations, the leadership -- and the future direction -- of the company remain in question.
In 1997, the board named G. Allen Andreas, Dwayne's nephew, to replace him as chief executive; two years later, Allen moved up to chairman as well. But in recent interviews, he has steadfastly refused to rule out the possibility that his 51-year-old cousin, Michael D. Andreas, Dwayne's son and onetime heir apparent, would return to the company after his three-year prison term ends in late 2002.
"I don't have any reason to respond until the circumstances change," Allen Andreas said in an interview two weeks ago. "His case is on appeal. He's maintained his innocence." Michael Andreas, the company's former vice chairman, was one of three top executives convicted of taking part in a global conspiracy to illegally fix the price of lysine, a widely used additive in animal feed during the early 1990's. On the tapes secretly recorded by Mr. Whitacre, who was head of the company's bioproducts division when he turned government informer, Michael Andreas was also heard making sexual and sexist comments about employees.
The $100 million fine that A.D.M. agreed to pay in 1996 to settle the government's charges was one of the largest price-fixing settlements in American history. But the company never admitted wrongdoing, and to this day it declines to say that its top executives were guilty of any crime.
"The board of directors made no judgment about the executives," Allen Andreas, 57, said last week. "Mick has been my close counsel and adviser. I had an excellent relationship with him," he said, referring to his cousin Michael.
If nothing else, those remarks suggest that the issue of who will ultimately lead Archer Daniels has not been resolved.
But the idea that Michael may return to the company -- either officially or unofficially -- does not sit well with big investors. "We would find this completely outrageous, if not immoral," said Theodore White, the corporate governance officer for the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the huge pension fund. "This underscores the fact that the longer you have a family running a public company, the more problems it creates. I think shareholders would flip if this happens."
Perhaps paradoxically, as A.D.M. searches for new leadership and a new direction, it desperately needs someone like Dwayne Andreas, who took control of the company in 1970. As its iron-fisted chairman, he dropped millions of dollars into the coffers of politicians of all stripes, to gain support for government programs that benefited his company -- price supports that helped increase the sales of high-fructose corn syrup, for example, and subsidies that helped create a national market for ethanol, a corn-based gas additive.
Yet as A.D.M. seeks to dispel notions that its fortunes were built on power politics and price-fixing, it needs to wield enough power to maintain its position as the world's premier agriculture company in a rapidly consolidating industry. "They're now at a crossroads," said David C. Nelson, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. "The world in the 90's changed faster than A.D.M.; they're playing some catch-up."
SINCE September, the company's shares have been climbing; they closed on Friday at $13.88, up almost 20 percent this year. But the movement has come largely because of optimism about growing demand for ethanol, the corn-based fuel additive, and soybean meal, which is fed to livestock. Most analysts say they are buying Archer Daniels as a bottom dweller to be prepared for an up cycle, not as a growth stock with long-term prospects.
"They do have a vision; it's just so far away," said Christine McCracken, an analyst at Midwest Research, an equity research firm based in Cleveland. "I just don't see any near-term catalyst in this story. It's really events, cycles. So you have to be a real Warren Buffett investor to stay with this."
Of course, the entire food industry has suffered a slump in the past few years. But few falls from grace have been as ugly as that of A.D.M., which suffered not only three senior executives being sent to prison, but also a huge drop in world commodity prices and shareholder meetings filled with angry questions about everything from the board's structure to the use of genetically altered crops.
Before its recent climb, the company's stock hit a 10-year low in September after another season of poor profits. Even now, the shares trade about 30 percent lower than they did in 1997.
And long-term growth prospects of A.D.M. remain relatively bleak, some analysts say, partly because it is already so big. A $13 billion company, it processes nearly one-third of the nation's corn, soybean and wheat crops and is one of the world's biggest cocoa producers. It also owns one of the nation's largest fleet of trucks, ships and rail lines.
The company's raw goods, bought from farmers, are processed at giant grain refineries that operate day and night. They produce the building blocks of breads, chocolates, vegetable oils and an array of other ingredients for products in every supermarket aisle.
Check the back of a bottle of Mrs. Butterworth's pancake syrup. The No. 1 ingredient is high-fructose corn syrup, which A.D.M. extracts from kernels of corn. It is the same sugar substitute that sweetens soft drinks. The company's ingredients are also in products like Skippy peanut butter, Hershey's chocolate syrup, Smucker's jellies and Campbell's soups. That is why A.D.M. calls itself the "Supermarket to the World."
But while those ingredients and grains are essential, food production nowadays is so efficient, so competitive and so commoditized that profit margins are slim.
NEIL E. HARL, a professor of agriculture and economics at Iowa State University, said the price-fixing scandal might have distracted A.D.M. at a time when other agriculture companies were reassessing their operations and broadening their focus.
"I think now, A.D.M. is playing catch-up and they're not sure where to go," he said. "They'd like to go into new businesses or move upstream toward the consumer. There's a growing realization that if you aren't close to the consumer, you're not going to go far."
That is precisely why General Mills, Pillsbury, Unilever and other food makers have divested themselves of some grain and milling operations to focus on branding and marketing higher-margin products. And it is why food processors like Tyson, Smithfield Foods and Conagra have moved up the food ladder, toward the consumer.
For years, A.D.M. has turned bulk commodities into more profitable goods like ethanol and high-fructose corn syrup. But it has not moved toward branded consumer goods. Though a strong backer of genetically altered crops, which executives say will revolutionize the agriculture industry, the company also chose not to acquire the seed or technology companies that are now developing the products.
Two major deals were considered, insiders say. In 1998, Monsanto, the chemical and biotechnology giant, looked at acquiring A.D.M. Later, DuPont contemplated such a move, according to press reports. Either deal would have tied together a major seed and chemical producer with a huge grain processor.
No deal was hatched, though, and some Wall Street analysts say it was probably a good thing, considering that biotechnology is now under fire.
Still, A.D.M. has failed to escape the low-margin cyclicality of its business. "You have to have realistic expectations," said Ms. McCracken at Midwest Research. "A.D.M. is never going to be Amazon.com. It's just not a high-growth company; it's a bulk processor."
However much they disagree with that assessment -- and they do -- executives at A.D.M. now have to convince investors that the new A.D.M. is a profit engine. As they see it, the company will achieve major growth through its nutraceuticals division, which sells natural vitamin E, isoflavones and other soy-based products believed to have health benefits.
As the country's population ages and becomes more health-conscious, health experts say people will look increasingly toward food supplements and substitutes for meats and dairy products. A.D.M. says its soy products will help fill that demand.
In a conference room at the headquarters, the company has been host to investors, analysts, reporters, food company executives and even Cuban dignitaries for lunches that show off multiple new prospects for using soy: the Midland Harvest taco filling, made with a soy meat substitute, a soy harvest burger, a soy pasta salad, soy-enhanced bread rolls and even a dairy-free soy ice cream.
The trouble is, the company's fortunes now are not tied to these relatively new products. Instead, they are linked to things like soybean oil, of which there is a global glut.
"The world is awash in vegetable oil," said Mr. Nelson at Credit Suisse First Boston. "We have the absolute worst market ever."
The problems began in Asia when an economic crisis swept the region in late 1997. That sent world commodity prices plummeting and eventually, over the next three years, helped clip more than $2 billion in revenue from the balance sheet of A.D.M., which sells a large portion of its products to the Pacific Rim.
Now, however, things are looking up. A recovery is under way in Asia, and in Europe, demand for soybean meal is rising because of a ban on bone meal in animal feed amid the scare over mad cow disease.
A.D.M.'s fate also depends on the ethanol factor. The demand and price of ethanol have surged with higher gasoline prices and could go even higher if Congress bans M.T.B.E., a gasoline additive that has been found to pollute water supplies. A ban might create a boon for A.D.M., which produces about 35 percent of the nation's supply of ethanol, the most likely replacement for M.T.B.E.
Potentially even bigger, however, are the company's plans to turn corn starch into other industrial goods -- like plastics, wood fibers, paper and other products now derived from petrochemicals.
Longer term, executives say, the company is investing in smaller technology companies and searching for joint ventures and new alliances with drug companies. It is also preparing a global network of grain elevators and processing plants that would segregate and process biotech crops in a way that analysts hope will be profitable.
"A.D.M. is trying to prepare itself for what will happen in the chain," Ms. McCracken said. "It's almost like the U.S. Postal Service; it's bulk service, but there's also Express Mail, so there's value there."
Indeed, A.D.M. has another plan. It says it will be one of just a few major grain handlers that will be able to efficiently track, segregate and ship to market genetically altered crops -- for which demand is increasing despite worldwide controversy over their safety.
"It's going to be a very complicated network," says Lewis W. Batchelder, a senior vice president at A.D.M. "Companies that don't have the infrastructure that A.D.M. has are going to have a difficult time pulling it off."
A.D.M. also wants to build closer relationships with farmers. Contract farming is already under way in much of the country, with farmers growing crops for companies like Frito-Lay, which wants a particular type of corn for its corn chips.
In the future, A.D.M. says it could help farmers choose their seeds, chemicals and fertilizers; line up the contracts and the financing; and even supply information about the weather, how best to plant a crop and the ideal date for harvest. Finally, A.D.M. would ship and process the crops.
It is unclear, however, whether farmers will agree to such a relationship. In the Midwest, many are already concerned about consolidation in the agriculture industry. The prospect of being contract farmers, tilling the land and taking orders from giant agriculture companies is even more troubling.
Unless companies like A.D.M. have control of a product from the farm to the processing plant, it will be impossible to get the growing number of specialty crops, like high-oil corn, to the market, Mr. Batchelder said.
THE company is also experimenting with several small-scale ventures. Here at the headquarters, in a giant hydroponic greenhouse, cucumbers slide off an assembly line to be carefully packaged and boxed for shipment.
About 500,000 heads of lettuce are also growing at any one time, year-round, in a space of just three-quarters of an acre. There is no soil, just a tray filled with a liquid nutrient solution that fosters faster growth.
"This is a kind of farm of the future," says Daniel Helfrich, the manager of the hydroponics division. "We can grow the same amount of lettuce in one-tenth the acreage."
The same facility also houses an enormous fish farm, home to more than 2.5 million tilapias, which are fed a diet of corn and soybeans. The fish farm is another, albeit small, outlet for the company's grains.
Feeding the planet is a mantra at this company. Indeed, its Web page, www.admworld.com, shows a running count of global population growth -- two and a half people a second, or about 80 million a year. A.D.M. is betting that the world's growing middle class will choose diets that mimic those in the United States, though analysts wonder who is going to pay for the food.
Skeptics also say that A.D.M.'s new initiatives will not amount to much in the next few years, and that the company still needs to show that it has cleaned up its act since the price-fixing debacle.
In 1998, under pressure from dissident shareholders, who complained about its insular nature and the influence of the Andreas family, the board's corporate governance committee recommended that a majority of the board and its committees be outside directors.
Now, most of the directors do come from outside, but many have close ties to the Andreas family, including Robert S. Strauss, the former chairman of the Democratic Party.
Dwayne Andreas, 82, serves as chairman emeritus and still has a board vote.
NOW leading the company, of course, is his choice, Allen, a former lawyer who has worked at A.D.M. for 27 years. (The board acknowledged that it did not interview any other candidates for the job.)
Allen has neither the fire nor the flamboyance of his uncle, but he is testy about the company's past. "This is five years ago, what do you want me to do?" he snapped when asked if the company ever admitted price-fixing and whether it would formally condemn actions by its own executives.
He would much rather talk about the future, stressing A.D.M.'s new mission statement ("to unlock the power of nature to improve the quality of life") and a new code of ethics and throwing around "new agriculture" lingo like renewable resources, nutraceuticals and functional foods. He foresees a planet that will produce much better food, for many more people, on much less land. And he sees a convergence of agriculture, food and pharmaceutical companies, with A.D.M. right in the middle.
"At some point, there ought to be a merger of interest between the pharmaceutical industry and the life sciences industry," he said. "We're in the life sciences industry; we're the largest producer of vitamin E, we're starting in vitamin C, and we have isoflavones. They need us to produce the foods that have good qualities."
Still, a question lingers: Will those products, and others, really make A.D.M. much less cyclical, as the company hopes? So far, Wall Street analysts are betting that the answer is no.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Thinking About the Day After Tomorrow

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS he has aged along with his generation, Bill Clinton, who likes to call himself the oldest baby boomer, went from thinking about tomorrow in his first national campaign to lamenting in his second that he had more yesterdays behind him than tomorrows ahead. Groaning at his sentimentality, his detractors -- his haters, really -- relished seeing him as the embodiment of what they considered his generation's immorality, self-absorption and instability.
That may have turned Mr. Clinton into a caricature of a caricature, but if so, it was partly his fault. Along with his self-image, his politics were consciously generational, from the moment he opposed President George Bush as a cold warrior ill-equipped to midwife a globalizing economy. His two terms tracked the arc of his ever-changing generation -- from scattershot, even reckless idealism to cautiously self-interested maneuvering, with a long, wasteful timeout for bad behavior and an increasing focus on finances. 
 "Each generation of Americans must define what it means to be an American," Mr. Clinton declared in his first Inaugural Address, as he seized the torch for his fellow boomers. Later, the country would learn that for this president "definitions" and "meanings" were starting, not ending points.
Under President Clinton, definitions changed. What it meant to be a Democrat, what it meant to be a Republican, what it meant to be the president, what it meant to be first lady, what it meant to be impeached, what it meant to say something "is" -- all these became more fluid.
Along with the political nomenclature, the world was also changing, and fast. Mr. Clinton is fond of noting that when he became president there were 50 sites on the World Wide Web. He still barely uses a computer, but he grasped early on how information technology could change society.
Mr. Clinton's own capacity for change was obvious from the moment he began campaigning. It was dismissed as chameleon slipperiness by his detractors and hailed as tactical brilliance by his supporters. It led both to underestimate him. Both saw him as emotionally weak, quick to agree with the last person who counseled him. He turned out to be ruthless and tougher than anyone who opposed him. He was seen as gross in his appetites and tastes -- and he can be -- but he also proved to be extraordinarily subtle, sometimes far more subtle than was good for him.
Mr. Clinton began with visions of an epic, big-screen presidency and ended up more like a celebrity promoter of cherished causes. But from the start, his critics and even his supporters underestimated how, while everything changed, he would cling to core goals -- expanding economic opportunity, negotiating trade agreements to promote growth and peace, making higher education a middle-class entitlement -- and would keep working toward them, albeit with ever-changing methods.
When Congress was with President Clinton, he passed the North American Free Trade Agreement and expanded the Earned Income Tax Credit, an underappreciated boost to the working poor. He passed a deficit-cutting plan that, paradoxically, became his most effective social program. But he overreached, and he had to switch strategies.
With Congress against him, he played defense, protecting entitlement programs for the elderly while pushing for incremental changes in health care. He signed a Republican welfare reform bill -- he had promised an end to welfare "as we know it" -- but came back, again and again, until Congress excised what he considered to be its cruel provisions.
President Clinton was largely indifferent to bureaucratic reform, but he wanted to restore confidence in the government. The shutdown of 1995 reminded Americans how much they depended on federal programs. After the 1996 campaign no one seriously talked about disbanding the Department of Education. Now, for the first time, the children of baby boomers have seen that the government can operate in surplus.
BUT Mr. Clinton wasted the opportunity he created. During the shutdown, over a pizza, he started his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, which ultimately gave cynicism about government a good name. His personal trustworthiness became a national joke. Yet, in powerful tribute to Mr. Clinton's gift for conveying that he understood and cared about Americans' problems, a strong majority continued to trust him to do a good job as president. As a result, his sexual experimentation -- like his generation's -- was read as either causing Americans to grapple honestly with the complexities of marriage and relationships or turning them into compartmentalizing moral relativists. In reality, it did both, and deepened the split between the camps holding each view.
"The urgent question of our time is whether we can make change our friend and not our enemy," Mr. Clinton said in that same first Inaugural Address. The baby-boom generation has brought on extraordinary change -- in civil rights, women's roles, the nature of the economy, religious practices, attitudes toward authority. It is hard to think of an public or private institution unaffected. All of it -- like the changes brought on in the last eight years by President Clinton -- feels unfinished. Their contribution, and his, seems transitional.
Now the country will see if George W. Bush -- another representative of the alternately feckless and ambitious boomers -- can handle change as adeptly as his predecessor. As for soon-to-be-former President Clinton, who has never been satisfied simply being, the always fascinating and sometimes aggravating question remains: What will he become next?

HEADLINE: The Nation;
A New Look at Russia

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
VLADIMIR V. PUTIN, the Russian president, has found little to talk to the Clinton administration about of late. And so there he was this month, circling the United States with visits to Cuba and Canada and seeming to say: Please take notice, Russia is still a power.
Mr. Putin is said to be eager to come to Washington to meet President-elect George W. Bush in the spring. If he does, he may find the new Bush administration taking notice of his country in an entirely new -- but perhaps unwelcome -- way. 
 That was the clear implication in the two key choices Mr. Bush made public last week of officials to lead his foreign policy -- Gen. Colin L. Powell as secretary of state and Condoleezza Rice as national security adviser.
"The watchword for the Bush administration will be pragmatism," said Thomas E. Graham, Jr., an expert on Russia at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace who, having served in the American embassy in Moscow, has studied the Bush policy as it has emerged for a year. "Gone will be the romanticism of the early Clinton years and the pretense of the later years."
In the 1990's, Russia was treated as the 500-pound gorilla of foreign policy problems -- a country whose nuclear arsenal, strategic position and imploding economy made its success or failure of immense interest to the United States, even though Washington ultimately had little real control over events there.
Now comes the Bush team, with plans to signal different treatment. Speaking bluntly, Ms. Rice said in the fall, Russia is now a challenge not because of the might it once had as the center of the Soviet Union but because it is a "declining power."
For starters, Russia policy is likely to be folded back into the European bureau at the State Department, a move that would suggest that Russia is not going to get all the special attention it had in the last eight years. Instead, Ms. Rice has said that America needs to re-cement relations with its allies in Europe and Asia. Mr. Bush promptly acted on that premise by dropping by to see a visiting President Jacques Chirac at the French Embassy here Monday night.
"They will seek relations with Russia that are a combination of cooperation, competition and indifference -- similar to relations the United States enjoys with most countries around the world," Mr. Graham said.
Ms. Rice has been Mr. Bush's tutor in foreign affairs, and now she will run the Russia policy from a desk just down the corridor from the Oval Office.
But Mr. Bush will also have a powerful and experienced secretary of state, General Powell, and that leaves a question of how the two will mesh their ideas, and how the Russians will react to them.
In his first statement as secretary of state designate, General Powell set a firm tone, saying that Russia would not be a strategic partner, an approach the Clinton administration used in the early going with its favorite Russian leader, Boris N. Yeltsin. General Powell, like Ms. Rice in the past year, spoke unambiguously about forging ahead with national missile defense, a clear-cut Bush foreign policy goal.
If missile defense is, indeed, the first issue to come up in relations with Russia next year, it is highly likely to enrage many Russian leaders, Mr. Putin among them. After Mr. Clinton failed to persuade Mr. Putin to agree to an amendment to the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 and thus to allow deployment of a limited missile defense, the two leaders had little to talk about on the four occasions when they met face to face.
THE Bush notion for national missile defense, as outlined by the governor in a speech last spring, calls for abrogation of the ABM treaty, a prospect that Russia and the European allies have fiercely opposed. Whether Ms. Rice and General Powell want to tear up the treaty right away is not clear. But they are intent on forging a new strategic concept with Moscow, and Ms. Rice has hinted she knows this is likely to introduce a new animus.
"Whether or not the Russians are fully ready to accept ballistic missile defense as a part of that strategic concept, I can't judge," she said in the fall.
Ms. Rice has chosen as her deputy at the security council Stephen J. Hadley, an assistant secretary of defense in the administration of Mr. Bush's father and a big promoter of national missile defense. Mr. Hadley is also an active member of the U.S. Committee to Expand NATO, a group that is aggressively seeking to bring into the alliance more nations that were part of the Soviet empire, a goal Moscow detests.
The Bush approach to Russia will focus much less than the Clinton team did on what the Russians are doing at home. Ms. Rice, whose basic expertise is in the Soviet system and its security arrangements, believes that the Clinton administration spent too much time and money trying to transform Russia into a Western look-alike democracy and market economy.
IT was good news, she said in her fall speech, that Mr. Putin had stopped making frequent calls for international financial assistance and had placed more emphasis on tax reform that would allow entrepreneurship to develop. "If we can rebalance the agenda with the Russians to one that deals more with the security challenges that we both face, I think we will have both a more realistic and a more fruitful relationship with Russia," she said.
Is this the kind of music Mr. Putin wants to hear? During the campaign, Russian officials suggested they preferred Mr. Bush to Mr. Gore for the next four years.
They suggested they liked the sound of hard power as opposed to the soft power of coddling Russia into imitating Western models of democracy and capitalism.
Indeed, on a Russian Web site that reflects the government point of view, a commentator wrote last week under the headline "Condoleezza Rice upholds Putin's policy" that Ms. Rice was their kind of hard-headed Russia expert. This was so, the writer said, because she would refuse to spoon-feed the "infant" with I.M.F. "baby food."
But given the content of the hard power agenda, a departing Clinton Russia expert asked: "I wonder if the Russians will like the meat and potatoes when they eat it."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Robert L. Rodriguez;
FPA Capital Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
HERE'S a holiday gift for stalwart value investors: On Jan. 1, the longtime value guru Robert L. Rodriguez will reopen his $375 million FPA Capital fund, which has been closed to new investors since 1995.
The gift comes courtesy of a collapsing stock market that provides him with buying opportunities. The major indexes flirted with new highs earlier this year, Mr. Rodriguez said, but by then the gains were limited to a narrow group of stocks. As he sees it, most stocks have been in a bear market since February 1998, and many are selling at bargain prices. 
 "The value style of investing has been under severe attack, the worst I've seen in 30 years in the business," he said. "The gap in valuations between high-expectation growth stocks and out-of-favor issues is among the widest in years."
Nor does he expect the carnage among technology stocks to stop soon. "It would not surprise us if the Nasdaq declined another 30 percent from present levels," he said from his Los Angeles office overlooking the Pacific Ocean.
FPA Capital, which reopens with a 5.25 percent load, down from 6.5 percent, has outstanding long-term returns. It gained 19.2 percent a year, on average, for the 10 years through Thursday, placing fourth among its peers in the mid-capitalization value category, which returned 15.1 percent, according to Morningstar Inc.
But the shorter-term picture is far different: it rose just 1.1 percent, annualized, for the three years ended Thursday, ranking near the bottom of its group, which returned 8.2 percent.
Those recent returns have not shaken Mr. Rodriguez's strict value discipline. He is a contrarian who chooses stocks from among the most unloved issues. "Many solid companies are selling at seven or eight times their projected 12-month earnings," he explained, compared with a ratio of about 25 for the Standard & Poor's 500. "Some have been hammered by even slightly disappointing earnings, others can't shake off their association with the old economy and others have simply looked dull to investors captivated by an era of headlong technological change."
Mr. Rodriguez, who is 52, races sports cars, a flashier hobby than his investing style might suggest. As chief executive of First Pacific Advisors, the funds' sponsor and a unit of United Asset Management, he also runs the $500 million FPA New Income fund.
At FPA Capital, he and three analysts bottom-fish among companies with market capitalizations of roughly $500 million to $3 billion. To pick the 35 or so stocks in the fund, they seek market leaders with strong balance sheets and depressed share prices, then look for low ratios of short- and long-term debt to total capital, which is debt plus shareholder equity. The fund's ratio of debt to capital is 30 percent, versus 36 percent for the Russell 2000.
"When you invest in companies that are hated," Mr. Rodriguez said, "you like to have a solid balance sheet as well as solid cash flow to give you the financial wherewithal to make it through a difficult cycle."
Mr. Rodriguez also favors stocks that are trading at 12-month lows or below their five-year average prices. He finds others by scanning Wall Street recommendations, then doing the opposite. "Usually we look for companies that have a lot of 'holds' on their stock, a euphemism that brokers use for 'sell,' " he said.
Mr. Rodriguez's mantra is "long term." The fund's turnover has averaged 20 percent a year or less during his 16-year tenure, compared with more than 100 percent for the typical domestic stock fund.
When oil prices hit new highs in recent months, he sold energy stocks and bought those of heavy energy users. "We don't feel that the present level of energy prices can be sustained over the next three years," he said.
In August, he bought Celanese, the German chemical company that trades as American depository receipts, in part as a bet on falling energy prices. He has bought and sold shares over the last decade, most recently buying at an average, including commission, of $15.863. The stock is now at $17.94.
He praised what he called the company's "low-cost leadership" in chemicals for industries including automobiles, construction products and clothing. The company's ratio of debt to capital is 30.9 percent.
Celanese is also a play on the recovery of the euro. "We think the odds are decent that the euro is presently overly depressed," he said.
Another favorite is Michaels Stores, an arts and crafts retailer with about 600 outlets. After the arrival of a new chief executive, Michael Rouleau, nearly four years ago, it is "moving to record profitability," Mr. Rodriguez said.
He bought shares in October 1996 at $14.125. The fund increased its position in October 2000 after the price fell 50 percent in the wake of a company announcement that earnings might not meet expectations. The stock now trades at $23.75.
Two big electronics components distributors account for nearly all the fund's 24.4 percent stake in technology -- Arrow Electronics and its chief rival, Avnet. Any company that wants to do global business requiring electronics parts, he said, must deal with one or the other. He called them "the poor man's way of participating in the growth of technology."
He first bought Arrow shares in 1989 at an average of $5.331; they are now at $26.13. He bought shares in Avnet's predecessor, Marshall Industries, in 1990 at an adjusted price of $12.475; Avnet now trades at $19.06.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Charity Begins at the Rule Book

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
CHARITY is kind, the Bible says. And in this season of coat drives and food baskets, who would disagree? Not President-elect George W. Bush, who has vowed to "rally the armies of compassion," and met with black ministers last week to promote faith-based charity as the kinder, more cost-effective alternative to government-run help for needy people.
But as charities attempt to take up the slack in the safety net caused by a $7 billion decline in government food aid for the poor, they have taken on some of the worst aspects of the government bureaucracy they try to replace. Seemingly arbitrary eligibility rules, inflexible limits on aid and impersonal requirements are now common features at many food pantries and religious social service organizations as they struggle with overwhelming demands. 
 To meet a new scale of need, many nonprofit agencies became more professional and so rule-bound. Public money to expand, or access to supplies from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, brought greater accountability and state rules so detailed they can specify the number of cans of green beans allowed one family in a year. Even small, church-based volunteers are adding rules that can make it harder to get help.
In New York City, a recent survey of 216 food pantries by the Coalition Against Hunger found 63 percent now set rules to limit use, though such rules were too rare to measure just a few years ago, and only reached half the pantries in 1999, said Judith Walker, director of the coalition. At United Bronx Parents, hungry families are barred from getting groceries from the food bank more than three times a year; before the coordinator hands out cans of chili beans and meat balls, he consults a ledger cross-referenced with names, dates and photocopies of such required documents as a referral from a church or social service agency.
The more programs are forced to turn people away for lack of supplies or money, researchers say, the more intent they become on adding rules that tighten their service boundaries, trying to slow demand and ensure help goes to those who need it most. The unintended result is that people unable to make ends meet because of low wages or serious health problems trudge from one food pantry to the next.
"What's most worrisome is that some of the people who are in most need are simply not able to play by all these rules," said Amy Brown, a researcher with the Community Food Resource Center in New York.
One goal of the welfare overhaul was to replace a sense of entitlement from government with a sense of personal responsibility for self-sufficiency. Private charity was expected by many to do a better job than government at deciding who deserved help. And agencies generally consider rules, even arbitrary ones, a fairer way to ration inadequate resources than unbridled discretion.
More rules can also be a healthy development in a growing organization, contends Noel Tichy, a professor of business at the University of Michigan and a management expert who advises corporations and nonprofits alike. In fast-growth software companies, he said, "we try to create some rules and bureaucracy to guide decision-making so it's not all anarchy." In lean social service organizations, "they're trying to be fair, and rules are one way to play triage."
But the result can seem like the worst of both worlds, said Doug O'Brien, director of policy for America's Second Harvest, which distributes $2.4 billion worth of donated food annually, compared to $18 billion-worth of food stamps delivered by the government, down from $25 billion five years ago.
In its survey of 12,000 food programs two years ago, 77 percent of pantries said they limit who can be served, and 70 percent screen clients, often to prevent use by those outside a certain geographic area. Some consider that applicants who make the rounds abuse the system, but 53 percent say the practice is fair, in part because clients cannot get enough food from one program.
At one food bank in Austin, Tex., for example, many young mothers who arrive with hungry toddlers in tow have been referred straight from the food stamp office for emergency supplies to bridge a 30-day delay before their first allotment. But Debora Duncan, the center director, said it cannot supply food for a whole month and bars a client's return for three months. If they go elsewhere, she added, "They are labeled as using the system, when all they're trying to do is survive."
Not surprisingly, a recent survey at the Community Food Resource Center's West Harlem food programs, which has no geographical restrictions, found 21 percent of clients travel there from other boroughs.
SUCH demand pushes charities to ratchet up eligibility requirements, said David Reingold, an assistant professor at the Indiana University School of Philanthropy, who studied the impact of welfare reform on faith-based charities in Indiana. Surveying 295 social service agency directors, he found 23 percent of the faith-based organizations had tightened eligibility criteria for their services -- far more than the 8.7 percent of their secular counterparts. In Green county, Indiana, some churches are limiting help to members of their own congregation, he said.
These trends have a familiar sound to American social welfare historians. In the late 19th century, after public relief was drastically cut in an effort to end "pauperism," private charity organization societies with the motto "not alms but a friend" promoted investigations to curb the "unworthy" poor from seeking multiple handouts and slipping back into dependency.
Then, as severe recessions hit, "scientific charity" came under attack. By the early 20th century, many charity leaders agreed that more government help was needed to relieve poverty rooted in ill health, low wages and economic dislocation.
"In any business solution is embedded the next problem," Mr. Tichy said. "You run a risk of creating a bureaucracy which becomes less human, less in touch with what the vision of these agencies was. On the other hand, you have little alternative."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Home Economics;
The First Lesson for Bush: It's Still the Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Texas

 BODY:
TO anyone interested in what happens when a new president meets a jittery economy, there was a fascinating bit of political theatre on Monday morning outside the Madison Hotel in Washington.
President-elect George W. Bush emerged from breakfast with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. A smiling Mr. Bush threw his arm around Mr. Greenspan's shoulders and, while the Fed chairman looked vaguely uncomfortable, said, "I talked with a good man here. We had a very strong discussion about my confidence in his abilities." 
 Actually, a more interesting question is how much confidence the economy's Delphic Oracle has in the abilities of Mr. Bush and his economic team, which is just now taking shape.
After all, Mr. Bush's designee for Treasury Secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, who has run Alcoa and is an old friend of Mr. Greenspan, had barely expressed how honored he felt before the Nasdaq fell 7 percent on Wednesday.
It has now fallen almost 45 percent since Sept. 1., evidence of an economy that has slowed far sooner than almost anyone expected at the end of the summer. Last week, a raft of companies announced disappointing earnings, layoffs and temporary plant closings, and Xerox, of all companies, reportedly asked its employees not to make so many photocopies.
Mr. Greenspan, who engineered a steady run-up in interest rates for fear that the economy needed to be cooled down, now seems to fear he has gone too far: The Fed indicated last week it may soon begin to cut rates, because fears of recession have come to outweigh fears of inflation.
Mr. Bush's advisers are not new to slowdowns: Mr. O'Neill ran an aluminum company, a business tightly bound to world markets, and Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, whose exact position has yet to be announced, used to serve on the Fed. But the issue facing them today is not just a slowdown here, it is a slowdown everywhere. Japan looks as if it is slipping into recession, Europe's hopes of reducing its chronic unemployment problem are slipping away, and in the past few weeks, the International Monetary Fund has put together a $40 billion bailout package for Argentina, and a smaller one to keep Turkey afloat.
In fact, what makes this slowdown different from the last one, said Allen Sinai, the chief economist of Primark Decisions Systems, whose reports are read by some of Mr. Bush's top advisers, is precisely its global character.
"The links in international economies are much, much tighter than they were during the last Bush administration," said Mr. Sinai. "And this time, the contagion that everybody worries about could easily emanate from us. That creates a particular problem for any administration, much less one that hasn't gotten to Washington yet."
OVER the past decade, it has become clear that troubles in one corner of the globe, even a remote one, can't be quarantined.
Think about the collapse of the Thai baht in 1997, which triggered the Asian crisis. As it spread, Hong Kong's markets began to sink. And that, in turn, provoked a huge sell-off here. The next year the same thing happened again with the relatively small economy of Russia, whose troubles nonetheless ignited panics from Wall Street to Latin America.
Now imagine the effect of the United States economy, the world's largest importer, slowing from 80 to, say, 55 miles an hour. Suddenly, Japan's bad prospects are far worse and China's toy-and-electronics-driven growth falls. And if the dollar weakens, which many economists expect, foreign investors could pull their money out of the United States, where it has been parked for most of the past decade, further depressing imports here.
Mr. Bush's economic aides understand this cascading bad-news scenario all too well, though they don't want to talk about it publicly, for fear of causing some of the very problems they hope to avoid. (They are also up for confirmation hearings, a period during which only fools talk policy.) In the past, Mr. O'Neill has strongly supported the Clinton administration's policy of paying down the national debt. How that squares with Mr. Bush's enthusiasm for tax cuts, a position that Mr. Lindsey helped develop, is not clear. The Bush folks say there is plenty of money to do both, but there won't be if a downturn turns those surplus projections into pixie dust.
For his part, Mr. Bush acknowledged the international dimension of his economic challenges at a press conference on Friday. But his approach sounded markedly different from that of Mr. Clinton and his advisers, led by Robert E. Rubin and then his successor as Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, over the past eight years. Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers never shied from telling other countries to get their economic houses in order, and offered billions in loans to Mexico, South Korea and others if they implemented reforms to Washington's liking.
"We'll have a foreign policy that is humble," Mr. Bush said, repeating a line from his debates with Vice President Al Gore. He added: "By that I mean that we should not be divining prescriptions for people's ills. If they want to work with us, fine. But our country cannot try to impose our prescriptions on nations."
It is too early to tell exactly what that means. It's hard to imagine that the United States will stop prodding Japan to restart its idling economy. Or that it will cease using the monetary fund as an instrument of American will. Because economic downturns these days have a way of gaining speed as they circle the globe.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Fashion's Political Forecast

BYLINE: By WILLIAM NORWICH

 BODY:
IT'S finally clear: Fashion is destiny. The Bush family tree grows in Washington once more and it looks like 1980's deja vu all over again.
Never mind the pundits and political analysts, the prognosticators to beat are fashion people. They have been saying the 1980's are back since 1996. That year, fashion design began to invoke the 1980's gold rush. Now, we have full-blown 1980's redux, with logo handbags (actually, logo everything), designer dresses, big hair, furs and Park Avenue princesses. And the Bushes are returning to the White House. 
 "The 80's just won't go away," said Joan Kaner, fashion director for Neiman Marcus. "Then and now, the excessiveness of detail and exaggeration of sharp shapes are a reflection of good times and the economy."
The range of 80's fashion in stores leaves none of the decade's stones unturned. There are shoulder pads, tight jeans and drapey necklines. There is punk, new wave and early Madonna -- the performer and new bride, not the virgin -- references. Also pearls. Republican red is the new black -- again -- which had been replaced by brown which replaced gray which was the new black.
The word "snippy" is back. Hanging up the phone when one feels "snippy" is back. Texas ranches are back. Reruns of "Dallas" are expected again in heavy cable television rotation. Back, too, is Hobe Sound, the snippy, exclusive Florida resort near Palm Beach, but social worlds away from it, where Dorothy Walker Bush, paternal grandmother of the president-elect, wintered.
Preppy-style clothing and accessories are back.
Also back is Arnold Scaasi, who dressed Barbara Bush when she was first lady in the 80's and still does. The American couturier will, apparently, not have the opportunity to dress Laura Bush for the Inauguration. The Dallas designer Michael Faircloth -- what's in a name? -- got the nod. But Scaasi's fingers are crossed for future commissions. (I know. I've seen the fingers.)
Attention all political analysts: Fashion prognosticators are already on to the next big thing. The fashion cycle spins ever faster. Why not the Clintonesque early 1990's, which featured a minimalism that, as Amy M. Spindler observed in The Times, was a "fashion mea culpa" to atone for the 80's excesses? Almost a decade old, this is already vintage in fashion time. And Bill Clinton himself does not seem to be going away.
Much like politics, fashion nostalgia is tricky. Buyers beware. It, "errs when interpretation digresses into imitation -- and there were many accusations of mimicry this season," as Anne Slowey writes in Elle.
Politics is dandy, but fashion is faster. And people who don't understand fashion are bound to repeat it.

HEADLINE: The Dot-Com Bubble Bursts

 BODY:
A year ago Americans could hardly run an errand without picking up a stock tip.Day-trading manuals were selling briskly. Neighbors were speaking a foreign tongue, carrying on about B2B's and praising the likes of JDS Uniphase and Qualcomm. Venture capital firms were throwing money at any and all dot-coms to help them build market share, never mind whether they could ever be profitable. It was a brave new era, in which more than a dozen fledgling dot-coms that nobody had ever heard of could pay $2 million of other people's money for a Super Bowl commercial.
What a difference a year makes. The Nasdaq sank. Stock tips have been replaced with talk of recession. Many pioneering dot-coms are out of business or barely surviving. The Dow Jones Internet Index, made up of dot-com blue chips, is down more than 72 percent since March. Online retailers Priceline and eToys, former Wall Street darlings, have seen their stock prices fall more than 99 percent from their highs. 
 Unlike the worrisome decline in the stock prices of solidly grounded technology firms due to a slowdown in profits, the sharper plunge taken by some of the trendy Internet companies that had no earnings in the first place has proved comforting to those who believe in the rationality of markets. After all, many of them lacked one key asset -- a sensible business plan. Even the most traditional brokers and investment banks set aside the notion that a company's stock price should reflect its profits and urged investors not to miss out on the gold rush. At the craze's zenith, Priceline, the money-losing online ticket seller, was worth more than the airlines that provided its inventory.
The current sense of despair in the dot-com universe may be as overdone as last year's euphoria. The Internet, after all, really is a transforming technology that has revolutionized the way we communicate. What recent months suggest, however, is that it may not be an indiscriminate, magical new means of making money.
Woeful tales of visionary innovators failing to capitalize on their revolutionary new technology are not new. The advent of railroads, the automobile and radio, to name other watershed innovations in history, also led to many a shattered dream. The number of failed auto makers far exceeded the number that ultimately succeeded.
In this holiday season, the financial implosion of so many dot-com retailers seems particularly cruel. It is not as if consumers do not appreciate shopping online. Online sales this season are expected to be about two-thirds greater than last year. But it is not the innovators who are reaping all the benefits. Online retailers are losing market share to the likes of Wal-Mart and Kmart. This holiday season, online sales of traditional retailers, initially hesitant to embrace the Web, will outpace those of the pure dot-coms for the first time.
The endearing Pets.com sock puppet is a fitting mascot for the demise of the dot-com mania. Less than a year ago the spokesdog for the online pet-supply retailer was starring in some of those $2 million Super Bowl commercials. Now, in the wake of his master's bankruptcy, he is looking to shill for another company -- one that can actually make money.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: FUNDS WATCH;
Mixed Offerings

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
The market for initial public offerings in 2000 was extremely good or extremely bad, depending on who is asked. Capital-hungry companies raised record amounts, but Internet issues dragged down the year's returns on new offerings to the lowest levels in five years.
"Despite raising a record amount of money, this was the year that the I.P.O. market succumbed to the double whammy of Federal Reserve tightening and too many speculative companies," said Linda R. Killian, who runs the $100 million Renaissance IPO Plus fund in Greenwich, Conn. 
 This year, 405 companies raised $97 billion, $4 billion more than in 1999. Their offerings averaged a record $240 million, far surpassing last year's $190 million.
But an anemic fourth quarter pulled down the year's returns. With the Nasdaq index declining far more than the Standard & Poor's 500, "investors lost their infatuation with growth I.P.O.'s and took second looks at the value plays," Ms. Killian said. Over all, new issues this year lost 7 percent from their offering prices, on average, through Dec. 18, and 31 percent from the close of the first day's trading.
All of the largest offerings for 2000 have been spinoffs from big corporations seeking to demonstrate value in high-growth divisions or subsidiaries. In March, the offering of AT&T Wireless raised $10.6 billion, the biggest initial public offering ever in the United States.
The worst results were from dot-coms with high expectations but disappearing cash. The biggest loser, Pets.com, an online retailer of pet supplies that is now in liquidation, lost 99 percent.
Ms. Killian sees brighter skies ahead. Investors hurt by risky initial offerings will demand stronger companies, she said. There are just 200 offerings scheduled, down from a bloated 400 at the start of 2000. Potentially lower interest rates and new retirement savings rules would also bolster interest in initial offerings, she added.
"Next year should mark the beginning of another classic I.P.O. cycle," Ms. Killian said. "With hundreds of dubious I.P.O.'s yanked from the pipeline, investors should be able to buy high-quality I.P.O.'s at reasonable valuations."
 Carole Gould

HEADLINE: DATABANK: DECEMBER 18-22;
A Wild Week Ends With a Tech Bounce

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks ended the week mixed after gyrating wildly in response to more corporate profit warnings and the Federal Reserve's decision to defer cutting interest rates.
 The Nasdaq market plunged to its seventh-biggest loss on record on Wednesday, hitting its lowest level since March 1999, and 53.8 percent off its peak in March 2000. On Thursday, however, it inched ahead, breaking a seven-session losing streak. And on Friday it soared to its fifth-biggest percentage gain ever, as bargain hunters swooped in on technology stocks. That held the week's deterioration to 136.25 points, or about 5 percent. At 2,517.02, the index is now down 38.2 percent for the year and has fallen in six of the last seven weeks. 
But the other major averages did better. The Standard & Poor's 500 showed little change, losing just 6.18 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,305.97. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 200.60 points, or 1.9 percent, to 10,635.56.
 The turmoil in stocks, combined with the economy's deceleration, diverted more money to the bond market. The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury eased to 5 percent from 5.17 percent the previous week. ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

HEADLINE: Fueling China's Growth

 BODY:
Oil has not figured prominently in the delicate relationship between the United States and China. But it soon will. China, the world's most populous nation with 1.3 billion people, will become one of the world's top oil importers in just a few years. This growing reliance on imported oil will further anchor China in the global economy and help shape its ties to the United States. Both nations should be thinking about how to manage this new reality and its strategic repercussions not only in East Asia, but also in places like the Middle East.
Though the issue is not yet much discussed, it is being closely studied by the Central Intelligence Agency, academics and oil industry analysts. As he devises a China policy, President-elect George W. Bush can draw on the research, some of which has been done by the public policy institute at Rice University named after former Secretary of State James Baker. 
 China's need for ever greater quantities of imported oil is driven by its torrid economic growth. In the next 20 years, China's gross domestic product is expected to quadruple, enhancing its people's living standards and partially closing the economic gap with the United States.
The underlying force behind China's growth -- the great migration of its population to the cities and the creation of a middle class -- is still in its nascent stages. There are, for instance, 10 motor vehicles per 1,000 inhabitants in China, compared with 30 in Egypt, 148 in Mexico, 552 in Japan and 770 in the United States.
A net exporter of oil until 1993, China now imports 1.2 million of the 4.5 million barrels it consumes a day. It is expected to import roughly 4 million barrels a day in 2010 and close to 7 million in 2020. The United States currently imports about 10 million a day. The Middle East is expected to supply more than three-quarters of China's oil imports by 2010. As this dependence grows, Beijing is likely to become a more active and influential actor in the Middle East.
This may well complicate the American role in the region. Beijing has been cultivating ties with oil-producing nations, including Iran and Iraq. China dislikes international economic sanctions, claiming that they represent unwarranted interference in the affairs of sovereign states. In recent years, Beijing has supplied Iran with ballistic missile technology and has taken an indulgent line toward Iraqi defiance of United Nations weapons inspectors.
But China's Middle East diplomacy has also grown more sophisticated than it was in the days of Mao Zedong, when Beijing's main allies were radical Palestinian terrorists. Now China maintains full diplomatic relations with Israel and seeks to purchase sophisticated Western military technologies from the Jewish state that it cannot buy directly from the United States or Europe.
China's strategic interests, like those of other major oil importers, will increasingly lie in maintaining political and military stability throughout the Middle East. For that reason, Beijing should not want to see Iran and Iraq develop unconventional weapons with which they could threaten Israel and other neighbors. Encouragingly, China recently promised the United States that it would no longer help Iran or any other country develop advanced missiles. In future years, China could even come to rely on American naval power to keep sea lanes open to ensure the uninterrupted flow of its economic life blood.
As China takes its place among the world's great powers, and attempts to integrate its economy into global markets, Beijing's need for foreign oil may have a moderating effect on Chinese behavior. That will require constructive thinking about China's future oil requirements by President Jiang Zemin and a willingness by the Chinese leadership to work alongside the United States in maintaining the free flow of oil around the globe. For a nation on the verge of becoming a full member of the World Trade Organization, that kind of attitudinal shift should be possible. Washington, for its part, should continue to encourage China's Communist leaders to see the two nations' growing economic interdependence as a source of stability and prosperity, not vulnerability.

HEADLINE: FAILING FARMERS LEARN TO PROFIT FROM FEDERAL AID

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: FORT BENTON, Mont.

 BODY:
For somebody who works the hard northern land that was first cut by homesteaders' plows less than a century ago, the big harvest of government checks usually happens in the fall -- $40,000 for just being a farmer, another $40,000 for emergencies like bad market conditions, more than $100,000 for not making any money on what is grown, and $50,000 for taking other land out of production.
Good crops or bad, high yields or low -- it hardly matters, the checks roll in from the federal government, the biggest payroll in farm country. By the end of the year, some farmers can receive up to $280,000 simply by having another miserable year of failure. 
 Perhaps never in the history of a nation founded by agrarian self-starters has the federal government propped up rural America to such a degree. This year, the government distributed a record $28 billion in direct payments, accounting for half of all the money made by farmers. In eight states, including Montana, government assistance made up 100 percent of overall farm income.
What these institutionalized bailouts have done, say many farmers who curse the government but take the checks, is strengthen a culture of dependency in a large part of the United States that consistently votes Republican and touts its feisty independence from Washington.
This dependency has only become more entrenched in the four years since Congress passed a farm bill that was supposed to wean food producers off government aid. Direct payments to farmers have tripled since 1996, and food producers who had never taken a significant piece of the aid pie are now getting big chunks of it, from apple farmers in Washington State to rice farmers in California.
"All that farm bill has done is opened the door for people to get bigger and bigger payments from the government," said Mike O'Hara, a wheat farmer whose grandfather homesteaded the Montana prairie just north of this little county seat and who relies on federal subsidies for his farm income. "It's been an absolute disaster."
The funnel of money from the capital to the heartland has created an unusual welfare state in places like Chouteau County, an expanse of slumbering winter wheat on the Montana high plains that slope to the Missouri River. This is one of the premier grain-producing areas in the world. But it is also essentially a ward of the federal government, a slow-fading county of barely 5,000 people that received $51 million in direct assistance this year. Only three farmers in all of Chouteau County do not receive government payouts, according to the Agriculture Department.
"At one time we were fairly independent, but through no fault of our own have become as dependent as anyone in American society on government assistance -- and it's deeply troubling," said Bruce Nelson, a third-generation Montana grain farmer, who just stepped down as head of the Farm Service Agency, which distributes government checks in Montana.
Despite the extraordinary reliance on government payments, these areas are still losing people, jobs and farms, all the things these payments were intended to support. Farmer dependence on federal money is even higher now, in both percentage terms and real dollars, than it was at the depth of the Great Depression.
The departing agriculture secretary, Dan Glickman, says farming has "become largely an income transfer program," with the government underwriting rural businesses and requiring very little in return. Farmers throughout this state, who seem genuinely torn by the disconnect between their ingrained philosophy of independence and their reliance on federal money to make a living, echoed his conclusion in numerous interviews.
There seems to be a gradual realization in farm country that federal subsidies in the United States -- like those in much of Europe -- are not so much about food supply anymore as they are about keeping the least-populated parts of the country afloat. So while he criticizes the size of some of the handouts, Mr. Glickman says that without the government, thousands of farmers and the businesses that depend on them would go bankrupt within a year or two.
The money keeps banks, schools, hospitals and small businesses afloat in counties that are one step short of the grave. But it also provides better than average incomes for farmers who have learned to take advantage of all the federal programs.
Over the last four years, the top 1 percent of farmers in this county -- about 15 farmers -- received an average of $616,000 each from the government. The top 10 percent -- about 150 farmers -- were paid an average of $308,000 per farmer over the last four years. These numbers do not include the record payout for the year 2000.
"It has created some huge dependencies, no doubt about it," said Wiley Good, a Chouteau County grain farmer and businessman. "It's easy to say, All this cash is out there, now what can I do to farm the government."
Mr. Good lives a comfortable life in a big house, travels to Europe on long vacations, and partakes of the various government programs for most of his farm income. He shrugs at the fact that the free enterprise system has virtually disappeared from the farm economy of Montana, the nation's No. 2 farm state by amount of acreage.
"It'd be nice to go to the local grain elevator and sell your stuff for a price close to what it cost you to produce it," Mr. Good said. "But it's just not in the cards."
Though the aid programs go against their market-oriented philosophy, Republicans have been reluctant to criticize the swelling farm aid programs because a majority of the money has been sent to states that traditionally send Republicans to Congress. The farm aid map is less favorable for Democrats. But a handful of crucial swing states that Democrats count on in major election years -- Iowa, Missouri and Illinois among them -- are also among the biggest farm bailout recipients.
Many farmers are going broke or barely getting by. And drought conditions over the last few years have made bad positions precarious in states from Texas to the northern Plains. The average government payout for this county this year is $36,000 -- and the growers say that money barely covers the crop production costs, like fuel, machinery, seed, labor and loan payments.
Nationwide, 1.6 million farmers received an average of more than $13,000 each last year in government money. After Congress raised the cap on one of the bigger farm subsidy programs this year, an individual farmer can get more than $280,000 a year from various payments.
"Virtually every farmer in the country is on the dole in one form or the other," said Clark Williams-Derry, a senior analyst with the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit research organization that has studied farm subsidies.
"It's social engineering with nobody at the switch," Mr. Williams-Derry said.
Even as the amount of money paid to farm counties has soared, restrictions on who can get those funds and how they are supposed to be used do not form a consistent policy, Mr. Glickman said.
"Essentially, the government's role in requiring the farmer to do something in return has been largely eliminated by Congress," Mr. Glickman said.
He added, "It's important enough for this country to keep rural communities going. And while I don't like the large payments going to some farmers -- that's an outright embarrassment -- many of these payments are keeping large sections of rural America from folding up and going down."
What has happened in rural counties like Chouteau completes a full circle, from the creation of farms by government incentive through the Enlarged Homestead Act of 1909 to a period of prosperity and independence in the 1950's and 60's, to the present where government is the only thing keeping people on the old bison grounds of half of Montana.
The homesteads have become sources of export crops. Nearly 90 percent of the wheat grown in Montana is sent overseas. But it faces global competition and a glut. Even countries like Pakistan, once seen as a relief target, are now exporting grain. If the Montana growers were to try and get by in the free market, they would lose about $2 on every bushel of wheat they grow.
Farm policy, in part, has been an effort to eliminate subsidized farmers, providing them with relief as they get into something more profitable. But as Congress has been raising the amount of money paid to failing farmers, many of them are making good profits.
"The general outlook for many of these farms is not good," said Bill Evans, the government's chief liaison in this county. "But they have become dependent on our office, and we don't want that."
Agriculture policy makers say the aid programs have become so big and are often at cross-purposes, that it is unclear exactly what taxpayers are getting for the $28 billion sent to rural counties this year. Some of the biggest payouts, like money given to farmers who agree not to grow crops on a piece of ground for 10 years or more, may actually be encouraging the dismantling of fragile rural economies.
Roger Axtman, the last farm implements dealer left in Chouteau County, says his family-run, three-generation-old business is slowly going broke even as the millions in farm aid courses through his county.
"We're taking very good ground out of production and paying people to do it," Mr. Axtman said. "So where we used to have a hundred regular clients, now we have sixty. And what do they do with the money? Well, some of them buy the Winnebago and hit road. They don't buy a new tractor from me."
Even as federal money to this county has reached record levels, farm employment has continued to fall -- declining by 32 percent, more than twice the rate of population decline, over the last 20 years.
But Mr. Axtman says that without the federal payments his business would fold, and with it would go most of the human attachments to Chouteau County, a place that calls itself "the birthplace of Montana" because of its proximity to the ancient highway of the big Missouri River.
"These farmers sit here and they tell me how much they hate taking the cheese checks from the government," Mr. Axtman said. "They're honest farm people, the majority of them, but they don't know what else to do."
Other payouts, like the money from programs in which individual farmers can receive up to $150,000 a year when commodity prices are particularly low, are disproportionately weighted toward the bigger operations, contributing to the loss of small family farms, according to taxpayer groups that have done independent analyses of farm programs.
But one thing that the people who grow the food and the people who write the checks agree on is that if the government were to suddenly disengage itself from its monumental entanglement with rural America, upwards of half of the 1.6 million farmers in the United States who now receive some form of federal assistance would go out of business.
Montana, for example, ranks nearly last in average annual pay and near the top in the percentage of people living below the poverty level. If the $500 million annual government farm payroll were taken out of the state, the Big Sky country could fall into bleak times rivaling those of the Great Depression, some analysts say.
"So maybe it is time we had some intellectual honesty in farm policy," Mr. Glickman said. "Nobody talked about this during the presidential election. And you rarely hear it spoken in Congress. But these farm payments have become truly rural support payments."

HEADLINE: East Village Journal;
Echoes of the Left Bank, but on the East River

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Christophe Croquelois was one Parisian who liked to think he knew the world party circuit. He had danced at the full moon raves in Ko Phangan in Thailand and Goa in India. He had worked the clubs in Montmartre and in Miami.
But on this Friday night, he was indulging in a different kind of night life, one that could be found only where the East Village meets the Lower East Side, he said. Here he was, watching a Parisian friend spin house music at Le Pere Pinard, the restaurant Mr. Croquelois started last year with another French friend. 
 It was a sound from two worlds, because the D.J., Benjamin Deffe, had spent years in the city tuning his Gallic ear to funk and hip-hop and soul. "It's really New York style, really garage," said Mr. Croquelois, 28.
Among the diners, there was much French being spoken and a lot of red wine being sipped and more lighting of cigarettes than at a chain smokers' convention.
"I think you start to see some French people in this area now, like never before," said Mr. Croquelois, who moved to the East Village with his girlfriend in 1998. "It's never cool when it's too much. But I'm sure they love this neighborhood. They love this. The French are fashion people a little bit."
And if you take Mr. Croquelois at his word, what appears to be fashionable for some of the French these days is to pack up one's life in Paris and relocate to the East Village. Young French visitors began settling in the neighborhood about five years ago in search of cheap rents and la vie de boheme. That has intensified in the last couple of years, with so many French people coming now that some of the pioneers say they are getting sick of the neighborhood.
In some ways, many of the settlers are at least superficially reminiscent of, if not exactly as blatantly intellectual as, the American expatriate artists who caroused their way around the Left Bank of Paris in the 1920's. They sit around cafes and talk about the old arrondissement. They attend one another's gallery openings. They go to local clubs and stumble home in the morning and wait for the next weekend when the new hot D.J. from Paris is supposed to fly in. If Paris was a moveable feast, as Ernest Hemingway once asserted, it is now downtown Manhattan that is serving the main course.
Of course, French hipsters have been coming to New York for many years, especially as the star of Paris dimmed in the ever-shifting constellation of the international arts scene. But only recently, as gentrification has swept the East Village, have such large numbers put down roots here.
"I thought I was being original when I moved to this neighborhood, but then I realized there are so many French people here now," said Eve Hernandez, 32, an aspiring playwright who quit her management consulting job in Paris in 1996 and left her boyfriend to move here. "The East Village comes with some familiar things. It has culture and art that can remind me of Paris and Europe in general."
There are no statistics on how many French live in the neighborhood. But one sign is the proliferation of French-owned or French-themed bistros, bars and cafes that attract throngs of ex-Parisians.
In the last two years, a half-dozen or so have opened off Avenues A and B alone. There is Casimir, the trendy dining spot on Avenue B between Sixth and Seventh Streets, once the site of a Cajun restaurant, that is always packed and always flowing with talk of Paris. Six blocks up, a jazz lounge called Rue B opened this year in a building formerly occupied by a soda warehouse. And on Fifth Street between Avenues A and B, a branch of Le Gamin recently opened next door to the Bouche Bar, down the street from a bistro called Le Tableau.
The French accent can be heard thick and furious at Jules and Leon, both firmly established in Continental dining circles. And at East Village Books, virtually an entire foreign literature shelf is stocked with used French books.
There are those settlers who came on their parents' dime. But like Ms. Hernandez, many of them are struggling writers, musicians or designers who spent their first years here staying up all hours and wondering how to pay for their next meal. In the process, they became enamored of the American entrepreneurial spirit and of a joie de vivre that they say was missing from Paris.
"There's a lot of young French people looking elsewhere for something else," Mr. Croquelois said.
Many of the first ones who came over said they were dropping out of a bourgeois society that was becoming both more impoverished and more conservative. In 1995, the unemployment rate in France hit 12 percent. That same year, a 14-year socialist presidency was toppled by the election of Jacques Chirac, ushering in a wave of right-wing sentiment and anti-immigrant rhetoric.
"There were so many unemployed people, and it was creating an atmosphere of intolerance and close-mindedness," Ms. Hernandez said. "I thought that if I had to stay, I wouldn't like my country anymore."
From 1995 to 1996, there was an almost 40 percent increase in legal French immigrants coming to New York, up to 307, according to statistics from the City Planning Commission. Since then, the number of entering green-card holders has hovered at about 290 per year, according to an agency demographer. But, he added, "our immigration numbers do not capture the actual flow of the French" since most of them enter on nonimmigrant visas.
Karine Duteil, for instance, lived for years in New York on a tourist visa. A struggling sculptor, she went through what she called the typical jobs that French women take: coat checker, waiter, baby sitter, language tutor. She said she had to fly back to Paris every three months to renew her visa, but later got a student visa and married an American lawyer whom she had been tutoring. She moved into his East Village apartment in 1996.
"At first, it was amazing, but now it's not fun anymore," Ms. Duteil, 33, said of the neighborhood. "There are too many French, and they are all white. Four or five years ago, I was the only white woman in the street sometimes."
Ms. Duteil has started artistic projects that take her out of strictly French circles, such as running an art gallery in the South Bronx. But she has also kept one foot in the world of her compatriots. To commemorate Bastille Day in 1995, she and a friend started "Le Francophile," a magazine for expatriates and immigrants in the region, as well as lovers of all things French.
As she ambled from her studio to her community garden on a recent afternoon, she pointed to an apartment building on Seventh Street. Inside lived another French artist, named Virgile. He had recently come to her seeking advice on opening a gallery.
"A lot of French come here to start things," she said. "In France, if you start your own business, it takes weeks. Here, it takes half a day."
