HEADLINE: Chinese Pigs Feed a Western Fashion Boom

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN and CRAIG S. SMITH 

 BODY:
Americans are buying animal hides like Hell's Angels. In the first nine months of this year, leather clothing sales were up 71 percent, according to the Leather Apparel Association. Stores from Gucci to Wal-Mart are chock-a-block with skins -- and not just bomber jackets. The Limited's Express has pink and gold metallic leather halter tops, and Ralph Lauren has designed a leather five-pocket jean in red.
What has marked this holiday season more than the color and abundance of leather goods, however, are the incredible shrinking prices. A decade ago, leather was predominantly a luxury product, purchased at boutiques. Today, Old Navy has seamed A-line skirts in olive leather on sale at $39.99. Kmart has stadium jackets at $59.99. Target, the giant discounter, entered the leather market this year with a highly promoted black zip-up coat for $109.99. 
 In Haining, China, a coastal city about 100 miles south of Shanghai, Zhou Zhanghe, a leather wholesaler, has a theory on why America is suddenly awash with inexpensive leather. "There are a lot of pigs in China," he said, chatting in his narrow shop stacked to the ceiling with tanned hides.
Pigs, of course, are not entirely responsible for transforming leather into the mass-market fabric that it is today. There are other important factors, among them an increase in meat consumption in the third world, easing of government labeling guidelines, and the wholesale movement of leather clothing manufacturing into the Far East, where the highly labor-intensive industry can buy workers' time for pennies on the dollar.
Retail prices in the United States are also being depressed because demand, while strong, has nevertheless fallen short of merchants' expectations.
A year ago, Gap Inc.'s "Everyone in Leather" promotional campaign, featuring sexy but wholesome youths in T-shirts and leather pants, was so successful that sales clerks in Manhattan reported women bursting into tears when stores ran out of stock.
Gap's foray was key to sparking the mass-market craze for leather, but also created too much of a hot thing as everyone jumped on the bandwagon. This year, Gap itself -- admitting it overordered -- slashed prices on its multicolor leather goods well before Christmas. Leather is being marked down substantially by department store and other speciality stores, too. Further cuts will probably come after Christmas.
"Put it this way," said Jack Dougherty, a Gap company spokesman. "Pretty much everyone who wants to be in leather is there already."
But Chinese pigs do figure in to perhaps the biggest contributor to lower leather prices: new technologies that can metamorphose cheap animal hides -- scratched cow, pocked sheep or porous pig -- into supple leather.
"The chief advantage of technology is that it improves finishes, making them softer and softer, so that leather that was only good for shoes is now pliable for clothing," explained Joel Waller, chief executive of Wilsons the Leather Experts, the leading American retailer of leather.
"The tannery people are magicians," said Hans Nutzhorn, who exports Chinese-made leather garments to Europe. "They can do anything with the right chemicals."
Increasingly sophisticated stamping and printing technology also allows tanneries to make low-quality skin from farm animals look like scaly snakeskin or crocodile -- or whatever manufacturers want. Wilsons, for example, used pig skin for its fall line of "python" blazers.
"As an extreme example, I can take a piece of leather and make it look like corduroy or over-dyed denim, and it is very economical," Mr. Waller said.
Very, very economical. Skins can be split into three layers, according to Mr. Zhou, and tanneries can now treat even the cheapest, innermost layer to give it a finish close enough to fine cowhide to fool most untutored buyers.
The inner layer of pig -- the "split-grain" leather once reserved for shoe sole inserts -- is now a staple for outerwear. It can cost as little as 30 cents a square foot, or a little more than $10 for enough to make a man's jacket. Skins account for roughly 70 percent of the cost of leather goods, according to Mr. Waller and other industry experts.
Previously, the Federal Trade Commission allowed only the most durable outer layer -- called top grain -- to be labeled leather in America, but it waived those rules in 1996.
Of course, most consumers, thrilled to get ostrich print boots at bargain prices, probably do not care if they are really wearing the inner hide of pig, the rest of which most likely ended up in a string of Chinese sausage. But even if they did, there is not much they could learn.
Under the F.T.C's labeling guidelines, anything made of animal hide -- including, say, gopher hide or rat hide -- can be labeled "genuine leather," according to Susan Arthur, a staff lawyer who headed up the last review of the guidelines in 1996. That might give a shopper pause over the really inexpensive items.
The Commerce Department has regulations banning the import of skins from endangered species and house cats and dogs; the law rules banning the use of domestic mammals became law only last month, inspired, in part, by revelations in 1998 that cat and dog fur were being used on coats sold, unknowingly, by Burlington Coat Factory.
The government's main aim in regulating labels is to prevent consumer fraud. When leather has been embossed to look like alligator, for example, the label has to say as much.
However, even within these bounds there is ample room for interpretation. Lambskin has historically been prized as a fine quality leather, but much of what comes out of China labeled as such is actually a bit longer in the tooth. The United States tariff code, which defines calves by size, makes no distinction between the skin of a lamb or an adult sheep; both can legally be called lambskin.
People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, or PETA, has tried to create consumer outrage about the growth of leather imports from countries like China, where they say animals are treated particularly inhumanely.
This fall the animal rights organization began a campaign against Express. And in April, PETA was able to convince Gap to stop buying its animal hides from China and India by showing them videos of cows as well as dogs being skinned alive. Gap now manufactures clothing in China, but says it gets most of its hides from tanneries in Italy. On Thanksgiving, PETA started a television ad campaign called "Cows are Cool," meant to raise awareness of all animal cruelty related to leather.
Perhaps out of concern that a backlash could emerge if enough consumers learned the source of their leather, many of the large chain retailers and manufacturers of leather products tend to offer more rather than less information.
The Gap says that the "vast majority" of its leather products are made from cow -- though shoppers have to guess themselves, because all of its products are labeled simply "genuine leather." Kmart's low-priced stadium jacket is a pig product, but its label, too, reads leather. Wilson's says that its sales clerks have been schooled in the different types of skin in each garment, but customers must ask if they want to find out.
Though retailers may be fuzzy about the origins of the skins they sell, the Chinese are more than willing to brag about having found a new export market for a product previously used only as a food (boiled, roasted or fried).
"If it's cheap and it comes from China, then it's probably pigskin," said Zhang Xuhua, a China Leather Industry Association official.
Leather clothing imports from China have almost tripled since 1992, according to the Commerce Department, accounting for roughly two-thirds of imported leather. Imported leather goods account for more than 95 percent of the entire American leather apparel market.
According to the Chinese trade group, about half of the leather garments China ships to the United States are made of pigskin. Another third are made of Chinese sheepskin, and most of the rest are cowhide imported from the United States or South America and tanned in China.
The lowest-quality cowhides, scratched by brushes or pocked with insect bites, are buffed and made into jackets with the "distressed" look especially popular in the West.
Mike Woo, a young salesman at the Haining Import and Export Corporation, said he sold lots of pigskin garments labeled simply as leather to Wilson's -- but that American discount chains tend to buy their jackets for even less.
"Kmart and Wal-Mart go further inland to look for the cheapest labor and the cheapest leather," he said. "We can't even do it that cheap."

HEADLINE: Lily Carlson Is Dead at 85; One of First Models for Ford

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Lily Carlson Schulte, one of the first models hired by the Ford agency and a favorite subject of photographers like Irving Penn and Richard Avedon, died on Dec. 14 at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 85.
"It's hard to explain to you what a star she was," said Eileen Ford, the agency's co-founder. "Every great photographer wanted to work with her. In this business, there certainly has never been a bigger star. " 
 Lily Carlson, as she was known professionally, stood 5 feet 11 inches tall. She stood out in a crowd, even of other models. She is the woman in the center of Irving Penn's famous photograph of the 12 most photographed women of the 1940's. She wears a white gown with a billowing skirt and gazes slightly upward.
Her face was more famous than her name, perhaps, but she was always famous to her photographers. George Hurrell, a distinguished fashion photographer, called her one of the three most beautiful women he ever photographed. The others were Joan Crawford and his wife, Phyllis Bounds, also a model. He called Miss Carlson "perhaps the best fashion model in the entire country."
In an interview in Cover Girl magazine, Mr. Hurrell said that some models are wooden and tend to simper, but that Miss Carlson was alive and vital. "Equally good in sports clothes or evening gowns," he said.
She came along just as the whole business of modeling changed, Mrs. Ford said. In the immediate post-war years, models became the elegant emblems of a newly booming haute couture fashion business, perhaps epitomized by Christian Dior's romantic New Look of 1947. There was an explosion of photography, and models like Lisa Fonssagrives, famously photographed at the Eiffel Tower with her skirts billowing, elevated the model's role far beyond that of simple clothes hangers.
"It was like a land rush," said Mrs. Ford, who with her husband, Jerry, opened Ford Models in 1946. They had hired only a couple of lesser-known models when Miss Carlson agreed to sign on. "She was our seal of approval, the first really, really great star," said Mrs. Ford. (Her agency agreed this month to be bought by Magnum Sports Entertainment.)
Lily Viola Carlson was born in Sheridan, Iowa, on April 4, 1915, Easter Sunday. "It was Bunny or Lily," said her daughter Christina Fleur, "and they called her Lily. Thank goodness."
Her father was a Lutheran minister who frequently conducted services in Swedish. Her son, William Dowell, said she hated both the plains and the plainness of the Midwest, greedily devouring The New Yorker magazine as if it were "an escape manual."
She attended the Art Institute of Chicago, specializing in watercolors and photography. She followed a fellow student, Julian C. Dowell, to New York and married him. Their honeymoon consisted of a nickel ride on the Fifth Avenue bus. They and their friends would hold spaghetti parties to which each person would bring a can of pasta to throw into the kettle.
With Mr. Dowell unemployed at the depths of the Depression, his wife looked in the mirror and saw what just might be a bankable asset. She flipped through a directory of fashion photographers and under the B's, spotted one named Erwin Blumenfeld. He shot some test pictures and sent them to Vogue, and Miss Carlson went to work.
"It was so amazing," she later told Cover Girl. "The first 28 days, I made $1,500," the equivalent of about $13,500 in today's money.
Mr. Blumenfeld said this was not all good news. He told her the pressures of the stratospheric career she could easily have might damage her marriage. Mr. Dowell, who envisioned her as a movie star, said she must do it, their son, William, said.
Soon they were living in different worlds. She was a regular at the Stork Club in a veiled hat and white gloves, while he found work as an art director. He moved to the suburbs, she stayed in Manhattan, and they were divorced.
She had not started modeling until her late 20's, but she quickly became a regular in both the fashion and general press. A picture in Life showed her striding down Park Avenue carrying a hatbox, then "the symbol of the model's trade," as the caption read. An Avedon photograph in Vogue showed her "wrapped in a cloud of red fox against black."
She sometimes veered beyond fashion, once escorting a sheep around the country for a wool dealers' group. She was the Drene Girl, showing off her voluminous hair for Drene shampoo.
To enliven her expression, she always conversed with an imaginary friend as she was photographed. "That way I just naturally warm up," she said.
Cover Girl reported, "Photographers with whom Lily works tease her about this. 'Well, Lily,' they say, 'who will it be today . . . Julian, Joe or John?' " Mrs. Ford said this is wrong. It was always John. She has no idea why.
In 1955, Miss Carlson married David A. Schulte, a financier who advised presidents on employment policy and still serves on the New York City Board of Corrections. Her new affluence allowed her to leave modeling and spend more time taking pictures herself. Her work appeared in Life, Look and other magazines.
The two would have been jet-setters had they not preferred the staterooms of luxury ocean liners. They spent almost half their lives in Europe, always staying at the Cipriani in Venice, the Ritz in Paris. At the Ritz several years ago, Mrs. Schulte spotted Richard Avedon and shyly approached to ask if he remembered her. He did.
But her son described a woman who furnished her elegant apartment with things she bought at flea markets.
In addition to her husband, her son and her daughter Christina, she is survived by another daughter, Holly Schulte Ellison, and four grandchildren, all of Manhattan.
At her funeral on Monday, there were mountains of white roses and white lilies. Ms. Fleur told of the time at age 8 or 9 that she was caught with her mother in a downpour. Yellow cabs were whizzing by, but you would have had a better chance of catching a snowball somewhere very hot. Suddenly, a cab screeched to a stop directly in front of Miss Carlson.
"I saw you standing there," the driver said.

HEADLINE: Chen Zhen, 45, Whose Artwork Explored Complexities of China

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
Chen Zhen, a Chinese-born conceptual artist and sculptor who lived in Paris and became a highly visible international art figure during the 1990's, culminating with an appearance at the 1999 Venice Biennale, died on Dec. 13 in Paris. He was 45.
The cause was cancer, reported Mr. Chen's New York gallery, Deitch Projects in SoHo. 
 Mr. Chen was born in 1955 in Shanghai to a family of physicians. The family was sent to the countryside for "re-education" during the height of the Cultural Revolution.
In 1973, he graduated from the Shanghai Fine Arts and Crafts School, and in 1978, he graduated from the Shanghai Drama Institute, where he specialized in stage design.
Eager to work in the context of international art, he left for Paris in 1986. Without any contacts there or any knowledge of French, he supported himself for three years as a sidewalk portrait artist. He enrolled in the Ecole Nationale Superieure des Beaux-Arts where he later became a visiting artist.
A solo show in 1990 in Paris was followed by more than 30 others during the next decade in Europe, the United States and Asia. He first appeared in New York in a group show at the Asian-American Arts Center in Chinatown in 1991, then in a solo show organized by Alice Yang at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo in 1994.
His debut at Deitch Projects in 1996 focused on a multimedia sculpture titled "Daily Incantations." The work was based on revered ancient Chinese forms: sets of bronze bells associated with ancestor-cult rituals and a ruling elite. In his piece, however, the bells were replaced by wooden chamber pots, utilitarian objects already obsolete in modern China. In the center was a satellitelike globe made of old television sets, computers and radios, from which came recorded voices reading from Mao's "Little Red Book."
Like all of his work, "Daily Incantations" blended critical and nostalgic views of China's past and present, and made references to Western culture and a global economy. It won a prize at the Kwangju Biennale in South Korea in 1997 and was included in the Carnegie International 1999/2000 in Pittsburgh.
A survey of Mr. Chen's work was organized by the Galleria Civica d'Arte Moderna e Contemporanea in Turin, Italy, last spring. He was working on a public sculpture for the Bibliotheque Nationale in Paris at the time of his death. His work was included in several international exhibitions, and he had a second Deitch Projects exhibition this year.
Mr. Chen is survived by his wife, Xu Min, and a son, Chen Bo, both of Paris; his mother, Xu Manyin, his father, Chen Jialun, and a brother, Chen Zhu, all of Shanghai; and a sister, Jian Chen Bristol, of Vancouver, British Columbia.

HEADLINE: Hartford Feels Science Center Can Fix Its Economic Picture

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 21

 BODY:
For years, in the hearts and minds of everyone who had ever pondered the best way to breathe some life back into this depressed capital city, the solution was neatly packaged into two words: football stadium. But now, those words seem to have been replaced by others that state officials believe stand for an even better idea: science and technology.
After considering several kinds of football stadiums, from a dome downtown for the University of Connecticut to a 50,000-seat coliseum custom-made for the New England Patriots, a state-appointed redevelopment group has decided to bank instead on the digital age. 
 The group announced recently that it planned to build a multimillion-dollar science and technology-based attraction, similar to a museum with interactive computer displays, to attract visitors from across the region.
The announcement by the Capital City Economic Development Authority, which was created by the State General Assembly to lead Hartford's redevelopment, ended years of political indecision about what, exactly, to build and where.
Two years ago, for example, Gov. John G. Rowland, legislators and business leaders discussed building a domed stadium to anchor the project, known as Adriaen's Landing, that envisioned turning unused downtown land into a gleaming hotel and convention center.
Then, last year, Mr. Rowland began high-stakes negotiations with Robert Kraft, the team owner, to move the National Football League's Patriots from Massachusetts to Hartford. To entice the team, state officials offered to build a new stadium near downtown, on the banks of the Connecticut River.
Mr. Kraft, however, eventually scuttled the deal, leaving the Adriaen's Landing project, worth $771 million, still without a high-profile regional attraction.
The new plan for a science and technology-based interactive museum is intended to fill that void, said Brendan Fox, the executive director of the development authority.
"This evolution has been a positive," Mr. Fox said, noting that a football stadium for the university's team will still be built across the river in East Hartford.
"What we've opened up here is some breathing room for the convention center," he added. "We want to generate a fair amount of traffic down here. I think we will."
Plans for the science and technology museum are still vague, Mr. Fox said, but it may include a wide-screen theater, a dinosaur exhibit and interactive computer exhibits with the Connecticut River as their theme.
The concept, which consultants to the redevelopment authority estimated could draw roughly 500,000 people a year, is meant to attract visitors from New York to Boston, and turn Hartford into something it has never really been in its 364-year history -- a tourist destination.
Governor Rowland's press secretary, Dean Pagani, said Wednesday that Mr. Rowland believed the science-based attraction would be good for Hartford.
"What he does like about the proposal is that it tries to tie in the science, art and history attractions that are already in the area," he said, like the Wadsworth Atheneum, the Mark Twain House and the Old State House, three of Hartford's most visible cultural attractions. "That could make it a very dynamic part of downtown Hartford."
Beyond the convention center, hotel and the science-based attraction, Adriaen's Landing, named after Adriaen Block, a Dutch explorer who sailed up the Connecticut River in 1614, also includes space for shops, restaurants and new housing, as well as renovations to several parks and plazas.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Venus Williams May Raise the Bar Even More

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON

 BODY:
THE slogan has a ring to it, though the marketers at Reebok surely didn't have to rack their brains to come up with "Defy Convention" for Venus Williams. She has authored her own campaign in rising from the urban courts in Compton, Calif., to being the hottest tennis player and female athlete in the world.
But now, as the richest pitchwoman athlete ever, can she continue to defy convention and the belief that corporate America prefers its transcendent and crossover clients to play it stultifying and safe? 
 We know the history here, how Michael Jordan and Tiger Woods positioned themselves as the standard-bearers of endorsement earnings.
Beyond the protection of the rights to his likeness and name, Jordan has seldom if ever confronted an issue that motivated him to move from the middle. As for Woods, he has worked assiduously off the Michael model, staying far away from issues political and especially racial -- no small feat, in the lily-white world of golf.
"Tiger and Michael have done a lot of good things, but there are places where people would have liked to see them go that they haven't," Kevin Davis, agent for the Williams sisters, said at the news conference last week to announce Venus's five-year, $40 million Reebok deal. "But I think you'll see Venus 'out there' more than those two other gentlemen."
As a 20-year-old woman who is crashing through barriers, perhaps even more than as an African-American turning a country club sport upside down, Venus is already ahead in the social activist game. The case and cause for female athletes is continuing, and grand, and the announcement of Williams's power-lifting the endorsement-earnings bar was applauded by Billie Jean King (via telephone) and Donna Lopiano of the Women's Sports Foundation (in person).
"The hardest barrier to break is the economic one," said Lopiano, the foundation's executive director. "It's one thing to let girls play. It's a whole other thing to share money with them."
To this point in their short careers, Venus and her not-so-little sister Serena have been simultaneously enterprising and edgy, nonconformists to the core. Last year, when the women's Tour stopped in South Carolina during the Confederate flag at the Statehouse controversy, Serena was alone in refusing to play.
Venus, injured at the time, later indicated that she would not have played, either.
The Williams sisters have also been selective playing nonoffensive events, and have been criticized by reporters and players for acting as if the Tour is a hotel to check into as they please. Yet why argue with their more diverse lifestyle when fashion school has helped produced a deal that will allow Venus to design her own brand of tennis wear?
When someone asked if the big money would force her to become more of a Tour drone, Venus deflected the question by saying she would play as much as she could. But as she and Serena, who grace the cover of Elle magazine this month, undergo the Madison Avenue makeover, how long can they continue to be Richard and Oracene's iconoclast kids?
"I know a lot of agents tell their clients to be careful, to stay away from controversy," Lopiano said. "As role models, like it or not, that's the worst mistake they could make. In the long run, you can only win by speaking out against social injustice."
Lopiano's point was that Jordan and Woods, pillars of Nike, may be representative of that particular company and their own conservative values, and that their way is not the way it has to be to maintain a high commercial profile.
When Jordan several years ago rejected calls for him to endorse Harvey Gantt, a Democrat running for Jesse Helms's North Carolina Senate seat by saying, "Republicans buy shoes, too," that was his own marketing strategy, and a shortsighted one at that.
Gone from the stage of championship-winning shots, Jordan now seems to have diminished appeal, beyond the small ownership stake and largely absentee front-office position he holds with the Washington Wizards.
So badly have matters deteriorated with that team, Jordan was back to revising history last week, assuring all those wondering where his golden touch has gone that he would still be winning titles if the Bulls hadn't made him retire.
In stark contrast, Magic Johnson, who lost all of his endorsements after contracting the virus that causes AIDS, is defining popularity in new entrepreneurial ways, especially in the inner city. He has been the point man for eye-opening development and the creation of jobs. The Magic model, one to be studied by superstar athletes, has been to teach corporate America that it needed him more than he needed it.
"Money doesn't change some people," Davis said, arguing that Venus and Serena will continue to defy convention.
We weren't talking about foundations; many star athletes are charitable, but few, if any, are the stand-up people they have the power to be. Most have wanted to Be Like Mike. Here's hoping that the newest women's marketing champ builds a model of her own and doesn't sell out.

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
Bush Waits, Politely, to Undo What Clinton Has Done

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 23

 BODY:
By road, it's a little more than 1,500 miles between the Governor's Mansion here and the White House. That's too far to spit.
Mere distance, however, is not stopping anyone from trying. 
 Just before they pack their bags, President Clinton's aides are taking one last shot at creating an America in their image -- churning out new emission rules for cars and trucks, reviewing last-minute authorizations for national monuments, putting the final touches on Mr. Clinton's effort to make sure that development stops in roadless areas of national forests.
All this has left the Bush folks fuming, because they know -- or their lawyers are telling them -- that the rules cannot be wiped out at the stroke of a pen. There must be hearings and committees. Mr. Clinton's chief of staff, John D. Podesta, whose passion is environmentalism, noted this fact a year ago when he stood atop a Virginia mountain with Mr. Clinton, who was announcing his plan to save millions of acres of federal land from the intrusion of new logging roads.
"Reversing this kind of stuff," Mr. Podesta said at the time, "is politically difficult, and a bureaucratic nightmare."
President-elect George W. Bush is going out of his way not to pick a fight, telling everyone that as long as Mr. Clinton is president, he should do "what he's got to do," and when Mr. Bush moves in, he will worry about it then.
"There's going to be a lot of opportunities, obviously, during the transition for me and the vice president or any of my designees to look backwards, but we're not going to do that," Mr. Bush said on Friday. "Our job is to -- once I'm sworn in and these members of my cabinet are sworn in -- is to look forward, is to think about the future."
But his spokesman, Ari Fleischer, told reporters that executive orders might be undone with reverse executive orders, and "regulations can be undone through regulation." And of course, Mr. Bush's greatest weapon is also Washington's oldest art: footdragging.
Not all the barbs, however, are coming from the White House. Mr. Bush arched his eyebrows more than once when describing Senator John Ashcroft's qualifications for attorney general. Mr. Bush stretched out the word "in-teg-rity" more than once, to let it settle in. He worked the facial expressions again when he suggested Mr. Ashcroft's Justice Department would "follow the truth."
But the first real conflict between the Clintonites and the Bushies may have nothing to do with forests or justice. It will focus on license plates -- the plates on the presidential limousine.
Mr. Clinton this week authorized the placement of the District of Columbia's new plate, with the slogan "Taxation without Representation," on the presidential limousine. The plate was created by the city to protest the fact that residents are not represented by a voting member of Congress. Republican sympathies for the District are limited; after all, the District is a Democratic bastion and gave Al Gore 85 percent of its vote. With the Senate split 50-50, Republicans are not terribly interested in statehood for the District, which would certainly add two Democrats to the upper body. Jake Siewert, the White House press secretary, insisted that the president was making his own statement, and that the next president was free to put anything on his car that he liked. "We're not tying anyone's hands," Mr. Siewert told reporters. "Screwdrivers are a dime a dozen."
 
Whose Recession?
The backbiting has been fiercest over what kind of economy Mr. Bush is inheriting. When Mr. Clinton's troops arrived in 1993, they went to some lengths to describe the "mess" that George H. W. Bush had left them, to make any recovery sound all the grander. What goes around comes around.
Vice President-elect Dick Cheney started it, talking about how the country might be slipping into recession. Mr. Bush picked up the theme, then sat in the Oval Office the other day while Mr. Clinton recited the opinions of 49 of 50 leading economists who think growth next year will be around 2.5 percent -- nothing to write home about, but hardly a recession.
No sooner was Mr. Bush finished with the tour of his new home than Gene Sperling, head of the National Economic Council (an institution Mr. Bush may kill off or reinvent), started telling reporters about the danger of undermining confidence in the economy by talking it down. Mr. Bush's aides, he said, were wrong on the facts, and unwise as they talked to the markets. Mr. Bush pulled back a bit on Friday.
"I keep hearing talks about, you know, well, this is an administration that is trying to talk down the economy," he said. "That's foolish talk. All of us in the Bush administration will want the economy to be strong. But there are some clear warning signs, warning signs that will require what we believe is important action in the halls of Congress, such as tax relief."
Most important, Mr. Bush appears to have learned early a lesson Mr. Clinton learned the hard way: Never, ever talk about whether you favor a strong dollar or a weak dollar. Mr. Clinton once opined about exchanged rates a little more than a year into his presidency, and touched off a mini-panic among currency traders and presidential aides. Mr. Bush, asked about the dollar on Friday, just ignored the question -- either because he knew enough not to answer, or not enough to know how to answer.
 
Lots of Fish. No Chad.
After all that's happened over the last month, you might think that the last place Mr. Bush wanted to go for relaxation was Florida.
You would be wrong.
On Tuesday, Mr. Bush and his family will head to Boca Grande, an island off the Florida coast known for fishing, golfing, wealthy winter residents -- and no recounts.
 
Truly Domestic Policy
With the long election and post-election battle over, Mr. Bush's staff can now focus on the big questions for January. A new approach to ousting Saddam? How about some innovative reforms for Medicare? "First things first," one of Mr. Bush's most senior advisers said this week. "I need a place to live. Warmer than a tent on Lafayette Park. Cheaper than a Victorian in Cleveland Park," one of the city's most tony neighborhoods. It's not easy. The rental market in Washington is tighter than ever. Whatever else happened during Mr. Clinton's tenure in Washington, home prices soared.
So now when Mr. Bush's aides complain about Washington, they're not talking about the city that overregulates, that intrudes in the life of the citizenry and sees their death as another opportunity to tax. Instead, they are complaining that the place is too expensive for anyone on a government salary.
It has clearly affected the Bush camp's internal discussions. One longtime Washingtonian discussed this week for a senior national security job joked that his main qualification was that "I already have a house." Then there is Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's political mastermind, who lives on a lovely piece of property in Austin that he bought for a pittance 30 years ago, and that he plans to keep because nothing in Washington is forever.
As everyone waited for Mr. Bush to name Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Mr. Rove was deep in discussions with the press corps. He was asking about their neighborhoods.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 3; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 2055 words

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Canadiens Showing Some Tarnish

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

DATELINE: MONTREAL, Dec. 22

 BODY:
In the glorious 91 years of the Montreal Canadiens, few days were more humbling than last Monday. In the afternoon, the Molson brewery announced in a cryptic news release that it had abandoned its target date of Dec. 31 to sell the hockey team. Molson said it would need "the time necessary to conclude a deal that is in the best interests of our shareholders and our fans."
In the early evening, a local television station reported that an American investor, Jonathan Ledecky, a part owner of the Washington Capitals, had offered to pay about $65 million in American money for 80 percent of the Canadiens, one of the world's most famous sports franchises. The offer made jaws drop. Wasn't the team valued at $191 million? Could the Canadiens be worth less than half of what many people thought? 
 Later that night, before thousands of empty seats in the 21,273-seat Molson Center, the Canadiens were defeated, 2-0, by the Columbus Blue Jackets, an expansion team. The Canadiens have won the Stanley Cup 24 times, including once before the National Hockey League was established back in 1917 in a Montreal hotel. The result Monday dropped the Canadiens to 30th place in the 30-team league.
Early in the game, Martin Rucinsky, Montreal's leading scorer, injured his knee seriously when he crashed into the boards after missing a check. The new coach, Michel Therrien, punched a wall as he walked to the dressing room. After the game, Therrien wore bandages on his bruised and bloodied fingers. When someone asked him how he felt, Therrien said: "Frustrated."
Around this city and the N.H.L., the frustration with the Canadiens is turning to astonishment. They last won the championship in 1993. Since then, the city's two most important hockey-related events have been the closing in 1996 of the Forum, the team's "temple of hockey," and the funeral last spring of Maurice (Rocket) Richard, the star of the mid-20th century who personified the Canadiens' hallowed history.
"We're taking a beating," Sheldon Souray, a Canadiens defenseman, said. "Obviously, it's not fun. Around the N.H.L., around the world, the Montreal Canadiens are known for history, for pride and for tradition. We're like the Yankees, one of the best teams in sports. It's hard when you are fighting for last place. If you play in Carolina, you can pull wool over people's eyes. In Montreal, you're not fooling anyone."
He spoke in a dressing room decorated with pictures of former Canadiens heroes, their faces like a silent jury gazing over the shoulders of the current athletes. A larger photograph of the Rocket in uniform adorns the north side of the outer wall of the Molson Center. Wearing the familiar "CH" logo, Richard looks over the city, toward snow-covered Mount Royal.
In this classic pose, his dark eyes burn brightly, like coals in the winter night. Shortly before the Canadiens' game with Nashville on Thursday, scalpers on the sidewalk beneath Richard's picture jostled each other to unload their tickets. A ticket with a face value of $74.77 went for $20. Under current circumstances, Richard's face could be construed to look startled, as if wondering what had happened to his team.
 
Poor Hockey Decisions
The answers are many. If the Canadiens miss the playoffs for the third consecutive season, it will be the first time that has happened since the early 1920's. In 24 seasons, from 1956 to 1979, the Canadiens won the cup 15 times. Since then, they have won it only twice and the franchise has declined amid undercurrents of economics, politics and sociology.
The Canadiens have drafted poorly for the last decade and have traded unwisely. They have been slow to tap the stream of European talent. To replace the Forum, they built a new arena, the Molson Center, which is too large, is dark on most nonhockey nights and is saddled with a local tax burden of $10.6 million a year in Canadian dollars.
Pierre Boivin, named president of the team 15 months ago, said, "It's not as bad as it looks on the outside." Boivin acknowledged that there had been "some very bad hockey decisions," and that the team was now "at the bottom of the cycle." But he also said that the franchise is fundamentally sound, even though the Canadiens will lose between $5 million and $10 million this season and season-ticket sales have dropped from 14,500 to 12,000.
"The press loves to dwell on the negative, so when you're 30th in the league, you've got no leg to stand on," Boivin said in his big corner office at the Molson Center. Gesturing toward a binder on a table, Boivin said, "There's a 134-page investor presentation that says there is a bright future for this organization."
Boivin refused to discuss the television report that suggested the team's market value was significantly less than previously thought.
Molson is selling the team and the new arena because the synergy between sports and breweries is not what it used to be; Molson's new management wants to concentrate on its core business -- beer. Many hockey franchises have changed hands in recent seasons, some more than once. The drift in sports ownership is toward multimedia companies, and some have explored buying the Canadiens. But there are conditions peculiar to this city and this country that complicate such a sale.
N.H.L. players are paid in American dollars, and with the Canadian dollar worth about 65 cents in American currency, Canadian team owners are paying more for their players than American owners. Although owning a team and an arena is usually advantageous, this is not necessarily so for the Canadiens. The arena was constructed with private funds for $265 million in Canadian money. When American teams need new arenas, they often use threats to leave town to obtain public subsidies and tax breaks.
The Canadiens, so much a part of the culture, did not make such threats. "Oklahoma City Canadiens just wouldn't fly, would it?" said John Paul Macdonald, Molson's vice president for corporate affairs.
"It's difficult enough to turn a profit in Canada under present economic conditions," Macdonald said. "With the taxes, forget about it."
The hockey team is trying to reduce its tax burden in a court proceeding. "We have worked very hard, talking with people in the mayor's office, talking with the provincial government," Macdonald said. "We see no sign."
But Mayor Pierre Bourque said the taxes come from the high value placed on the building by the owners. "I have to send my bills according to the values," Bourque said. "This is not my problem. We hope to find a solution."
Since Quebec's "Quiet Revolution," the French-Canadian population has been politically and economically ascendant, while the English-Canadian population has lost power. Many Anglos, as they are called, have left the province, some taking their businesses and money with them. Some Montrealers say this tribal friction -- with its sign laws favoring French and its occasional referendums about separating from Canada -- is a factor in the decline of Montreal's economy and has even contributed to the hockey team's troubles.
Mayor Bourque said emphatically that there was no correlation between the decline of the team and the struggles of the city. But he also maintained that, in a much broader way, the team and the city were inextricably linked.
"There is a very strong feeling of belonging with the Canadiens and Montreal," he said. "They are part of the soul of the city. It is a love story. You cannot separate them. What they need are another one or two French-Canadian stars like they used to have, like Rocket Richard, Guy Lafleur, Jean Beliveau, Yvan Cournoyer. They could lift the team back on its feet."
This is not as easy as it once was. Until 1967, the N.H.L. was a six-team league made up almost exclusively of athletes from Canada. The league president, Clarence Campbell, lived in Montreal and the amateur draft was often held here. A league bylaw gave the Canadiens first choice of the best players from Quebec. So stars like Richard, Beliveau and Jacques Plante were essentially born to the team. Since that era, the number of N.H.L. teams has multiplied and all players are subject to a universal draft. Nearly half of the players are Americans and Europeans.
 
French-Canadian Pride
But Montreal fans still want their French-Canadian stars, more now than ever. "It is important to have Francophone players for people to identify with the franchise," said Boivin, the 47-year-old team president who grew up in Montreal. "This is the only franchise that needs to worry about this. It's true in players. It's true in management. It's true in strategy. We need to think biculturally all the time. It's a fact of life in Quebec."
This fact restricts top management. Because a general manager or coach of the Canadiens must be bilingual, at least 75 percent of all candidates are immediately eliminated, no matter their hockey qualifications. The Canadiens won their last cup under General Manager Serge Savard and Coach Jacques Demers. They faltered under General Manager Rejean Houle and two coaches, Mario Tremblay and Alain Vigneault. The new leaders, General Manager Andre Savard and Coach Therrien, are Francophones, as were the others.
"It makes it more difficult, no question about it," Boivin said of this unusual consideration. But, he added, "a lot of great hockey minds have come from Quebec."
This hockey ethnocentricity is studied in local universities. Professor Anouk Belanger, who teaches sociology, popular culture and media at Concordia University, said people still assess the political implications of the Richard Riot of 1955. On that night, N.H.L. President Campbell was attacked in the Forum and fans raged through the streets after Campbell suspended the Rocket for roughing up an official. "That emboldened the Quiet Revolution," she said. "A lot of people called that event a turning point."
Boivin said that the threat of the province separating from Canada had caused a lot of capital to flee Montreal and had inhibited the city's ability to attract new capital. But in the last five years, he said, there has been a resurgence, which is reflected in the Canadiens' business. "All our private suites are sold," Boivin said. "For corporate entertainment, there is no better product in town. Our catering is up significantly this year."
But for whom are they cheering? In recent seasons, Montreal management squandered its best French-Canadian players. Patrick Roy, the great goalie, was traded to Colorado in 1995 after an angry spat with Tremblay, then the coach, and Ronald Corey, then the team president, during a game at the Forum.
Pierre Turgeon, a captain who carried the team's symbolic torch from the Forum to Molson Center, was traded to St. Louis and became the top scorer on one of the league's best teams. Eric Desjardins, a defenseman, was traded to Philadelphia and has become captain of the Flyers.
Desjardins said it can be difficult to play under the smothering love of Montreal's fans and news media. "The people around the team have to realize hockey has changed," Desjardins said recently. "They have to realize the Canadiens can't win the Stanley Cup every year."
He said Montreal's fans and news media "make it hard on the players."
"They don't have patience," Desjardins said. "It's hurting them now." Desjardins paused and monitored his words for how they might look in print. "I don't want to get booed when I go back there the next time," he said, then concluded: "It's really sad. I don't like to see it. I played for them for so many years."
Desjardins wore the "CH" sweater from 1988 to 1995. One of his young teammates on the 1993 champions was Patrice Brisebois, now a veteran. Brisebois, about to turn 30, is a native of the city. After a recent defeat, he discussed what it has been like to play for such a team at such a time, underscoring his remarks with motion and emotion.
"Born in Montreal," he said, throwing a shin pad into his equipment bag.
"Raised in Montreal," he said, throwing in the other pad.
"Played in Montreal," he said, tossing in one of his skates.
"Won a Stanley Cup in Montreal," he said, tossing in the other skate.
Then he concluded with a couple of curse words in his native language. "That's French," he explained.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1905 words

HEADLINE: Angola's Goal: Stepping Back From the Abyss

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: KUITO, Angola

 BODY:
The morning wind whistles through the bullet holes in the tiny house on Teofilo-Braga Street. The electricity is out again. And Agostinho Capitango shuffles through the dark, his wooden leg dragging, as he considers his rusting faucets. "We used to take showers when there was water," he said. "That was in 1992."
In the far-flung provincial capitals of America's eighth-largest oil supplier, history has seemingly reversed course, leaving entire communities with dimming memories of modernity. 
 Here, wheelbarrows and bicycles wobble along avenues once clogged by automobiles. Street lights have been blinded by rifle fire. There is no running water, no postal service, no garbage collection and scant rehabilitation for a shattered town where collapsed roofs, missing walls and other scars from the continuing civil war disfigure nearly every building.
Angola is vowing to rebuild its broken cities after decades of war, neglect and squandered riches. The government just recently allowed foreign auditors to begin their accounting of the country's oil revenues for the first time and renewed promises to increase spending on crumbling infrastructure, all in an effort to secure low-interest loans from the West.
But the measures -- which have been praised by the State Department and the International Monetary Fund -- have only exposed the magnitude of the task ahead.
This country may surpass Kuwait in oil exports by 2010, but it is still crippled by an inefficient and corrupt public service, decaying infrastructure and attacks by a weakened but unrepentant rebel army, say diplomats and local and United Nations officials.
In November, the government decided to commemorate 25 years of independence from Portugal by pardoning rebel soldiers and pumping water to thousands of homes on Independence Day, Nov. 11. One month later, the rebel leadership rejected the olive branch.
And Mr. Capitango's tap is still dry.
Forty years have passed since sub-Saharan Africa began shaking off colonial rule to harness the continent's natural riches for its oppressed people. Today, one of every five Africans lives in a country severely disrupted by conflict. And the wealth that once enriched Europe's colonial powers now fuels many of those wars.
The World Bank estimates that conflicts in Central and West Africa have cost those regions more than $1 billion and $800 million respectively. In Angola, where the continent's longest-running civil war simmers, the toll is achingly apparent in communities undone by violence, poverty and corruption even as oil exports boom.
About a quarter of the country's 13 million people have been forced to flee their homes since war erupted after independence in 1975. The World Food Program, which issued an urgent appeal for donations this month, struggles to feed nearly a million people. And every day, about 500 children die from malnutrition, disease and exploding land mines.
Leprosy and polio -- illnesses virtually eradicated in the West -- are rampant. Rebels and bandits roam freely through vast swaths of the country, making roads impassable. And since the national airline refuses to fly to most stretches of the interior, most Angolans are stranded in remote towns that seem like islands in dangerous waters.
In a roofless, doorless warehouse of this isolated, destroyed city, a war-weary graffiti writer vents his people's frustration on the cement walls. "Angola says, 'Enough!' " he cried in his black scrawl.
President Jose Eduardo dos Santos blames the continuing misery on the rebels, who have reneged on two peace agreements since 1990. But criticism of Mr. dos Santos is mounting as the United Nations, human rights groups and ordinary Angolans increasingly raise pointed questions about how the government is spending its wealth.
Deeply indebted and desperate for low-interest loans, the government finally agreed this year to open its oil accounts to the I.M.F. and to redirect its oil revenues from defense toward rebuilding, a move that Human Rights Watch has described as "a positive first step."
"The government of the Republic of Angola recognizes that the present still remains marked by numberless difficulties," the government told the nation in an Independence Day communique. "The government of unity and reconciliation is already implementing deep, wide-ranging reforms."
I.M.F. officials, who are still assessing Mr. dos Santos's commitment, say the government pledged $90 million for public repairs this year. There are reports of a new power station in Humpata, a repaired dam in Matala, running water in Huambo, new money for roads, hospitals and housing.
But that message has yet to trickle down to the bureaucrats click-clacking on manual typewriters in dusty offices without electric lights. Salomao Canhanga, a 49-year-old administrator, works in the housing rehabilitation bureau, but he admits that there is no housing rehabilitation happening here. His friends and neighbors beg for help with the gaping holes left by falling mortar shells. Mr. Canhanga tells them the office has no money for repairs. Even he has to scavenge for wood planks and straw mats to replace the glass windows in his house that were shattered by rebel attacks seven years ago.
As for sanitation? He shrugs his shoulders.
"Those workers don't have cars," Mr. Canhanga said gloomily. "We don't have trash cans. We have nothing, nothing." Mr. Canhanga earns about $16 a month and grows vegetables to feed his family. His youngest son, born in 1994, has only fuzzy memories of glass windows or houses without bullet holes. And these days, some of Mr. Canhanga's colleagues look back on their Portuguese oppressors with nostalgia.
"There's a feeling of sadness," Mr. Canhanga admitted. "People see independence as suffering. That's how they understand it. Some people say, 'When is this independence going to end?' " Underpaid and undersupplied, provincial bureaucrats have abdicated most responsibilities to foreign charities.
The World Food Program repairs classrooms and feeds nearly half of the town's 220,000 people. Oxfam builds water pumps. Doctors Without Borders provides supplies and medicines at the local hospital; it says the government covers only about 1 percent of the operating costs.
The government is technically responsible for the town generator, the water supply, the roads, defense and administration. But when officials tried to restore water on Independence Day, the underground pipes were so corroded that most people ended up without even a drop.
In its most recent report, the I.M.F. estimates that 40 percent of government spending went for defense in 1999, compared with 5 percent for social issues like health and education. Human rights groups say corrupt officials have siphoned off millions, a charge the government denies.
What is clear, however, is that the government is still unprepared to rescue this graceful colonial city once known for its gardens, its fountains and its rich soil.
In the vast camps for displaced people, babies with polio creep on hopelessly deformed limbs. In the dingy hospital, a teenager with leprosy screams as a nurse disinfects his diseased flesh. A young soldier with empty eyes lies motionless as his amputated leg bleeds steadily into a blue bucket.
But they, at least, are alive.
In the fiercest fighting here in 1993 and 1994, 30,000 people were killed in street battles that spilled out from Avenida Joaquim Kapango. So many died in the hail of falling mortars and machine-gun fire that bodies were buried where they fell, in alleys, parks, backyards, basements.
But in a town where thousands are hungry and homeless, the dead are no longer sacred. Grave robbers chip away at the walls of the municipal cemetery. They plunder coffins and drag away precious headstones. "People used to respect the dead," said Francisco Cavamba, 60, a grizzled man who has been burying bodies for 30 years. "These days, people need bricks and stones to rebuild houses."
Building supplies are flown in on cargo planes at exorbitant prices. That means there are too few bricks on the market, said Mr. Cavamba, staring at the rows of desecrated graves. "And there are so many, so many dead." People are still dying.
At first, the fighting was fueled by the cold war. The Russians and Cubans backed Mr. dos Santos and his Marxist party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola.
The United States and the apartheid rulers of South Africa supported the rebels, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, known as Unita, led by Jonas Savimbi.
When the cold war ended, Mr. Savimbi sold the country's abundant diamonds to equip his army. He returned to war in 1998, but government soldiers armed with the profits of oil sales destroyed much of his war machine last year.
Mr. dos Santos has trumpeted the military successes, saying the rebels no longer threaten the government's efforts to rebuild.
But recently a bomb exploded outside the police station here, relief workers said. And in the last few months, 40,000 people have poured into the town, fleeing guerrilla attacks and skirmishes between the two sides in nearby villages.
In an assessment in November, the United Nations reported that rebel attacks on civilians, banditry and exploding land mines continue to disrupt the country. In some cases, the report says, government soldiers and the police are implicated in the robberies, rapes and forcible relocations of the very people they are supposed to protect.
"It should be noted that while the government claims to have control of over 90 percent of the country, the control that the government exercises does not infer normality," the United Nations said in its report.
Next year, Angola hopes to export as much as one million barrels of oil a day. And some critics believe that Mr. dos Santos is playing down the country's problems to reduce pressure on the government to invest more in the beleaguered provinces.
Hendrik Vaal Neto, the minister of communications, denies such charges. He says the government had no choice in the past but to spend its oil money on weapons. But with the war ebbing, he says the government is moving rapidly to rebuild.
"There has been a lot of suffering since 1975, but right now we are in a better position to solve our people's problems," Mr. Neto said in an interview earlier this year.
"There are already many positive changes," he said. "Some people do not want to recognize that. If you give the government two or three years, you will see the government directing even more finances to social problems."
When there is electricity, Mr. Capitango hears those promises revived on the grainy newscasts on his black-and-white television. And most mornings, he pedals his black bicycle to church and asks God to help the government keep its word.
"My father, he encouraged me to believe," said Mr. Capitango, 51, his brown eyes wistful with the memory of it, as he invited a stranger into his dim parlor on another afternoon without power.
"He told me there were many wars in the past and that things would change," he said. "The world wars ended. This, too, would end. But my father, he was captured and killed by Unita.
"Now, I talk to my children," said Mr. Capitango, sighing. "I tell them one day the war will finish. But the situation is worse all the time. And I am getting old."

HEADLINE: VOTERS IN SERBIA ERASE THE REMAINS OF MILOSEVIC RULE

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Sunday, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Serbs voted overwhelmingly on Saturday to sweep away the broken parapets of the rule of Slobodan Milosevic and give Serbia its first non-socialist government in more than 50 years.
Preliminary results early this morning showed that the 18-party coalition supporting the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, had won more than two-thirds of the seats in the Serbian Parliament and would form a government, to be led by Zoran Djindjic, 48, as prime minister. 
 According to forecasts based on a representative sample of votes, the 18-party coalition, still known as the Democratic Opposition of Serbia, won more than 64 percent of the votes and 177 seats of the 250 in Parliament. The total will allow the coalition to change the Serbian Constitution easily and dismantle the structure of Mr. Milosevic's rule.
Mr. Milosevic was not a candidate, but his Socialist Party did relatively well, winning about 13 percent and 35 seats, making it the largest opposition party. About one-third of its previous voters defected to the coalition.
The nationalist Serbian Radical Party of Vojislav Seselj won nearly 9 percent and 23 seats. In a surprise, it looked as if another nationalist coalition of four parties -- including the Serbian Unity Party of the slain paramilitary leader Zeljko Raznatovic, known as Arkan -- would make it into Parliament with nearly 6 percent of the vote and 15 seats.
But the Serbian Renewal Movement of Vuk Draskovic, once the strongest opposition party, was not expected to reach the 5 percent threshold to win seats. And the Yugoslav United Left party of Mr. Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic, essentially disappeared, winning less then one-half of one percent of the vote.
This was a crucial election for the future of the Balkans, where the United States and other Western nations have poured billions of dollars and thousands of troops in the last 10 years, including the waging of NATO's first war, over Kosovo.
But even with Mr. Milosevic and his Socialist Party out of power, the future of the Yugoslav Federation remains uncertain. Serbia's tiny sister republic, Montenegro, is still pressing for independence, along with the Serbian province of Kosovo, which is home to an ethnic Albanian majority, administered by the United Nations and patrolled by NATO-led troops.
One of the crucial tasks of the new Serbian government will be to manage its own neighborhood, trying to reduce the instability that could discourage the foreign investment needed by impoverished Serbia after 10 years of international sanctions and regional warfare.
How well the new government does, in cooperation with Mr. Kostunica, will have a major impact on the American military presence in the Balkans. President-elect George W. Bush has already made clear that he would like to reduce the number of and eventually withdraw the nearly 10,000 American troops in Bosnia and Kosovo.
But there are significant strains between Mr. Kostunica and Mr. Djindjic, and their fractious coalition is expected to break up over time.
Mr. Milosevic voted with his wife in a Belgrade suburb, but made no comments, other than to wish Serbs a happy new year.
Mr. Kostunica said the vote "is a continuation of the work that started in September," when he defeated Mr. Milosevic for the Yugoslav presidency. Mr. Milosevic resigned after a popular revolt on Oct. 5, and this election -- called early after popular pressure on the previous Parliament -- was intended to consolidate the democratic coalition's victory by taking over they key power center of the dominant Serbian republic.
But after a quiet campaign and an unusual Saturday vote, turnout was about 60 percent, considerably lower than the 75 percent in September. That aided the smaller parties and cut into the coalition's margin.
Voters said they expected economic reforms, an improvement in their standards of living, a battle against widespread corruption and justice meted out to high-ranking officials of the Milosevic government.
Mr. Djindjic, who has already announced the key figures in a government of politicians and policy experts, has promised quick action on all fronts, arguing that Serbia must discard its "relaxed" and "Oriental habits" and understand that "we have already lost a lot of time."
Mr. Djindjic, who studied philosophy in Germany and sees himself as a modern European politician, has promised to establish the rule of law, reform the police, create a true market economy and decentralize the state, bringing it closer to the European mainstream. "I think that the main thing starts after the election, which means introduction of reforms, raising the population's living standard and creating conditions for normal life in this country," he said.
The election marks the end of a provisional, caretaker Serbian government, where power was shared with Mr. Milosevic's Socialists.
Mr. Djindjic has suggested that charges will be brought against Mr. Milosevic on issues like bribery and corruption. But the Socialists' position as the largest opposition party may provide the former Yugoslav president, who was indicted by the United Nations tribunal for war crimes during the Kosovo war, with protection against an indictment.
Mr. Djindjic, like Mr. Kostunica, has said that he will not hand Mr. Milosevic over to the Hague tribunal, but that his government will cooperate with investigators.
While Mr. Kostunica was not running himself, he is extraordinarily popular, much more popular than Mr. Djindjic, and the coalition list bears his name.
He has used his popularity to benefit his Democratic Party of Serbia in the coalition list, and his party will get as many seats as Mr. Djindjic's Democratic Party.
The two men do not trust each other and have had different views on the pace and nature of change, with Mr. Djindjic favoring more "revolutionary speed" and Mr. Kostunica, a constitutional lawyer by training, insisting on legality and constitutional forms. But Mr. Kostunica rejected the temptation to break the coalition apart before this election, even though his previously tiny party would have emerged as the country's largest.
Both he and Mr. Djindjic say they know that they now have shared responsibility for the new democratic Yugoslavia. But how long the coalition holds together is anyone's guess, with some suggesting that it will inevitably break up with the next elections.
When those elections arrive will depend in large part on what happens with Montenegro, where its president, Milo Djukanovic, is promising a referendum on independence by the summer. His supporters boycotted the federal elections in September that ousted Mr. Milosevic.
If Montenegro breaks away, Mr. Kostunica's position as president of a nonexistent Yugoslav federation becomes nearly meaningless, and he may then run for the powerful presidency of Serbia. If Montenegro stays, new federal elections are likely by the spring.
Senior Western officials say an independent Montenegro, which Washington and the European Union oppose, would hasten pressure for independence for Kosovo and Republika Srpska, the Serb-dominated part of Bosnia-Herzegovina.
To keep turnout low, Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party spread rumors that an invisible spray intended to prevent someone from voting twice is dangerous to health and male potency. Voters also were required to sign voting lists and cast their ballots in transparent plastic boxes.
Stojan Cerovic, writing in the liberal magazine Vreme, said the coalition could no longer blame anyone else. "Serbia will be a true reflection of the intelligence, capabilities and integrity of these people, who can amass huge merit," he said. "Yet no sin will be forgiven them. The first scandal, the first case of corruption, the first greater injustice or neglect to establish justice will significantly set them back and will soon squander October's high hopes."

HEADLINE: Crime

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio 

 BODY:
There's a sickly odor -- of something rich with life that has started to decay -- about Nicolas Freeling's disturbing psychological study of a mild-mannered killer, SOME DAY TOMORROW (St. Martin's Minotaur, $22.95). Like the smell of garden mulch, it is not unclean, or even unpleasant; but it carries overpowering hints of death.
Death and decay are very much on the mind of Bert van Bijl, the elderly Dutch flower grower whose ambiguous confession this is. Although Bert is in prison ("It was decided that I should be put out of society," he says. "I'm supposed to have killed a girl"), the only crime to which he confesses is the crime of being old, redundant and ridiculous. On this subject, he is positively eloquent. "One might regret Bert, who made few mistakes," he tells us, "but there's no place for him in the modern world. He's another of the great army of oldies who are no longer productive, who do not contribute, who are a drag upon society." Despite the self-pity and the self-loathing, he still manages a vigorous defense of himself as the frail remnant of a once robust species, the last of the "old stock" produced by "the old Holland." And although he sees himself as an example of genetic exhaustion, there is vitality in his lewdness, which never entirely flickers out. Even at the end, one horticultural life lesson persists: "You are perishable. So learn not to perish." 
 Joanne Dobson takes the title of her new novel from Sinclair Lewis's observation that "our American professors like their literature clear and cold and pure and very dead." COLD AND PURE AND VERY DEAD (Doubleday, $22.95) uses Lewis's sharp point to poke at male-dominated literary traditions and their old-boy boosters in academe. When a reporter for The New York Times asks Karen Pelletier, who teaches English at a proper New England college, to cite the best novel of the 20th century, the quick-witted scholar thumbs her nose at the establishment and names a steamy 1950's potboiler (think "Peyton Place") that shocked literary sensibilities even as it exposed "the hypocrisies of life in a smug New England college town." Quicker than you can say "Oprah's Book Club," the book becomes a sensation and its female author is forced out of seclusion.
Pelletier's guilty efforts to stop the mischief she set in motion take on urgency when the nosy reporter is shot to death on the author's goat farm. The amateur sleuth is on the right track when she looks into the buried scandal that inspired the autobiographical novel, but with people literally chasing her down the street to spill their secrets, her investigation looks silly. Pelletier is on surer ground when she sticks to her literary search for the emotional truth in popular fiction and the "subtle analyses of class aspirations, struggles and prejudices" that give it value.
In times of crisis, Abe Lieberman, the world-weary detective in THE BIG SILENCE (Forge/ Tom Doherty, $23.95) and other Chicago police procedurals by Stuart M. Kaminsky, applies his personal motto: "Hope for the best. Expect the worst." He found it in the Bible. Unless he picked it up from a Mel Brooks movie. Lieberman isn't quite sure, but the way he deals with a crisis, either source would do as well.
This warmhearted cop and his morose partner, Bill Hanrahan, find themselves backed into a corner by a blackmailer who kills a mob informant's ex-wife, kidnaps his 17-year-old son and threatens to do away with the boy unless the informer pledges ultimate silence -- by committing suicide. And that's only the first labor of the day for this herculean cop. Heaping one calamity on top of another, Kaminsky piles up a whole stack of woe to try his hero's soul: a deadly duo robbing Korean convenience stores; a sleazy con artist extorting money from old people; a Mexican gangster calling in favors; and Lieberman's own brother falling apart and blaspheming God in a Torah class. In Kaminsky's seamless style, these interlocking stories and their ethnically diverse players reflect the textured face of the city, a little bruised and battered but full of life and worthy of Lieberman's pragmatic brand of humane justice.
After reading THE SQUIRE'S TALE (Berkley Prime Crime, $21.95), by Margaret Frazer, I'm inclined to think that being a nun was the only way for a woman to survive the Middle Ages. True, the cloisters were drafty in winter and the heavy prayer schedule cut into your free time, but you could work at peace in the herb garden and copy lovely manuscripts in the library. Whatever the discomforts of the job, it was better than the lot of a virgin bride, which condemned you, as likely as not, to a forced marriage and an early death in childbirth. Dame Frevisse, the pious and perceptive nun who gives focus to this sober series, lends her wisdom to a noble family caught up in the political intrigues of arranging such a marriage for their ward -- if some randy knight doesn't carry her off first. Frazer can't write an action scene for all the gold in the papal treasury (the foiled kidnapping is all nuance and no event), but her domestic scenes set in castle and nunnery show a meticulous detail that speaks of trustworthy scholarship and a sympathetic imagination.
Bad boys like Ray Bob and Eddie need no introduction; they just are what they are, "outsiders from the rural frontier . . . young and unemployed and broke, trawling boredom after a late greasy lunch." Christopher Cook puts the match to these combustible "running buddies" in ROBBERS (Otto Penzler/Carroll & Graf, $24.95), a debut novel with classic noir bones, when he sets them down in Austin, Tex., in a stolen Eldorado and points them to the highway. Eddie, the stupid one, comes up a penny short for a pack of smokes, so he shoots the clerk at the 7-Eleven, giving Ray Bob, the crazy one, the excuse for a crime spree. Jumping lanes to elude a mean Texas Ranger on their trail, the outlaws shoot, rape and rob their way to Galveston and would still be tearing up the blacktop if Eddie hadn't fallen for a Houston hairdresser with higher aspirations. This is familiar plot territory, but Cook covers it with fearless originality, in a lyric voice that sings itself raw.
