SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1373 words

HEADLINE: New Economy;
Bringing Competition Policy Into the Age of the Internet

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
So let's see if this makes any sense.
The government allows the No. 1 Internet provider, America Online, to acquire the No. 2 cable company, Time Warner, but the No. 1 long-distance carrier, AT&T, was not allowed to acquire the No. 2 local phone company, SBC. 
 Bell Atlantic, now known as Verizon Communications, was allowed to buy Nynex, creating the biggest local phone company, but WorldCom was not allowed to acquire Sprint, even though the combined company would have played second fiddle in long distance. At the same time, AT&T was allowed to buy its way to the top of the cable business.
If all this seems confusing, it is. But antitrust experts say that there really is an intellectual consistency lurking there under the covers: deals between direct competitors tend to be rejected, while mergers are often approved between companies that are in the same or related industries but are not direct competitors.
Even though competition policy is not enforced that cleanly in the real world, at least the basic principles are reasonable.
And yet, many of the ways in which the decisions are currently made appear overly rigid. Many of the analytical and intellectual tools that competition authorities use these days were developed for slow-changing industries like manufacturing. But these methods may not be up to the task of dealing equitably with technology sectors where the competitive landscape can change significantly from year to year.
That is why many experts are beginning to question the current state of competition policy and why even some regulators are wondering whether it is time for a new antitrust approach to the new economy -- an approach that tries to take the future into account.
"We are at a potential turning point for competition policy," said Michael K. Powell, the man whom many people in Washington expect to be the next chairman of the Federal Communications Commission -- if he wants the job. "These new information industries pose new questions and not all of the answers are in yet. It presents the challenge of having to wrestle with inherently more speculative predictions about how fast-changing innovations in new markets will unfold."
Mr. Powell, currently a Republican F.C.C. commissioner, would not talk about his professional future. But his comments on the state of competition policy are resonant with those of many other experts.
In important ways, the approval of the America Online-Time Warner deal is a near-perfect reflection of the current state of competition policy. The mere fact that the No. 1 Internet provider is acquiring the No. 2 cable provider does not raise many red flags because America Online and Time Warner have a fairly classic "vertical" relationship.
Companies are considered to have a vertical relationship when they represent different parts of the same production chain, like a manufacturer and a distributor. Companies are generally considered to have a horizontal relationship when they are direct competitors in the same market, like two car makers.
Under the so-called Chicago school of antitrust analysis, named for the University of Chicago, which has been in ascendance since the 1970's, mergers between horizontal competitors are likely to get closer scrutiny than are deals by companies with a vertical relationship.
"There is no question that horizontal problems are easier to understand and are more likely to trigger law enforcement than vertical arrangements," said A. Douglas Melamed, the acting assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division. "Antitrust law is now, and I think quite appropriately, focused on identifying where there might exist a particular competition problem in the sense of the creation of economic power in certain markets. It is not a populist law meant to deal with mere bigness."
Current antitrust law and doctrine make some provision for looking ahead to future developments. But antitrust authorities basically take a snapshot of a horizontal market for a given product and then look at whether a merger would explicitly reduce competition in that market.
The difficulty is that in fast-changing industries, the snapshot approach can lead to outcomes that appear to ignore what is actually happening, or what may reasonably be expected to happen, in the market.
Consider the failed WorldCom-Sprint deal. Here, the No. 2 and No. 3 long-distance companies, fierce competitors, were trying to merge in a classic case of horizontal consolidation. The Justice Department and the European Commission evaluated snapshots of long-distance markets and concluded that the deal would reduce competition significantly.
But what may have been lost in the process is the fact that the Bell local phone giants are jumping into the long-distance market in a huge way, mostly in the voice telephone business but also in the Internet sector. It is fairly clear that in a few years, the Bell companies will be the dominant force in the consumer long-distance market, but no one knows exactly how fast that will happen. The traditional antitrust approach did not seem to be able to deal with that ambiguity.
"WorldCom-Sprint is a great illustration of the limitations of antitrust enforcement," said Joe Sims, a lawyer for America Online and chairman of an American Bar Association task force that is examining the state of antitrust law. "Antitrust is always going to be a lagging indicator rather than a forward indicator, and that was less of a problem when industries were changing more slowly than they are today."
As for the Bell mergers, the case that really set the tone for local phone consolidation was the Bell Atlantic-Nynex merger in 1997. Two de facto monopolies were sitting just across the Hudson River from each other. But the Justice Department took snapshots of the local markets, and because the companies were not already competing, it was unable to conclude that the deal would impede competition.
"That approach, taken to its logical conclusion, would allow all of the Bells and GTE to combine into one massive national monopoly," said James W. Cicconi, general counsel of AT&T, which has tried and failed to block various Bell mergers.
The essential problem seems to be that current antitrust doctrine is not flexible enough to take account of how various communications markets are evolving, or should be expected to evolve.
So what is to be done?
"The problem with the traditional antitrust analysis is that it assumes static markets," said Reed E. Hundt, a former F.C.C. chairman, who shot down AT&T's merger talks with SBC in 1997 at least partly because SBC -- a Bell company -- was not then allowed in the long-distance market. "I think we need a new antitrust for a new economy. It needs to assume dynamic markets."
The problem is that when the government tries to predict the future, it risks falling into a rabbit hole of subjectivity.
"The people who are reviewing these mergers in detail are good and they make some pretty sound decisions," said John Thorne, a deputy general counsel at Verizon. "Their biggest handicap is that what is happening in these markets is very unpredictable. If you start down this other road, you've got to be a pretty good predictor."
Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, contends that changes in antitrust doctrine can be made while preserving the structural checks and balances that lead to sound policy decisions.
"High tech, or more specifically intellectual property markets, are different," Mr. Pitofsky said. "The kind of static analysis that we often have applied in the past, Chicago school and non-Chicago school, is in fact unlikely to be fully adequate to take high tech into account.
"Ultimately, these regulators are going to have to justify what they predict in court," he continued. "And courts have been pretty good in the area of cracking down on what they call conjecture and speculation and asking for evidence of reasonable likely effects."
As the Bush team arrives in Washington, this will be one of its primary challenges in dealing with the new economy -- bringing more flexibility to competition policy while maintaining the rigor of the past.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1120 words

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report;
Will bricks-and-mortar merchants grow complacent now that the dot-com boom is quickly fading away?

BYLINE: By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
TRADITIONAL retailers greeted the first strains of the dot-com swan song, when online-only merchants died en masse, as great news. It meant they had at least a little more time to construct their own Internet strategies. But now that the consumer e-commerce landscape looks like it has been struck by a neutron bomb, industry analysts say bricks-and-mortar merchants are breathing a bit too easily.
"There are a lot of incumbent retailers who are sitting back and saying: 'Well, I'm glad that's over. We can get back to traditional business again,' " said James Vogtle, who leads the e-commerce practice of the Boston Consulting Group. "They're reading the current shakeout as a sign that the online channel itself is not viable." 
 Neither Mr. Vogtle nor the other analysts who recently expressed similar sentiments would disclose the names of traditional companies that are slowing down their e-commerce efforts, but the idea is worth noting, particularly if the American economy heads into a recession in the coming months. If traditional merchants let e-commerce slide down their priority lists, technology companies that serve the e-commerce community may be in for even more difficult times than they currently face.
Dawn Robertson, president of Federated Direct, the subsidiary of Federated Department Stores that oversees the Web and catalog operations of Bloomingdale's and Macy's, said her own company was "pushing ahead fast and furious, but that is not true of everyone else."
"I think the rate of growth has slowed for some people," Ms. Robertson said. "There's been a bit less expansion and building" of Internet strategies among traditional retailers.
Ms. Robertson said Federated had indeed felt less pressure to sell all its items on the Web now that so many online-only merchants had died. For instance, she said, "we have a pretty substantial furniture business that we chose not to put online yet. It could've been one of the natural businesses we would have done online, but over the last year, a lot has changed" in the online furniture category. Indeed, two leading online only companies, furniture.com and living.com, have gone out of business.
As for the other categories of goods the company sells, Ms. Robertson said "we're continuing to focus, edit, and refine our space on the Internet. There's no complacency here."
Lisa Allen, an analyst with Forrester Research, a technology consulting firm, said, "The smart retailers are not giving up on the Web. They're working hard and spending the bucks to figure out how to integrate all their channels, because they know that when they do, their customers' spending jumps."
Indeed, Forrester and other consulting firms have found that customers who shop at a company's online and offline stores tend to spend more than those who shop at one or the other. A study by McKinsey & Company found that so-called "multichannel" shoppers spend more than twice the amount of single-channel shoppers.
Although those at the vanguard of traditional retailing have the money to aggressively follow this strategy, Ms. Allen said those who are neither at the cutting edge nor the trailing edge are in a difficult position. "They need to embrace new technologies," she said, "but they're saddled with big old legacy systems and minuscule budgets, and they have to meet their numbers every quarter."
She added, "Promises of what e-commerce will do are hard to swallow when you need to make your numbers next month." Ms. Allen said she has told executives at traditional retail companies that "the demise of the dot-coms is a great opportunity to go in and grab a dynamite URL like eToys, or buy the tools or functionality that a dot-com has created. But I still see far too much hesitancy. I think it comes down to complacency, and not having enough money, and the simple fact that retailing has been around for a thousand years, and there are traditions that are tough to change."
Some retail executives are hardly apologetic when it comes to their tortoise-like approach to adopting e-commerce. "We've been called a dinosaur," said Ron Griffin, chief information officer of Home Depot. "The fact is, we're moving very methodically. We take steps, make sure we're managing things appropriately, pay as we go, and shift spending as we need to."
Home Depot is still in the early stages of its Internet rollout. Rather than build a central warehouse and ship items all over the country, as other traditional merchants have done, the company has opted to point customers to the Web site of the Home Depot store nearest them. The site will keep an up-to-date count of a particular store's items, and will ship goods to customers from that store. The company tested the strategy in the Austin, Tex., and Las Vegas markets this fall, and will soon test the San Antonio markets, a spokesman said.
"I know that what we do runs counter to the people who said, 'Damn the cost, damn the torpedoes and profitability, the name of the game is market share,' " Mr. Griffin said. "You have to get market share in a way that maintains profitability."
Be they slow or complacent, traditional retailers are beginning to think about what future e-commerce efforts will look like if, in fact, the economy heads toward a recession. With little competition from e-tailers, and more incentive to concentrate on the parts of the business that are producing profits today, analysts said retailers could slow e-commerce spending significantly if a recession hits.
"For many, it will definitely slow down their e-commerce investments," said Ms. Allen of Forrester. "But again, for the smarter ones, this would be an opportunity. When money gets tight, you want to be sure you're getting the biggest bang for your buck, and the efficiencies the Web brings to marketing can increase that bang."
For instance, Ms. Allen said strategically aimed e-mail advertising gives businesses a way to accurately measure the success of a campaign, whereas offline ads offer no such benefits.
Ms. Robertson, of Federated, agreed that a recession would bring cutbacks in overall e-commerce spending by traditional retailers. "They won't abandon it, but there won't be as wild a pace of spending as there was," she said. "There will be more focused spending. It won't be as emotional a decision as it once was."
If and when the economy contracts, Ms. Robertson also said bricks-and-mortar retailers will weather the recession better than the Internet companies, assuming that there are any left standing. "Bricks-and-mortar companies have been through great economies, we've been through recessions, and we continue to survive," she said. "That's why the bricks-and-mortars win."

HEADLINE: Mining an Untapped Market, Radio One Becomes a Force

BYLINE: By CLEA SIMON 

 BODY:
Consolidation has brought hundreds of radio stations into the mainstream embrace of giant companies like Clear Channel and Viacom's Infinity, but it has also left some audiences out in the cold.
The trend, though, has created an opportunity for Radio One, a family-controlled radio company that has built a thriving business by serving one audience overlooked by the giants: urban African-Americans. 
 Not that Radio One is tiny. Since going public in May 1999, after two decades as a private company, Radio One has achieved a stock market value of nearly $1 billion. With stations in Los Angeles, Detroit, Philadelphia, Atlanta and more than a dozen other major cities, Radio One is the largest broadcast group controlled by African-Americans in the country, owning 48 stations. It has only two big metropolitan gaps in its holdings, although they are significant gaps indeed: New York and Chicago.
By offering listeners a mix of hip-hop and rap on some stations and rhythm-and-blues on others, Radio One is mining a market that its 35-year-old chief executive, Alfred C. Liggins III, thinks other media companies are mistaken to overlook.
"I call the African-American market the emerging market in the domestic market," said Mr. Liggins, a Wharton M.B.A. who assumed the chief executive job two years ago from the company's founder -- his mother, Catherine L. Hughes. "As companies are looking to break into China and other countries around the globe," he said, "they should really be looking here."
Mr. Liggins's target market has a household income that is growing faster than the national average and yet has been largely ignored by advertisers. Between 1972 and 1998, factoring for inflation, average African-American household income grew 16.3 percent, to $25,351, significantly outpacing the 9.2 percent growth rate for total United States households, according to Banc of America Securities, which predicts continued growth.
"Radio One can lay out the facts and figures that this is a very attractive group for advertisers," said W. Timothy Wallace, a Banc of America Securities senior broadcasting analyst.
The methods Radio One uses to reach this audience have changed little since Ms. Hughes borrowed heavily to buy her first station, WOL, a 1,000-watt AM station in Washington, for $900,000 in 1980.
Ms. Hughes's broadcasting experience had come from running WHUR, the station of Howard University, the prestigious and predominantly black university in Washington. She programmed her new station for the inner-city audience, making WOL a forum for African-American issues and an advocate for the homeless and often bringing local political leaders into the studio for interviews.
It was not the best time to be starting a business, with inflation raging and interest rates heading into double-digit range. Divorced and concerned with saving money to send her son to college, Ms. Hughes went 18 months without being able to give herself a paycheck and was forced to sell her car and home to stay solvent. For a short time she even lived at the station. "It did not matter to me where I slept and ate as long as I kept my radio station alive," Ms. Hughes recalled in a recent interview.
People who knew her back then remember her persistence. "It was a tough time to be in the center of the city," said Robert Unmacht, former publisher of the M Street group of radio trade publications. "She was known by everybody and involved in everything, and she put a lot of effort into building the business, which was by no means a sure thing."
To save money, Ms. Hughes made herself the morning host on the station, which focused on local talk. The resulting mix of activism, chat and District of Columbia politics eventually made the little station profitable and paved the way for the acquisition of her second station, WMMJ-FM in Washington, seven years later.
For WMMJ, Ms. Hughes envisioned an adult African-American audience eager to hear rhythm-and-blues. But her primary lender, the now defunct DC National Bank, cautiously sought to keep the station playing its established format of soft mainstream pop from the likes of Barbra Streisand and Melissa Manchester.
"We're in a city with a 75 percent black population, on a station purchased by a woman who is a community activist, and you give us Barry Manilow?" Ms. Hughes said, laughing gently at the memory. The format fared so badly that during one ratings period, the station was reported as having no listeners.
The bank finally relented. And within two years, playing the gentle rhythm-and-blues of performers like Barry White and Smokey Robinson, the station was attracting listeners and advertisers -- and turning a profit.
What Ms. Hughes had developed at WMMJ in Washington became the formula for Radio One, whose headquarters are now in Lanham, Md. The company takes smaller, underperforming metropolitan stations and focuses them on specific parts of a city -- not only ethnically and demographically, but geographically, too. Radio One's engineers carefully calibrate the transmitters to coax the maximum power from the stations to reach the target neighborhoods.
"African-Americans tend to live in certain areas in the community," Mr. Liggins said. "They tend to be concentrated. So if you're serving that community, you don't need to have enough power to cover the entire market."
A financial advantage to this strategy, Mr. Liggins acknowledged, is that it enables Radio One to acquire lower-power, lower-priced stations. The company's most recent purchase, WILD, an AM station Radio One acquired in Boston in November, was $5 million. (Compared, for example, with the $26 million that another Boston AM station, WEEI, fetched two years ago.)
What Radio One's stations put on the air counts for a lot, too, of course. The goal is to serve the African-American community "from cradle to grave," as Mr. Liggins puts it.
In markets like Houston, Baltimore and Philadelphia, that means at least two stations. One plays the hot, rhythmic music that is usually labeled "urban," performed by rappers and hip-hop artists like Jay-Z, Snoop Dogg and OutKast and designed to appeal to teenagers and young adults.
At least one other Radio One station in such markets, meanwhile, aims for adult listeners by focusing on the softer, smoother rhythm-and-blues sound that Ms. Hughes first took to Washington. These days, that is likely to mean Montell Jordan and Angie Stone as well as classics by Barry White and Marvin Gaye. Always part of the mix, Ms. Hughes said, are community issues, like this fall's voter registration drives by all the Radio One stations, or the radio marathon by the company's four Baltimore stations that raised money for city residents left homeless by a broken water main.
There are other radio companies controlled by African-Americans, like Blue Chip Broadcasting, which is based in Cincinnati, and Inner City Broadcasting, which is based in New York and owns five stations that include WBLS-FM in the city.
Blue Chip and Inner City remain privately held, though, and have neither the market reach nor the financial power of Radio One. "In most of the markets where Radio One has stations, it doesn't have direct competition," said Ron Rodrigues, editor in chief of the trade publication Radio & Records.
In some ways, Radio One is pursuing an ethnic strategy made successful by Spanish-language radio groups like the Hispanic Broadcasting Network, a public company based in Dallas that is building a national audience, local market by local market. But compared with the Hispanic radio market, the African-American market remains significantly undervalued, in the view of stock analysts like Mr. Wallace.
Paradoxically, consolidation among the larger mainstream radio companies has helped make properties available for Radio One's expansion. In August, it purchased a dozen stations for about $1.3 billion from Clear Channel, taking Radio One into Houston, Dallas and Los Angeles. Clear Channel had been forced to sell the properties to stay within federal ownership rules after merging with the broadcasting company AMFM.
Radio One is also adding two more Dallas stations, having purchased airwave rights for one station from Infinity Broadcasting and conducting negotiations with Sunburst Media for another.
"Those additional stations and markets make the company the unchallenged leader in African-American radio," said Tom Taylor, editor of the M Street trade publications.
The next challenge will be managing the company's growth and its emergence as a national player. The family remains in charge, with Ms. Hughes and Mr. Liggins controlling 55.6 percent of the voting stock. But the transition from a longtime private company into a publicly held corporation has not been without stumbles.
In September, for example, cautious comments at an analysts' conference by Mr. Liggins, warning of a slowdown in advertising revenues for the third quarter, helped trigger a sell-off in Radio One shares, which plunged from the $19 range to below $6 within a few weeks.
"It caught investors somewhat off guard," Mr. Wallace said. But Radio One then beat analysts' forecasts by posting revenue of $42.9 million. For the quarter, the company reported a net loss of $4 million, which it said was the result of tax consequences of the August deal to buy stations from Clear Channel.
Earlier this month, the company said it expected revenue to grow 10 to 13 percent next year, higher than average for the mature radio business. And with no direct competition and an increasingly affluent audience, Radio One is being rated as a strong buy by the analysts who follow the stock, which closed Friday at $10.13.
"There are other radio companies out there that have some urban-oriented formats, but Radio One is the only one that is dedicated to these formats; this gives them greater clout with advertisers," said Paul T. Sweeney, broadcasting analyst for Credit Suisse First Boston.
Mr. Liggins, like most radio company executives these days, sees new technologies like Internet broadcasting and distribution over cable and other broadband conduits as possible areas for future expansion.
But he still sees plenty of growth ahead for Radio One in conventional broadcasting -- particularly if any affordable stations go up for sale in New York or Chicago.
"Just in acquisition-related growth alone we can double the size of the company," he said. "Urban music, R&B music is not just African-American. Because the music is so huge, it gives us entree into a crossover culture. That makes us not just an African-American company but an urban company."

HEADLINE: REVISIONS;
Horrific, Heroic or Banal, Black Life in the Artist's Lens

BYLINE: By Margo Jefferson 

 BODY:
Going page by page through Deborah Willis's grand book "Reflections in Black: A History of Black Photographers, 1840 to the Present" was what finally made it possible for me to go, page by page, through "Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography in America," where the earliest photo dates from 1870 (lynchings took place earlier) and the last from 1960 (lynchings took place later, too).
The "Reflections in Black" exhibition, organized by Ms. Willis, is touring the country and has yet to come to New York City. I had seen an exhibition of the lynching photographs last winter at the New-York Historical Society; I found them horrific and necessary to look at, but at the time paying money for the book felt embarrassingly voyeuristic, even a little obscene. 
 As to why I would discuss lynching photographs during religious and festive holidays: if such holidays mean anything, it is because these celebrations mean taking questions of brutality, sacrifice and redemption seriously. And as visual evidence and testimony, "Reflections in Black" helps repudiate once again the awful lies and obsessions that created lynching.
The images in "Without Sanctuary" (Twin Palms Press) belong to several genres. Like the pictures of Cambodian prisoners taken by their interrogators and torturers, they record what we can call civil war crimes. The lynching pictures were taken by local or traveling photographers who made a killing (pun intended) selling them to the citizens. The images are also what the historian Leon F. Litwack calls, in his introduction, race pornography: they were often made into picture postcards that were mailed, with curt, gleeful or venomous messages to friends and foes with nary a peep from the United States postal authorities.
They are visual anthropology, too. You can't look at these black bodies, beaten, burned and hanging from trees, lampposts and bridges, without thinking of the savage blood-lust rituals that scholars spend their lives investigating in other countries. Then you read about the gap between the accusations (the favorites were murder, rape or attempted rape of a white person) that led to the lynchings and the actual facts behind them (black economic success, union organizing or the kinds of things whites did constantly and got minor or no punishment for, like gambling, stealing a pair of shoes and "talking big" or simply displaying "utter worthlessness.")
You start looking at the perpetrators and spectators who treated lynchings as family affairs, civic celebrations, picnics (the preferred term was "Negro barbecue") and some kind of sexual catharsis. A lot of the men have the rugged dusty look of bit players in old westerns, and they strike movie attitudes for the camera or clasp the ankles of the dead man sternly.
Some wear white shirts, ties and straw boaters. (One young man with immaculately styled hair looks dressed to call on his sweetheart once the lynching's done.) And they give their children private viewings. The virtue of white womanhood is upheld by placing one's daughters (in crisp little dresses) around the tree from which a black man hangs. The black servant is there, too, in her white uniform. She has managed to turn away.
What anthropologists would not ask who these people were with their primitive, barbaric practices? What belief system did they invoke to justify such deeds? Why were they considered civilized?
When my niece left the Historical Society lynching exhibition, she said: "They made it up. They made it all up." And to open "Reflections in Black" (W. W. Norton) is to feel just that. To which race does the phrase "the race problem" really apply? That's the question asked by generations of black photographers as they recorded -- unearthed is probably the best word -- lives unknown to most white Americans until quite recently. And the point was not just the spectacular and the uplifting. The point was the small-time and the commonplace, too, even the trifling facts of life that people forced to justify their existence learned to fear as weaknesses or loathe as mortal flaws.
Ms. Willis organizes the book into five time periods, supplying a useful overview of each, along with short biographies of the photographers. As she makes clear, one all-pervasive aim was to commemorate black achievements. There are fine formal portraits of political leaders and beautifully intimate ones of musicians, dancers and artists.
But achievement could just mean doing everyday things most whites didn't imagine you doing. It isn't only the glamorous black 19th- and 20th-century aristocrats with their elegant airs and wardrobes and looks that make you think their ancestors must have come from every known continent. It's the nurses' training schools, the baseball players and beauty queens, the all-male card games in bars, carefully angled hats of women on a Bronx street corner waiting to be hired as low-paid domestics. The restaurants, barbershops, beauty shops and funeral homes that were part of what black writers through the years have called Bronzeville, Negroland, Aframerica or the 'Hood.
You will find heroism, lyricism and naturalism here. And, through the 1980's and 1990's, abstraction, collage and exuberant technical experiment. Photographers well known to blacks and whites are represented. (James Van der Zee, Gordon Parks, Roy DeCarava, Chester Higgins Jr., Carrie Mae Weems and Lorna Simpson). So, too, are many, like Robert H. McNeill, Monetta J. Sleet Jr. and Charles Harris, who spent most of their lives working for the black press. There is so much good work from so many.
And in the end "Reflections in Black" turns out to include whites, too. Nineteenth-century black professionals often photographed nonblack subjects, from abolitionists to the obscure citizens whose pictures are in every in state historical society collection. Like their white counterparts, these photographers, occasionally women, traveled, set up studios, advertised and won medals at state fairs.
When James Presley Ball moved to Richmond, Va., in 1846, an observer wrote: "The Virginians rushed in crowds to his room; all classes, white and black, bound and free sought to have their lineaments stamped by the artist who painted with the Sun's rays." Augustus Washington began his career in Hartford, and before it ended he had photographed the fierce John Brown and had traveled to Liberia, photographing the black families who had emigrated there from the United States.
Ms. Willis includes a 1946 photograph of an anti-lynching march: the sign-carrying women all wear hats and some wear white gloves, too. And there is one picture, taken by James Presley Ball, of a black man hanged in Helena, Mont., in 1896. In Ball's first picture of him, the man is wearing a suit with a white flower in his lapel and smartly folded pocket handkerchief. In the second picture, he is hanging from a rope, a hood over his head, flanked (since the hanging was legal) by a sheriff and a minister.
He was an ex-slave named William Biggerstaff and in Ball's last photo, he lies in a white-lined coffin, mustache combed, wedding ring in view.
All varieties of the human are in this book. They don't always defeat cruelty and bigotry but they do at last make them bear the weight of those terrible words "inhuman" and "subhuman."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Last-Minute Surge by Shoppers Caps Tepid Retail Sales Season

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Wal-Mart, Macy's and other United States retailers welcomed crowds of last-minute holiday shoppers this weekend, in what analysts predicted would be among the two biggest shopping days of the year.
"We were busy all day" on Saturday, said Kathy Tariche, a manager at a Williams-Sonoma store in Manhattan. "It was a lot of guys doing last-minute shopping." The cookware chain had KitchenAid mixers, wine-bottle openers and food baskets wrapped and ready for customers in a hurry, she said. 
 Retailers were hoping for an 11th-hour sales surge after three weeks of so-so sales, and they had good reason to expect one. The Saturday before Christmas has been the busiest holiday shopping day for the last five years. With Christmas on a Monday this year, consumers had a full weekend to finish, or in some cases -- and you know who you are -- to start buying gifts.
Strong results this weekend could help the industry stave off a shortfall in sales at stores open at least a year, known in the industry as same-store sales, analysts said.
Few analysts now expect that such sales will wind up matching last December's 6.7 percent jump, what with higher fuel prices and volatility in the stock market weighing on consumers this month. As of last week, some doubted that the industry would meet even more modest expectations.
A Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi economist, Mike Niemira, who had forecast a 4 percent increase this season, adjusted his sales estimate last week down to a range of 2 percent to 4 percent. This came after Wal-Mart, Target, Sears, Roebuck and other chains said sales had not kept pace with forecasts.
"On the strength of this last-minute surge, we are likely to see a same-store sales increase of about 3 percent," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report. "If it hadn't been for the final surge, I think it would've been a disastrous holiday."
After this weekend, retail analysts will switch their focus to industry profits, which may have been hurt by the heavy discounting that some retailers offered to lure shoppers.
Some chains, afraid of having too much holiday merchandise left over, slashed prices this weekend, providing a taste of the kinds of bargains that will be available after Christmas.
Kmart, which kept its stores open 24 hours on Friday and Saturday, cut prices on jewelry and other items by as much as 70 percent. Federated Department Stores offered 20 percent-off coupons for holiday clearance merchandise at its Macy's and Bloomingdale's chains, while Circuit City gave away a DVD player with each purchase of a projection television.
Shoppers have become accustomed to the late-season discounts, with many people saying they wait for big price markdowns before buying gifts.
"I look for tags of 50 percent off," said Louanne Tan of Toronto, who shopped at the Manhattan Mall in Herald Square while visiting her brother for the weekend.
In Atlanta, where ice and snowstorms last week made it harder for many shoppers to get around town, the weather cleared just in time for Jimmie Carey to finish her shopping and take advantage of markdowns at the downtown Macy's.
"I shopped later this year because I couldn't get around as easily" with the weather, said Ms. Carey, who bought pots and pans at 20 percent off. "I also wanted to wait for sales. The sales are very good this year."
The pressure on sales affected smaller merchants as well. Virginia Nelson, 40, who sells handmade Navajo jewelry in downtown Santa Fe, N.M., said she lowered her prices for the weekend to compensate for a slower economy and to compete with last-minute sales at local shopping malls.
"You have to adjust your prices with the season and the customers," she said. "I took $5 off of everything."

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Reality Dampening the Dot-Com Hoopla

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI; Lisa Napoli is the Internet correspondent for MSNBC.

 BODY:
A miniature set of playing cards. A 12-carat faux diamond ring. A candy bag containing more lollipops than chocolate. A holiday music CD attached to a box of Cheerios. A giant banner personalized with my name and company logo. 
 Two copies of the catalog entrepreneur J. Peterman's new book, one addressed to my former producer, who quit nine months ago.
Eleven other books, all with "cyber," "e" or "Internet" in the title, some addressed to the person who had my job before me, almost 18 months ago.
For an entire month recently, I saved all the mail and trinkets I received at my office, rather than route them to the circular file or give the contents to colleagues. Four crates in all.
I also tabulated the e-mail messages sent to my public mailbox: 2,170. I tried but couldn't keep tabs on the phone calls.
"You're so popular!" the nice man at the switchboard told me once.
Hah! He and I know -- as I'm sure you do, too, by now -- that this flood of attentiveness has nothing to do with my personal charms.
It's my television network, MSNBC, where I am the Internet correspondent, and the fact that a brief audience with me may yield a mention on the air, on a Web site or both. This is the "dance that's not a duet," as a public relations person called it.
Like everything else about the new economy, this dance is nothing new -- just taken to ridiculous extremes, with some new moves, twists and stumbles thrown in.
Even within the dot-com world, however, things have changed, and fast. In the early days of e-commerce in New York City, some five long years ago, you could stand in the center of Silicon Alley and scream for a press agent to give you particulars about a new Web site and no one would answer. Early Silicon Alley parties were chock-full of eager "radicals" who were fascinated by the Net even before the dot-com boom. Back then, journalists found stories the old-fashioned way: sniffing them out themselves.
Just about nine months into the Web boom, though, there was a discernible change. It started with a sputter. In the Web's infancy, I was a reporter for CyberTimes, which at the time was a section of The New York Times on the Web. Uncertain voices would call and leave messages in which they nervously recited the Web addresses of clients.
And then, quickly, that sputter became a tidal wave, with an endless series of -- well, refer to the beginning of this article. In 1999, $13 billion was spent courting the technology media, according to Jack Bergen, the president of the Council of Public Relations Agencies, an industry trade group.
"There's been this heightened demand for P.R., as opposed to other communications tools," he said, because public relations offers three benefits helpful to a start-up company: speed, credibility and efficiency. For those benefits, some companies are paying public relations firms $50,000 to $60,000 a month. Agencies, in fact, are turning away business; in some cases, they see nine clients for every one they take.
"Clients are now pitching agencies," Mr. Bergen said, instead of the other way around. "That has never happened before."
Technology journalism has been booming the last 10 years, but the effect of technology on the news cycle is far-reaching. News is not something you get only from a newspaper in the morning and from television at night. The Internet has accelerated what was already becoming a 24/7 cycle as early as 1981, with the introduction of the Cable News Network (now called CNN).
All this has produced interesting kinks in the balance between supply and demand, creating a weird permutation of Economics 101. An abundance of start-up companies vying for attention leads to a demand by readers and viewers who are hoping to get expert help in making sense of the heavy promotion. An abundance of space and time in print and other media lead to a demand for more "news," which leads to a supply of information -- or an equally confusing oversupply.
And abundance does not necessarily translate into quality.
Consider this scene: A stylish conference room high above gleaming new Times Square. Four men, wearing suits, are preparing to meet the news media. They have invited a television reporter and a crew to videotape a demonstration of a "hot new" technology product. The reporter was skeptical, but the promise of something that could "revolutionize education" was alluring. The producers and her viewers would love this.
Just as everyone is cozying up around the enormous conference table, disaster strikes.
"You can't release this story, of course, until January," says one of the suited men. It is September. "And this product demo, well, it's not how it actually works. And when you shoot it, could you avoid that part of the screen? We don't have clearance for that yet."
That is the face of desperation, just like last year's dot-com start-up parties, each seemingly louder and costlier than the last, the ostentatious face of baseless optimism.
Pity the perky 20-somethings actually given the task of calling people like me. "Hi, I wanted to see if you were interested in meeting our C.E.O., a very exciting guy," they chirp on the phone, which rings a hundred times a day, and I try not to pick up.
Public relations people are gauged by their "hits" -- they keep logs of the notes and packages they send. They get extra points for keeping a journalist on the phone. They get many extra points if a reporter meets them in person. If that reporter actually writes a story or puts it on TV, they can get a raise.
Knowing this, I sometimes invite people to have coffee with me in Secaucus, N.J., where I work. It is one part sadist -- if they're that badly interested in meeting me, let them trek out here from New York, I reason. But it is another part compassion -- I know it's hard to sell something, and hard to deal with rejection. I'll give the person who sounds smart and eager a break. Besides, I might actually learn something.
Lately, though, the tide has again turned. As many high-technology companies consolidate or just plain go out of business, more frequently than not it is the reporter who makes the initial phone call -- to ask about the gory details.
And lately, in addition to plunging stock prices and rising layoff totals among the dot-coms, I have seen one other clear economic trend: a steep decline in the number of faux diamond rings and lollipops in my office in-box.

HEADLINE: Miami Airport Full of Santas, All Heading South

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Some folks need snow and Santa to feel it's Christmas. But in some Central American mountain villages or sandy Caribbean islands, a lot more people are depending on William Lora, especially when their stateside relatives implore him to check his holiday list: a schedule of cargo flights.
Mr. Lora shares more than just his girth and his smile with the season's better-known package delivery specialist: he is the Santa of last resort. As the manager of ABS Freight Forwarders at Miami International Airport, Mr. Lora is the go-to guy for desperate travelers who discover that many airlines here have severe holiday restrictions on the number of bags and boxes they can take back to the old country. 
 That is not a minor concern. Each Christmas season, 100,000 people troop through the airport daily, carrying everything from toys and television sets to car parts and livestock. Festively wrapped in green-and-red Christmas paper, encased in yards of see-through plastic like bulging Saran-wrap stockings or just stuffed into crates and bags, the packages make the airport's main concourse look like a seasonal swap meet.
Forget about the duty-free stores hawking Chanel, Hermes or Dior. The big names on the concourse are Zenith, Samsung and Casio. They are a testament not just to the strength of the economy, but also to the enduring allure of the North American dream, which makes Latin American and Caribbean immigrants leave behind everything they ever knew and loved. To these women and men -- wise, but weary from hard work -- the gifts they bear are signs of success that ease the months, and sometimes years, of separation.
"Latin Americans work all year so they can take gifts home," Mr. Lora said, with a nod to a pile of packages that included a chandelier bound for the Dominican Republic, a solar panel headed for Haiti and a boom box destined for Nicaragua.
"From past experience, as far as the Latin American traveler, the airlines tell them you can only bring two pieces per person and they show up with eight. They always bring gifts to relatives, and once a year they travel. Their relatives expect that from them."
Baggage handlers and airport clerks who work at the airport during its busiest season have come to expect anything. Most of the presents are run-of-the-mill consumer items, especially electronics, clothing and toys. But some people get a little carried away.
"Roosters," said Luis Arce, a supervisor with the Miami Dade County Aviation Department. "You can hear roosters in the terminal. I once saw a guy walking a bobcat like a pet on a leash."
Geneva Hairs, another county aviation worker, is still wondering about a woman she once saw at curbside. "I saw a lady with a tail hanging out of her blouse," she said. "It was a black tail. She was going to Santo Domingo or someplace."
But the only snapping airport workers usually have to fear is from irate passengers when they learn that their airline will not permit them to take their gifts.
"They bring everything," Mr. Lora said, with a dead-serious look. "People have brought 700 pounds worth of goods. That's just one person."
He pointed to two slender car axle rods being shipped to Japan. Written on the paper was "Tokio." "I said to the guy, 'I thought you fabricated cars over there,' " Mr. Lora said. "It turns out the guy is building a car over there. An American-made car. Yesterday he brought some transmission parts."
American Airlines, the dominant carrier to the Caribbean and Central America, imposes a no-box rule from early December to early January to prevent cargo holds from being so crammed with packages that luggage will not fit. Selected flights also have a two-bag luggage limit.
Airlines also have safety rules barring aerosol cans, flammable liquids and some other goods. But many travelers to poorer countries show up with household goods, like the many women who try to go to Haiti with four-packs of spray starch.
The explanation for the box ban might make sense to those who are staying home. But it sounded like nonsense to Hector Castillo, who was told he could not take aboard a microwave oven he had bought for his sister in the Dominican Republic. Now all she will get is an excuse.
"Why?" he asked. "This is the time of year when people bring the most gifts. My sister asked for this. Now I'll have to take it in the summer."
Good luck, since American also has a similar ban during the heavy travel season in the summer.
The reactions are not quite passenger rage, but letdown, eased a bit by some holiday entertainment at the freight forwarding counter, where merengue music is sometimes played to soothe travelers.
Maria Isabel hugged a brown teddy bear as she waited with her teenage son Martin to check into their flight to Tegucigalpa, Honduras. Beside them, still inside their boxes, were a laptop computer and "My Walking Doll," which wasn't going anywhere, walking or otherwise, as long as she stayed in the box. Ms. Isabel had already left at home a bicycle and television set she had bought for her grandchildren in Honduras and will now have to ship.
"The computer is for my daughter because she started her first year at the university there," Ms. Isabel explained. "I want her to get ahead."
She paid for her gifts over the year, saving her money from her job planting and picking tomatoes at a southern Florida farm.
"Life is easier here," she said. "What we want is joy for our family. That's why we work, to make money and bring joy to our children."
On the other side of the airport, where the line for the afternoon TACA flight to Nicaragua was several hundred feet long, Luis Chavez was embarking on a busman's holiday. He is a truck driver, so the 10 huge bags he had hauled to the airport were a breeze compared with his usual cargo. His daughter Sheyla, 6, rested on one of the plastic-wrapped packages. Inside, there were clothes, toys and a microwave oven. More were left behind at home.
"This is a way to help those who are not here and show we are well," he said. "I have not been home in two years. It's a tradition for us to go home and be with the family on Christmas Eve. Here, we celebrate Thanksgiving American style. But you always remember and miss how we were raised."
Michael Rose will spend the holidays scanning luggage and not relaxing with his mother in his native Jamaica. His job as an airport security guard is one of the two jobs he holds, making it easier for him to help out back home. One might think he would become numb to all the presents he sees -- or their X-ray outlines, at least. Hardly.
"That's Christmas, man, for real," he said. "You get everything you want here, as long as you have the money. The U.S. is a very powerful country."
He repeated his last few words like a statement of faith.
"The U.S. helps a lot of Caribbean countries," he said. "If there were no foreign nationals living here, I don't know what kind of Christmas they would have over there."
Two weeks from now, the rush will begin anew, in reverse, as holiday revelers return to their jobs. Then, the stress will be on the Customs line. Tom Roland, the chief inspector for the United States Customs Service at the airport, said he could expect to stop people smuggling Cuban rum, animal skins, or even endangered birds or chicken blood (for religious rituals).
And, inevitably, Grandma's mango.
"These are people who are closer to the earth than we are," he said, explaining why someone would risk a $50 fine for violating laws against bringing in agricultural goods to smuggle the forbidden fruit.
"These are treasures to these people," he said. "They could be carrying a mango, but it grew on Grandma's tree back on the islands. That means something. They would go to those lengths to smuggle in a mango."
He spoke with warmth, not cynicism. There was something about the parade of humanity and its hopes that he sees whenever he walks through the concourse.
"The holidays to me are about family and food," he said. "We do the big Italian thing ourselves, and I'm going to be cooking for 26 people. I'll get my fish at the market in Coral Springs. I'll go to the Italian butcher in Pembroke Pines. I'm going to have my cannolis and my Sicilian wine waiting for me at the store."
He had a faraway smile for a second.
"And you know something?" he said. "I don't have to get on a plane to do it. Geez, this is a pretty good place to live. And work."

HEADLINE: Did U.S. Bombs Help or Hinder?

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Serbs voted Saturday for a new Parliament and government that put an end to the era of Slobodan Milosevic, leaving one major question: how much of a role did the American-led bombing war against Yugoslavia, in spring 1999, have in Mr. Milosevic's fall?
The question matters, not just for history or for the legacy of the Clinton administration, which, as it prepares to leave office, considers the fall of Mr. Milosevic one of its great foreign policy successes. It also matters for what lies ahead. 
 By all accounts, the incoming administration of George W. Bush will be more reluctant to intervene abroad if American interests are not directly at stake. And the new president of Yugoslavia, Vojislav Kostunica, is convinced that a Bush administration would not have bombed Yugoslavia over Kosovo, and that Mr. Clinton's policy choices kept an unpopular Mr. Milosevic in power longer than necessary.
Colin L. Powell, the former general and designate for Secretary of State, opposed the use of American power in Bosnia and criticized the conduct of the Kosovo war. Both he and Condoleezza Rice, Mr. Bush's choice for national security adviser, have said they want to reduce and then eliminate the American military presence in the Balkans.
Virtually all Serbs, like Mr. Kostunica, opposed the NATO bombing war as a crude, unnecessary and even unjust use of power when other Western policies had failed, even as some of them do acknowledge that it helped -- eventually -- to push Mr. Milosevic from power.
They believe that American support for international sanctions against Mr. Milosevic over Bosnia helped prop him up; that Washington did not push the Kosovo Albanians to vote, which would have defeated Mr. Milosevic as Serbian president even in 1992; that the Americans made Mr. Milosevic more important than he was, after the 1995 Dayton accord that ended the Bosnian war, as the "guarantor of stability in the Balkans"; that Washington did not provide enough help to the Serbian opposition when it challenged Mr. Milosevic in late 1996 and early 1997 and kept trying to pick "favorites"; and that Washington had an inconsistent and counterproductive policy toward Kosovo, especially after Mr. Milosevic fanned the crisis there to create new support at home.
However much these points can be debated, there is also understanding here that the shock of the bombing and the loss of Kosovo finally stripped Mr. Milosevic, already deeply unpopular, of all but his firmest supporters. The bombing at first consolidated patriotic support around him as president, which was reinforced by the immediate revenge attacks against Serbs in Kosovo that NATO forces did little to stop.
But that support could not last, and when Mr. Milosevic himself decided to call an early election for September, the only real question was whether he would be able to steal enough votes to pretend to win, and whether the Serbs would stand up to defend their votes.
"Milosevic lost because he called an election, which he would have had to do sooner or later, and the result would have been the same," said Aleksandar Fatic, head of the Security Policy Group at a Belgrade policy institute, the Management Center.
"What was most important to people was the poor state of the economy and their own lack of perspective," he added. "What was really different was a united opposition with a credible candidate, Kostunica, and that would have worked before, in 1997, too."
While the election was definitive, and stripped Mr. Milosevic of legitimacy and thus support from the police and the army, Kosovo was "an important contributing factor in his defeat," said Aleksa Djilas, a Serbian historian and analyst.
"He wasn't popular for a long time," Mr. Djilas said. "He would have lost in 1992 if the Americans had pressured the Albanians to vote. But in the end, it was this divided opposition of ours that kept him in power." As for any American help in removing Mr. Milosevic, he said, it reminded him of a dedication that P.G. Wodehouse wrote to his daughter, "without whose never-failing sympathy and encouragement this book would have been finished in half the time."
Dr. Velimir Pajevic, a physician from Kragujevac, is more definitive: "The last resort in psychiatry is electroshock, and that's what the bombing of Serbia was, unfortunately. I'm not justifying the bombing, but it was clear afterwards that the West had stopped playing with Milosevic and that we had no future with him."
Milivoje Mihajlovic, a Serbian journalist who lived and worked in Kosovo, said the loss of the province was crucial to Mr. Milosevic's fall. "The war mattered, definitely," he said. "It showed that Milosevic was a loser, a liar, and didn't care for his own people."
After the Western bombing of Serbia and the loss of Kosovo, no one could any longer believe, as they did after Dayton, when the Serbs kept half of Bosnia, that Mr. Milosevic was a political mastermind who could find a tactical victory, said Ljiljana Smajlovic, a political analyst for the magazine NIN.
Serbs lived with the sanctions and the loss of foreign goods, visas, air travel and much else as the "price of something dearer to us, this sense of national interest, what makes us a people," she said. "But after Kosovo, it was all in vain. We had lost living standards, our pride in our history and honor as warriors, and finally lost Kosovo, too."
By standing up to NATO in what Serbs felt was an unjust and even scandalous war, Mr. Milosevic had earned some respect and political rehabilitation, which was reinforced by the aftermath in Kosovo -- the expulsion and murder of Serbs there. "People said that this hate-filled chauvinism of the Albanians had to be confronted, even if the heavens fell on our heads, and that redeemed him to a certain extent," Ms. Smajlovic said.
But it was clear this spring that the Milosevic government was on its last legs and that any reasonably fair election would defeat him, she said.
A united opposition with a credible candidate, and Mr. Milosevic's "hysterical attacks" upon anyone who opposed him as agents of NATO, displayed his weakness to everyone, said Dragor Hiber, a leading opposition politician.
The Americans and the West, desperate to push out Mr. Milosevic, finally understood for this election that the Serbian opposition was the only one available, Mr. Hiber said, and provided much more help than before, pouring money into Serbia -- to the opposition, the media, to student protesters, almost everyone who could claim to be anti-Milosevic.
"But no one really knows how important Western support was," Mr. Hiber said. "It was preaching a lot to the converted. It's unprovable." By then, he said, the question wasn't if Mr. Milosevic would lose to Mr. Kostunica, but whether Mr. Kostunica would be allowed to win.
Probably as important as any aid to the opposition, Washington accepted Mr. Kostunica and his campaign criticism of American policy -- including the bombing war and the indictment of Mr. Milosevic for war crimes -- with dignity and discretion, trying to ensure that Western policy would at least do no harm.
The protests that led to Mr. Milosevic's ouster and the acknowledgment of his defeat had little to do with the West, but with the Serbs themselves, everyone here agrees. And senior American officials, who say they feel vindicated by the outcome, also concede that the main idea of promoting Mr. Kostunica was not theirs, but the Serbian opposition's.
Some American officials with long experience in the region accept many of the criticisms, especially the accusation that a more focused policy in 1996 and 1997 could have defeated Mr. Milosevic. American aid to the democratic opposition began then, but it was small and late, and Washington, worried about problems in Bosnia and thinking it needed Mr. Milosevic's help, did too little then to force the opposition to keep together for the 1997 elections.
Whatever the earlier Western mistakes, once the bombing war started NATO could not afford to lose it. And whether the war was necessary or not, due to miscalculations in the West and in Belgrade, it did help bring about the fall of Mr. Milosevic, said Milan Bozic, a professor and politician, because it broke his relationship with the West, which finally had no more use for him.
"If in 1996, the West had wanted to push harder, he would have been out then," Mr. Bozic said. "But the war in Kosovo finally ended Milosevic's symbiotic relationship with the West. It was an important leg of his stool and it was gone, and it helped unseat him."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Critical Player on Bush Agenda Is an Unknown Quantity

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the six years he was in the House of Representatives and the 20 he has been in the Senate, Charles E. Grassley made it a practice to reserve the hours of 3 p.m. to 5 p.m. every day he was in Washington for meetings with outsiders.
His constituents from Iowa always had first crack. Then came lobbyists, reporters and others interested in specific issues or legislation. He almost always had time for everyone, and often had time to spare. 
 That has all changed now.
When the new Congress convenes next month, Senator Grassley, a Republican, will be chairman of the Finance Committee, the panel with jurisdiction over taxes, Social Security, Medicare, health insurance, trade and welfare. By virtue of his seniority and the defeat last month of the chairman for the last six years, Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, Mr. Grassley, 67, will move from relative anonymity to a position with a dominant voice on most of the top items on President-elect George W. Bush's agenda.
Already, lobbyists and policy advocates are lining up to meet with him, and his phone is ringing incessantly. "I've had to ask my staff," Mr. Grassley said the other day, "to say to people that I might have met with over the past 26 years that I want their first meeting now to be with staff so I can reserve time for the broader questions of administration of the agenda and mastering of the issues."
One reason those interested in particular legislation are so eager to meet with Mr. Grassley is that he is such an unknown quantity. With a few notable exceptions like his opposition to the Persian Gulf war resolution in 1991, his voting record has been solidly conservative Republican. But his main interests have been agriculture, aging and Pentagon waste, and he has never taken the lead on the hot issues over which he will now have so much influence.
Even colleagues on the Finance Committee do not know, for example, how strongly he feels about across-the-board tax cuts or providing prescription drug coverage under Medicare or establishing private investment accounts under Social Security or giving patients the right to sue their health insurance companies.
More narrowly, the lobbyists who plead for tax breaks from the Finance Committee have no clear sense of where Mr. Grassley is likely to stand. He created a splash by uncovering excessive military spending on items like toilet seats, and there is anxiety in some circles that he might turn his attention to tax loopholes.
The senator is not ready to tip his hand. He has met, he said, with Vice President-elect Dick Cheney to "open lines of communication," but they have reached no conclusion on the order in which the Finance Committee should take up the Bush agenda.
Mr. Grassley said his sense is that "with a Congress so divided and a presidential election so close, we ought to start on some things where we can build some bipartisan consensus."
Into that category, he places measures approved by Congress this year and vetoed by President Clinton that would reduce the income taxes owed by married couples and gradually phase out the federal tax on large estates.
If the economy turns sour, Mr. Grassley said, it may be possible to get some overall tax relief, though probably not the huge tax cut proposed by Mr. Bush.
"With the 50-50 makeup of the Senate," he said, "I think we've got to be realistic that there might be some compromise necessary."
He said he was inclined to take up Medicare in two steps. The first, he said, might be a bill that would give the states money they could use for prescription drug coverage for low-income Medicare beneficiaries. The second step, which might take a year or two, would be more comprehensive legislation that would combine broader prescription drug coverage with a more market-based approach to Medicare generally.
Mr. Grassley said that he was under no illusion the elderly wanted big changes in Medicare but that changes must be made or the system will go bankrupt.
"Sometimes, little old ladies in Iowa say to me, 'Just leave it alone,' " he said. "I tell them, 'If you just leave it alone, you won't have Medicare pretty soon.' "
MR. GRASSLEY does not look, talk or act like the archetypal senator. He is tall and thin with a crooked smile and an awkward gait. He wears off-the-rack suits, and his voice has a country twang. He is proud of his background as a farmer, and he spends his weekends and Congressional recesses on the corn and soybean farm he owns with his son Robin in New Hartford, west of Waterloo, the city where he was born. Mr. Grassley, whose term runs through 2004, rarely delivers extended monologues in the Senate the way most of his colleagues do. He is not a Republican firebrand, but he makes no secret of his partisan views.
Asked, for example, what he thought of Mr. Bush and Vice President Al Gore, he replied: "I think there's a difference between how Bushes of three generations approach public office and Gores of two generations. I think the Bushes see it as a responsibility and an opportunity and probably a privilege. I saw the Gores seeing public office as a right."
People who have followed Mr. Grassley's career say his slow-talking farm boy demeanor is an act like a pool hustler's meant to lull his opposition into complacency. True or not, he has certainly been successful in politics. He lost a race for the Iowa House of Representatives in 1956 when he was still in graduate school. But he won two years later when he was 26 and has never lost an election since.
"I think what you see is what you get," he said. "I'm not one thing in Washington and another thing in Iowa."
That seems true enough. One afternoon in the impeachment trial in the Senate last year, Mr. Grassley astonished visitors looking down from the gallery by taking off his shoes.
Questioned about it the other day, he said: "You know, my feet were hurting. My gosh, I probably had on some shoes I shouldn't have been wearing because, you know, I don't normally take off my shoes except at home."

HEADLINE: Resort's Full-Time Residents Getting a Break on Housing

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich.

 BODY:
Marvelous Victorian summer cottages and magnificent views of Lake Huron and Lake Michigan make this teardrop-shaped island one of the most popular resort destinations in the Midwest. But with some home prices exceeding $1 million, an increasing number of the 500 islanders who live here all year and earn low wages are hard pressed to run the local government and perform other vital work while keeping a rented roof over their heads.
Many of them can no longer afford to stay. 
 Resourcefulness, however, has been a part of this island's heritage since it was a haven for French "voyageurs" in the 17th century. Mindful of this history, modern island residents have come up with a solution for affordable housing that could well provide a model for other expensive resort communities.
This month a single-family home and a comfortable two-family duplex were offered for sale at subsidized prices by the Mackinac Island Housing Corporation, a nonprofit group founded and managed by island workers, including a schoolteacher, a public works clerk and a delivery agent.
The units are the first of 10 single-family homes and 18 two-family duplexes to be built over the next two years on a three-acre parcel owned by the housing corporation in Harrisonville, a hamlet near the island's center where many year-round residents live, some in tiny two-room cabins.
So far, about 30 families have signed up for a lottery next month that will determine who will be the first to live in the plainly named Harrisonville Subdivision.
Among the first to enter the lottery were Julie and Christopher Malfroid, year-round residents whose housing plight has been emblematic. The couple, who have two young sons and a third child on the way, have lived in four different cramped rentals since arriving from Grand Rapids, Mich., in 1997.
They live off Mr. Malfroid's earnings as a bicycle mechanic and maintenance man. But the family was forced to leave its three previous apartments because of higher summer rents.
"I tell you, it builds character," said Mrs. Malfroid, 33, who said she was hoping to buy a three-bedroom duplex for around $75,000 through the lottery.
The planning on the subdivision project began in 1995, when land prices sharply escalated and the island's school enrollment dropped below 100 students as young families departed.
Several prominent summer residents joined a group of year-round residents in the effort, and by 1997 the resulting company, the Mackinac Island Housing Corporation, had raised $475,000 from private donors and foundations and bought 3.16 acres from an island family.
The corporation has worked with a succession of private donors, foundations, technical specialists, bankers and state officials to raise another $750,000, including a two-year $517,000 state housing grant to install a road and sewers, and to build the first three homes.
Michael Hart, 48, a longshoreman who serves as the corporation's president, said the position involved riding a sea of details. For instance, to qualify to live in the Harrisonville Subdivision, a family cannot earn more than $33,200 a year. The Mackinac County median income is $35,000 for a family of four.
Each family must also sign a contract certifying full-time residency; no more than one month a year can be spent off the island.
"If they take a vacation it better be short," Mr. Hart joked.
"We don't want these homes to be rented or subleased," he added. "We want them to used by the families that bought them."
To ensure that the subdivision's homes are affordable and remain so for many years to come, the housing corporation owns the land beneath each house and leases it to the homeowner for a nominal fee. The buyer is thus insulated from high land values.
In addition, the buyer agrees to a limit on any profit from future sale of the home. Twenty percent of the increase in value is the maximum profit allowable, under a contract that the Mackinac Island Housing Corporation is drawing up.
For example, a single family home that sold for $98,000 this year could theoretically be worth $130,000 in 10 years. But under the contract, the seller would legally be entitled to only slightly more than $6,000 from such a sale -- 20 percent of the increase in value. So the new price for the home would be set at approximately $104,000.
Such a formula ensures that a family in the future will be able to afford the home, said Edward Bobinchak, an executive at the Michigan Capital Fund for Housing, a nonprofit group in Lansing, Mich., that has provided financial and technical support.
The general concept underlying the Harrisonville Subdvision, known as a community land trust, was developed in the late 1960's and is promoted nationally by the Institute for Community Economics in Springfield, Mass. Sarah Page, the institute's director, says 90 community land trusts exist in the United States, most of them in small cities and suburbs where decent housing is perennially in short supply for low-income people.
The Mackinac Island project is the first community land trust in Michigan and among the first nationwide in a resort community.
The people who settle on Mackinac Island are, in many ways, modern pioneers. They live an isolated, spartan, nomadic lifestyle on low wages. In exchange, they receive splendid maritime scenery, safety and quiet.
Of all the inconveniences the residents contend with, none is more bothersome than the constant moving around. The Malfroids pay $425 a month for a cramped two-bedroom home -- a step above their $500-a-month one-bedroom apartment of a few months ago, which was so small they had to sleep in the living room.
Of the duplex they are seeking, Mrs. Malfroid said, "This is where we want to be, and if we are able to buy one of those homes, it will really help."

HEADLINE: U.N. Workers Return to Afghanistan After Taliban Safety Pledge

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: se emb KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Non-Afghan employees of the United Nations began returning to Afghanistan today after the Taliban militia, who rule most of the country, guaranteed that the workers would not face a violent backlash because of newly proposed sanctions against the government.
Three United Nations workers arrived in the Afghan capital, Kabul, early today, while seven others returned to the cities of Herat and Kandahar, said Erick de Mul, the United Nations coordinator for Afghanistan. 
 They are among about 50 workers the United Nations had pulled out of Afghanistan last week because there were fears that there would be a violent reaction to a sanctions resolution that the United Nations Security Council passed last week.
Mr. de Mul said the Taliban had guaranteed the safety of the United Nations employees, most of whom work for agencies involved in removing land mines, aiding refugees and providing food assistance.
Most employees who left will be back in Afghanistan in the coming week, he said.
"I am very happy to back here and resume work," David Pakas, a United Nations security official, told reporters after he arrived at the Kabul airport today.
The United Nations gave the Taliban a month to surrender Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born financier of militancy who is thought to be in Afghanistan. Mr. bin Laden is wanted in the United States on charges of being behind the bombings of two United States Embassies in Africa in 1998.
The Taliban were also told by the United Nations that they must close terrorism training camps or face new sanctions proposed by the United States and Russia.
The Security Council said the sanctions would affect only the Taliban, not ordinary Afghans already devastated by a protracted civil war and a persistent drought.
However, ordinary Afghans already are suffering: the currency has plunged and prices have gone up because of the sanction threats. Thousands of people are trying to flee the country.
The sanctions call for an arms embargo on the Taliban, including foreign military assistance that is believed to be provided by Pakistan. It also calls for the closing of all Taliban offices overseas.
The sanctions will go into effect in a month if the Taliban fail to close Afghan camps that are believed to be training grounds for terrorists and to deliver Mr. bin Laden to the United States or to a third country for trial in the bombing of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
Taliban leaders have refused to hand over Mr. bin Laden. They also have denied allegations that the camps are used to train Chechen rebels, who are fighting for independence from Russia.
In November 1999, the United Nations imposed limited sanctions on the Taliban to try to force Mr. bin Laden's extradition.
The Taliban, who rule more than 95 percent of Afghanistan, including Kabul, are fighting a northern-based opposition alliance in an attempt to extend their control over the entire country.
The Taliban, mostly Sunni Muslims, practice a fundamentalist version of Islam, imposing, among other things, severe restrictions on education and work for women.
The opposition is based in the north and includes some of the commanders who have been fighting since the days when the West helped finance an effort to expel Soviet rulers. It is made up of predominantly ethnic and religious minorities.
