SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 4414 words

HEADLINE: A War on Poverty Subtly Linked to Race

SERIES: THE CLINTON LEGACY -- Third of five articles: Redefining Welfare

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE and STEVEN A. HOLMES 

 BODY:
As his turbulent first term approached its close in 1996, Bill Clinton faced one of the most consequential decisions of his presidency: whether to sign a popular welfare bill largely shaped by his Republican enemies.
Many of his allies saw the bill's get-tough features as an unthinkable surrender of victories won in the New Deal and the Great Society. In signing the measure, they said, Mr. Clinton would push millions of poor people and minorities deeper into poverty. Worse, many suspected he would be doing so for his own short-term political gain. 
 But others turned the accusation of expedience on its head. They told Mr. Clinton that the welfare restrictions -- time limits and work requirements -- would do more than revamp one discredited program. The restrictions would help create a political climate more favorable to the needy. Once taxpayers started viewing the poor as workers, not welfare cheats, a more generous era would ensue. Harmful stereotypes would fade. New benefits would flow. Members of minorities, being disproportionately poor, would disproportionately benefit.
Whether driven by a vision of social renewal or a clear-eyed look at the polls, Mr. Clinton not only signed the bill but also went on to embrace it as a centerpiece of his domestic legacy, calling it a new "social bargain with the poor."
Now as his presidency comes to a close, Mr. Clinton's contentious drive to "end welfare as we know it" stands as an embodiment of his broader approach to the problems of poverty and race. Blending the causes of the left and the right in ways that unsettled both, Mr. Clinton pursued a bold, some say risky, antipoverty strategy that he hoped would attract public support and avoid the racial backlash that had burdened previous programs for the poor.
At its heart was a demand that the poor go to work, even those with very young children, low skills and low wages. With strict time limits and vast local discretion to turn the needy away, Mr. Clinton carried his antiwelfare crusade much further than even he had once intended. As a result, he leaves far fewer protections for families who, for whatever reason, fail to hold jobs.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton has presided over an unprecedented expansion of aid for poor families who do work. He won billions of dollars in wage supplements and smaller subsidies for everything from child care to children's health insurance, all framed as a moral obligation to "make work pay."
The shift in antipoverty policy, though sold in race-neutral terms, is central to the racial legacy Mr. Clinton leaves. At times he spoke explicitly, even eloquently, about racial justice; he defended affirmative action; and he appointed record numbers of blacks and Latinos to positions of influence. Yet much of his work consisted of more subtle efforts to reshape racial perceptions.
In taking tough stands on issues like welfare and crime, Mr. Clinton sought to reduce stereotypes and resentments among some whites. In seeking new benefits for the working poor, Mr. Clinton understood that an outsize share of the aid would flow to Hispanics and blacks. But neither those efforts, nor many others, were cast in racial terms.
"Clinton understood that welfare had become a racially stigmatized program," said Theda Skocpol, a political scientist at Harvard University who studies programs for the poor. "He ended the most controversial aspects of welfare, but at the same time, he built up supports for working families. And he certainly did see this as an effort to quiet racial disputes about social supports for the vulnerable."
Citing initiatives from urban tax breaks to college scholarships, Hugh B. Price, president of the National Urban League, put it this way: "He has attempted to do things that have been of enormous benefit to communities of color, without labeling them that way. The idea was that you could build a stronger consensus for public policies that were cast in race-neutral terms."
Has the strategy been good for the poor? And have race relations improved?
Any assessment must take into account the extraordinary economic growth that, depending on one's view, Mr. Clinton either inherited or helped create. He will leave office having helped more Americans escape poverty than any other president since Lyndon B. Johnson. The last president to enjoy an extended economic expansion, Ronald Reagan, lifted 290,000 Americans out of poverty. So far, Mr. Clinton has multiplied that record 24 times, reducing the number of poor Americans by seven million.
"This is the first recovery in three decades where everybody got better at the same time," Mr. Clinton said in an interview with The New York Times before leaving office. "I just think that's so important."
And other repositories of social statistics have overflowed with good news. Crime is at a three-decade low. Wages for unskilled workers have reversed a 15-year decline. From Oakland to Newark, urban cores once abandoned as hopeless are sporting restaurants and shops.
The change is evident in politics as well. Twelve years ago, President George Bush came to power after a racially divisive campaign in which his supporters broadcast pictures of a furloughed black rapist, Willie Horton, to paint the Democrats as soft on crime. By contrast, Mr. Bush's son George W., ran this year by labeling himself a "compassionate conservative." He sought to be photographed with minority children and borrowed the slogan of the Children's Defense Fund, a liberal advocacy group: "Leave No Child Behind."
"Who's running against welfare now?" asked Al From, president of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, a political group Mr. Clinton helped start. "Who's running against poor people? Crime and welfare were surrogates for race. By taking both of them away as political issues, we did a lot of good for minorities and low-income communities. We also changed the tone of the political debate to where it is more tolerant and inclusive."
What remains to be seen is how well the welfare cuts, and other policies, perform when tough times arrive. While they welcome the falling poverty rates, some of Mr. Clinton's critics see the past eight years as a landscape of missed opportunities. Even with prosperity and budget surpluses, Mr. Clinton made virtually no progress on one of his central promises, the pledge to provide all Americans with health insurance. If anything, the new welfare laws may have made matters worse, by inadvertently driving some eligible families off Medicaid rolls.
"We should be ashamed we haven't made more progress in this economy," said Marian Wright Edelman, the president of the Children's Defense Fund. "It is totally unacceptable that with this much prosperity we have millions of uninsured children. What's going to happen when a recession comes?"
And while Mr. Clinton has celebrated the welfare law as a success, he signed it over the objection of advisers who believe it will still prove harmful to the poor.
"When unemployment starts creeping up again, a long line of people are going to be in trouble because we've taken away a safety net," said Robert B. Reich, who had been Mr. Clinton's friend for more than two decades before becoming his first secretary of labor.
Even now, many problems persist. The brutal dragging death of James Byrd Jr. in Texas in 1998 and the complaints about racial profiling have marred the racial peace. While poverty is down, the percentage of children born to single mothers remains at an all-time high. As Mr. Clinton himself has argued, even the best government programs cannot take the place of missing fathers.
Still, whatever reversals may lie ahead, there is one achievement that should not be ignored. That is the rediscovered sense that progress is possible on problems once thought impervious to change. Some people say progress is the president's doing, and some say it happened despite him. But few people now share the sense, prevalent just a decade ago, that every war on poverty is destined for defeat.
"The legacy of the 1990's, of which Clinton is a part, is a healthy reinvigoration of our sense that government policies matter," said William Kristol, the editor and publisher of The Weekly Standard, a conservative political magazine that has been critical of Mr. Clinton. "It's been very important to show that these trends don't inevitably continue downward. It's a different world after the 90's."
In a sense it is odd that Mr. Clinton now takes such pride in the welfare law. While it is one of his most popular achievements, it is also an area where his attention flagged, his own plan failed, and his enemies seized control. Mr. Clinton supplied the volatile words that set events in motion, the famous 1992 campaign pledge to "end welfare as we know it." But his antagonist, Newt Gingrich, the Republican speaker of the House, supplied much of the law's content.
From the start, Mr. Clinton was trying a high-stakes linguistic maneuver. "End welfare" sounded bold. "As we know it" offered a hedge. Mr. Clinton's original plan balanced new obligations, like work requirements, with protections for those willing to work. But the president waited 17 months to introduce his plan, did little to promote it, and renounced it a year later, telling a Washington columnist, "I wasn't pleased with it, either."
By then, the Republicans controlled Congress, and "end welfare" gained a more literal meaning. Under Mr. Clinton's plan, mothers could remain eligible as long as they joined a work program. But under the measure he signed, most mothers can get no more than five years' help in a lifetime. The law also made deep cuts in unrelated programs like food stamps, capped federal spending and gave states virtually a free hand in shaping their programs.
"He agreed to 'end welfare as we know it' on Republican terms that were very different from his original terms," said Kent Weaver, a political scientist at the Brookings Institution who has written a legislative history of the law. "It's a bill with fewer protections that has as its primary emphasis getting people off of welfare rather than getting people to work."
In truth, the law created 50 very different programs. Here and there, some combine work requirements with the mix of services Mr. Clinton originally envisioned: counseling, training, placement in jobs. But most have placed a greater emphasis on reducing the rolls. The law's fine print is telling: the "caseload reduction credit" allows states to meet federal work requirements simply by cutting the rolls, whether or not those who leave find jobs.
The welfare rolls, in turn, have plummeted. Nationwide, they have fallen by more than 50 percent since their 1994 peak. Within a year of signing the bill, Mr. Clinton had proclaimed victory. "We know now that welfare reform works," he said.
In part the good news is the shortage of bad news. There are few signs of the widespread deprivation that opponents of the law predicted -- no "children sleeping on grates," as Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, warned. On the contrary, women once on welfare are working more, and earning more than ever before. The flood of single mothers into the robust labor market is the law's signal achievement.
The question is how much unskilled single mothers can achieve once they enter the job market. Few manage to keep full-time jobs all year. While their earnings are up, the growth of their paychecks has been largely offset by reductions in welfare and food stamps. Indeed, in purely economic terms, it is not clear whether the average woman leaving welfare is gaining ground.
In a confidential memorandum to President Clinton last year, Donna E. Shalala, the secretary of health and human services, offered a reading of the evidence more cautious than his.
"Many parents leave welfare for work yet still do not earn enough to raise their families out of poverty," Dr. Shalala wrote, adding that ost studies "indicate that average family income has been unchanged."
Some analysts see those studies as great encouragement. Despite dire predictions, they say, most families are beginning the transition to post-welfare lives -- a point Dr. Shalala herself echoed in a recent interview. With more experience, their earnings will rise. Meanwhile, the bill's supporters say, work gives children new role models and adults new pride.
"Work helps give structure and meaning to people's lives," said Bruce Reed, Mr. Clinton's domestic policy adviser.
But others read the same evidence as a source of worry. If the incomes are not rising now, they say, what happens when the economy slows? Even now, there is some evidence that incomes have fallen, in some cases precipitously, for the most troubled people leaving welfare. Though some have coped temporarily, by living with friends or relatives, it is unclear how long such arrangements can last.
And the effect of one of the law's toughest features -- time limits -- will not be known for another few years. "At that point, we will know if we took too great a risk," Mr. Moynihan said. "I think we did. I hope we did not."
In a recent interview, Mr. Clinton said he shared the concern about the most troubled families, especially when the time limits take full effect. "I am worried about the hardest to place," he said, "when you have a combination of tough times and people who may not care about them."
But for most families, he thought "this thing would work pretty well," he said. "And I think it plainly has."
"Ending welfare" was Mr. Clinton's most famous poverty pledge, but not his only one. He coupled it with a parallel promise to "make work pay" through aid to the working poor. Even while dismantling one safety net, Mr. Clinton has tried to build another with programs for struggling workers: wage supplements, child care and subsidies for children's health insurance.
"We're spending more on social policy, not less," said David Ellwood, a Harvard economist and former administration official. "But we're spending it in a completely different way. We've radically expanded help to working folks."
By far, Mr. Clinton's most significant legacy to the working poor is in a large program of wage subsidies with an opaque name, the earned-income tax credit. The details are complicated, but the bottom line is not: the program provides low-wage workers with annual cash bonuses of up to nearly $3,900. Workers must have children to qualify fully.
With little public fanfare, Mr. Clinton pushed through a vast expansion of the program in 1993, as part of his first budget. Since then, spending on the wage supplements has almost doubled to $30 billion a year. That is nearly twice what the federal government spent on the old welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, even at the its peak.
For an average woman leaving welfare, the annual payments now "make work pay" by turning a job that pays $6.50 an hour into one worth about $8.35 an hour.
"It's the largest antipoverty program since the Great Society," said Mr. From of the Democratic Leadership Council. "People don't give Clinton credit for that, but that's what it is."
While the general public is only dimly aware of the program, in many poor neighborhoods it turns tax season into an annual fiesta. Furniture stores run blowout specials, and used-car sales surge. As with welfare, the benefits disproportionately flow to racial minorities: 23 percent of the wage supplements go to black families and 25 percent to Hispanics.
But the program has proved more popular than most antipoverty initiatives, since its benefits are reserved for workers. Last year, Congressional Republicans sought to reduce the program, citing concerns about fraud. Then Mr. Bush criticized them for balancing the budget "on the backs of the poor," and his poll ratings rose.
Mr. Clinton's other efforts to build a work-based safety net have met with mixed results. He won support for child care subsidies by arguing that they help people work. But despite a doubling of the budget, child care programs still reach only about 10 percent of the eligible families, according to the Department of Health and Human Services. Even with subsidies, many parents have a hard time finding good care, especially if they work odd hours.
"We've established the principle that child care is a serious work support," said Joan Lombardi, a former administration child care official. But, Ms. Lombardi added, in terms of financing and quality, "we've still got a long way to go."
If child care is a story of mixed progress, health insurance is a story with little progress at all. Mr. Clinton sought office with a promise to extend coverage to all Americans. But his plan for universal coverage met defeat in a Democratic Congress. And tougher welfare laws have driven some eligible families from the food stamp and Medicaid rolls, as critics feared.
Mr. Clinton did win a program to help insure about 2.5 million children of low-wage workers. But despite eight years of economic growth, there are now more Americans without health insurance -- about 43 million -- than when the Clinton presidency began.
"We've learned that prosperity is never going to guarantee coverage for all workers," said Dr. Judith Feder, a dean at Georgetown University and a former Clinton administration health official. "While we're making some progress for children, we still lack a safety net for adults."
Virtually no one sees a finished product in this work-based safety net. While acknowledging that many holes remain, Mr. Clinton's supporters contend that he has changed the underlying politics in a way that promises future gains.
"The resentments that stood in the way of helping poor people have diminished considerably because we're no longer fighting about whether they deserve help or not," said Mr. Reed, the domestic policy adviser. "Everybody's expected to work, and as a result, society's willing to help."
Though critical of some aspects of the welfare law, Dr. Shalala agrees it has improved the political standing of the poor.
"I think there's a lot more respect on the part of the business community" for low-wage workers, she said. "There has been an education for all those people who used to sit around and say 'if only those people would get a job.' "
Others take a less sanguine view, fearing that the politics will turn when the economy falters.
"I wouldn't give Clinton failing marks by any means," said Wendell E. Primus, a former federal human services official who resigned to protest the welfare bill. "We've clearly made gains in this administration. But I think we missed an opportunity to do even better."
That racial themes would be woven through the domestic policies of Bill Clinton is unsurprising in a way, given his experiences with black Americans during his formative years in Hope, Ark.
As a child in Hope, he had grown to know many black people who frequented his grandfather's store. Throughout his life he was extraordinarily comfortable around black people -- so much so that some leading black commentators, like the writer Toni Morrison, wryly noted that Mr. Clinton was the country's first black president.
But as a Southern Democrat, Mr. Clinton also witnessed how conservatives had lured white voters by tarring Democrats as too willing to coddle black criminals and too supportive of expensive social programs intended for minorities.
Balancing these twin experiences, President Clinton embraced a series of unpredictable positions that in turn angered both conservatives and the leaders of traditionally liberal civil rights groups. Yet both expressed their awe at his ability to maintain his popularity among minority voters.
That popularity had roots both in substance and symbolism. Unlike some past economic booms, this one has been especially good to minorities: the poverty rate among African-Americans has fallen to an all-time low.
As president, he appointed a far greater percentage of minorities to cabinet and subcabinet posts than did Jimmy Carter, who had the second-highest percentage. One of Mr. Clinton's best friends, Vernon E. Jordan, is black and the two are frequently photographed together playing golf and taking vacations.
And in 1995, fearing that the Republicans in Congress might scuttle any federal programs that grant any types of preferences for minorities or women, Mr. Clinton stoutly defended affirmative action, saying the nation should "mend it, don't end it."
At the same time, Mr. Clinton was able to say or do things that rankled leaders of traditional civil rights organizations. As a candidate in 1992, he used a speech at Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition to rebuke the rapper Sister Souljah for suggesting that blacks "have a week and kill white people."
Mr. Clinton said such comments were divisive.
In a 1993 speech at a Memphis church, Mr. Clinton chided blacks for having too high a homicide rate, declaring that the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. "did not fight for the right of black people to murder other black people with reckless abandon."
The president also angered many civil rights advocates early in his term when he yanked the nomination of Lani Guinier to head the Justice Department's civil rights division without giving her the chance to defend her unorthodox writings on race and the electoral system before a Senate panel.
Yet despite these actions, Mr. Clinton was able to maintain an extraordinary amount of support from minorities.
"When you think about the record, he did a lot of things like welfare reform that no white politician affiliated with the Republican Party would ever get away with," said Michael D. McCurry, the former White House press secretary.
John Hope Franklin, a historian whom President Clinton eventually appointed to head a commission on race relations, said Mr. Clinton's popularity stemmed in part from his deep, various and long-term friendships with black Americans.
"People admired that Vernon Jordan was his best friend," Mr. Franklin said. "This becomes a part of the lore that African-Americans admire, pass on informally."
Given his ability to bridge the racial fault lines in the Democratic Party, perhaps Mr. Clinton's most important legacy in the area of race and politics has been to bequeath the party the recipe for recreating Robert F. Kennedy's 1968 coalition of working class whites, high-end liberals and minorities. In Mr. Clinton's case, this was accomplished by pushing for conservative to centrist policies that many white working-class voters favored and many civil rights leaders opposed, while using the sheer force of his personality and the projection of good will to maintain support among minorities.
And while some liberal civil rights advocates fumed that Mr. Clinton was pulling the wool over the eyes of minorities, he himself acknowledged that it was his personal rapport with minorities, especially black people, that allowed him room to maneuver.
"A lot of this was just personal, and I think that even when some people disagreed with some of my policies, they knew where I was on the big issues of race and civil rights and equal opportunity," Mr. Clinton said.
Yet, when Mr. Clinton undertook his only large-scale effort in the area of race, his initiative on race in 1997, the results were, at best, disappointing.
The president had given hints of his desire to enter into the tricky world of race relations in his second inauguration address just a few months earlier when he called on the nation to put aside differences and work toward creating "one America." In the succeeding months he had explored the idea of trying to bridge the country's racial divide in conversations with scholars like Taylor Branch and Henry Louis Gates Jr.
Aides said Mr. Clinton was concerned about isolated incidents of hate crimes, segregation on college campuses, a lack of dialogue on race in the country.
But the board, headed by Mr. Franklin, ran into trouble from the start. Its seven members were not well versed in the ways of Washington. Mr. Franklin drew sharp criticism when he said he had not invited critics of affirmative action to a session on how to increase racial and ethnic diversity on college campuses because he did not think they had anything to contribute.
The panel did have some limited effect. It recommended that a special assistant to the president of race and ethnic matters be appointed, which was done. It urged an increase in the budgets for agencies like the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that enforce antidiscrimination laws. That too was accomplished. And it spurred some agencies like the Departent of Health and Human Services to start programs to reduce disparities in health care.
But even the early supporters felt the initiative failed to generate a new national consciousness on race. "The president's initiative on race was basically stillborn," said Mr. Price, the president of the National Urban League. "It was too soft in its focus. Basically the president invited the country to come to the table for a discussion on race, and the country said, We're too busy. I don't think anything was lost on that. But it's hard to tell because it was hazily framed."
Mr. Franklin defended the advisory board's record, saying that it was a victim of unrealistic expectations. "I think we did pretty well" in starting a national dialogue, he said. "The charge to the advisory board was a relatively modest one. We had no illusions about solving the race problem."
The effort might have had more of a force if Mr. Clinton was not enmeshed in the scandal stemming from his relationship with a White House intern that broke about six months into the work of the advisory board. Fighting for his political life, Mr. Clinton gave too little attention to the board's work, and he will leave office without having produced the report on racial reconciliation that he had promised.
"One of the things that to me is so depressing about the Monica Lewinsky affair is that it sucked all the energy out of the race initiative," Mr. McCurry said.

Chart: "HIGHLIGHTS: Trying to Change Welfare and Bring The Races Together"
JAN. 20, 1993 -- President Clinton is sworn in, having campaigned on a promise to "end welfare as we know it."
 
AUG. 6, 1993 -- Senate passes budget reconciliation bill with Vice President Al Gore breaking the tie vote. It expands wage supplements to low-income workers through the earned-income tax credit.
 
NOV. 13, 1993 -- Mr. Clinton gives an emotional speech on crime at the black church in Memphis where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. gave his last sermon.
 
MARCH 1994 -- The welfare rolls reach their all-time high of 5.1 million families and 14.4 million people. (By June 2000, the rolls would drop to 2.2 million families and 5.7 million people.)
 
JUNE 14, 1994 -- Mr. Clinton issues a welfare plan proposing work requirements and time limits but retaining basic rights for welfare recipients.
 
MARCH 24, 1995 -- The new Republican House passes a welfare bill that would sharply cut spending and replace federal programs with lump-sum payments to the states.
 
JULY 19, 1995 -- Mr. Clinton strongly reaffirms the goals of affirmative action, saying "mend it, don't end it."
 
DEC. 6, 1995 -- Mr. Clinton vetoes the Republicans' balanced-budget bill, which contains an overhaul of the welfare system. A month later, he vetoes a second welfare bill.
 
FEB. 6, 1996 -- The nation's governors reach bipartisan agreement on a welfare plan that would give vast new power to the states.
 
JULY 18, 1996 -- The House passes a sweeping welfare bill, calling for new control by the states. The Senate passes it five days later.
 
AUG. 22, 1996 -- Mr. Clinton signs the bill shortly before the Democratic convention.
 
MARCH 8, 1997 -- President Clinton orders federal agencies to hire welfare recipients as an example to private employers.
 
JUNE 14, 1997 -- Mr. Clinton appeals for racial reconciliation and vigorously defends affirmative action, beginning an effort to lead the country in a "great and unprecedented conversation about race."
 
JULY 29, 1997 -- The White House and Congress reach agreement on a balanced budget that would pay workfare recipients the minimum wage, would alter the 1996 welfare law to restore disability benefits to legal immigrants and would provide $24 billion in health-care coverage for children.
 
DEC. 3, 1997 -- President Clinton leads a contentious town hall meeting on affirmative action intended to sharpen the national conversation on race.
 
OCT. 8, 1998 -- House votes to begin impeachment inquiries which lead to Mr. Clinton's acquittal more than a year later.
 
MARCH 22, 1999 -- In a confidential memorandum, Health and Human Services Secretary Donna E. Shalala cautions that much of the welfare bill's impact remains uncertain. Though many former welfare recipients have found work, their earnings remain low and "most families exiting welfare continue to be poor."
 
JULY 5-8, 1999 -- To draw attention to the plight of the poor, Mr. Clinton visits pockets of urban and rural poverty throughout the country, pledging tax breaks and other government aid. He continues the effort in early November.
 
FEB. 6, 2000 -- In his final budget proposal, Mr. Clinton further seeks to expand tax credits for low-wage workers, which now exceed $30 billion, a 100 percent increase from 1993.
 
SEPT. 26, 2000 -- A Census Bureau report shows the poverty rate for blacks reached an all-time low in 1999, falling to 23.6 percent from 33.1 percent in 1993.

HEADLINE: Three Circuses, a Ring at a Time;
New Yorkers Flock to the Competing Little Big Tops

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The primordial duel between Paris and New York for international pre-eminence has never been a battle of the circuses. That's because a dozen one-ring circuses have long been an ornament of the holiday season in Paris, while New York has had but one, the Big Apple Circus, for 23 years.
But suddenly New York has caught the fever. 
 Audiences are clamoring to see three major one-ring circuses in Manhattan that have won critical raves. Vying for attention are the home-grown Big Apple; a stately newcomer, Barnum's Kaleidoscape; and Circus Oz, a spiky vagabond from Australia.
So much for the dire predictions of entertainment executives that there might not be enough circus-loving, ticket-buying New Yorkers to support the year-end circus competition.
But "Clown Around Town," the new Big Apple show in its tent at Lincoln Center, is on track to exceed last year's ticket sales. Kaleidoscape has had to add three more shows to handle the crowds mobbing its tent in Bryant Park. And Circus Oz was running at 83 percent capacity last week in the New Victory Theater on West 42nd Street, and this week's performances are close to sold out.
Seen-it-all New Yorkers seem happy to be so well clowned. "This is a circus festival that no one planned," said Leonard Kamsler, a photographer and circus aficionado from Manhattan who was sitting in one of the red crushed-velvet Kaleidoscape seats at a recent performance. "It's the first time we've had so many high-quality circuses in town at the same time."
Raffaele De Ritis, the Italian director of Kaleidoscape, called the shows' collective popularity nothing less than "a celebration of the renaissance of the one-ring circus in America."
Because it's the new toy in town (Circus Oz has been in the city twice before, last in 1998) Kaleidoscape has played to column-fodder names like Tom Cruise, Richard Gere, Lee Iacocca, Liam Neeson and Natasha Richardson.
"I think these three shows have different styles and attract different audiences," said Kenneth Feld, the producer and chief executive of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, which created Kaleidoscape 20 months ago and propelled it on a tour of 12 American cities before New York.
The impromptu circus festival is the culmination of years of effort spiced by some unusually sharp partisan dialogue in a tightknit community, by bold showmanship, by fierce marketing and even by a dramatic clown defection.
Mr. Feld ignited the year-end circus wars last summer by announcing the arrival of Kaleidoscape, an elaborately produced, $10 million one-ring show that offers the comforts of padded seats with backs, red-carpeted hardwood flooring and premier "couch" seating at $75 a head.
In August, a Big Apple board member, Alan B. Slifka, publicly worried that the nonprofit Big Apple could be "driven out of existence" by the for-profit Kaleidoscape. Mr. Slifka contended that "the only reason for them to come at Christmastime is to compete with us."
Mr. Feld countered that he chose the city because "New York is the ultimate goal of any entertainment attraction," adding that the end-of-year window "is the time of year when people want to see things."
This season Big Apple, the spunky Manhattan-born institution that will play to a total of 450,000 circusgoers under its tent in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center, is more than holding its own. Loyal fans are flocking to the tent, and the show is having "a great season, we're selling out on a regular basis," said Gary B. Dunning, executive director of Big Apple.
Nevertheless, Big Apple is still smarting from the city's decision to permit Kaleidoscape to pitch its tent in Bryant Park. "Feld is there to make money for himself," Mr. Dunning said, "and we are there to pursue our mission of artistic excellence and give back to the community."
Beyond this, Big Apple is far from overjoyed that Ringling has signed Bello Nock, the vertical-orange-haired lead clown for Big Apple during the previous three seasons, as a star of Ringling's next three-ring arena show. "There was a sense of disappointment," Mr. Dunning said. "But that's business."
Thanks to the new competition, Big Apple has been forced not only to surrender its exclusive primacy in its high-profile season, but it has also had to ratchet up its marketing to maintain visibility. An entertainment executive with knowledge of Big Apple's marketing costs, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the circus would spend $1.3 million this year on television, print and direct-mail advertising, about $250,000 more than last year.
Mr. Dunning would say only that Big Apple was spending "more this year," adding that the cost "comes out of the programs we sponsor." He estimated that Big Apple returns a third of its $19 million yearly budget to city community programs, health institutions and other charitable causes. For years Big Apple has run efforts like the Big Apple Circus Clown Care Unit, which sends trained clowns into city hospitals to cheer up sick children.
Given Ringling's deep pockets, Kaleidoscape's massive publicity effort is three times the size of Big Apple's. Mr. Feld would not say how much the show has spent on marketing and advertising, but several media buyers with knowledge of Ringling's expenditures, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, estimated that the company has spent from $3.5 million to $4 million in television and print advertising for its New York Kaleidoscape campaign.
Furthermore, Kaleidoscape has a cheaper rental deal. Ringling has promised a guaranteed payment of $200,000 to the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation, and more if the show is a hit. Big Apple pays Lincoln Center $400,000 to $500,000 a year, according to people with knowledge of the arrangement.
Meanwhile, the circus performers themselves are trying to remain above the fray. "To us, circus is not a competition, it's not a sport -- it's an art form," said David Larible, the Italian-born master clown who is the star of Kaleidoscape. "And everyone knows everyone else."
His own family has had a close working relationship with the Flying Pages of the Big Apple Circus. Mr. Larible's wife, America, an aerialist, used to fly the triple somersault to the hands of Willy Pages, now the catcher of the Flying Pages troupe. That was when they were all on the Ringling three-ring show. The families' friendship has, they say, transcended the battle of the circuses.
"It is a very tight community, and circus people love to visit other circus people," said Dominique Jando, the associate artistic director of Big Apple. Among Mr. Jando's friends on Kaleidoscape is Philippe Sosman, who performs as Pipo the white-faced clown. Mr. Jando has known him "since he was 5 years old, at Cirque d'Hiver" in Paris, said Mr. Jando, who once performed as a clown himself.
Alexander Petrov, the star wire-walker of Kaleidoscape who traverses a 21-foot-long steel wire carrying a spangled lady, Lucy Kirilova, said, "It's hard to feel competitive with other performers when you've been in the ring with them."
Mr. Petrov has visited with his friend Serge Percelly, Big Apple's featured tennis-racket juggler, who performed in 1991 with Mr. Petrov under the tent of Circus Benneweis in Denmark. "I saw Big Apple's show, and then I went to Serge's trailer to see his wife and two daughters -- I'd never met them before."
All this fraternization has its practical side. "You can get ideas from other shows when they're in town," said Tim Coldwell, a founder of the 22-year-old Circus Oz who is its star clown. "Though hopefully it's not, 'Now I'm going to do that very same thing in my show.' "
Mr. Coldwell's irreverent assortment of clowns, acrobats and musicians performs under a tent in Port Melbourne, Australia, but it can be seen onstage at the New Victory for a top ticket price of $35. Circus Oz "is at a different price point than Big Apple or Kaleidoscape," said Mary Rose Lloyd, director of programming at the New Victory, referring to its competitors' top prices of $62 and $75 respectively. Circus Oz has spent $85,000 on city newspaper and magazine advertising.
If New York enjoys an embarrassment of circus riches, the city has a long way to go before matching the decades-long tradition in Paris, where the tented shows' budgets are heavily underwritten by arts grants from the French government.
Currently Paris is ahead of New York by considerably more than a clown nose: 14 circuses are playing there, including Circus Pinder, with its 4,500-seat tent, more than twice the capacity of Kaleidoscape. Mr. Larible, who worked the Christmas season at the Cirque d'Hiver in Paris in 1979, asked, "If Paris can host 17 circuses, then why shouldn't New York welcome more than three?"
And it is true that Big Apple isn't going away, that Circus Oz plans to return and that Mr. Feld hopes Kaleidoscape can come back to Bryant Park "year after year, as a holiday tradition."
So, depending on the economy and New Yorkers' fickle tastes, "maybe New York can become an annual circus festival," said Mr. De Ritis, the director. "That could further raise the level of audience sophistication, and force all the circuses to maintain a high level of performance -- something that New Yorkers expect."

HEADLINE: Can Capitalism Reduce Flights And Delays At LaGuardia?

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
There are 26,000 airline flights a day in the United States, and sometimes it seems as if every last one of them flies into La Guardia Airport. In fact, only about a thousand of them do on any given day, but that can be enough to create waits of an hour or two to take off or land, and that, in turn, delays air traffic around the country.
So over the next few months, the government plans to reduce the number of flights at La Guardia permanently, using a method almost unheard of in air traffic control: capitalism. There could be some problems on the way, however, as a free-market solution promises to yield a free-for-all. 
 The parties involved agree, though, that the old system has broken down. For decades traffic was kept bearable by a rationing system, based on incumbency, with airlines claiming flights the way Columbus claimed America for Ferdinand and Isabella: they got there first. A second way to add a flight at La Guardia was to persuade Congress or the Federal Aviation Administration that to do so would bring much-needed competition or serve a small community that had few or no connections to New York. Earlier this year, Congress opened the floodgates by increasing access for airlines in that category.
When the delays became unbearable, the F.A.A. held a "slot lottery" to reduce the new flights. But the fix is only temporary.
By Sept. 15, La Guardia's owner, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, together with the airlines, the Federal Aviation Administration and various other interested parties, are supposed to have worked out a new rationing system, which the F.A.A. has decided will be based on "market forces."
The system currently works against new airlines trying to offer service and, perhaps, increase competition that would be good for consumers. Slots for flights at La Guardia come on the market only infrequently but are worth about $2 million, according to people in the airline business; few new airlines have enough capital on hand to compete with established carriers.
Nobody is quite sure how the Port Authority could constructively change the fee system, because of some unusual complications.
For example, it is not clear whether fees should be based on the size of aircraft. Landing fees have always been based on weight -- at La Guardia, $5 per thousand pounds. The idea is that airplanes should be charged the way trucks and cars are on toll roads and bridges, with the heavier ones paying more to make up for additional wear and tear on the concrete.
That means that a 225-seat Boeing 767, which approaches 400,000 pounds landing weight, pays about 30 times more than a small, twin-engine turboprop, like an 18-seat Jetstream 31, which weighs less than 12,000 pounds.
But the Port Authority points out that small planes actually take more runway time to land, not less. Big planes can land relatively quickly behind one another; small ones have to stay farther back to stay out of the turbulence of a larger plane's engines. And they fly at different speeds, 150 miles per hour or so for big planes and perhaps 100 m.p.h. for smaller ones. So depending on landing order, the larger aircraft sometimes have to be held far behind the small ones to avoid overtaking them.
The new regional jets, which are now so popular, start their takeoff slowly and climb slowly, controllers say, a situation that reduces the airport's capacity. The airport could handle more traffic if the mix of planes were not so complicated, said Leslie Warfield, the representative of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association union at the La Guardia tower.
Small planes "place about one and a half times more burden on the airspace," said William R. DeCota, the Port Authority's director of aviation.
But the trend in aviation is toward more and more small planes that can provide service to small cities, or toward policies that allow an airline to offer five flights a day instead of one to draw more passengers. For La Guardia, that also means more planes.
The argument can be made that the airport should charge a flat fee for each plane, regardless of size, which would encourage the airlines to use bigger planes. Or perhaps airports could charge small planes more than big ones.
The idea is tempting because La Guardia handles 95 percent of its annual passenger load on just 75 percent of the planes flying in and out of it. The other 5 percent of the passengers -- about 600,000 people -- fly on planes that make up 25 percent of the landings and takeoffs.
"It would make enormous sense for the runways," said Peter Samuel, a transportation expert who has written about variable toll rates for the Reason Foundation, a conservative research group. "You're wasting scarce time by bringing in a plane with rather few people in it." Variable pricing, he said, would encourage airlines to make "rational use" of a scarce resource.
But many of the small planes are flown by big airlines, as part of their feeder networks to collect passengers for long-distance flights, and they do not want to reduce the number of flights in the small markets they serve.
Alfred E. Kahn, chairman of the Council on Wage and Price Stability under President Carter and known as the father of airline deregulation, said the pricing system should resemble the one used in "bumping" passengers when flights are overbooked. In that case, the airline offers bonuses to people who will get off the plane and take a later flight, rewarding those who value money more than time. A similar system for the airport, he said, would have "intelligent landing fees," in which airlines pay extra and pass the cost on to passengers through higher fares. Those passengers who really want to go to La Guardia would pay for that privilege, he said.
But no one is certain how high landing fees would have to go to alter airlines' behavior. The total airport costs, including rent for hangars and fuel fees, come to only 3 or 4 percent of operating costs for airlines, Mr. DeCota said.
This does not satisfy the have-nots, however. "We cannot go to a scenario where the deepest pockets control that airport," said Edward P. Faberman, who represents the Air Carrier Association of America, a group of small airlines. Even the Port Authority does not seem ready to cut back too much. "How do you factor in things like how to guarantee service to smaller communities," Mr. DeCota said. "How do you allow new entrants to come in?"
An executive at an airline that has many flights in and out of La Guardia said that to change airline practices, "you're going to have to raise the bar very, very, very high." The airport should run on the basis of "public convenience and necessity," he said, which includes service by small planes to small cities. And the allocation has to include traditional services like the air shuttles to Boston and Washington, he said.
The problem is a collision between physics and economics. La Guardia is so small that all of it, runways included, would just about fit into the terminal area at Kennedy International Airport. There are two long runways of 7,000 feet, but they intersect, which means that even in perfect weather, using both of them turns the air traffic controller into a choreographer of a three-dimensional ballet. And of the top 10 domestic airline routes, 9 are out of New York, so the number of planes that want to come to the region's three major airports is inexhaustible.
Another possibile solution is "congestion pricing," varying price by time, as the Port Authority is now considering for drivers at its Hudson River crossings. (The board had considered simply imposing this, but decided on Dec. 14, given the possibility of widespread anger among drivers, to hold hearings next month. A problem with congestion pricing at La Guardia is that airlines get just as angry as drivers do, and the airlines have more lawyers.)
But La Guardia is now so crowded that there is no hour of the day when there is spare capacity.

HEADLINE: Two Grades, One Record

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
In her seven years as governor of New Jersey, Christie Whitman has been firm about how she wants her approach to the environment to be measured.
Do not tally up the fines paid by industry and do not count the number of new regulations put on the books, she has urged, but do look at the quality of the air and of the water. And watch for a good balance of competing forces. 
 "This great country of ours has the ability and the will to build a more prosperous America while meeting our environmental obligations," Mrs. Whitman said Friday in Austin, Tex., as President-elect George W. Bush announced that she was his choice to lead the Environmental Protection Agency.
In New Jersey, whose most recognizable symbols might well be a factory smokestack and the Jersey Shore, industry and the environment make for particularly powerful political forces. And Mrs. Whitman is fond of saying that her policies often subject her to vitriol from business interests and environmental advocates alike.
"The fact that we're being attacked by both sides leads me to believe that we're probably right where we need to be, which is in the middle, to find some kind of common ground," she said in an interview earlier last week in her office in the State House here.
Mrs. Whitman has been a national leader in land conservation, a bold experimenter in finding ways to combat air pollution, a magnetic spokeswoman for smart-growth strategies to prevent suburban sprawl. Leading business groups praise what they call her balanced approach to environmental issues. But some New Jersey environmentalists say that she is a foe doing a remarkable job of masquerading as a friend, loudly preaching the eco-gospel while hobbling regulatory enforcement efforts, chipping away at pollution-control standards, and supporting controversial development projects in New Jersey's vanishing wetlands and woods.
Her record as governor includes noteworthy clashes between state regulators and the Environmental Protection Agency over wetlands development, clean air and clean water, raising questions about how Mrs. Whitman will guide policy at the federal level.
As she said in Austin, "Having served as governor, I also know what it's like to be on the receiving end of mandates from Washington."
Mrs. Whitman, 54, has dealt with virtually every major environmental issue in her seven years in office: regulatory reform, suburban sprawl, air pollution and water quality.
As a regulator, Mrs. Whitman has valued consensus and cooperation over confrontation, styling her approach after that of the Netherlands, where businesses are given great leeway to arrive at goals for pollution control on their own terms.
"She and I share the same point of view," Mr. Bush said in announcing her selection. "We share a philosophy that moves beyond the old, central command-and-control mind-set that believes Washington has got all the answers."
Mrs. Whitman took office in 1994 and sharply altered the regulatory policy of her predecessor, Jim Florio, a zealous environmental advocate who had written the federal Superfund law while in Congress.
Conservatives in Congress who have long wanted to cut back or eliminate the environmental agency might be cheered by a review of Mrs. Whitman's first term: Frequently blaming the state Department of Environmental Protection for causing job losses, she cut its budget by 30 percent and laid off hundreds of workers. She ordered that state regulations be no more stringent than federal rules. And she cut inspections, eliminated penalties and introduced grace periods for violators, to the point that collections of environmental fines plunged 80 percent.
Adopting the motto "Open for Business," Governor Whitman eliminated the environmental prosecutors Mr. Florio had introduced, and replaced a public advocate's office, which had at times sued the state on behalf of environmental groups, with a business ombudsman's office to guide businesses through the permitting process. And she sought to move away from punitive measures toward voluntary compliance.
"We'd spent an awfully long time with a very negative business environment for manufacturers," said Hal C. Bozarth Jr., spokesman for the Chemical Industry Council of New Jersey. "What she finally did was to bring the pendulum back somewhere in the middle, to balance economic development and environmental protection."
Jeffrey Tittel, director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club, who is perhaps Mrs. Whitman's harshest critic, put it another way. "A month doesn't go by where we don't find there's been a rollback or attempted rollback," he said.
If Governor Whitman is seen by many as more green than brown -- stronger at preserving open space than protecting the air, water and soil from pollution -- it may be because her signal achievement was in conservation: borrowing $1 billion to buy up vulnerable parcels of open space in the nation's most densely populated state.
Critics say it will not be enough money to achieve the governor's goal of preserving a million acres of land, and say that on her watch about 60,000 acres have been lost to development each year. Still, more than 250,000 acres of open space and farmland have been protected since 1994, nearly as much as in the prior three decades combined, officials say.
Governor Whitman has spoken frequently of the need to control growth by steering new development to urban areas, redeveloping old industrial sites and reining in suburban sprawl. Yet her administration has supported two projects that would further cut into New Jersey's remaining wetlands: a 200-acre retail development in the Meadowlands, and an eight-mile highway connector through Middlesex County. The federal Environmental Protection Agency opposes both.
The Whitman administration has also been at the vanguard of interstate and international efforts to reduce air pollution, although attempts to reduce in-state emissions have led to embarrassing failures. New Jersey's environmental protection commissioner, Robert C. Shinn Jr., played a crucial role in persuading the Midwestern states to bear responsibility for the air pollution they were exporting to the East, said Ned Sullivan, who was Maine's top environmental official and now runs Scenic Hudson, an advocacy group in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
"The Midwestern states had never, until then, admitted that their emissions from dirty, coal-fired power plants were causing the pollution and health problems that we experienced in New Jersey, New York and New England," Mr. Sullivan said. "Gaining that consensus, based on an analysis of the science, was the critical achievement."
The multistate agreement led to the E.P.A.'s 1998 order requiring power plants in 22 states to curb such smog-forming pollution, to lawsuits against those power plants filed by New York, New Jersey and other states, and ultimately to settlements such as one announced last week by the Cinergy Corporation, a utility in Cincinnati that said it would clean up 10 electric generating plants in Indiana, Kentucky and Ohio.
Mrs. Whitman's efforts to comply with the federal Clean Air Act in New Jersey, however, gave rise to a managerial disaster. The governor chose to enhance the state's automobile-emissions inspections to detect more pollutants. But the contract was delayed for two years, ran about $100 million over budget, and, when it finally opened in freezing temperatures last year, proved a nightmare of frozen equipment, lines dozens of cars deep, poorly trained workers and the occasional mangled tire. That the contractors included several Republicans with ties to the state Republican party did not help.
On water, Mrs. Whitman's record is one of progressive ideas, but, critics say, wanting in execution.
She won praise for establishing 20 watershed management areas across New Jersey, setting in motion what advocates say could eventually prove an effective way to put limits on new development. But in 1996, the Department of Environmental Protection, putting into place the federal Clean Water Act, proposed a set of rules that critics said would have let hundreds of millions of gallons of carcinogens and other pollutants into the waterways. Dozens of lawmakers objected, advocates sued, and the E.P.A. rejected the rules.
The state is now revising its proposal, but has encountered heated opposition from environmental groups as well as builders.
Mrs. Whitman, of course, asks to be judged not on the regulatory process itself but on its results -- in short, on the quality of New Jersey's water, and of its air. Yet the statistics she chooses to highlight almost always allow for a counterpoint.
On Friday, for example, even as Mrs. Whitman was in Austin, New Jersey's environmental agency released a report on the quality of water in the state's rivers and streams. The report, based on data collected from waterways that flow into the Delaware River in northwest New Jersey, painted a somewhat blurry picture.
The portion of rivers and streams "severely impaired" by pollutants had declined to just 1 percent in 1998 from 5 percent in 1993. But in 1993, 67 percent of the waterways, some of which are used for drinking water, were free of pollution. By 1998, that number had declined to 58 percent.

HEADLINE: Another Tradition: Refuge in a Shelter

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
On the coldest Christmas in more than a decade, the hungry and the homeless began lining up early yesterday for hot meals.
Outside the Y.W.C.A. at the corner of Third and Atlantic Avenues in the Boerum Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn, the temperature was 19 degrees at 10 a.m. and the line of people waiting for the annual Christmas meal stretched around the block. The doors, scheduled to open at 11:30, were opened early; within the first hour and a half, more than 350 people had been served, and by day's end, more than 1,500 -- about 500 more than in years past. 
 Lee Perlman, one of the volunteer organizers of the holiday meal, said he was unsure how to explain the influx: The cold? A deep need belying an age of affluence? Wider publicity that a meal would be served?
That it was cold was irrefutable. Temperatures yesterday produced the coldest Christmas since 1989, based on the high of 27 degrees at midnight Sunday. Based on daytime temperatures, it was the coldest Christmas since 1983.
Todd J. Miner, a meteorologist with Pennsylvania State University, said a high pressure system over the Midwest and low pressure over southeastern Canada were directing cold air south and east from central Canada into the Northeastern states.
The gusty winds -- as high as 46 miles per hour at La Guardia and 48 miles per hour at Kennedy International Airport -- made the air feel even colder. Wind-chill temperatures were well below zero across the metropolitan region yesterday.
With the particularly cold weather, city police officers as well as social workers were operating at a "heightened level of intervention" regarding the homeless, said the city's commissioner of the homeless services, Martin Osterreich. Homeless people in mental or physical distress found on the street would automatically be taken to a city hospital or homeless shelter for evaluation, he said. Otherwise, they would be offered the opportunity to go to a shelter. If they refused and were not in distress, they would be left alone, he said.
The city had about 300 available beds left for single adults on Christmas Day, with another 400 or so emergency beds that could be set up to supplement its capacity of approximately 7,600 beds for single adults, and 18,000 beds for families, Mr. Osterreich said. In addition, the city had about 169 units of housing available for families, translating into about 600 beds.
By 5 p.m., there had been 1,008 complaints about a lack of heat or hot water to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said a spokeswoman, Carol Abrams. On a typical cold winter day, she said, the agency receives about 1,600 calls, a benchmark it seemed likely to surpass yesterday.
For the families going to the Y.W.C.A., the cold was the least of their worries. They had left homeless shelters, single rooms and overcrowded apartments to trudge, halfway across the city in some cases, to fill their stomachs and their children's hopes.
"This year I cannot buy my children nothing," said Constancia Riveria, a 38-year-old mother of four, including 5-year-old twins. "My husband have no job" -- the candy store where he had worked has closed -- "and I have no job." As it is, the family lives in a one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn.
"This year, I really couldn't afford no presents," said Lois Chadwick, 27, a struggling mother of four who had traveled from the Bronx for turkey, stuffing, presents and diapers.
She said she had just received a letter from her welfare caseworker saying her case was being closed because she had missed an appointment. That left her entirely dependent on her children's father for support. She said that she would like to work so she would not have to depend on welfare, but that she had never really learned to read. And she kept having children "back to back."
Lisa Schnell, 33, had arrived from the Bronx, eight children in tow, aged 14 to 1, to try to fill in the gaps at Christmas. Her children's father was unemployed, and they had been homeless for two years, finally resettling in a home of their own recently. "Christmastime is the hardest time, especially with a large family," she said. "The bills."
A 26-year-old single mother said inflation seemed to be diminishing the value of an already meager public assistance check: $87 every two weeks, with her rent paid as well. She said she braided hair to earn money, but as her son, now 5, grew, so did the bills. And, she confessed, she spoiled him with fashionable clothes. "Now I'm stuck."
For many, there was comfort in the numbers -- visible affirmation that many were as hard up as they were -- and the range of ethnicities, ages and family sizes, a reminder that poverty is not an exclusive club.
"I'm not too embarrassed -- there are a lot of people here today," said a 46-year-old woman who nevertheless refused to give her name. She was at the Goddard Riverside Community Center at the corner of Columbus Avenue and 88th Street on the West Side of Manhattan, where the first people had begun arriving for holiday meals at 9 a.m. She and two sons had been in a shelter since September, after relocating from Maryland. With no home and no job, she said, "I think God is testing us."
For Gerald Dupree, 39, who described himself as a former shoplifter and addict now living in a single-room-occupancy hotel, there was comfort in anonymity -- the warmth of strangers preferable to the turmoil of family. "I wanted to go somewhere where I don't know nobody, and they don't know me, but there's unity," he said. He too found comfort, he said, in seeing others who had been dealt a "bad hand."
At 2 p.m., it was 21 degrees, and people were still coming in the center's doors.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
MITCHELL, EDSON V.

 BODY:
MITCHELL-Edson V. Born in Portland, Maine, on May 19, 1953, and grew up in South Portland and Auburn. He attended Edward Little High School, where he met his wife Suzan James. They married on November 11, 1972. Mr. Mitchell graduated from Colby College with distinction in Economics in 1975 and later earned an MBA from Dartmouth's Ames Tuck School. He and his family have resided in Maine, New Hampshire, near Chicago for a short time, and in Northwestern New Jersey and London. Edson Mitchell was head of Global Markets for Deutsche Bank AG, Europe's biggest investment bank, where he directed the powerful global fixed-income business from London and New York. This past June, Mr. Mitchell was one of two Americans ever to be named to the management board of Deutsche Bank AG. Prior to Deutsche Bank AG, he worked for Merrill Lynch and Bank of America's Chicago Branch. Mr. Mitchell served Colby College as an Overseer or Trustee since 1990. He has served on numerous Colby committees, including chairing the Campaign for Colby, the largest capital campaign in the college's history. In 1991, he established a scholarship fund to benefit students from Western Maine. He and his wife Suzan established the Mitchell Family Professorship in Economics and provided one of the three naming gifts for the Anthony-Mitchell-Schupf residence halls. In June, 2000, he was presented with Colby's Distinguished Alumnus Award at his 25th Renunion. Mr. Mitchell was very committed to preserving the natural beauty of Maine while at the same time promoting economic opportunities for the people of the state. He was co-founder of the Rangeley Lakes Heritage Trust, an environmental organization in the Rangeley Lakes region, which has preserved 10,000 acres and is purchasing another 800 acres at Bonney Point. It also offers a summer program for Maine youth called Ecoventure. Each year 250 children have the opportunity to learn about the environment and conservation. Mr. Mitchell was a major shareholder of Keiser Industries, a home manufacturer in Oxford, ME, and Phycogen, a biotech research firm in Falmouth, and was part owner of the Stoneybatter and the Gingerbread House in Oquossoc. He is survived by his wife, Suzan, and five children, Erik, Katie, Becky, Scott and Ellen of Chester, NJ, and Oquossoc, ME, his parents, Edson Jr. and Helen Mitchell of Cape Elizabeth, his brother Glenn of Cumberland, and his sister Karen Villeneuve of Berlin, NH. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM, Tuesday, December 26, at Lorimer Chapel, Colby College, Waterville, ME. For information, contact Adams Funeral Home, Main Street, Phillips, Maine. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rangeley Lakes Heritage Trust, PO Box 249, Oquossoc, ME 04964.

HEADLINE: EN ROUTE: THAILAND;
The Very Pungent Start Of a Most Piquant Sauce

SERIES: Second of three articles on Thai food.

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

DATELINE: SAMUT SONGKHRAM, Thailand

 BODY:
IT was with great curiosity and the tiniest bit of apprehension -- that I walked toward the fermentation building at the Thai Fishsauce Factory in this small village 44 miles southwest of Bangkok. The tropical sun was beating down on the corrugated tin roof. Would heat and dissolving anchovies prove too much for a Westerner, even one who loves fish sauce?
There was no mistaking the aroma. Even people who make fish sauce acknowledge that for the first six months of the process, when the anchovies are still visible in the fermenting mixture of water and salt, they smell pretty bad. 
 "Like old sneakers," said Pass Nithipitikarn, the international marketing manager of the factory, which produces Squid Brand fish sauce. His description is more than generous. He quickly added that "the finished sauce is totally different." And it is. But even at its most intense, the smell doesn't seem to bother the workers, who cheerfully remove chunks of fermented matter from the tanks with their rubber-gloved hands.
Fish sauce is to Thailand and Vietnam what salt is to the West and soy sauce is to China. If it isn't in a Thai dish, a bottle of it is certainly placed nearby, along with sugar and fiery minced peppers, sometimes in vinegar, sometimes naked.
In the United States, fish sauce has joined soy sauce on store shelves. It is used for the most part in Southeast Asian dishes, but more and more American cooks are learning that it adds a mysterious complexity to meats and seafood, vegetables and even fruit, contributing a saltiness that enhances sweetness.
Like Gorgonzola and tofu, which are also fermented, fish sauce is something you are either brought up with or have to get used to. Anyone who is willing to get past the odor that emanates from a bottle when the cap is taken off finds that the aroma dissipates after the sauce is added to food. Like Worcestershire sauce, all that is left behind is an elusive flavor. This is not surprising, since both have anchovies in the brew.
Although fish sauce is linked to Southeast Asia, it also has ancient roots in the Mediterranean. A popular seasoning in ancient Rome was a salty sauce called garum made with layers of fish, salt and herbs. This pungent sauce, borrowed from the Greeks, was highly prized. Martial, the Roman poet, wrote: "Accept this exquisite garum, a precious gift made with the first blood spilled from a living mackerel."
Fermentation was a way to preserve foods before refrigeration and canning. The Asian precursor of fish sauce was a strong-smelling paste made from fish fermented with salt and rice bran or rice powder in a ceramic barrel. The first versions of fish sauce were apparently just the liquid poured or pressed from the paste.
Today, the best fish sauce is the color of pale sherry and fairly clear. As a general rule, Thai nam pla is milder and less pungent than nuoc mam, the version manufactured in Vietnam.
While some connoisseurs insist that fish sauce should contain nothing but fish, salt and water, two of the most popular Thai brands, Tepiros and Squid, are flavored with sugar. Both are available in the United States. In one Bangkok supermarket, I counted 20 brands. Quality varies widely; some even contain additives like MSG.
Fish sauce made in the backyard is fast disappearing in Thailand. "In the old days everyone made their own fish sauce during the cold season using a small fish that came from the river," said Dr. Sisamon Kongpan, deputy dean emeritus of research and development in the home economics department of Rajamangala Institute of Technology in Thailand. "They put it in a big closed amphora out in the sun and filtered the liquid that came off. Then they boiled it with galangal and lemon grass. It's a very ancient method."
Dr. Kongpan said commercial fish sauce has been made for about 70 years. These days it is produced in factories like Squid Brand's, with concrete tanks, assembly lines and employees in white uniforms, maybe even an American-style program for food safety. The factory, which was started by Mr. Nithipitikarn's grandfather 50 years ago, produces more than 24 million bottles a year. The aroma is not offensive, except for those moments when an unseen plume of newly fermenting anchovies blown by some unfelt breeze assaults the nostrils.
Most of the anchovies arrive at the plant in September and October, the end of the rainy season when the fish are most plentiful. The anchovies have already been salted to preserve them; now they are salted again and put in wells with water to cover. The brew stews for 12 to 18 months, producing a concentrated mixture that is then placed in another well with still more salt and water. Fermentation continues for four more months.
Then the liquid is siphoned off through a small blue plastic pipe; as with the first pressing of olive oil, this is the highest quality. Sugar is added and the mixture is filtered. The sauce is then bottled, capped and labeled on an assembly line by workers dressed in white coats, hats and hygienic masks.
A final test is done on sample bottles to check the salt content, the nitrogen level and the color. The higher the nitrogen level, Mr. Nithipitikarn explained, the better the quality of the sauce.
Thai cookbooks describe fish sauce as a good source of protein and B vitamins, especially important in a diet of rice, vegetables and very little meat. But one tablespoon of fish sauce contains only one gram of protein and 1,790 milligrams of sodium.
It takes most Americans years to use up a bottle. But Thais treat fish sauce the way Americans treat ketchup: Mr. Nithipitikarn's family of four adults goes through one bottle a month.
 
THAI SWEET AND SOUR PORK
Time: 30 minutes
2 tablespoons canola oil
1 small red onion, very thinly sliced
12 ounces pork tenderloin, thinly sliced
4 cloves garlic, crushed
1 red bell pepper, seeded and diced
3 large ripe plum tomatoes, quartered and thinly sliced
 1/2 English cucumber, julienned crosswise
1 cup diced fresh pineapple
2 tablespoons fish sauce
1 tablespoon sugar or palm sugar
2 whole scallions, finely sliced
Freshly ground black pepper to taste
Chopped fresh cilantro for garnish
Lime quarters for garnish
Minced hot chilies for garnish.
1. Heat oil in a large nonstick pan over medium-high heat. Saute onion until it softens and colors. Add pork, and brown quickly. Stir in garlic, and saute 30 seconds. Add red pepper, and saute until it begins to soften. Add tomatoes, cucumber and pineapple, and cook a minute or two.
2. Lower heat, and add fish sauce, sugar, scallions and black pepper. Stir well. If mixture seems too thick, add a little water. Sprinkle with cilantro. Serve with lime quarters and chilies.
Yield: 2 servings.

HEADLINE: A Year to Forget for the Japanese Stock Market

BYLINE: By MIKI TANIKAWA 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 26

 BODY:
As new government data raise concern that Japan might be falling back into recession, the country's stock market is becoming both a victim of and a contributor to the economic slowdown.
Japan's key stock market gauge, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks, is down 26 percent for the year, its worst performance since 1992. The index hit a two-year low Thursday, to 13,423, before recovering slightly in the three trading sessions since. It ended today at 14,007.85. 
 Thursday's decline set off widespread concern about the economy and was the top story on many of the country's news programs that night, a rarity in Japan.
With the domestic economy on shaky ground -- witness the latest economic reports showing an increase in the jobless rate and a decline in consumer spending -- the stock market was unnerved last week by the influence of markets overseas, specifically the 7 percent decline in the Nasdaq on Thursday.
The reversal in Japanese stocks came after the Nikkei surpassed the 20,000 mark last spring for the first time in three years.
Suddenly, with high-tech industry no longer able to provide an economic spark plug, Japan's wobbly old-economy industries like retailing, construction and banking looked more problematic, said Kazuhiro Miyake, strategist at Mizuho Securities. "As share prices fell, those areas with lingering problems were spotlighted."
The country's banks are saddled with piles of problem loans from those sectors. And the descending share prices sent banks, which depend on their stock holdings to write off nonperforming loans, into deeper crisis, creating a vicious sell-off, Mr. Miyake said.
One fund manager argued that the reason lenders to Daiei -- the country's largest supermarket chain, but one saddled with 2.4 trillion yen of interest-bearing debt -- have not reached agreement to forgive debt to the retailer or to liquidate it was that stock prices were currently too low.
While some analysts fear that the current situation could create an economic crisis similar to the one in 1997 and 1998, others see some positive underlying fundamentals.
Supported by newspaper reports that the Japanese postal ministry would invest 2 trillion yen each year over the next five years in the stock market, the Nikkei gained more than 500 points on Monday.
Naoya Orime, chief investment officer at Merrill Lynch Investment Managers in Tokyo, said corporate earnings were expected to rise an average of 10 to 15 percent in the next fiscal year.
In addition, the yen has fallen to a 16-month low against the dollar and a 9-month low against the euro.
"Investors haven't fully realized how good the current yen level is for exporters," Tatsuhiko Takura, a general manager at Tokio Marine Asset Management, told Bloomberg News. "Their share prices will start to reflect the benefit as people become more confident in a U.S. rate cut early next year."
And the stock price levels, while low, are not as bad as they seem, said Yoshikazu Takao, managing director at Asahi Life Asset Management.
The Nikkei, which is compiled by Nihon Keizai Shimbun, publisher of a financial daily newspaper, was revised in April, with leading information technology companies like NTT DoCoMo replacing some of the old-economy components.
The Nikkei looks low now partly because the information technology shares have fallen so much. The index would be 2,900 to 3,000 points higher without the revisions, Mr. Takao said.
Whether they see a bigger crisis or not, analysts and investors commonly point to one organization: the Bank of Japan.
The central bank raised interest rates in August by moving the benchmark overnight loan rate from near zero to 0.25 percent, ending the so-called zero-interest rate policy despite calls by economic policy makers to wait. The bank's rate increase "was a main culprit" for the faltering stock market, Mr. Takao said. "It hurt sentiments."
Critics have charged that the Bank of Japan adjusted rates higher to prove its mettle and to show that it will not bow to political pressure.
Since the increase, market liquidity has dried up, contributing to the stock market's fall, Mr. Orime said.
A Bank of Japan governor, Masaru Hayami, said in August that the bank raised rates because deflationary concern had been dispelled, but prices have continued to fall.
