SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 3; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1704 words

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Teeming Mural of a War Fought and Lost

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Steven Soderbergh's great, despairing squall of a film, "Traffic," may be the first Hollywood movie since Robert Altman's "Nashville" to infuse epic cinematic form with jittery new rhythms and a fresh, acid-washed palette.
The agitated pulse of the hand-held camerawork (by the director working under a pseudonym) that roughly elbows its way into the center of the action is perfectly suited to the film's hard-boiled subject, America's losing war on drugs. The color scheme sandwiches a few lush patches between sequences filmed in two hues -- an icy blue and a sun-baked yellow-orange -- that are as visually discordant as the forces doing battle. 
 Where Mr. Altman's masterpiece portrayed American culture as a jostling, twangy carnival of honky-tonk dreams, "Traffic" is a sprawling multicultural jazz symphony of clashing voices sounding variations of the same nagging discontent. The performances (in English and Spanish), by an ensemble from which not a false note issues, have the clarity and force of pithy instrumental solos insistently piercing through a dense cacophony.
The characters run the social gamut, from affluent United States government officials and wealthy drug lords on both sides of the United States border with Mexico and their fat-cat lawyers, to the foot soldiers doggedly toiling in a never-ending drug war.
The most indelible performances belong to Benicio Del Toro as a burly, eagle-eyed Mexican state policeman of pluck and resourcefulness who has the street smarts to wriggle out of almost any squeeze; Michael Douglas, as a conservative Ohio Supreme Court Justice who is appointed the country's new drug czar, and Erika Christensen, as his sullen drug-addicted teenage daughter. Catherine Zeta-Jones is also riveting as a wealthy, ruthless, Southern California matron who is unaware that her husband is a high-level drug smuggler until he is dragged out of their house by federal agents.
The movie, which jumps around from Tijuana to Cincinnati to Washington to San Diego, from a posh Ohio suburb to the inner city to the Mexican desert to the White House itself, offers a coolly scathing overview of the multibillion-dollar drug trade and the largely futile war being waged against it.
But as despairing as it is, "Traffic" is not cynical. It gives its isolated heroes in the trenches their due. One of these is Javier Rodriguez (Mr. Del Toro), a wily, good-hearted Mexican policeman who conspires with the Drug Enforcement Administration to bring down his own boss (Tomas Milian), a corrupt Mexican general who uses torture to get his way. Other heroes include a pair of D.E.A. undercover agents, Montel Gordon (Don Cheadle) and Ray Castro (Luis Guzman), who spend half their lives in cramped vans engaged in surveillance.
"Traffic" is an updated, Americanized version of a 1989 British television mini-series, "Traffik," that followed the drug trade from Pakistan to Britain. From an ambiguous, paranoically-charged opening desert sequence (reminiscent of the crop-dusting scene in "North by Northwest"), in which Javier and his partner, Manolo (Jacob Vargas), surrender a newly captured truckload of cocaine to the corrupt general, to a late scene in which an American agent risks his life to plant a bug in a dealer's mansion, "Traffic" is an utterly gripping, edge-of-your-seat thriller. Or rather it is several interwoven thrillers, each with its own tense rhythm and explosive payoff.
What these stories add up to is something grander and deeper than a virtuosic adventure film.
"Traffic" is a tragic cinematic mural of a war being fought and lost. That failure, the movie suggests, has a lot to do with greed and economic inequity (third world drug cartels have endless financial resources to fight back). But the ultimate culprit, the movie implies, is human nature. Waging a war against drugs isn't just a matter of combating corruption but of eradicating the basic human desire to "take the edge off," as Mr. Douglas's character, Robert Wakefield, says in defense of his nightly drink of Scotch. "Otherwise, I'd be dying of boredom," he adds.
"Traffic" is no friend of the government. When Wakefield returns from Washington, where he has been briefed by the president's chief of staff (Albert Finney) and other major Beltway players in the war, he describes the experience to his wife, Barbara (Amy Irving), and daughter, Caroline (Ms. Christensen), as like being "in Calcutta, surrounded by beggars wearing $1,500 suits who don't say 'please' and 'thank you.' "
While Wakefield is exploring this new turf, Caroline is rapidly succumbing to crack addiction under the tutelage of her cynical boyfriend, Seth (Topher Grace), her classmate at the exclusive Cincinnati Country Day School and as a scary a contemporary teenager as you're likely find in a recent movie. A high achiever who is sullen and angry beneath her preppy glass, Caroline quickly plummets to the bottom. Early scenes of her stoned friends sprawled around a fancy living room, drinking, sniffing cocaine and mumbling fuzzily about their discontents offer a devastating vision of youthful suburban ennui.
The movie does not shy away from portraying the pleasure of drugs, and Caroline's initiation into free-base cocaine by Seth is a voluptuous rush. Her head rolls back, and tears of joy trickle from her eyes as Seth repeats in a soothing voice, "You see? You see?" before making love to her. From that moment, Caroline is hooked, and she becomes a glazed-eyed baby-faced demon whose precipitous fall lands her in a seedy hotel under the thumb of the drug-dealing pimp who introduced her to heroin. As Wakefield tries desperately to wrest her from the gutter, this strand of the movie threatens to turn into a Charles Bronson-like vigilante drama. But the acting is so powerful that the scenes have documentary crediblity.
A parallel strain of the demonic runs through the story of Helena Ayala (Ms. Zeta-Jones), whose comfortable world begins falling apart the moment her drug-dealing husband, Carlos (Steven Bauer), is arrested. Six months pregnant and the mother of a young son, she finds herself a social outcast, her finances frozen, her son's life threatened by Carlos's creditors. "I want my old life back," she declares furiously to her husband over a prison telephone. Then, with coldblooded determination, she sets about getting it back by any means necessary.
Her key to getting it back lies in forestalling the testimony of Eduardo Ruiz (Miguel Ferrer), a midlevel drug dealer busted by Montel and Ray who is being held in protective custody as the key witness in Carlos's trial. A harsh realist who knows his chances of survival aren't great, Eduardo bitterly scoffs at his captors for "knowing the futility of what you're doing and doing it anyway," and his words resound through the movie. The film's most exciting scenes demonstrate the efficiency of the drug cartels at penetrating the most heavily guarded inner sanctum.
If "Traffic" illustrates how the underfunded, red-tape-bound good guys are no match against the enemy's superior resources, what makes the film more than a powerful thriller is its unflinching contemplation of human frailty. From Helena's take-no-prisoners schemes to stay rich, to a hired assassin tracked down in a gay bar and seduced into a trap, to Carlos's two-faced lawyer (Dennis Quaid), who is tempted to steal from his boss while he is behind bars, the film understands the sheer, brutal force of human desire.
A theme that percolates throughout Stephen Gaghan's screenplay is a reflection on addiction and dependence. From Wakefield's nightly Scotch, to the two glasses of red wine Helena recommends to her friends over lunch at a fancy La Jolla restaurant, to Ray's chain smoking, to the druggy past of Wakefield's wife (was it experimentation or something more?), "Traffic" poses unanswerable questions about selfmedication, pleasure, dependency and addiction. One character, who early in the movie invokes the slogan "In vino veritas" while plying a paid assassin with red wine to coax information out of him, later commits suicide by injecting heroin.
In the end, Wakefield, exhausted and demoralized after all he has been through, delivers the White House address he's been instructed to prepare in a weary, halfhearted voice, mumbling words like "courage," "perseverance" and "new ideas" before announcing a new "10-point plan." But as we've been shown, there are no new ideas. Wakefield's speech ring hollow until the moment he pauses and wonders out loud, How can you wage a war against your own family?
That family, "Traffic" implies, is not just his own drug-addicted daughter but also a culture devoted to instant gratification and quick-fix pain relief. The drugs, after all, don't flow out from the United States into the third world, they flow in. For this is a culture in which, at the end of the day, millions of people, just like Wakefield, find themselves "dying of boredom."
"Traffic" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has scenes of violence (including torture), sexual situations and the preparation of free-base cocaine and drug injection.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Power's Future

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The improved performance of American nuclear reactors in the 1990's is a result of concerted efforts to learn from experience and correct weaknesses in existing reactors (news article, Dec. 20). 
 Next-generation reactors embody major further improvements, featuring advanced safety features and economy. Two such reactors are operating in Japan and could be ordered here, public attitudes permitting. New reactors may or may not win out in a simple price competition, but they make sense if we attach a proper value to reducing emissions of pollutants, our dependence on energy imports and our vulnerability to oil and natural gas price rises.
A forward-looking energy policy should emphasize conservation, renewable sources and nuclear power.
 
DAVID BODANSKY
Seattle, Dec. 21, 2000
 
The writer is emeritus professor of physics, University of Washington.

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 730 words

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
We're Not Japan

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
When Lucy tells Charlie Brown that this time she really is going to let him kick that football, you know what's going to happen. When Wile E. Coyote insists that this time he really is going to catch the Road Runner, you know what's going to happen. And when Japanese officials tell you that this time their nation really is on the road to self-sustaining recovery . . .
A new clutch of indicators confirms that, sure enough, Japan's economy is stalling yet again. Business confidence has gone flat, consumer spending is falling, unemployment is rising, deflation is accelerating. And the Nikkei stock index, which was over 20,000 earlier this year, is now oscillating around 14,000. 
 For Japan, it's the same old story. But with the U.S. economy going through its roughest patch in years, with panicky analysts and self-interested politicians declaring that the sky is falling, maybe it's worth explaining why our story remains very different.
You see, the general rule -- the rule to which Japan is the great exception -- is that recessions are not a serious problem for large, modern economies. It's not that the forces that cause recessions have been abolished -- though every long expansion brings foolish proclamations of the end of business cycles. Rather, the point is that recessionary tendencies can usually be effectively treated with cheap, over-the-counter medication: cut interest rates a couple of percentage points, provide plenty of liquidity, and call me in the morning.
Or more accurately, call me in six months -- or maybe as much as a year. Experience suggests that the Fed can almost always persuade consumers and businesses to spend more by cutting interest rates, but that there's a longish lag between the rate cut and the spending increase. And that's why we're still vulnerable to recessions: now and then the Fed gets behind the curve, failing to recognize a weakening economy until it's too late to prevent a slump. That's what happened in 1990; it may be what's happening now.
Specifically, it's now pretty clear that the Fed went an interest rate hike too far -- that while it was right to raise rates in late 1999 and early 2000 to cool off a red-hot economy, that last half-percentage-point increase in May was overkill. Of course, I'm talking with the benefit of hindsight; it seemed like a good idea at the time.
The Fed can and almost surely will reverse that rate hike sometime soon, but the favorable effects of that reversal on spending will take time to materialize. Meanwhile the economy will slow, and could shrink for a couple of quarters, which is the technical definition of a recession. But it should be only a temporary setback -- which brings us to the difference between ourselves and Japan.
In Japan, the sky really is falling. Because the interest rate is already very close to zero (it isn't quite zero, because of the Bank of Japan's foolish decision to raise rates back in August -- but don't get me started), the slowdown is a sign that the nation's basic economic policies aren't working, and that it is long past time to do something radical. By contrast, our slowdown is just one of those things that happen now and then; it doesn't indicate any fundamental flaws in our economic policy, any need to do anything except cut interest rates.
So what should we be afraid of? The nightmare scenario, which cannot be completely ruled out, is that we will turn out to be more like Japan than we think -- that we have just gone through our own version of the infamous "bubble economy," and that we are about to find out that this time cutting interest rates won't do the trick. But at this point that scenario isn't very plausible.
What worries me is not the recession that we may or may not be about to experience; it is the way that our politicians are likely to react to that slowdown. Will they use a mild, easily treated ailment as an excuse to force expensive, dangerous quack remedies down the nation's throat? I am, of course, talking about tax cuts -- which won't cure the short-term slowdown, and will undermine our long-run fiscal health.
We don't need to fear a recession; if it does happen, it's something that the Fed can easily cure. What we do need to fear is fear itself: the all-too-likely prospect that the threat of recession will panic us into doing things we will regret for years to come. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: JAPAN (96%); UNITED STATES (92%); 

COMPANY: FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM (59%); FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM (59%);

HEADLINE: Management -- Wanted: One C.E.O., Ready to Work;
Long Boom and a Shortage Of Top Executive Talent Fuel Growth of Recruiters

BYLINE: By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
The departure of a key manager can create consternation at any corporation, but Michael Sternklar, a principal at the Unifi Networks unit of PricewaterhouseCoopers, knew what to do when it happened to him.
The manager, who had been working closely with a client who paid millions of dollars annually to Unifi, left its Fort Lee, N.J., office last May. Mr. Sternklar did not even think about trying to find a replacement on his own. Instead, he put out an emergency appeal to William Kelly, president of Kelly & Company, a boutique executive search firm that had a continuing relationship with Unifi. 
 "There might be 20 people in the whole United States" who could do the job Mr. Sternklar remembers thinking, and there was no way he could track them all down. "I needed one, and I needed one quickly."
He got one, too. Ed Davey, with more than 20 years of experience in human resources management, accepted an offer to work at Unifi in August.
The predicament Mr. Sternklar faced then is one that more and more companies are finding themselves in these days, as the longest economic expansion in American history coincides with a worsening shortage of management talent. But their quandary is gravy for executive search firms like Kelly.
For all the publicity surrounding the explosion of Internet start-ups and other high-technology concerns, the executive-recruiting industry has been quietly registering double-digit growth every year since 1992, according to Kennedy Information, a firm in Fitzwilliam, N.H., that publishes The Executive Recruiter News.
Recruiters at the smaller, privately held search firms that dominate the industry say their revenues have risen between 30 and 50 percent just over the last two years. At Heidrick & Struggles, one of very few publicly held search firms, revenue has nearly quadrupled since 1995, from $114 million to $415 million in 1999. At Korn/Ferry International, another public company, revenue has more than doubled from $218 million in the fiscal year ended April 30, 1996, to $501 million in the period ended last April.
Joseph Daniel McCool, editor of The Executive Recruiter News, estimates that between 300 and 400 new firms sprang up in 1998 and 1999 alone, bringing the total to more than 5,000. The Internet job-posting site Monster.com, a unit of TMP Worldwide, joined the fray in September with ChiefMonster.com. "There's really no barrier to entry in this business," Mr. McCool said.
The boom is fueled by an old-fashioned supply shortage -- in this case, of people. As older managers retire or defect to rivals or high-technology start-ups, companies are scrambling to lure talent to fill their shoes. And because corporate profits have been rising and the price of technology falling in recent years, they have the cash to do it.
The trend also reflects investors' willingness to spend whatever it takes to hire the people who can achieve good financial results, as well as their decreasing tolerance of anyone who does not.
"Companies have realized in recent years that their key strategic weapon is their people," Mr. McCool said. "What that has led to is companies are willing to pay more for their best people."
The average compensation for chief executives soared throughout the 1990's, for example, rising 23 percent in 1999 alone, to $11.9 million. Recruiters generally are paid one-third of a hired executive's first-year pay package by the prospective employer, so they share in the bounty.
In addition, the willingness of corporate boards to dismiss people who fall below expectations and promote those who exceed them has created a high-stakes game of musical chairs, with executive search firms a big part of the action.
"These are halcyon days for headhunters," said Alan Neely, managing director of the North American advanced technology practice for Korn/Ferry, which focuses on searches for very senior executives. "The war for talent is really raging," and companies are increasingly turning to search firms for help, he added. "It is truly a boom."
Mr. Neely led a Korn/Ferry team to find a new chief financial officer for the company formed from the merger of EarthLink and MindSpring early this year. That search was incredibly high-pressured, because the new entity -- the current EarthLink -- needed to have a the executive in place before the merger was consummated early in February.
"You don't want to be without a C.F.O.," said Garry Betty, EarthLink's chief executive. "The financial markets don't like that."
Finding a new chief financial officer was necessary, though, because the combined company was going to be significantly larger -- too large for either company's previous chief financial officer to handle, he said. After the merger, EarthLink would have roughly $1 billion in annual revenue, compared with $350 million for MindSpring alone and $650 million for premerger EarthLink.
EarthLink authorized Korn/Ferry to begin searching last December, and Mr. Neely's team proceeded to search the company's databases and reports on publicly traded companies. Then members of the three-person team called potential candidates and described the position to them to see whether any were interested.
Fortunately, the combination of EarthLink and MindSpring was very appealing to the candidates because both companies had good reputations, Mr. Neely said. "That obviously affected the speed of the search," he said.
Last Dec. 22, Korn/Ferry presented the resumes of 13 interested candidates for review by MindSpring's chief executive, its largest investor and Mr. Betty.
"It's very unusual to have that many candidates that quickly, but let me tell you, they were in such a rush that we absolutely had to focus," Mr. Neely said.
Among the resumes was that of Lee Adrean, chief financial officer at the First Data Corporation. Mr. Adrean was ideal in many ways: First Data was a large company, with more than $5.5 billion in revenue, which meant that Mr. Adrean had experience both in working with a big company and dealing with investors.
First Data was based in Atlanta, so that it would be easy to set up interviews at EarthLink's offices -- also in Atlanta -- on short notice. Based on his resume, EarthLink and MindSpring told Korn/Ferry to pursue Mr. Adrean, along with a few other candidates.
Although Mr. Adrean was not actively looking to leave First Data, he was worried that the company was planning to shift some operations to Denver. "I didn't feel that was something we wanted to do," he said. This was an important factor in his willingness to talk with Korn/Ferry initially and with EarthLink later.
Mr. Neely's team met with Mr. Adrean in person after Christmas, and by the end of the first week in January he had met with Mr. Betty. The two men clicked.
"Garry and I established a great rapport," recalled Mr. Adrean. "We had a great conversation about the business, what he thought the challenges were."
That rapport was critical to his decision to take the job, he added. "At senior levels, success or failure is more a question of management chemistry," he said. "I like the management team here."
This was a very speedy recruiting mission. Mr. Adrean formally accepted the position at the end of January and joined EarthLink early in March.
"The search was done in essentially four weeks," Mr. Neely said. "Usually a search will take 90 to 100 days."
And finding Mr. Adrean would have been very difficult without the help of the recruiters, Mr. Betty said. "On our own, we would've never gotten to be considered by as many candidates," he said. "I was frankly quite pleased."
EarthLink was fortunate. It is not a simple thing to find candidates who fit in well with employers, and often takes a good deal more time than Korn/Ferry had to find Mr. Adrean.
"There's not a lot of people out there that might meet a company's expectations," said Mr. McCool of The Executive Recruiter News.
It is also difficult to match a potential recruit to an employer. "There might be positions out there that only 100 people are eligible for," Mr. McCool said. "Then you consider how many are mobile, how many would fit into the firm culture -- then that number gets into the single digits."
More and more often the process is complicated by the aversion of the next generation of executives to sacrificing quality of life to further their careers, said Mr. Kelly of Kelly & Company.
"I can put as much money on the table as I want, but I can't get people to stay until 7 o'clock," he said, "There are fewer younger people who are willing to forgo everything for a career."
Another reason for the scarcity of desirable executives is the aging of the baby-boom generation, Mr. Kelly said. With fewer experienced executives to choose from, searches may go unfilled, he added.
"We continue to lose searches to counteroffers," which used to be relatively rare, he said.
"Companies will do more to keep their best people," Mr. Kelly added. "That has more to do with demographics than anything else."
Fiercer competition to recruit experienced managers has meant that searches for executives take longer, on average four months now, instead of three in recent years.
Successful recruiting requires constant attention to who is doing what in a particular industry and how well the executive is doing it, say consultants. When a client company calls seeking a qualified executive, usually the recruiters already know the client firm and what kind of people have done well there, according to Kelvin Thompson, a senior partner at Heidrick & Struggles.
Normally, in a search that is less time-pressured than EarthLink's, the client and the recruiter determine the characteristics of a good replacement executive and figure out where such an executive might be found, he said. "We work with the client to identify target organizations, target companies, which are impressive and have been through some of the same changes," Mr. Thompson said.
Then it's a question of talking to people at those companies, trying to figure out whether they can thrive at the client company, and determining their willingness to jump ship, he said.
Maintaining the databases full of biographical information and also keeping up personal relationships with talented managers can be expensive and time-consuming. That has already led to some degree of consolidation in the industry and will likely lead to more as economic growth slows, according to Mr. McCool.
Still, a downturn will not affect the recruiters for several months, he said. "A lot of firms are still playing catch-up in terms of trying to find the kind of talent that they want," he said. "The executive recruiters won't feel the pain as quickly as their clients."

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Is Sought By Bradlees

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The discount retailer Bradlees said yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection after exploring several options to change its financial outlook, including a possible sale of the company.
 Bradlees, which is based in Braintree, Mass., said an "orderly wind-down of operations" would allow it to maximize its value. The process is beginning this week, the company said. 
 Pending the bankruptcy court's approval, the company said it had reached an agreement to sell its inventory to a group led by Gordon Brothers Retail Partners of Boston. Bradlees said it expected to retain store associates through this process.
 In its petition for bankruptcy protection, Bradlees cited a general economic downturn, including rising interest rates and higher gas and heating oil prices, as reasons for its financial trouble. It added other problems included new competition, unseasonable weather in the first half of 2000, and more recently, the tightening of trade credit and curtailment of inventory shipments.
 Bradlees operates 105 stores and three distribution centers in Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Hampshire, Maine, New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
Bradlees was founded in New London, Conn., in 1958. It went public in 1992 and emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February 1999.
Shares of Bradlees were unchanged yesterday at 22 cents.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
International Shipping Company to Follow Port to New Jersey

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
When the Port of New York was actually in New York, there was a good reason for D. F. Young Inc. to be in Lower Manhattan. The company, a freight forwarder and customs broker, had to be near shipping operations and financial institutions to exchange documents and coordinate cargo movements.
But all that remains of the once-bustling docks on the West Side of Manhattan are huge old buildings like the former Port Authority Commerce Building at 111 Eighth Avenue and the Starrett-Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street, which have shed their industrial past and are becoming the home of telecommunications companies and fashionable offices. 
 The introduction of container shipping moved the port's cargo operations to New Jersey, where land was available to handle and store the bulky containers and there was a land connection with the rest of the United States.
Now, after more than 97 years downtown, most recently at 17 Battery Place, D. F. Young is moving to New Jersey as well. It has recently agreed to lease 14,000 square feet at 1 Journal Square in Jersey City. It is scheduled to relocate early next year and to occupy the entire second floor of the building.
While much of the attention on the migration to New Jersey has been focused on big financial industry companies that have leased shiny new buildings on the Hudson River, the D. F. Young decision shows that smaller companies are moving as well, in this case to a smaller building set well back from the water's edge.
"With the new technology, there was no need to be physically near other companies, so why pay the rents downtown?" asked Gregory L. Collins, a managing director of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage firm that specializes in representing tenants. He said the annual rent per square foot in the old location probably would have been in the $37 to $44 range, while in New Jersey the rent is in the high $20's per square foot.
"When this company was started in 1903, all the shipping companies and banks were all in the bottom of Manhattan," said Thomas Mosimann, the president of D. F. Young. "But the port has moved and most of the other forwarders have followed it to New Jersey over the last 10 to 15 years. We are just following them."
Because many of the downtown buildings were built in the early part of the century, they are typically riddled with interior columns and are not as efficient in their space utilization as newer designs. Mr. Collins said the 1 Journal Square building has a central core and very few interior columns, making it possible to house D. F. Young's 100-member staff in half the space it was renting at 17 Battery Place.
"That is a huge savings," Mr. Collins said.
He said the space devoted to elevators, stairwells and other uses not suitable for offices -- known as the loss factor -- typically runs between 11 and 17 percent in modern suburban office buildings.
"In the city you are talking multiples of that," he said. "We have a stock of old buildings downtown where you have to play hide and seek with columns as you lay out offices."
Mr. Collins said that because many of D. F. Young's employees already live in New Jersey, the relocation of the office, which will serve as the firm's global headquarters as well as the hub of its New York area operations, will ease their commutes. Both surface and in-building parking are available at the site.
Nor need the workers sever their links to the city. If they want to shop at a favorite store in Manhattan or go to a restaurant for lunch, the Journal Square PATH station is a block away, the trip on the underground railway only a few minutes from downtown.
Adding to the economic attractiveness of the move to Jersey City, Mr. Collins said, was the array of state and municipal incentives offered to companies that bring jobs with them. Because Jersey City is an urban renewal zone, the incentives are sweeter than in more prosperous areas.
As a result, Mr. Collins said, D. F. Young will not have to pay sales tax on things bought to improve the new space, funds are available for training workers and there is even assistance with moving costs.
"You can get $1 to $1.50 a square foot credit for moving costs," he said. "That is pretty rare today, but New Jersey will do it." He said the credits and abatements are important to a company in a competitive business, because they lower operating costs. The net effect is that the company is getting its space at a below-market rate.
"New Jersey's incentives are very attractive," Mr. Mosimann said.
The floor of the building to be occupied by D. F. Young was previously occupied by medical offices, but Mr. Collins said the owner, Journal Square Plaza Urban Renewal Associates, was willing to do the conversion to conventional offices for the right tenant.
"Because of the way the space was built out, I think there were limited inquiries for it," he said. But with the new lease, he said, the building will be fully occupied.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Williams Leads 3 Suppliers Of Natural Gas To Large Gains

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Forget nitrous oxide. Natural gas has Wall Street giddy these days.
Investors snapped up shares in natural gas companies yesterday after Williams, a gas trader and pipeline operator, said its fourth-quarter profit would "substantially exceed" analysts' estimates of 17 cents a share. Williams, which operates 27,000 miles of gas pipelines nationwide, said its extra profit would come mostly from trading. 
 The announcement lifted shares of Williams $4.56, or 13.9 percent, to $37.44, and other major gas companies also gained. El Paso Energy, another major pipeline operator, rose $4.06 to $71.88, and Enron, the world's largest natural gas trader, rose $2.31, to $83.50.
Word of higher profits for gas companies may anger consumers, who are facing soaring energy bills this winter. Natural gas prices have quadrupled since last winter, to about $10 per million British thermal units, the standard measurement. But with gas supplies tight, prices appear unlikely to drop soon, analysts say.
An unexpectedly cold winter has caused gas supplies in storage to drop 23 percent from their mid-December average of the last five years, according to the American Gas Association's report for the week ended Dec. 15. And with cold weather continuing throughout the East and Midwest, the most pessimistic analysts now think it is possible the United States will run out of gas in storage by the end of the winter heating season. That could lead to severe price spikes because stored gas accounts for about 20 percent of all gas used during the winter and as much as half the gas used on peak heating days in the East and Midwest.
"We're going to be at record low levels if winter continues," said Donato J. Eassey, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. In addition, with most new electricity plants built to run on gas, demand for the fuel is rising year-round, so gas supplies will probably not be replenished as quickly next summer as they have been in years past, Mr. Eassey said. Reflecting that concern, prices for gas to be delivered next summer stand at more than $5 per million British thermal units, compared with less than $2.50 in summer 1999.
But what is bad for consumers has proved to be very, very good for investors in major gas companies in 2000. While the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has fallen 10 percent this year, Enron has risen 88 percent, El Paso is up 85 percent and Dynegy has more than tripled.
The conspicuous exception has been Williams, which was up only 7 percent for the year before its gain yesterday. Analysts said investors had punished Williams because it owns 85 percent of Williams Communications, which is building a nationwide fiber optic network next to Williams's gas pipelines. With Wall Street concerned about a glut in communications capacity, Williams stock has fallen almost one-quarter from its March high of $49.75.
As a result, Williams is significantly cheaper than its peers, even after today's run-up, Mr. Eassey said. Williams was expected to earn $1.28 a share this year before yesterday's announcement. But that figure has been depressed by substantial losses from Williams Communications, which Williams said in November that it would spin off to shareholders in "the first part" of 2001. Factoring out those losses, Mr. Eassey estimated last week that Williams would earn $1.96 a share this year and $1.65 in 2001.
Williams looks even cheaper, considering that Williams Communications, which is publicly traded, has a market value of roughly $5.7 billion, or $13 a Williams share, Mr. Eassey said. Factor out the value of Williams Communications, and the core Williams gas business trades at only 12 times 2000 earnings, compared with more than 40 times earnings for Dynegy and almost 60 times earnings for Enron.
"I like Williams because it's just flat out of favor," Mr. Eassey said.
While prices may fall this spring, Williams and other gas companies are likely to continue to prosper in the long run, said David Kiefer, portfolio manager of the $4.5 billion Prudential Utilities mutual fund, which has risen 33 percent this year. "We have enough for the next five to seven years, but if we don't start finding as much as we're using, we're not going to keep pace with the growth of the economy," he said.

HEADLINE: In 'the Other California,' A Land Rush Continues

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: TRACY, Calif.

 BODY:
They are the Tom Joads of the new economy. At dawn, they form a serpentine chain of red brake lights in the darkness as they head west over the Altamont Pass, the undulating hills, often shrouded in fog at this time of year, that separate the Great Central Valley from the San Francisco Bay region.
Locally they are called BAT's, Bay Area transplants, long-haul commuters who in the past 20 years have changed the face of this agricultural community. Tracy, about 60 miles east of San Francisco, was founded in 1878 by the Central Pacific Railroad, and has grown to 55,000 residents since 1980 from 18,000. 
 Ninety percent of the new homes here are bought by commuters, said Michael Locke, former Tracy city manager and president of the San Joaquin Partnership, a private economic development group. Collectively, the commuters are transforming new "premium developments" with names like Hidden Lake, Heartland and Countryside into ghost neighborhoods that empty each workday morning.
"You don't question it -- you just do it," said Yolisma Garcia, 44, a divorced mother of four who grew up as a migrant farm worker and now commutes four days a week, telecommuting on Fridays, to her job as a program systems manager for Sun Microsystems Inc.
Ms. Garcia takes the 4:54 a.m. Altamont Commuter Express train to Santa Clara, in Silicon Valley, where the last three cars, some bearing alarm clocks, are kept dimly lit for "sleepers."
The average length of a one-way commute over the pass is 58.3 miles, according to a recent survey co sponsored by the San Joaquin group. The extreme distances to work are spurred by housing prices that fan out like aftershocks from the epicenter -- Silicon Valley and San Francisco. In San Carlos, for instance, in Silicon Valley, where the median home price is $680,000, the mayor recently said he was leaving because he could not afford a home. Every mile east of San Francisco roughly equals a $5,000 reduction in housing costs, Mr. Locke said. The median price in Tracy is $225,000; in Manteca, 15 miles farther east, it is $161,000.
"I look at it as I'm paying myself half a million to commute," said Jeff Essex, 28, who recently moved from Sausalito, across the Golden Gate Bridge, to Patterson, 15 miles south of Tracy, where he commutes via the commuter train to Sunnyvale.
"The Central Valley was always 'the other California,' isolated and distinct," said Carol Whiteside, president of the Great Valley Center, a public-policy organization in Modesto. "Tracy is the intersection where two worlds collide."
By the time Alison Kong-Holtzclaw, a research technician with a medical device company, loads her three sleeping children into her minivan at 5:20 a.m. to take them to day care, her husband, Stephen, has been on the road for an hour, commuting two and a half hours to Menlo Park. By 5:55 a.m., Ms. Kong-Holtzclaw is joining thousands of fellow commuters in the hundred-mile-plus round-trip trek "over the hill" to Fremont and points west and south. She dreams of "continuous sleep," of becoming a stay-at-home mom like so many women she knows in Tracy.
Nancy Vasquez, 40, had been living in Gilroy, 20 minutes from her job, where the family could afford only a small apartment. Now she travels 160 miles a day from Tracy to her job as a harvester for a garlic company.
"I would go by the big houses, especially at Christmastime, and I was always wondering what was inside," Ms. Vasquez said. "Now, I'm in one."
The Tracy she inhabits is ringed by developers' flags and newly landscaped boulevards, where the promise of a four-bedroom house with a pool for $829 a month, "a place big enough for us all to relax," in Ms. Garcia's words, is worth the trek.
The new Tracy, with its spacious houses with tiled courtyards, leaves some old-timers grousing. The old Tracy was rooted in tomatoes, dry beans, sugar beets, walnuts, almonds and apricots. About 500,000 tons of tomatoes were processed annually here by the H. J. Heinz Company until the plant closed two years ago.
"You could tell when it was going to rain, because the wind from the southeast brought the smell of vinegar," said Sam Matthews, publisher emeritus of The Tracy Press, a daily.
The city, which has a Dry Bean Festival each summer with a pinto bean mascot, planned for and courted commuters, though residents recently passed Measure A, an initiative that will limit development in the city to 600 new houses a year. The people who work in Tracy itself, versus "over the hill," cannot afford his-and-her walk-in showers. Most of them live east, too.
The average income in Tracy is now $45,000 to $48,000, compared with $35,000 for San Joaquin County at large, said Mr. Locke of the San Joaquin Partnership. The new Tracy residents have made it possible for the city to sustain new restaurants and a new mall by Interstate 205.
But the tenor of life is changing, symbolized by the closing of the Moose Lodge and some Lions clubs.
"Before you kind of had an idea of who people were and what the makeup of the community was," Mr. Matthews said. "A lot of old-timers still get nervous about the form the city has taken. You go through these new subdivisions and you kind of wonder who they are."
David Bafford, a construction manager, recently quit a job in Foster City, in Silicon Valley, because it required him to leave his house at 4 a.m. Now he commutes only two hours one way.
"I figured out I spent 2,048 hours working last year," Mr. Bafford said with barely concealed disgust. "I spent 1,100 hours commuting. I spent 608 with my family. I spent twice as much time driving as with my kids."
At Merrill F. West High School, Kathy Burrow, a counselor, orients an average of 13 new students a week. Dr. Keith R. Larick, superintendent of the Tracy Unified School District, added, "We laughingly refer to Tracy as U-Haul City."
Although Tracy's relatively lower housing prices have financially liberated some dual-income couples, allowing one parent to stay home with the children, the city's schools are increasingly responding to long commutes. The district just started a program called "parent connect," which gives parents computer access to attendance, tardiness and whether homework was turned in period by period. Parent conferences are scheduled through 8 p.m.
"The parents are under such high stress that at times the last thing they want to hear is that something is wrong at school," Dr. Larick said. "We see a big increase in anger in parents, like road rage. They're just worn out."
David Schroeder, a clinical psychologist with a managed-care program in Modesto, sees a growing number of burnout cases in Bay Area transplants.
"They're very excited at first, because they come out here and can live like a king," Dr. Schroeder said. "They know they can do it. Then they do the commute, with the added three to four hours, for one or two years."
Then, he said, the stress surfaces -- in increased alcohol or drug abuse, especially stimulants; sleep disorders; sleeping pills; and auto accidents. Some adapt by carpooling, or taking the train, or spending some nights closer to work.
"It's a treadmill," Dr. Schroeder said. "Some families can tolerate it, some can't."
Young people like Sarah Jobin, and her stepsister, Natasha Mears, both 15, who are dropped off at Merrill F. West High School at 5:45 a.m., learn to adapt. They huddle together singing the national anthem, waiting for sunrise.
Sarah was skipping school regularly until recently, when she switched high schools. "We never ask to go anywhere, because it's noticeable our parents get up early and home late," she said. "Five days a week they're exhausted and everybody's mad."
Both girls live for Sunday, Sarah said, "the only day we're calm and mellow and together."
From his 1,200-acre farm, David Cordes, 54, can hear the drone on Interstates 205 and 580 and see the train, filled with commuters, wending its way through the pass. It is the land his great-great-grandfather homesteaded 131 years ago, the land he has worked on since age 3.
"Back then, you could look at Tracy and it was a dot of light," Mr. Cordes said. "A little spot between two water tanks."
The old Lammersville school sits on Mr. Cordes's property, a one-room schoolhouse that opened in 1878. It will soon be transported to a park beside a subdivision.
Mr. Cordes recently sold his land to developers, who plan to build an 830-acre high-tech industrial park. He is moving with his family to the Nebraska Sand Hills, where they will continue to farm, the one place he figures there will be no commuters.
Often these days, Mr. Cordes finds himself thinking of something his father told him 35 years ago, something he did not believe at the time.
"My dad said, 'Someday people will come over the hill and this will all be the Bay Area,' " Mr. Cordes recalled. "He said, "I won't see it. But you will.' "

HEADLINE: Specter of Cancer Haunts a School;
Industrial City of Elmira Confronts Environmental Legacy

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

DATELINE: ELMIRA, N.Y.

 BODY:
Years ago they drew little notice, the pond that never freezes, the rainbow of colors glinting off the surface of a creek, the hard-to-pronounce chemicals sprayed, painted and, yes, sometimes spilled around the mile-long stretch of factories on the south side of town.
This small Southern Tier city, which promotes itself as the gateway to the Finger Lakes and the place where Mark Twain wrote classics like "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," owes much of its existence to the less glamorous might of industry, which in the last century turned out cars, tools, typewriters, warplane components, fire hydrants and much more. 
 But as Elmira strives to rebound from years of hard times after the decline of manufacturing, residents have begun to question the legacy of all those factories as never before.
They are especially concerned by suggestions that a number of cancer cases reported by former and current students of a high school here are linked to the school, which was built on land that has supported a diverse array of industry from the Civil War to the 1970's.
The State Health and Environmental Conservation Departments have conducted tests at Southside High School and a neighboring property that is the site of an abandoned plant.
The State Department of Health has received reports of 53 cancer cases among the 7,500 current and former students since the school opened in 1979. It confirmed 25 cases of reportable cancer, meaning those other than the most common, easily treated skin cancers, and determined that the illness was diagnosed in 22 people while attending or after graduating from the school.
The most prevalent forms were leukemia and lymphoma, but the state determined that with the exception of one form of cancer, testicular, the number of cases was not statistically unusual.
The state found fewer than six cases of testicular cancer -- patient privacy rules forbid the department to specify the number when there are more than one and fewer than six cases -- in the last three years and is reviewing the medical records of those young men to assess any common threads.
The State Department of Health, after testing the air and ground, declared the school safe, though its conclusions have been disputed by some parents and by officials who suggest that the state investigation was hasty and not comprehensive.
The state is checking the medical records of the current and former students who have testicular cancer to assess whether there is a pattern of risk factors for the disease, though it is one of the least understood cancers and a link to environmental pollution has not been confirmed.
Testicular cancer accounts for only 1 percent of all cancers in men, according to the National Cancer Institute, but it is the most common form of cancer in men between the ages of 15 and 35.
The school district is also sending out a survey to all former students in an effort to check whether the 53 reported cases, compiled from school and state cancer registry records largely limited to New York State, are the only cases out there. Independent experts hired by the city and school district are also evaluating the state's findings.
Elmira is one of about three dozen communities nationwide that are questioning whether building schools on or near former industrial sites, usually because of cheap, readily available land, is causing ill effects among children, according to the Center for Health, Environment and Justice, a Virginia-based advocacy group founded by Lois Marie Gibbs, who led the calls for federal officials to clean up 20,000 tons of toxic waste that was buried beneath her neighborhood in Love Canal.
As in those communities, the cancer scare here has frayed nerves in town, not only at the notion that children's health may be in danger, but also because some people say the issue is being blown out of proportion. State officials have told residents that such cancer cluster investigations seldom make a direct link between past environmental contamination and illnesses because of the gaps in knowledge about chemicals and because risk factors for cancers include genetics, nutrition and lifestyle.
But parents of the stricken students, while acknowledging it may never be proven that the illness was caused by contamination, remain steadfast in exploring the possibility.
"We are just looking for some type of answer and to see if there is a reason to be worried about any kids in the future," said Andy Patros, whose son, Tom, 21, is one of the former students with testicular cancer.
Mr. Patros used to joke about the "pond that never freezes," a retaining pool next to the school that on a subfreezing morning in December was indeed largely unfrozen. (State officials are exploring the possibility that it does not completely freeze because it is fed by an underground spring.)
Mr. Patros and his wife, Julie, a nurse at a private hospital, were among a group of parents and officials from the neighborhood around the school who sent a letter to the school district in April outlining their concerns about a spate of cancer cases they had heard about from friends and neighbors. This followed the cleanup of the adjacent property, where about 2,000 cubic yards of contaminated soil was removed in 1999 by the new owner of a site where American LaFrance fire trucks were once made.
Former employees have come forward with tales of cavalier handling of dangerous chemicals and common dumping and burying of waste on the property and in nearby creeks and ponds.
Bob Schneider, 79, who worked at Remington Rand, which made typewriters and other office machines, recalled handling both powerful chemicals and metals. His father, who also worked at the factory and who died in 1979 of prostate cancer, "used to get nasty jobs, all this toxic stuff to clean out."
"They would give him time off after he did it, cleaning out all these vats," Mr. Schneider said. "I don't know what it was, but it would make you sick if you smelled it. Smelled like rotten onions or something. They would strip steel with it."
Mr. Schneider, like many others in town, never thought to question the substances they were handling. In the boom times during and just after World Wars I and II, the dozens of manufacturers played a major role not just in the city's economy but in its social fabric as well, sponsoring basketball leagues and charity functions, said J. Arthur Kieffer, the county historian and a former construction worker at the factories.
"We never thought about things like that, contamination or cancer, when people were working in the factories," said Mr. Kieffer, 79. "I am not going to say that's right or wrong, but there were thousands of people working in them factories, and if we are going to say things about the school, the environment caused cancer, then it would seem to me they would have to check the former workers, too."
So far, nobody has proposed that, and the focus has remained on the school and on the children.
The school property, owned by Remington Rand from 1937 through 1972, was acquired by the school district, hungry for cheap land to build a new school, for $1 from the county redevelopment agency. Craig Slater, a lawyer hired by the city to advise it on the state investigations, said records were scarce on whether the property was cleaned up before construction began, but he noted that environmental regulations and awareness of the toxicity of chemicals were not nearly as strong then as they are now.
Jay Grossman, a spokesman for Unisys, which through a series of mergers absorbed Remington Rand, said the company had been monitoring the investigations but did not plan to take any action on its former property because the state had not determined that it posed any health risk.
Just before the school year began, the board closed the school's athletic fields as a precautionary measure after state scientists found elevated levels of dangerous compounds in the soil, but not in quantities, they said, that would pose a health risk.
The contaminants included arsenic, barium, nickel and mercury. PCB's, a known carcinogen, were found in a creek next to the school. Investigators with the Department of Environmental Conservation said the toxic substances on the school site were found well below the surface and were unlikely to cause health problems unless someone dug deep and ingested sizable portions of soil.
Since then, pressure has increased to open the fields in time for spring sports. (The board has opened a practice field a few miles away.)
"All this contamination they are talking about on the south side, they are blowing way out of proportion," said Bill Smith, who worked in a nearby foundry and, even though his sweat was sometimes yellow at the time, says he is still going strong at 77. "I feel sorry for the kids that got cancer, but I'm not so sure it's from the school."
But others in the community contend that state officials have not looked hard enough and say they believe that any health risks go beyond the school.
"You just constantly hear about people getting cancer or dying from it," said Debbie Brimmer, whose children live with their father in the neighborhood near the school. Ms. Brimmer, who grew up in the area, said she once admired the "pretty greens and blues and reds" on the surface of creeks near the school that state officials now say are contaminated with oil and PCB's.
At this point, the focus remains largely on the school, where officials expect their consultants to complete their review of the state testing by Jan. 15.
Nobody expects the questions to end there. Indeed, some say they believe an element of mystery will always pervade, given the gaps in knowledge about pollutants and their health effects.
"As long as they say we tested everything and everything is fine beyond a reasonable doubt, that would be O.K.," said Michael Tobin, 16, a junior at the school who has been treated for cancer. "But I don't expect that any time soon."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Of more Web sites and gridlocked skies: Tying up some loose ends as the year runs down.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
TYING up some loose ends as the year runs out: Last week's column listed some Web sites that are especially useful for business travelers. But I overlooked a few.
"I believe you left out the best of all travel Web sites. It has everything, including many of those mentioned in the column . Try it: www.smilinjack.com," writes a reader, Roger J. Baccigaluppi. 
 Tried it. Mr. Baccigaluppi is right. The site, designed with a motif honoring Smilin' Jack, the dashing comic-strip aviator whose adventures spanned the era from barnstorming to jets, is maintained by Jack Irwin, a St. Louis-based airline pilot. The links -- including world airport and airlines home pages, more than three dozen weather sites, and scores of other travel-related pages -- are terrific.
Speaking of travel Web sites, two rapidly growing national restaurant Web sites are starting to become useful for business travelers who want to book reservations or research dining choices for future destinations.
They are www.opentable.com and its chief competitor, www.foodline .com. Both sites are scrambling to sign up more clients in major business-travel destinations this year. Choices currently range from a dozen or so restaurants in some cities, to 100 and more in others.
Rosters are growing as more restaurants, traditionally among the most hidebound of businesses when it comes to embracing technology, realize that opening their reservations books to the Internet bazaar means they can fill tables that might otherwise go empty. At the same time, assuming enough people actually use these services, restaurants can apply sophisticated data-processing techniques to their customer relations strategies.
Of course, the dot-com graveyard is fast filling up with dearly departed practitioners of technology without common sense. Running a restaurant that people actually return to is a delicate art. One Manhattan restaurateur, Danny Meyer, who is on the board of Open Table Inc., said that he planned to have the Union Square Cafe, Gramercy Tavern and two other popular New York restaurants that he operates listed "within a month or two" on the site.
I wondered if he was worried that we might be edging toward a brave new restaurant world, where a computer will call all the shots. Mr. Meyer said that technology would be a useful marketing tool, but "there is an art to hospitality, whether it's done by computer or by hand."
Used indiscriminately, too much information can present a problem, he said, recalling a lesson he learned when he opened the Union Square Cafe 15 years ago and began keeping various tidbits of customer preferences for future reference. A woman who had been in previously returned with friends and requested the same table. "Not only did I remember the table she'd had, which was of course fine, but I remembered that she was wearing the same beautiful dress, and told her so," he said, laughing. "I was a 27-year-old single guy. What did I know? Luckily, she ended up being a regular."
The year's top story in business travel was, of course, the record number of delays and cancellations on commercial airlines -- a situation so bad that it practically obscured the runners-up, soaring business fares and deteriorating airline customer service. Last month, by the way, the delay fiascos continued. According to Federal Aviation Administration data, November's delays were nearly 50 percent higher than the year-earlier month.
As the skies gridlocked, complaints and recriminations filled the air. Remedial recommendations ranged from resigned acceptance of the status quo (and hopping a train if it's going your way), to entirely junking federal management of the air-traffic control networks in favor of a privatized system.
A column here a couple of weeks ago on delays and various proposals to fix the system made an assertion that needs clarification, according to Dorothy Robyn, a White House special assistant who specializes in aviation issues.
I said that the commercial airline industry widely opposed "user fees." But I didn't differentiate between two kinds of proposed fees. One proposal, more generally palatable to the industry, would impose airspace fees as an alternative to the current ticket surcharge for financing the air-traffic control network. Another, the imposition of higher airport landing fees, is widely opposed by airlines, partly because they are increasingly using smaller, more economical regional jets, with a resulting increase in the numbers of landings.
The snarled air system is a transportation crisis that a new administration will have to confront this year. Soon, some airlines are expected to move more publicly behind proposals to replace the Federal Aviation Administration entirely with a new quasi-public system, based on some formula of fees, that they will manage themselves.
But one thing everyone agrees on is that the current system is in urgent need of repair. "While airlines have developed the most sophisticated pricing models of any industry, we have not introduced basic market-based pricing for allocating air-traffic control and airports," Ms. Robyn said in a speech to an aviation group last summer. "The predictable result is congestion, delays and unhappy passengers."

SECTION: Section B; Page 6; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Block May Be Revived, but Some Ask for Whom

BYLINE: By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
For a mostly abandoned block, there is a great deal of activity on West 148th Street between Adam Clayton Powell and Frederick Douglass Boulevards in Harlem.
There is the constant bustle of traffic because cars from the nearby service area for the Police Department and the few neighborhood businesses use the trash-strewn street as a parking lot. Then there are the rodents that leap through the garbage and dart in and out of the boarded apartment buildings. Children play there, too, coming from other streets to throw balls through a makeshift hoop fashioned from a plastic crate nailed to a wooden scaffold. 
 Bright sunlight shone harshly yesterday on the gritty street, and on all the little dumps that have sprung up where entrances used to be, yet the structures' delicate masonry and sturdy brickwork suggest that this was once a noble-looking block.
Area residents say it was not only that, but well known as the "best block in Harlem."
"Now it's the worst block in Harlem," said Talmon Ford, 44, a nurse who grew up on West 148th Street. "You can't find any other place that's totally abandoned like that."
News of the city's plans to revitalize the street, which has New York's highest concentration of vacant, city-owned buildings, has brought out feelings of skepticism and betrayal for many of the former residents -- some of whom still remain so close as a group that they hold 148th Street reunions twice a year.
They say they would like to move back into the buildings they grew up in, but fear that they would not be able to afford the new, higher rents. They have concerns that too few apartments are being earmarked for area residents, and they wonder why the buildings were allowed to decay in the first place.
The city plans co-ops and rentals affordable to moderate-income families, according to housing officials. The apartments are to be awarded by lottery, but preference will be given to area residents for at least 30 percent of the units.
"It seems that they let that block go down, they wanted everybody out," said Mr. Ford, 44, who was talking with friends at Tommy's Barber Shop on Frederick Douglass Boulevard near the corner of 148th Street. "And 30 percent for us? That's hardly nothing from 100 percent. They're just going to draft people into the neighborhood when we would love to live in our houses."
Also in the barber shop was Thomas Prescod, 39, a construction worker who grew up on West 148th Street. "I'd go back to my block in a minute," he said. "There's nothing like that part of Harlem."
Mr. Prescod said he moved out of an apartment at 203 West 148th Street in 1987. But already, he said, the neighborhood had begun to tumble.
Carol Abrams, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said the block was the victim of a "wave of abandonment" that swept through Harlem in the late 1970's and 1980's.
"The economy turned and building owners said, 'Hey -- I can just walk away. The asset is not worth the investment,' " she said.
The city came to own most of the troubled block between 1978 and 1992 because of tax foreclosures, Ms. Abrams said.
Walter Roberts, the department's assistant commissioner for planning support services, described the neighborhood at that point as "very, very scary."
Arson and drugs were major problems, he said, and the apartments were substandard. The occupancy rates were about 50 percent and repairs were done on a piecemeal basis. "There wasn't enough money to do major upgrades," Mr. Roberts said, so officials began to concentrate on finding other places to live for the remaining residents.
Only one building housed tenants by the end of the 90's, he said.
"I think we did what was right for the tenants at the time," Ms. Abrams said. "The tenants who were there certainly have the opportunity to move back. The apartments will be for rent."
Generally, Ms. Abrams said, the department sees a far higher number than 30 percent of community residents return to rehabilitated housing. But whether those tenants will be able to afford the rent is a different issue. In the early 1990's, a one- or two-bedroom apartment on West 148th Street rented to those who qualified for about $215 to $250 a month.
But "quality of life" improvements in Harlem have driven demand for housing to a place that would have been unimaginable just eight years ago, Ms. Abrams said.
"Developers want to develop there and people want to live there," she said.
Still, for all that demand, it was a particularly slow day in the Victory Barber Shop on Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard near 148th Street, where only three customers had shown up by 2 p.m. According to the shop's owner, Osbon Savage, 77, who has been there since 1969, most days are slow.
"What killed my business was when all of them moved out of that block," Mr. Savage said. People waiting to get trims in Mr. Savage's shop repeated concerns about the affordability of the new housing.
"If the people can afford the rent, it will be O.K.," said Brenda Edwards, 40, whose parents once lived on 148th Street.
Tony Rosado, a courier who keeps pigeons on a 148th Street rooftop, said the first thing the city should do is get rid of the rats.
"Personally," he said, "I think that's going to be the hardest part."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Holiday Shopping Season Could Be Worst in Decade
Despite widespread markdowns and a burst of last minute buying, this year's holiday shopping season is shaping up as among the worst in a decade, industry analysts said.
Consumers were treated to deep and widespread price reductions during the holiday season, and almost everywhere they reacted with restraint. Several of the nation's largest chains acknowledged that December sales were going to be lower than they had predicted at the beginning of the season. Page A1. 

White House Ends Drug Import Plan
The Clinton administration killed a program created by Congress to allow imports of low-cost prescription drugs, saying the plan would not be safe and would not save money. A1.

EarthWeb to Sell Sites and Services
EarthWeb, one of the first Silicon Alley content companies to make a splash with its initial public offering, is selling most of its Web sites and its news services and plans to lay off about 100 employees, company officials said. EarthWeb officials said they would continue to operate their business as a recruiting company for technology workers. Shares of EarthWeb rose 75 cents, to $7.50. C3.

Seven Killed at Internet Company
A heavily armed employee killed seven co-workers in a shooting spree at the Internet consulting firm Edgewater Technology in Wakefield, Mass. A1.

Stocks Are Mixed as Nasdaq Falls
The main market gauges were mixed as technology stocks fell. The Nasdaq composite index fell 23.50 points, or 0.9 percent, to 2,493.52. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 56.88 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,692.44, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 9.24 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,315.19. C5.

Japan Reports Raise Recession Fear
Adding to fears that the world's second-largest economy is slipping into recession again, the Japanese government said that the unemployment rate climbed and consumer spending fell last month. World Business, Section W.

Good Ideas From Outside the Office
Marcos Moraes, the founder of the Brazilian company Zip.net, an Internet portal that was recently sold to Portugal Telecom for $365 million, wanted to be an astronaut but said he became an explorer instead. He says it is important for everybody to get out of their environment before they get too old. "If I ever had a good idea, it was not when I was behind my desk," he said. The Boss. C4.
 
Vietnam Is Predicting Solid Growth
Despite an $892 million trade deficit, weak foreign investment and tottering state-owned industries, Vietnam predicted that its economy has grown 6.75 percent this year, beating forecasts. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: Sales in Holiday Season Rose, Just Barely, Over Last Year's

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Despite widespread markdowns and a burst of last-minute buying, this year's holiday shopping season is shaping up as among the worst in a decade, industry analysts said yesterday.
The slowdown has come as a bit of an 11th-hour shock to the nation's merchants. As recently as September, retailers expected solid sales through the holidays and ordered merchandise accordingly. But a slew of factors including rising gas prices, a tumbling stock market and a new administration clearly worried about a recession combined to chill customer appetites for everything from home appliances to sweaters. 
 Shortly after Thanksgiving, retailers responded by cutting prices steeply. But even when they were faced with 50 percent off leather jackets at Gap or 10 percent discounts on everything at Home Depot, consumers showed restraint.
"Retailers are going to remember this as a Christmas that took place during a recession," said Carl Steidtmann, chief retail economist with PricewaterhouseCoopers, who predicted that the season would be followed by "less expansion, more consolidation and more bankruptcies" among merchants nationwide.
The day after Christmas, several of the nation's largest chains, including Wal-Mart Stores, Target, Sears, Roebuck and Federated Department Stores, acknowledged that December sales were going to be lower than they had predicted at the beginning of the season.
The International Council of Shopping Centers, a trade group, reported yesterday that sales at specialty stores in malls increased only 2.2 percent -- hardly a wipeout, but sharply lower than the 7.7 percent increase last year. The sales looked especially meager after several years of boom times. The news was disappointing across almost all categories, but merchants selling big-ticket, discretionary items were particularly hard hit. For example, jewelry sales were down 3.2 percent from last year, and home entertainment, which included electronics, was down 6.3 percent, according to the council.
Similarly, TeleCheck Services, which monitors check spending nationwide, said holiday sales rose 3.2 percent, exactly half last year's gain and among the worst year-over-year increases since 1991. Merrill Lynch predicted a holiday gain of only 2.4 percent, which would be the worst since at least 1990, according to its calculations.
Mirroring the brick-and-mortar world, sales on the Internet were also a disappointment. Although total online sales grew to $5.83 billion, an increase of 55.4 percent, according to BizRate.com, which gathers consumer information, many Internet merchants had counted on sales at least doubling.
This year, Web merchants were not immune to greater macroeconomic trends. "It reflects the maturity of the business," said Seth Geiger, BizRate's vice president for professional services. "When there is a slowdown in the economy offline, online will feel it as well."
A few retail watchers still held out hopes that a flurry of post-season sales -- up to 60 percent off furs at Saks Fifth Avenue, and up to 50 percent off cleavage-enhancing bras at Victoria's Secret -- would finally ignite a customer spending outburst. But while malls were busy, shoppers seemed to be returning as much as they were buying, and many voiced caution about digging deeper into their wallets.
Yesterday afternoon at the Plaza at Buckland Hills in Manchester, Conn., Dawn Byrne, 34, was exchanging a computer game at CompUSA. With rising fuel costs, she said she still felt she had less money to spend for Christmas shopping, despite having taken on a high-paying night shift at a local Mobil station to earn more money. "It just seemed to be a tough year," she said.
The week after Christmas accounts for roughly 11 percent of holiday sales, according to the shopping council. Still, most economists said that whatever the purchases in the last week of the month, the overarching message from Holiday 2000 is already clear: the American shopper is feeling the pinch.
"It shows consumers are on the leading edge of feeling economic pressure that they have not felt for five years," said Stephen Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. While personal incomes remain strong, Mr. Roach said that Americans at all but the lowest income levels had been hit hard by the drop in the stock market. And everybody, he added, is feeling the pain of higher prices for gasoline and natural gas.
The country's sudden financial queasiness was palpable even over last weekend, which will still probably end up as the busiest shopping period of the year. With a dozen cashiers available, lines at Toys "R" Us in Seattle last Saturday were no more than five deep and customers were waiting no longer than 10 minutes.
"It's been really relaxed and easy," said Joy McGowan, cruising the electronic toys aisle with her husband, Terry, for their four children, ages 11 months to 11 years.
The goal of the McGowans this year, like many Americans, was to spend less, they said. "Last year we went overboard," Mrs. McGowan said. This year, she said, they set out "to emphasize the spirit of Christmas -- love and family."
Taking a break at the food court in Grand Central Terminal in New York last Friday, Allen Balbiera, a financial consultant, said he had been more cautious this year. "I am pretty conscious of what the market looked like in mid-August and what it looks like now," he said.
Consumer spending dropped so swiftly this fall that it left many of the nation's merchants mute or confused. Wal-Mart Stores, which released its disappointing results as part of a Dr. Seuss-inspired poem entitled "Did the Holiday Troll Steal Christmas," had no comment on what went wrong.
Jan Drummond, a Sears spokeswoman, said there were a "litany of things" that could have affected sales, including ice storms and high home heating prices. "But we have not speculated on how exactly they came together to affect Sears," she said.
At Bloomingdale's, Michael Gould, the chief executive, said sales in two core businesses, cosmetics and women's casual clothing, were up by single digits. But he said sales were below forecasts because he had underestimated the impact that the millennium had had on sales last year, particularly in categories like home furnishings and fashion accessories. "We sold an awful lot of evening bags and Waterford millennial flute crystal last year," he said. "And we were not realistic about whether we could match that."
While retailers were hesitating to acknowledge a slowdown, a move that would hurt their stocks further, the market was already taking bets on who would successfully weather a recession. Bonds of troubled retailers like J. C. Penney, Dillard's and Kmart have been trading at low prices for weeks, according to George Strachan, a Goldman, Sachs retail analyst, reflecting investor worries.
"Supermarkets and drugstores are positioned the most defensively. After that comes the dollar stores and to a lesser extent the discounters," Mr. Strachan said.
Dr. Steidtmann of PricewaterhouseCoopers predicted consolidation in electronics and jewelry, areas where sales have been particularly poor. He also said there would be "a lot less new store openings for sure." Retailers have been expanding at an astonishing rate the last several years, leading many analysts to conclude the country simply has too many stores. Among those gobbling up real estate at a voracious pace are Gap and Wal-Mart, both of which had lackluster holiday seasons.
Among Internet companies, stock investors have rewarded Yahoo, which announced yesterday that in contrast to many online retailers, its holiday sales had doubled from last year. Shares of Amazon.com, the Internet's largest retailer, were also up despite the fact that it has not yet reported sales. Still, there were plenty of casualties of the season, most notably the once highflying eToys. EToys, which said that sales were coming up drastically short of predictions, put itself up for sale in the middle of the month.
