HEADLINE: Clinton's Comments on the Democratic Party

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton in the Oval Office by The New York Times:
 
Q. There's been a lot written about how you redefined the Democratic Party and turned it in the direction of the third way. . . .
 
A. To me, this whole so-called New Democratic approach was a way of synthesizing our values and our policies in a way that would work. And probably the test of all this is whether it worked or not, and I think that if that's the test, that we pass. 
 And if you look at the debate in this election, to go back to your election question, if you look at the debate -- I remember the first time I heard Governor Bush give his compassionate-conservative speech. He was out in Iowa, and everybody was sitting around on bales of hay. And I thought, this is pretty good; this basically says, O.K., I'm a New Democrat, except I'll do more of it with the private sector than the public sector, and I'll give you a bigger tax cut.
Now, we obviously felt that the differences were much more profound. But the point is that it shows the extent to which the idea of finding a synthesizing, progressive movement that unifies instead of divides people has captured the public imagination.
 
Q. So you think it will last, or too soon to tell?
 
A. I think it will last if that's the only way to get stuff done. For example, if you look at the fact that the Congress is now more closely divided even than it was before, and it was pretty closely divided before, I think that if you want to fight, you can fight, and have a dead-even split on everything.
If you want to do things, I think it will be possible to do quite innovative things in the next four years, important things. But in order to do it, you'll have to define a dynamic center, which is what I've tried to do. I've tried to restore a vital, dynamic center to American life. . . .
 
Q. Your critics say that, on the other hand, when you came into office, there was a Democratic majority in the House, a Democratic majority in the Senate and a majority of Democrats in the governorships around the country. And, of course, none of those majorities now exist. What happened . . .?
 
A. In the Congress, I think we had a combination of two things. First of all, all the Democrats will tell you that we had a lot of older Democrats who represented districts that had grown more and more Republican over the last 20 years, and when they retired, we were going to have a hard time holding them.
And then I don't think it's complicated; I think I got in and I adopted an economic plan that they characterized as a big tax increase, and the benefits of it weren't yet felt, and people weren't sure whether they were getting their taxes increased or not then. I adopted a crime bill which the N.R.A. told everybody was going to take their guns away, and people hadn't felt the lower crime rate or seen the community police on their streets, but they heard the fear. And I tried to pass a health care reform and failed, so that when you fail, people can more easily characterize what it was you tried to do, even if what they say you tried to do has no relationship to what you tried to do.
And we almost had the reverse of what happened in '98. What happened -- so a lot of our people, our base voters in the '94 election, they were kind of sad that welfare reform didn't pass -- I mean, health care didn't pass. They didn't know about, they didn't know how they felt about this economic plan because they maybe didn't feel their lives were better yet. And they didn't perceive that the crime rate had come down yet.
So we were running in the worst of all environments, and I basically have some significant responsibility for that because I jammed a lot of change through the system in a short time. And maybe politically, I made a mistake not doing welfare reform in '94 and trying to put health care off until '95 or '96. And maybe it would have been less. I think we would have lost seats in any case because of the dynamics of who was running and what the seats were and all that. But I think that it was much worse than otherwise it could have been. And it's pretty much what happened to Harry Truman when he tried to do health care reform.
I mean, basically, we sort of repeated the cycle of history. And I just made an error. And I felt terrible about it, and I spent the last six years trying to undo it. We picked up several House seats in the '96 election, and then in '98, when we won seats in the House and didn't lose seats in the Senate is the first time in 122 years that in the sixth year of a presidency, the president's party picked up seats in the Congress.
And this year we did immensely well in the Senate races, because for the first time in six years, for the first time we had a good rotation, and we had good candidates. And because the House was so close, the energy of the Republican right -- the public energy of the Republican right shifted from the House to the Senate the last two years. And I think that's one of the reasons that we did better in the Senate.
When Hastert became the speaker, they tried to present a more moderate image. I mean, there are lots of other things -- I haven't had time to analyze all these House races -- but we're in the position we're in partly because we were going to lose some seats which had been moving Republican when our senior people retired or got beat. But also because of all the things I did in '93 and '94. And one of the things I feel badly about is I think that those decisions were good decisions. I think one of the reasons I got re-elected in '96 is because the economy was in good shape and we were getting rid of the deficit, and a lot of the people who made the decision to do it paid the price.

HEADLINE: A Revival and a Party Transformed

SERIES: THE CLINTON LEGACY -- Fourth of five articles: The New Democrats

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26

 BODY:
It is easy to forget how beleaguered the Democratic Party was at the dawn of the 1990's.
A generation had come of age with only the dimmest of memories of a successful Democratic presidential campaign. 
 The extraordinary popularity of Reaganism had shaken liberals to their cores, and three straight Republican victories, two of them landslides, led many analysts to conclude that the Republicans had a lock on the White House. Many Democratic Party gatherings were like Irish wakes, filled with mournful, longing tributes to dead heroes and despair about how to move on.
If his critics and his defenders agree on one thing, it is this: Bill Clinton transformed that political world. Whatever the cost -- and some in his party's left say it was too high -- Mr. Clinton restored the Democrats' national stature.
"Just winning two times in a row for the first time in a long time was a huge achievement," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader of the House. "We hadn't had a president since Roosevelt who had done it, and a lot of us had begun to wonder whether it would ever happen again."
First as candidate, then as president, Bill Clinton dealt, one by one, with the Democratic vulnerabilities, perceptions of the party that had become easy targets for Republicans from 1968 on: that the Democrats were soft on crime; that they were big taxers and spenders, addicted to giveaway programs; that they were achingly sensitive to the needs of minorities and the poor but cared little for the problems of the white middle class; that they were more interested in redistributing wealth than in fostering economic growth.
This year's election showed that many of these vulnerabilities remain, just below the surface: Republicans portrayed Vice President Al Gore repeatedly and effectively as a champion of big government and new spending programs. They also pointedly promised a new moral tone in the White House. But much of the post-election analysis has explained Mr. Gore's defeat by pointing to the flaws in his campaign rather than deeper flaws in the Democratic Party, particularly since Gov. George W. Bush's victory was so narrow.
Al From, president of the Democratic Leadership Council, which Mr. Clinton once chaired and used as a launching pad for his presidential campaign, argued that Mr. Clinton's Democratic Party should be measured by the distance traveled rather than the shortcomings of the last campaign.
"Don't forget where we were," Mr. From said. "We'd lost 40 states in three straight elections. If Clinton pulled us to parity in an election where we ran what a lot of people thought was not a stellar campaign, that is some progress."
Stan Greenberg, who was Mr. Clinton's first presidential pollster and who worked for Mr. Gore this fall, said of Mr. Clinton: "He has created the possibility of a Democratic majority. But it's not a Democratic ascendancy."
Critics scoffed throughout the 1990's that Mr. Clinton's New Democratic Party was all about tactics, but inside the White House, the party's new mission was seen as something grander.
Michael Waldman, the president's former speechwriter, remembered that Mr. Clinton declared one night in 1998, while they were working on the State of the Union address: "Roosevelt saved capitalism from itself. Our mission is to save government from its own excesses so it can again be a progressive force.' "
Mr. Waldman added, "We came to believe that the public would be willing to back activist government, but first they had to believe that government had been brought under control."
What Mr. Clinton called "the third way," the political path between left and right, was not an easy journey for Democrats. Even some of his closest aides say they cringed when he declared in 1996 that "the era of big government is over."
James Carville, a longtime Clinton strategist, said he was furious about parts of the welfare overhaul that Mr. Clinton signed into law. Congressional Democrats were often enraged at his willingness to strike deals with Republicans, especially in the difficult middle years of his administration, after the Republicans took control of the Congress.
The question, for different Democrats at different times, was whether the careful repositioning at the heart of Clintonism ceded too much to the right, reacted too much to the polls and endangered the party's soul. But by and large, the party followed his march to the center.
"We are now advocating, almost to a person, that we have to grow the economy first and balance the budget and be fiscally responsible," said Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, often a Clinton critic.
"That doesn't mean you can't be progressive or even liberal," Mr. Kerrey said, "but you've got to give the public economic growth and safety on the street and a defense that's credible. I think Clinton has done that. I think the party is back to being a party of the middle class."
Mr. From offered an even more generous view of Mr. Clinton's accomplishments.
"He modernized the Democratic Party for the information age," Mr. From said. "He made it competitive again in national politics, and it became the model for center-left parties all over the world."
In fact, third-way expertise and the pollsters and consultants who purveyed it became an important export in the 1990's, notably for the resurgent Labor Party of Tony Blair in Britain. And Mr. Clinton clearly helped modernize a Democratic Party that a decade before was committed to a vast public jobs program, tax increases and a trade policy that was staunchly protectionist.
A New York Times/CBS News poll question last fall spoke volumes: When asked which party was more likely to make sure the country was prosperous, the Democrats -- once the party of taxing and spending, "stagflation" and the misery index -- had the edge.
Scholars and strategists are debating how lasting this change will be. Mr. Gore's campaign demonstrated that it was not easy to run as a Clinton-style "New Democrat" and keep the loyalty of the Democratic base. Mr. Clinton's raw political skill, some strategists say, might be a necessary ingredient, which suggests the party repositioning might not be as fundamental as Mr. Clinton's allies suggest.
And there is another, even broader, criticism of Bill Clinton, Democrat: while he was busily trying to rebuild the presidential wing of the party, much of the rest of it was collapsing. When he took office, there were Democratic majorities in the House and the Senate and a majority of the nation's governors were Democrats. As he leaves office, none of those majorities exist, mostly because of the Democrats' devastating defeats in 1994, the first midterm election of the Clinton presidency.
The party has made gains since then. The last election produced a 50-50 Senate and reduced but continued the Republican majority in the House. But the party has not fully recovered. There were powerful underlying trends behind the Democratic losses of 1994, from the longstanding realignment of the South to the complacency of the Democratic majority. But Mr. Clinton, in an interview, acknowledged that his early missteps, notably his disastrous effort to push through a national health plan, played a role.
"We were running in the worst of all environments," he said, "and I basically have some significant responsibility for that because I jammed a lot of change through the system in a short time."
"And maybe, politically, I made a mistake not doing welfare reform in '94 and trying to put health care off until '95 or '96," Mr. Clinton said. "And maybe it would have been less. I think we would have lost seats in any case because of the dynamics of who was running and what the seats were and all that."
"But I think that it was much worse than otherwise it could have been," he said. "And I felt terrible about it, and I spent the last six years trying to undo it."
Ralph Nader, one of Mr. Clinton's harshest critics, said: "The cardinal thing you remember him for was what a selfish politician he was from the Democratic Party's point of view. He lost it all except for himself."
And Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House and the principal strategist of the 1994 Republican takeover in Congress, was cheerfully blunt when asked whether he could have won without Mr. Clinton's blunders.
"Let me give you a clear, unequivocal answer," Mr. Gingrich said. "No."
But for all his flaws, and for all the fault-lines in the party that Mr. Clinton was trying to traverse, he held his coalition together, so masterfully at times that even politicians who hated him could only marvel.
Bill Clinton's redefinition of the Democratic Party succeeded, in large part, because of what Mr. Carville called an "amazing act of political dexterity" that other politicians had tried but failed to pull off.
"He basically moved the party to the center, and kept as his most loyal supporters the traditional Democrats," Mr. Carville said.
In short, he did what George W. Bush is apparently trying to do in the Republican Party.
It rarely looked like a sure thing, and, indeed, Mr. Gingrich, among others, asserted that it was less a visionary strategy than a series of short-term tactical decisions to ensure Mr. Clinton's political survival. It was never easy for Congressional Democrats to parse out, in his actions, what was good for Bill Clinton and what was good for the party.
The tension between the traditional and the so-called New Democrats was a constant of the Clinton era. His insistence on free-trade policies opened a split with organized labor that remains. His welfare overhaul, emphasizing work but also, for the first time, putting federal time limits on assistance for poor women and their children, outraged many on his party's left. (The party's platform in 1972, for example, denounced the very idea of requiring welfare recipients to work.)
He supported the death penalty, anathema to civil rights leaders, and proclaimedhis commitment to putting thousands of new police officers on the streets. And his pursuit of a balanced budget, and ultimately the use of the federal surplus to reduce the debt, led some liberals to wonder why fiscal stewardship took precedence over new government programs.
"In each of these cases, and particularly on the budget, he went further than he needed to to redeem the areas in which the Democratic Party had a weak reputation," Robert Kuttner, co-editor of The American Prospect, a liberal magazine, said in an interview.
In a recent essay, Mr. Kuttner maintained: "The problem with the third way, in the style of Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, is that you begin by meeting the conservatives halfway. When that doesn't quite succeed, you meet them halfway again. And again. Soon, you have two conservative parties."
Mr. Clinton's relations with Congressional Democrats were, to put it mildly, rocky. They were outraged at his strategy after the Republicans won control of Congress in 1994, when he distanced himself from Democrats on Capitol Hill, with the help of Dick Morris, a Clinton adviser, in the process known as triangulation.
"We thought it was strangulation," remembered Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, and a Clinton fan.
At one point, weary of the administration's tactic of going around its own party to do business with the Republicans, a Gephardt staff member ripped the White House phone from the wall in the Democratic leader's office.
Yet Mr. Clinton, especially toward the end of his administration, was remarkably popular among core Democrats. Part of it was his sheer political skill and his success in arguing that it was better to win and to get things done than to stick with the liberal orthodoxy of the past.
"I never believed there was an inherent conflict between the traditional objectives of progressives and liberals in the Democratic Party and what I thought of as the third way, or the new Democratic approach," Mr. Clinton said in the interview.
The third way, he argued, was simply an effort to break through the either-or choices that characterized the debate between liberals and conservatives and the stalemates that it caused.
"I tried to find some 'both' solutions, some win-win solutions," Mr. Clinton said. "And a lot of people criticized me at the time. They said, 'Well, he doesn't have a foot in either camp. Therefore, he must not have any convictions.'
"But that's not where I saw it at all. For example, I didn't think we could have an economic policy that would work unless we both got rid of the deficit and invested more in education and science and technology."
Mr. Clinton also held a loyal base because he stuck with some of his party's most controversial stands. Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts Democrat, bristled at the accusation that Mr. Clinton had compromised too much of the party's soul.
"What was our soul?" Mr. Frank demanded in an interview. "He stuck with us on affirmative action, on choice, on gay rights, on immigration. What was our soul?"
But Mr. Clinton was more than the sum of his political parts. Rahm Emanuel, a former aide, had a theory that while voters in the center were attracted by the issues, much of the Democratic base was drawn to the man.
Mr. Waldman, Mr. Clinton's speechwriter, agreed. "He's a one-man coalition."
Mr. Clinton was the fatherless son of a single mother, a Southerner, a product of the struggling white working class, a man clearly at home in black churches and communities, a baby boomer, a parent.
Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, said that black voters, a crucial part of the Democratic base, sensed that Mr. Clinton "felt very comfortable in the presence of African-Americans," and the feeling was mutual. His approval rating among blacks hovered around 90 percent in the final years of his administration.
"I hear it over and over again," Mr. Lewis added. "You heard it during the whole attempt at impeachment: Is the president going to be all right? Is my man going to be all right?"
The Democratic base, particularly on Capitol Hill, was also rallied by the enemies he made. Paradoxically, Ironically, during impeachment, the darling of the New Democrats was fortified, and arguably saved, by the old Democrats, including the Democratic leadership, in part because they simply could not abide his attackers: Newt Gingrich, Tom DeLay, Kenneth W. Starr.
"It was the New Democrats who went South on him first," a House Democratic strategist said."They're the people you don't want in the trenches with you."
What does Mr. Clinton leave his party? Clearly, a different image.
"The Democratic Party brand used to stand for a lot of things -- labor unions, big spenders, soft on crime, not necessarily friendly to business, interested mostly in redistribution," said Robert B. Reich, a secretary of labor under Mr. Clinton. "Bill Clinton fundamentally repositioned the Democratic brand."
He has not left the party better off when it comes to questions of values; more Americans give the edge to Republicans when it comes to issues labeled under family values, and Mr. Clinton's personal scandals almost certainly play a part in that, although he denies it.
Whether he left his party an enduring political philosophy is a harder question. Mr. Clinton did leave policies that will, almost certainly, be remembered as Clintonian, like giving poor people more of an incentive to work by expanding the earned-income tax credit and benefits for child care and health care. He left his party the idea that deficit and debt reduction and good economic stewardship could co-exist with the party's traditional commitment to a more equitable society.
"By being actively for deficit reduction, open markets, respecting the Fed's independence, he created the message and the reality that the Democrats are focused not only on equity but growth and managing the larger economy as well," said Gene Sperling, director of the National Economic Council.
But he did not find a "third way" to create universal health insurance, arguably his greatest domestic policy failure, nor to overhaul Medicare and Social Security for the coming onslaught of baby boomers. Nor did Mr. Clinton resolve the great schism in his party over trade.
Mr. Clinton does leave a party that remembers, thanks to him, what it feels like to win. Even some of his greatest critics on the left give him credit for deflating, with dizzying speed, the Gingrich revolution. In campaigns, Mr. Clinton and his troops institutionalized rapid response and the war room in a party that, just four years before, swore off negative campaigning and then proceeded to lose 40 states. But his any-means-necessary approach also helped transform the Democratic Party into a vast soft-money machine, some critics say.
"There was simply no leading by example by a person who probably, of all the presidents in our time, could have pulled off significant reforms and significant change had he decided to," said Scott Harshbarger of Common Cause.
While giving credit to Mr. Clinton for strengthening the party politically, Mr. Harshbarger argued that he also "corporatized" it.
"When you look at the major donors of the Democratic Party," Mr. Harshbarger said, "with few exceptions, you can't tell the difference between them and those of the Republican Party."
Mr. Clinton clearly hoped for a sweeping political vindication this year -- a Democratic president, House and Senate -- that he did not get. But the election did not spur the kind of soul-searching and agonizing over identity that past Democratic defeats did.
Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster, said, "It's clear that the Democratic Party won't ever go back to being the party it was before Bill Clinton." Implicit in the post-election analyses is the belief that Mr. Clinton left Mr. Gore an eminently winnable election.
Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster, argued that Mr. Gore did not defuse the public's concern about big-government Democrats the way Mr. Clinton did. An analysis for the Democratic Leadership Council said that Mr. Gore's "old-style populism" cost him the "new economy voters" whom Mr. Clinton had wooed so skillfully. Some suggested that the candidate who mastered the lessons of Clinton this year was Mr. Bush.
Still, there is an argument that Mr. Gore was hurt, badly, by the shadow of Mr. Clinton and the conservative cultural rebellion against the president.
In a recent analysis, Mr. Greenberg, the former pollster for Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore wrote: "The failure to stop Clinton in 1992, the aborted Gingrich revolution, Clinton's victory in the 1996 election and the impeachment war left the right in rebellion determined to end this era of 'moral decline.' For the ideological right, defeating Gore in 2000 was to be the final act in redeeming the country from Clintonism."
In short, Mr. Clinton bequeathed his successor a cultural war, in addition to a booming economy and a modernized party.
The loss of the White House was particularly painful to Mr. Clinton's most loyal supporters, who thought they were on the first leg of a historic journey. Redefining the Democratic Party, and all the compromises it entailed, would pay off down the road, they believed, when a more confident public could accept the federal government tackling the remaining issues of the social agenda, like universal health care.
Now, they face the prospect of a Republican president who plans to use the surplus and the public's good will for a huge tax cut. It adds to the wistfulness, and the strange mixture of pride and regret, among so many Democrats who joined the governor from Arkansas on his improbable journey to remake their party.
"It depends on what day you ask me," said Mr. Reich, the former secretary of labor, when he was asked asked to reflect on his service. "On Monday, Wednesday and Friday I say, 'Thank God, Bill Clinton was there.' He was a bulwark against the right-wing Republican charge that began early on. He ended, for all intents and purposes, Newt Gingrich's career; he stuck it out in the showdown over the government shutdown and weathered the storm. And he repositioned the Democrats for a much more successful future and presided over a much more successful economy. So my overall sense is buoyant.
"Now, on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, there's a little bit of wistfulness, I suppose. Had we been more disciplined, not tried to do so many different things, had health care been handled more carefully and subtly, had Bill Clinton avoided the reckless engagement with Monica Lewinsky, we could have accomplished much more."
 
The Clinton Legacy

Israelis and Palestinians Weigh Clinton Peace Plan
The Clinton administration expects to receive answers to its Middle East peace proposals that will be qualified but positive enough for Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to go to Washington for talks. The proposals, which Mr. Clinton laid out to negotiators last weekend, call for wrenching concessions by both sides. A3
 
Corruption Charges in Thailand
The government anticorruption agency ruled that Thaksin Shinawatra, the leading candidate for prime minister, had engaged in financial wrongdoing that could disqualify him from holding office. Mr. Shinawatra said he would appeal the ruling to the Constitutional Court, a process that is likely to last past Election Day, Jan. 6. A5 

Bias Attack in Germany
Officials said rightist youths shouting anti-immigrant insults stabbed a man of "Asian appearance" in Guben, a town on the Polish border that was the scene of the killing of a 28-year-old Algerian man last year by a xenophobic mob. The police detained three men aged 16 to 19 in yesterday's attack. The victim, a 20-year-old man, was hospitalized in serious but stable condition. A12
 
Testing Soldiers for Radiation
European NATO allies began checking whether their soldiers had been exposed to dangerous levels of radiation from depleted uranium ammunition used by American warplanes in Kosovo last year. Spain said initial findings were negative. (AP)
 
Rebels May Get a Second Zone
The Colombian government said it was pursuing a plan to establish a second demilitarized enclave for leftist rebels. President Andres Pastrana and other officials met with community leaders in two areas north of Bogota to address concerns about creating such a zone. A7
 
Arrests in Deadly China Fire
The police made an undisclosed number of arrests following a Christmas Day fire in Luoyang that killed 309 people, mostly revelers in a disco, New China News Agency reported. The cause of the fire is under investigation. Residents said emergency exits in the building had been blocked by boxes of merchandise. A3

Administration Drops Prescription-Import Plan
The Clinton administration killed a program created by Congress to allow imports of low-cost prescription drugs. Donna E. Shalala, the secretary of health and human services, said the program would not be safe and would not save money for consumers, findings that barred the plan from going forward under terms of the legislation that created it. Although George W. Bush said at the Oct. 17 presidential debate that the program "makes sense," his advisers said yesterday that he would consider other ways to moderate spending on prescription drugs, which has grown rapidly in recent years. Legislation to Protect Sharks
President Clinton signed a measure banning the practice of removing the fin from live sharks at sea and dumping the fish back into the water to die. The legislation, which covers all waters of the United States, provides for international negotiations to prohibit the practice and authorizes research to help conserve shark populations. Shark fins are considered a delicacy in many Asian countries, where they are served in top-class restaurants as shark-fin soup. AP

Investigators said Mr. McDermott, who was arrested without a struggle, might have been upset over tax troubles and the company's agreement to an I.R.S. request that his wages be garnisheed to pay back taxes. HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Taste of the Good Life, Served With Gusto

BYLINE: By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
IT can be a delicate matter, asking a businessman about the ups and downs of his professional life, but one thing you don't have to worry about with the chef Mario Batali -- unless we are talking about the proper way to approach and assess his homemade salami -- is delicacy.
Whaddaya wanna know? 
 Why Mr. Batali, the Food Network star with the trademark red ponytail and shorts, broke up with his partner at Po, his first restaurant? -- oops, there's been an 11th-hour chat with his lawyer, he needs to eat his words on that one. Whether he got the money to open Babbo, his three-star restaurant in Greenwich Village, from his wife, whose family owns Coach Farm? (Nope, it was a book advance.) His extracurricular life at Rutgers University? A hundred and fifty Grateful Dead concerts. More?
Here is Mr. Batali, who kind of reminds you of the actor John Goodman, or maybe the only guy you wouldn't mind sitting next to at an airport bar on a long layover, talking about the four months he worked for Marco Pierre White. "The most important chef in London," he calls him. A man of "unbounded imagination."
So why did he work for him for only four months? "He threw things at you," Mr. Batali, 40, says in a quiet moment at Babbo. "A whole pan of hot risotto right at your chest. He's famous for being incorrigible."
(Two phone messages, left for Mr. White in London, brought no reply.)
That scar on Mr. Batali's forehead? Is this a souvenir from his days with Mr. White?
"No," he says, laughing. "That's my near-death experience from last year. Brain aneurysm. I was out with my wife, and I heard this whooshing sound, and my vision was a little funny -- the kind of thing I remember from my recreational drug use in college. They fixed it, but aneurysms are dangerous things -- you can die from them. My wife always uses this to remind me that life is an incredible gift. Like someone could appreciate it better than I could."
Times are good for Mr. Batali. In addition to Babbo, which won the Best New Restaurant of the Year award from the James Beard Foundation in 1998, there are two other restaurants, cookbooks, a wine store and his "Molto Mario" television show. In January, there will be a new show, "Mario Eats Italy."
His philosophy, as told to Nation's Restaurant News: "Italian cooking is not putting together a symphony of nine very strange ingredients, but two or three separate things and allowing them to sing."
He always loved good food. Growing up in Seattle, third-generation Italian, his father an engineer for Boeing, his mother a nurse, everybody cooked. The first career goal of Mr. Batali, who stands 5-foot-11 and weighs 240 pounds, was pro football -- until he realized how big the pros were. He was never one to hit his head against obstacles greater than himself, he notes. Instead, he studied Spanish theater and economics at Rutgers, in New Brunswick, N.J., then cooked in California hotels.
BUT his real training was in Italy in the mountain town of Borgo Capanne, at a family-run trattoria, La Volta. He stayed three years, mostly working for nothing. What great memories: everything was made to order there, he says; O.K., maybe not the ravioli, but you didn't cut an onion before the service started. Mr. Batali returns to the United States, gets a job at a Village restaurant called Rocco, and lives the single chef life: you get out at 11:30 p.m., he says, it still gives you five hours to hang out.
Then one day into Rocco walks a saleswoman for Coach Farm goat cheese, Susi Cahn. Mr. Batali doesn't like her: she is too aggressive, too pushy -- in other words, a good saleswoman. She is also beautiful, which Mr. Batali notices when she comes back to Rocco for dinner one night. His parents also happen to be there, and when dinner is over somebody brings out an accordion and his father plays and they drink Averna and everybody sings. Today there are two sons, Benno, 4, and Leo, 2 1/2, and Mr. Batali sends his wife flowers on the ninth day of every month, because the ninth day of November, in 1994, is when they married.
But let us now accompany Mr. Batali through his empire: Esca, on 43rd and Ninth, where the chef David Pasternack cuts cubes of raw salmon, adds balsamic vinegar and a pinch of sea salt for the visitors, and teases Mr. Batali about getting home at 3:30 a.m. from the R.E.M. Christmas party; to Lupa, on Thompson Street, to taste a sea bass and potato ravioli filling; then to what is clearly Mr. Batali's deepest new love, his salami kitchen, behind his new wine store, Italian Wine Merchants, on East 16th Street.
"If you're a vegan, this is what hell smells like," he says happily, opening the door to a cooler where hams are hanging, then inhaling deeply. "So little time, so many cool things."
He takes out a lardo coppa, a salted pork butt and tries to cut it with his new toy, a $5,000 slicer you use by hand -- otherwise, Mr. Batali says, the heat from an electric slicer might melt some of the "beautiful fat." There's only one problem: the chef can't make it work. Out comes an assistant; the salami is sliced into thin curls and offered around.
"There's a way to eat salami," Mr. Batali says, as a wine lover might discuss wine. "First you rest it on your fingers to warm it up a little. Then you smell it. Then you put it on your tongue and let it sit there for a second, then ----" a happy gulp.
And -- you may not believe this -- the salami sings.

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 109 words

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
ALUMINUM SMELTER TO REDUCE OUTPUT AND SELL POWER

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Golden Northwest Aluminum Inc. said it planned to cut production by 83 percent through October 2001 because of power shortages on the West Coast. Smelters in The Dalles, Ore., and Goldendale, Wash., will scale back output and allow the Bonneville Power Administration to resell the electricity they would have used to California, where power prices have quintupled in the last year. Aluminum smelters are among the biggest electricity users in the region. Golden Northwest will use profits from electricity sales to keep all its 1,225 employees on its payroll or to supplement unemployment compensation to match their salaries, a spokesman said.

HEADLINE: Evictions Illuminate Issue Of Illegal Loft Apartments

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
The immediate crisis may be over for residents of most illegal loft apartments in New York City, but the larger issue remains: what to do about a growing stock of unlawfully converted buildings and the people who have made them their homes.
An uproar arose Dec. 15 when city inspectors suddenly evicted 60 people from an illegally converted factory building in Brooklyn, citing fire hazards. Officials then confirmed that 120 other sites in Brooklyn were also being investigated. 
 That prompted fears that up to 2,000 other residents would be removed, until Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's office intervened with a pre-Christmas assurance that there would be no mass evacuations.
But rather than resolving the issue, the threat of evictions made the illegal conversions too visible to ignore. And the scope of the problem may be much wider than the 121 buildings that have officially been acknowledged.
There are glimmers of a solution in Albany. By a stroke of good timing, March 31 is the expiration date of the state law that legalized lofts existing in 1980-81, most of them in SoHo, TriBeCa and Chelsea. The chance to renew the law opens the door to changing it.
Some city and state officials are now talking about not just a routine renewal, but an expansion to cover the new generation of illicit lofts that have sprung up across the city, mostly in Brooklyn. The discussions are far from over, however.
Although the Dec. 15 evacuation of the residents of 247 Water Street in Brooklyn was traumatic, the event, by virtue of the publicity it generated, may well prove to be the catalyst for a solution to a broader issue.
"It's almost like when we didn't recognize Red China; it was out there with a lot of people but we couldn't officially talk about it," City Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher, a Democrat from Brooklyn, told a crowd of about 200 loft tenants on Dec. 20 at a hastily called meeting.
Arthur Rhine, a lawyer who has specialized in loft cases for 20 years, said in an interview: "Things are exploding. We've met with several politicians, and things are starting to happen in ways we could only have dreamed about six months ago."
Even before the recent evictions, the loft issue was being reviewed by the chairman of the State Assembly's Housing Committee, Vito J. Lopez, a Brooklyn Democrat whose district includes loft buildings. "We are trying to work in a collaboration with the city and state to consider legislation to grandfather in these loft tenants," said his chief of staff, Diana Reyna.
Chuck DeLaney is the tenant representative on the city's Loft Board, a panel set up to oversee the legalization of lofts that existed in 1980 and 1981, and a leader of the Lower Manhattan Loft Tenants group.
"The situation is reaching critical mass," Mr. DeLaney said. But much remains unclear. "It's hard to craft a solution till you have an idea of what's in play, and nobody really knows what we're talking about in terms of numbers."
Mr. Rhine said the 121 listed buildings were "truly the tip of the iceberg." He added, "I would think there are probably a thousand buildings -- I'm talking just Brooklyn -- and 10,000 tenants." In addition, he said, there are a few hundred buildings in the other boroughs, including 200 in Manhattan.
But the proposal to expand the loft law, which gives legal status to those illegal conversions of two decades ago, does not have universal backing. Some tenants do not want to be covered by it, saying it allows too many landlord abuses.
Some tenants say exploitive landlords encourage them to invest in renovations and then push them out and bring in new tenants at higher rents. "It's a scenario I've seen over and over again," Mr. Rhine said.
Others say they fear that legal status would make their neighborhoods so valuable that they would be priced out of them, or that, if a residential use was allowed, their buildings would be demolished for luxury developments.
Another obstacle to expanding the loft law is that it was intended to be a one-time exemption, allowing the legalization of lofts that had been renovated to meet residential building codes and prohibiting later conversions.
But rising real estate prices in Manhattan and the city's tightening housing market have driven people to vacant industrial space in stagnant neighborhoods. The city did little to stop the trend, Mr. Rhine said. "There are philosophical discussions about what should be, but we're dealing with what is," he said.
Proponents of lofts say they use neglected space, revive neighborhoods, stimulate the economy and ease the housing shortage. Critics say that they are illegal, unsafe and unplanned.
The Center for an Urban Future, a nonprofit research group, said the lofts are squeezing out potential employers. Others argue that many loft tenants are self-employed artists, consultants and other professionals, industries of another sort.
"There's no way to roll the clock back," said Councilman Fisher, whose district includes many lofts in Williamsburg and Greenpoint. The area, he said, had "been transformed, a de facto rezoning from a heavy- industry series of neighbors to a mixed-use and residential neighborhood."
All sides agree that safety is paramount. "No matter how much space or how cool the nabe, it's not a good deal to live in a firetrap," Mr. Rhine said.
While state officials face a spring deadline on the loft law, a different pressure is mounting on city officials.
After one loft building was vacated last year, Mr. Fisher began pushing the city to confront the broader problem. The many agencies involved, including buildings, fire, planning and the Loft Board, complicated the matter.
At a meeting of agencies early this year, everyone acknowledged the problem but no one took the lead or offered a solution, Mr. Fisher said. "No one wanted to be the last one who touched the ball before it went out of bounds," he said.
Although Fire Department officials say they identified the 121 sites a year ago and notified the Buildings Department, that agency said it got the list only recently and acted promptly. The two agencies have often been at odds. Critics say that what really prompted the sudden crackdown was an inquiry from The Daily News about the list.
The resulting evacuation caught the mayor by surprise. He told the two agencies of his displeasure and ordered the other sites reinspected. Teams returning from buildings with the most serious problems reported that none required evictions, and everyone seemed relieved for the moment.
"But now we've got to figure out what to do with all these buildings," Mr. Fisher said.
So far, there has been plenty of blame for all concerned.
"Everybody's wrong here," said Leslie Samuel, a fashion consultant, as he stood outside the Water Street building, where he had lived and worked for six years. "We were wrong for going into an illegal building. The landlord was wrong. The city was wrong for letting it go on, and then for throwing us out without any notice. Now they should all sit down and work it out." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Is 'Bipartisan' the Slogan du Jour?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Nuts and Bolts of Bipartisanship" (Op-Ed, Dec. 24):
Richard Darman cites history in asking Democrats for tolerance so the substantial goals of the Bush administration can be met. I wish he had said this in 1992, when Congressional Republicans viewed Bill Clinton's victory derisively and opposed his initiatives. 
 Mr. Clinton lacked a resounding mandate and so was denied the honeymoon that President Ronald Reagan got. But the bipartisan legislation passed after the Reagan victory resulted in an unbalanced economic expansion financed by deficits that increased the income gap between rich and poor. It also shifted spending in favor of the military and hurt the environment. Now Mr. Darman asks Democrats to support similar goals.
I hope that Democrats will respond with initiatives on campaign finance reform and the environment. Neither Mr. Darman nor President-elect George W. Bush should request a bipartisanship that disproportionately favors them.
 
FRED SCHACHAT
Durham, N.C., Dec. 24, 2000

HEADLINE: TRENDS;
Labor Puzzle: As Need for Temporary Workers Soars, Pay Lags

BYLINE: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
Labor activists say temporary workers are exploited and need more legal protection. Business groups say it just isn't so. The National Labor Relations Board weighed in on the issue last summer, giving temps more leeway to join unions.
 But what about the temps themselves? How vulnerable are they, really? 
 It is an important question because temporary workers make up one of the fastest-growing segments of the workforce, increasing to nearly 3 percent of the total today from less than 1 percent in 1985.
 As it turns out, they are a mixed group. They have missed out on the economic boom, with their inflation-adjusted annual pay rising just 5.1 percent since 1982, to an average of $20,500 today, compared with a gain of 14.8 percent to $36,500, for all nonfarm workers.
 But temporary workers are not necessarily downtrodden. According to the American Staffing Association, a trade group representing companies that supply temporary labor, more than half of temp workers are between jobs and do not need long-term representation. Of the remainder, one-fifth work occasionally because they do not want permanent jobs and one-quarter have stable work and receive the same benefits as traditional employees. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
MARCECA, ROBERT K.

 BODY:
MARCECA-Robert K., 57, President and owner of RKM Enterprises Real Estate Investments Inc. and Kane Realty Services, Inc., died on December 26, 2000 at NYU Hospital in NYC. Mr. Marceca was a real estate investor, developer and property manager. Mr. Marceca was in the real estate business for over 30 years. He developed, owned and managed his own real estate portfolio, both in the U.S. and abroad. During the 1980s he was extremely active in the cooperative/condominium business, having converted over 100 buildings throughout NYC, Westchester and Long Island. In the 1990s Mr. Marceca began buying unsold cooperative shares and condominium units of rent-stabilized and rent-controlled apartments at discounted values and more recently, began acquiring residential rental properties. Mr. Marceca was truly a maverick in defining the undervalued market niche for blocks of unsold shares of cooperative and unsold condominium units. Mr. Marceca maintained relationships with dozens of brokers, banks, financial institutions and private lending investment groups who assisted and participated with him in his many ventures. Robert was born on December 1, 1943 in NYC, the son of Alda Marceca and the late Robert P. Marceca. Mr. Marceca, a devoted family man, is survived by his wife, Nini, daughters Cathy Pilkin, Kobi, Kaylie, Riley and Siena, son, Nico, and grandchildren Kaitlin, Sean and Maggie. His contagious enthusiasm for life, his courage, commitment and leadership will be missed by his friends, colleagues, business associates and employees. Mr. Marceca was also a philanthropist, especially interested in organizations which served children. Mr. Marceca was a devoted member of the Steering Committee for Fight Against Childhood Epilepsy and Seizures (FACES), a charity at Mt. SinaiNYU Medical Center whose mission is to promote improved quality of life for children with epilepsy through clinical care, education, and research. Among Mr. Marceca's many generous contributions to the organization was an apartment for families to use while their child has brain surgery or is monitored at the Comprehensive Epilepsy Center at NYU. He was the founder of the Siena New Hope Home, which provides a safe haven to support children and aid them to achieve their maximum psychological, social and economic potential while fully respecting the dignity and worth of each individual. The home presently houses five children at a time. Mr. Marceca was also the founder of the Siena Hostel in Eluru, India, which schools 100 very poor children. He also purchased various supplies for the poor including food for hungry children and vehicles in Brazil, India, Ireland, Albania, Ethiopia and Eritrea. Funeral services will be held for the family on Thursday, December 28, 2000. A memorial serivice wil be held on Wednesday, January 3, 2001, at 10:30AM at the Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, 570 E. 33 St., NY NY. Expressions of sympathy may be made in Robert Marceca's name to the Siena New Hope Home, Box 518, New Monmouth, NJ 07748.
MARCECA-Robert K. In memoriam. The friends, colleagues, business associates and employees of Robert K. Marceca are profoundly saddened by his passing on December 26, 2000. After a noble struggle with cancer, he left a legacy colored by his keen intelligence, generosity of spirit, entrepreneurial brilliance and remarkable ability to be supportive of those he cared about. These wonderful qualities shall endure forever in the hearts of all who were fortunate enough to know him. Our deepest condolences to his family.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Issues Down in a Mixed Day for Share Prices

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Technology stock prices fell yesterday, in a weak follow-through to Friday's strong advance. Over all, however, major market indexes were mixed on the day.
Weakness in computer-related companies like Sun Microsystems and Oracle pushed the Nasdaq composite index down 23.50 points, or 0.9 percent, to 2,493.52. A rise late in the session limited the size of the Nasdaq's decline: earlier in the day the index was off as much as 80.10 points. 
 Meanwhile, energy and drug stocks lifted the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The Dow gained 56.88 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,692.44. Merck and Exxon Mobil were big gainers, while the S.& P. 500 rose 9.24 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,315.19.
"There is still some tax loss selling going on," said Andrew M. Brooks, head of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. "We are all waiting for the new year. This has been a brutal year."
Barring a solid advance over the remaining three trading days of 2000, the Nasdaq composite index will record the worst year since its inception in 1917. As of yesterday's close, the Nasdaq was down 38.7 percent so far this year. To date, the worst year for the Nasdaq was 1974, when the index fell 35.1 percent.
"It will be tough to prevent this being the worst year ever for Nasdaq," Mr. Brooks said.
Al Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, said "there was some tentative buying in motherhood stocks like utilities and some of the consumer nondurables, but the majority of investors are still concerned the Fed has overdone it, and probably precipitated a recession."
Mr. Goldman said such pessimism was unwarranted. "I think investors are making a mistake if they think the Fed will not be a friend" in the new year, he said. He expects a reduction in short-term interest rates of a quarter point or more by no later than the end of January.
"There are very low expectations for 2001," he said. "I strongly advise investors to be investing here."
With many traders and investors on vacation this week, activity on the New York Stock Exchange was the slowest in almost three months. About 806.5 million shares changed hands on the Big Board.
Among technology stocks, Sun Microsystems fell $1.56, to $30.31. Oracle lost 94 cents, to $30.94, and EMC slumped $2.94, to $65.31.
Yahoo was a technology highlight. The stock gained $1.63, to $31.19, after it said United States orders to Yahoo shopping sites almost doubled this holiday season from a year earlier. Orders outside of the United States were even stronger.
Wal-Mart Stores, a Dow component, fell $1.88, to $50.63. The retailer said holiday sales in stores open more than a year rose less than the 3 percent to 5 percent it had predicted earlier.
Merck led the gains in drug stocks, rising $2.19, to $92.69 a share. Eli Lilly was up $2.25, to $89.94. And Bristol-Myers Squibb closed at $70, up $1.63.
Rising demand for heating oil pushed oil stocks higher. Sunoco climbed $2.31, to $33.50, and Exxon Mobil rose $1.75, to $88.56.

Treasury Prices Fall
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices drifted lower yesterday as traders exploited a lull between the Christmas and New Year holiday weekends to book profits from a powerful surge in recent weeks.
But losses were limited and Treasury yields strayed little from near two-year lows hit last week as sentiment deepened that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates in the near future to rejuvenate a slowing economy.
Extremely thin volumes made for volatile trading, as a pricing error in an electronic trading system sent Treasuries stumbling sharply lower in the morning before the market regained its composure when the snag was discovered.
"That seemed to have been the excitement of the day," said Jay Meany, bond trader at CIBC World Markets.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 12/32 , to a price of 105 9/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.05 percent from 5.00 percent on Friday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 18/32 , to 112 2/32 . The bond's yield rose to 5.42 percent from 5.39 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Hope Is Artists' Medium In a Bronx Neighborhood;
Dancers, Painters and Sculptors Head to Hunts Point

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
In the late 1970's, while the Bronx was burning, a small cadre of artists gathered in a storefront gallery on Third Street near the Hub at 149th Street, in the heart of a neighborhood rapidly turning to rubble. They put sculptures in abandoned lots, photographed teenagers dancing on linoleum laid over cracked concrete and painted kaleidoscopic murals on the grayest of walls.
The arts scene that sprouted at the Fashion Moda Gallery, founded by a Viennese artist, Stefan Eins, helped ignite the careers of artists like Keith Haring and Jenny Holzer, the radical performance group known as the Guerrilla Girls and 1980's break dancers like the Rock Steady Crew. And it generated enough enthusiasm in the mainstream media for a short while to draw the art world's attention. 
 The spotlight shifted when the gallery closed in the mid-80's. And though that movement has dissolved, artists continue to live, work, and even thrive in the borough. Today, as the South Bronx enjoys an economic resurgence, artists and community organizers in Hunts Point are trying to recreate an arts scene that will draw attention back up to their neighborhood, this time to show off the area's revitalization.
"The difference now is that people aren't being imported into the neighborhood to make the scene," said John Matos, 38, a graffiti artist who exhibited at Fashion Moda in the 80's and has continued to work in his studio near the Hub. Instead, he said, the new scene is more grass-roots.
At the Point, a community center situated between a bank of auto repair shops on Garrison Avenue and a tiny stretch of historic row houses on Manida Street, Paul Lipson, the executive director, is leading an effort to make Hunts Point a magnet for the arts. He has invited dancers and theater artists to use the Point's rehearsal spaces and its theater at reduced rates, depending on their resources. And he has persuaded the landlord of a long-vacant warehouse across the street, the former American Banknote Building, to remodel the space and rent it out as artist studios.
Three new dance companies -- the Arthur Aviles Typical Theater, the Contemporary Ballet Theater and Full Circle Productions -- are rehearsing and performing in and around the Point, developing new work and attracting collaborators to the neighborhood. About a dozen artists -- sculptors, photographers and painters -- and artisans have moved into the Banknote Building.
Eddie Torres, visual arts director of the Longwood Art Project, an arts program and gallery that has been in the South Bronx since 1981, said the longevity of the scene would depend on how deeply artists around the Point could plant roots.
"So often, the temptation when you're an artist is to say that if you're going to make it, you have to go to SoHo or Chelsea," he said. "We want to cultivate the idea that you can stay here and make it here. When I worked in Detroit, we used to have a saying, 'There are stayers and goers.' We want to cultivate a community of stayers in the South Bronx."
The artists who have settled there have done so for the usual reasons artists seek new homes: cheap space and the hope of creating a cutting-edge arts community. At the Banknote Building, artists pay just $400 for a new 650-square-foot studio, about a third of what they might pay in downtown Manhattan.
Pepper, who uses one name, founder of the Contemporary Ballet Theater, a multiethnic dance company that fuses ballet with modern and traditional forms, said she could not ignore the obvious economic advantages of setting up shop in the South Bronx. Two years ago she started a dance instruction program at the Point, and in March she established her company's home there.
Through an arrangement with Mr. Lipson, her company gets free rehearsal space at flexible times. By saving money on rehearsal space, she is able to pay her dancers not only for performances but for rehearsals as well; she is also able to provide a small stipend for travel to and from the Bronx.
"I wouldn't have been able to start as big a company in any other venue," said Pepper, a small woman with an athletic build, locks of braided black hair and fiery eyes. "The spaces downtown are so in demand, there's no availability. Here I could dictate, and I could set up normal rehearsal schedules." She enlisted 34 dancers, including 20 professional adult dancers and 14 neighborhood children and teenagers, for a production of "The Nutcracker" that was presented at the Point last weekend.
Ana Garcia, like many artists working in and around the Point, was drawn by the neighborhood itself.
"Hip-hop originated in the Bronx, so a lot of people want to come here to see it," said Ms. Garcia, 29, who uses the name Rokafella when she dances. She and her husband, Gabriel Dionisio, 32, who goes by the name Kwikstep, established their hip-hop dance company, Full Circle Productions, at the Point this year.
As a group of young acolytes rehearsed head spins and deep back bends in the Point's studio, Ms. Garcia noted that Afrika Bambaataa, the founder of the hip-hop "family" Zulu Nation, grew up in the Bronx River Projects across the river from Hunts Point and helped create the hip-hop movement in the late 70's. He held some of the first parties in the South Bronx to feature break dancing, graffiti writing and D.J.'s.
"He brought artists from SoHo here, and D.J.'s from London up to the Bronx," Ms. Garcia said. "I do want to be part of that history. Being up here, as a hip-hop person, makes sense. It's like a rite of passage."
The first dance company to settle in Hunts Point was the Arthur Aviles Typical Theater, which took over a 3,500-square-foot space in the Banknote Building in the spring of 1999 and turned it into the Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, or BAAD! Mr. Aviles, who danced for many years with Bill T. Jones, grew up in the East Bronx and said he wanted to return to the borough to "create a dialogue" with his own community.
Mr. Aviles, who is gay, said his main goal was to explore the homophobic attitudes of some Puerto Ricans through his choreography and performances, like a recent production of "El Pato Feo," an interpretation of "The Ugly Duckling," with a transgendered protagonist.
"Here a boy and a boy kiss onstage and everyone goes, 'Ewww,' " he said. "Downtown, people don't go, 'Ewww,' but there's a silent way of dealing with homophobia, and usually it's a way that allows you to talk around the issue and never really talk about it. Here it's direct. And I want to be direct."
Other factors make working in the South Bronx a challenge, he said. For example, when he first began working in Hunts Point, he continued to hold rehearsals in Manhattan because he did not want to inconvenience his dancers. "It made no sense," he said recently. "I made a decision that any dancers who wanted to be part of my company will have to come here." He lost a few dancers, he said, but his company is stronger as a result.
Pepper, too, was wary about venturing to Hunts Point. Instead of asking dancers to meet her at the studio, she would pick them up by car in Lower Manhattan. Now she and her co-artistic director, Chantler L. Townsend, plan to move to a home on Manida Street so they can live as well as work in the neighborhood.
"What Mark Morris is doing near the Brooklyn Academy of Music in Fort Greene, what the Dance Theater Workshop is doing on the Lower East Side, is what we're doing here," Pepper said. "It's a little slower, and it's probably not as visible, but that's what we're doing."
Hunts Point remains one of the city's poorest neighborhoods, and the businesses near the Point still have a ramshackle, haphazard look. With the exception of historic Manida Street, a preserved row of quaint two-story homes, the blocks surrounding the center are mostly filled with new low-income housing developments, pawn shops and discount stores. To get to the Point from the No. 6 subway line from Manhattan, one has to cross a gloomy nine-lane underpass of the Bruckner Expressway where cars and trucks roar by at dangerous speeds.
The Point is a kind of oasis, shielded from the clamor of the surrounding area by large brick walls painted with vibrant graffiti murals by Tats Cru, the resident arts group. Inside squealing children run giddily from one arts program to the next, whether they are learning to play Latin jazz with Angel Rodriguez at the South Bronx Academy of Music, housed in a small room downstairs, or learning about photography in a darkroom set up last year with the help of the International Center for Photography in Manhattan.
The center's vitality both reflects and helps reinforce the slow but steady upturn in Hunts Point. In the last several years new housing has risen in many formerly abandoned lots, and neglected buildings have been rehabilitated. Storefronts on Hunts Point Avenue, the main drag, has attracted new businesses, like stores selling clothing and CD's, and the neighborhood even has its own new credit union and post office.
But while much has changed in Hunts Point since its reputation was forged by the 1981 film "Fort Apache, the Bronx," stigmas endure. While other areas of the city that have been adopted by artists, like the East Village (the once-forbidding "Alphabet City") and Williamsburg, Brooklyn (also troubled by looting, fires and abandonment in the 1980's), have managed to shake off their old reputations, the image of the burning Bronx has proven more tenacious.
"There's still a kind of psychological barrier for some artists and audiences to overcome," said Lydia Yee, curator of the Bronx Museum of the Arts in Morrisania. "Perhaps it is because the images of decay have been so persistent, and there haven't been any other images to counter that idea yet. Those kinds of positive images are slowly starting to make their way into mainstream culture, but it may take another decade or so before that becomes the dominant perception."
The stigma, she said, may be one reason why the South Bronx has had a harder time maintaining artists and art programs. Last fall an arts entrepreneur, Jack White, opened Hunts Point's first commercial gallery, A=I Gallery, at a space donated by ABC Carpet and Home, but within two months it folded.
But Gail Blauner, the manager of the Banknote Building, says she expects no diminution of artists' interest anytime soon. She is renovating the top floor of her warehouse in anticipation that she will be able to rent out the entire building, which had been vacant since 1985, by the end of the year.
"There are a lot of artists out there who are looking for space, and we'refilling up this space very quickly," Ms. Blauner said. "When people come in and see what this little area is, I think everyone walks away with a different attitude. My building already has enough artists so that it seems pretty easy to sell them. If I have a space for them, there are very few people who have not taken it."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Plymouth, Minus the Mythic Trimmings

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

THE TIMES OF THEIR LIVES
Life, Love and Death in Plymouth Colony
By James Deetz and Patricia Scott Deetz
Illustrated. 366 pages. W. H. Freeman and Company $24.95.
James Deetz and Patricia Scott Deetz begin "The Times of their Lives," their scholarly examination of life, love and death in the Plymouth Colony, with a bit of down-to-earth realism about Thanksgiving. 
 They go back to a primary source, a letter written in 1621 by a Mayflower immigrant, Edward Winslow, that, the Deetzes say, is the only "eyewitness description of the events that were to become the basis of a uniquely American holiday." They find that the standard view of the origins of Thanksgiving -- devout Pilgrims looking toward heaven giving thanks in the company of a few Indian -- is essentially mythical.
"In a sense, the most remarkable thing about Winslow's brief account is that it makes no mention of giving thanks," the Deetzes write. What the settlers were doing on that fateful day in the fall of 1621 in Plymouth was to celebrate a standard English custom: harvest home. They probably didn't eat turkey, the authors say, although they drank plenty of beer. There were twice as many Indians as settlers present, and the celebrants most likely sat on chests or stones or logs, not on chairs around what look like picnic tables in typical depictions of the feast.
The point is not only that our concept of Thanksgiving as an essentially American festival of gratitude is a myth. It is also that the Pilgrims are not exactly who we imagine them to be. They are, the Deetzes put it, "a quasi-mythic group of people who are looked upon today as the founders of America, and whose dedication to hard work and noble purposes gave rise to our nation as we know it."
In fact, in a time given to revisionism, skepticism and debunking of national fables, it is not at all clear how many Americans take the semi-apocryphal Pilgrims as historical reality. Still, the Deetzes have written a hard-headed description of what we can know, based on the evidence, of life in the Plymouth Colony during its first century or so. Their book is fascinating on certain subjects: crime among the Pilgrims, their sexual practices, the legal status of women and the frequency of accidental deaths.
On other subjects -- the designs of houses, the artifacts that have been dug up in archaeological excavations and the development of Plimouth Plantation, today's museum of Pilgrim life -- the Deetzes' book is dry, textbookish and of interest more to scholars than to general readers.
What you will not find in "The Times of Their Lives" is much political history or theological description of the Puritans of Plymouth Colony. Indeed, the Deetzes don't even mention the work of such historians as Perry Miller, whose lifetime examination of Pilgrim intellectual life is deemed basic reading by historians. But the Deetzes do show in many ways, from the quantities of alcohol the Pilgrims consumed to the absence of log cabin homes in Plymouth Colony, that the Pilgrims were more flavorful, more colorful, more tempestuous than their religiously righteous images would suggest. The Pilgrims committed adultery (of course, we've known that since Hawthorne's "Scarlet Letter"); there was homosexuality; they were superstitious; and they were litigious: the court records are replete with formal accusations of witchcraft, attempted adultery and defamation.
The Deetzes point out early on that from the very beginning the Pilgrim enterprise involved more enterprise than the search for religious freedom, though they do not discount the importance of religion for many. The original Puritans went into voluntary exile in the Netherlands when they formed the idea of creating a community in the New World. But there weren't enough of them to attract the support of English investors. So among the Mayflower passengers, in addition to the Separatists, who had no use for the established English church, were others who were mainly interested in economic opportunity.
Mr. Deetz, who died a few weeks ago, was a professor of archaeology at the University of Virginia and had been assistant director of the Plimouth Plantation; Mrs. Deetz is a cultural historian and anthropologist. The final chapters of their book are largely histories of American Colonial archaeology, with an account of the project to make Plimouth Plantation historically accurate tacked on at the end. The lay reader will find material of interest here -- that, for example, the Pilgrims ate with spoons, not forks (which were considered a foppish affection until the 18th century).
The Deetzes also make an important observation about the absence of log cabins in Plymouth: "This is yet another small part of the Pilgrim Myth, and as is the case of the other parts of this story, it reflected widely held ideas about the American past," they write, "in which log cabins symbolized the spirit of the pioneers, and how humble beginnings can sometimes lead to greater things."
Despite such valuable insights, these portions of the book smack of shop talk. They are simply not very interesting, especially in comparison with more earthy matters like the kinds of crimes committed in Plymouth and by whom. Examining court records, for example, the Deetzes uncovered the case of Mary Mendame, who in 1639 was put on trial for adultery; her partner in the offense, for which she was publicly whipped, was an Indian named Tinsin. Tinsin was given a lighter sentence because his crime came about, the court found, "through the allurement and enticement" of Mendame.
In short, illicit passions inflamed the hearts of at least some of the Pilgrims, even in the first two decades of settlement. The examples of real life, erotic and not, discovered by the Deetzes give the ostensible founders of the American nation not only a less mythic past but a far more frail human one as well.

HEADLINE: Vietnam's Trade Imbalance And Economy Keep Growing

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE Dec. 26

 BODY:
Higher oil prices have not diminished the allure of Vietnam's own symbol of upward mobility, the motorbike, as the country's slowly opening economy and the prospect of freer trade with the United States bolster consumer demand.
Vietnam imported 1.58 million motorbikes this year, more than double the number imported last year, according to figures released today by the country's General Statistics Office. The bikes, typically with engines of 100 horsepower or less, contributed to an overall $892 million trade deficit for the year. 
 Despite the trade deficit, weak foreign investment, and tottering state-owned industries, Vietnam's government predicted today that the economy has grown 6.75 percent this year, beating forecasts by both the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
Oil was a larger factor in driving up Vietnam's trade imbalance. While Vietnam exports crude oil, it lacks the refining capacity to turn its oil into useful things like gasoline for the motorbikes that already clog its city streets. So while higher oil prices have helped bolster Vietnam's oil revenues 70 percent, to $3.6 billion this year, the bill for imported fuel and other petroleum products rose 90 percent to more than $2 billion.
The hope is that exports will get a hand from a new trade agreement with the United States signed earlier this year. Trade experts say the accord, which puts Vietnam on equal footing with America's other trading partners, is likely to be ratified by the United States Congress by this spring, giving a boost to Vietnamese exports of textiles, shoes and seafood. Tariffs on Vietnamese goods will fall from an average of 40 percent to just 3 percent. The World Bank has estimated that would increase Vietnamese exports to the United States more than 50 percent.
But exports are not the only source of wealth in Vietnam's economy, as the boom in motorbike sales attests. There are already an estimated 6.5 million motorbikes in Vietnam, one for every dozen Vietnamese (with each motorbike often carrying three or even four people simultaneously). Yet the average motorbike costs several times what most Vietnamese earn in one year, officially. Bankers and executives say up to $1 billion in cash and gold is saved under mattresses. Vietnamese living abroad, moreover, send back what by some estimates amounts to another $1 billion every year.
