HEADLINE: A Park Offers Nature, Not Just Hoops

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
TO sit quietly under a tree. To dance in the grass, play in a stream. Until the recent opening of the Augustus F. Hawkins Natural Park -- a park the neighborhood helped design to include bits of wildness -- these were some things it was impossible to do in South Central Los Angeles. With irresistible symbols that include hills made from recycled Malibu mudslides, residents of one of the city's densest and poorest neighborhoods finally have a park, with an around-the-clock ranger in a Smokey Bear hat and an arroyo with rocks from the Los Angeles River.
"Something we couldn't have, we have now," said Jorge Lopez, who, with his wife, Silvia, was on the neighborhood committee that helped transform an eight-acre storage yard for water pipes into a natural habitat anchored by a giant avocado tree. "We can say, 'This is mine,' like fine jewelry." 
 Any kind of park -- let alone one with an Arts and Crafts-style ranger station -- would be news in South Central. The neighborhood, which is mostly Latino, is perhaps best known to outsiders for the 1992 riots, a landscape dominated by industrial buildings, freeways, rail lines and houses ornamented with security grillwork. A majority of the city's parks are in movie-star habitat, the verdant Santa Monica Mountains. The city's west side, which includes Bel Air and Beverly Hills, has 13,310 acres of public open space, compared with 75 acres for the southeastern section.
The natural park, which local teenagers call "o.g." -- original -- is designed to confound this social geography, to bring "the messiness and utter joys of natural places" to the community, in the words of Randy Hester, a Berkeley landscape architect who worked pro bono on the plan with the neighborhood. The $4.5 million park was financed largely by city, county and state bond measures, including a recent state proposition for safe neighborhood parks.
With its undulating hills, shady walkways and slightly unruly vegetation, including baby cattails along the new arroyo, the park deliberately recalls the work of Frederick Law Olmsted, whose "pleasure grounds" simulated the nature of the countryside in the city. It reflects a growing movement among landscape architects, city planners, environmentalists and neighborhood advocates for natural, ecologically diverse parks that also function as community gathering places.
It is a reaction against the design equivalent of racial profiling -- the assumption, dominant in urban park design from the 1930's until recently, that what poor neighborhoods need most is active recreation dominated by rec centers and asphalt basketball courts.
"In a sense, we've come full circle back to Olmsted," said Walter Hood, chairman of the landscape and environmental planning department at the University of California at Berkeley, who recently designed a small park in this spirit in the Latino Fruitvale district of Oakland. "We're rediscovering the idea of wild, romantic landscapes in the city as a way of balancing social, physical and economic issues."
The formerly foreboding stretch of Compton Avenue where the new park lies, about three miles from downtown, was called the "pipe graveyard."
"This was the most unsightly junkyard you've ever seen," said Rita Walters, the city councilwoman who championed the idea of bringing the feeling of the city's distant mountains and canyons to her flat, tree-starved neighborhood. "Who says wonderful parks are only for the affluent?"
The original plan for the land called for sports fields and facilities, which the neighborhood already had. "It reflected California's fondness for turning everything into an outdoor gym," said Stephanie Landregan, the landscape architect for the Mountains Recreation and Conservation Authority, which joined another state entity, the Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy, in building the park. "What hasn't been given to neighborhoods is a social place, a safe place for people to recreate the spirit, as opposed to recreating their bodies," she said. "That's what this neighborhood said it wanted."
Tom Carter, an English teacher at Edison Middle School, about two blocks from the park, was picnicking with a group of students on a recent Sunday under the cool embrace of the avocado tree. "These kids have nothing," he said. "At night they hear gunfire and mosquos" -- police helicopters, that is, as they are called in a clipped form of the word for mosquitoes.
"The schools are asphalt," he continued. "Except for restaurants and boxing centers, there's very little beauty that's public."
The park's design was a little over a year in the making. Mr. Hester had previously worked with the conservancy on the Big Wild, a system of roughly 20,000 acres of wilderness in the Santa Monica Mountains. He met Ms. Walters in 1991 while re-forming a mountainside that had been graded for a six-lane freeway over the Santa Monicas, which was eventually halted. She saw the earth sculpturing, the natural planting and carefully placed rock, essentially a rebuilt mountain, and said, "I want one of those in my neighborhood," he recalled.
He began canvassing the community with his landscape students from Berkeley, setting up a table in front of Martha Maravilla's M&M Mini Market & Takeout, a little restaurant across the street from what is now the park entrance, which is flanked by massive stone pillars that evoke Yosemite more than South Central. Famous locally for its menudo, or tripe and hominy soup, the restaurant became the unofficial park design headquarters, with blueprints and drawings pinned to the wall beside the pan dulce display. "It was important for the community," said Mrs. Maravilla, who grew up in the Mexican state of Michoacan. "It's back to nature, the way it should be."
The community was given a range of choices, including more typical playgrounds and soccer fields. It went for the greenest alternative. The first priority was to get a 24-hour-a-day park ranger and good security: the residents wanted the park to be fenced and locked at night. South Central is home to at least four major street gangs, and children know to avoid playgrounds and other shreds of unguarded open space.
A close second was a desire for places where older people and families could sit and walk, with benches, like a traditional zocalo, or plaza. They also wanted picnic areas for large groups; natural places for children to explore, especially an arroyo, or stream; and lots of hills, which Mr. Hester calls "miniature mountains," to play in. The hills also allowed for a variety of habitats, from woodlands to fields of native grasses.
"At first people said: 'What do we need to see birds for? The kids want seesaws,' " recalled Mr. Lopez, a member of the Volunteer Neighborhood Oversight Committee. "Then they began thinking of something different. Hispanic people like outdoor fiestas, big parks. Here you can do that, but there is also quiet."
Alma Lopez, another committee member, said: "Our kids don't go to the mountains or summer camp. It's too far to get to nature. We felt we should have nature right here."
Programs will include Saturday morning bus trips to the real mountains, nature talks, tutoring in science homework and a "survival program" -- survival in the wild, that is -- with Ranger Luke McJimpson, who will be living full time above the nature center, which includes a small wildlife museum. The five jobs available in the park -- three full-time and two part-time -- have attracted more than 400 applications from the community.
One recent afternoon, the sun was warm, beckoning the neighborhood to the boughs of the avocado tree. A group of young women had shed their sneakers, just to dance. Children were playing steppingstones in the arroyo, filling their squirt guns in the stream that cascades beneath the glinting windmill. Others tested their scooters on the hills, whizzing past fledgling oaks, marsh grasses and scruffy chaparral.
Cotton-candy vendors, bearing tall plumes of blue, pink and violet, plied their wares, and Maria Jesus Davalos, who grew up in El Salvador, sold homemade gorditas, or corn cakes, from a big silver kettle.
The park -- instantly, it seemed -- had become a living place. Like all living things, it is fragile. "Believe me, it's going to be hard to keep it the way it is," Mr. Lopez said. "I think the community is going to change a little, look out for itself more."
Olee Evans, a phone installer who now lives in the Simi Valley, grew up as a gang member in the neighborhood and knows well the violent dance that turf border wars can bring. He was standing atop the hill with the windmill with his baby daughter, Olesha, looking out from a new vantage point on his old turf.
"Before, this place was rough, frightening, and it could be either one still today," he said. "It's a crosscut of borders." But he predicted that the gangs will respect the park.
"Anything that's change around here is for the better, and this has a little naturalness to it," he said. "It gives you more of a view on everything. It's real out here."

HEADLINE: More Than Just Clutter: Eclecticism by Design

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY STEVENS 

 BODY:
WITH its natural oak Stickley rocker and bench, Arthur English's studio apartment in Manhattan is a paragon of Arts and Crafts style. Or with its shiny veneered 1920's chest of drawers, is it Deco? Wait, with the trendy Danish dining room set, maybe it's midcentury modern?
"I gave up trying to stick to one style," said Mr. English, a computer consultant who moonlights as the host of a public access cable show. "I prefer an eclectic mix of periods, and even though it's a challenge to do it well, right now that look is the hottest look out there." 
 It's official: Empire-style bureaus may be placed next to Eames cubbies, and 1950's Formica kitchen tables will go with traditional American jelly cupboards, original paint intact. Moreover, stark modern plastic chairs may henceforth nestle up to country pine farm tables imported from Provence. So-called shelter magazines are touting eclectic as cutting edge.
Haven't people always lived with a mix of hand-me-downs and new furniture? Of course they have. The difference is that they haven't been told that harmonious-but-fragmented is an official style, one that they should set out to achieve. Besides, how do you really know if you've gotten it right?
People rip out pages of magazines and zip from auction house to antique store in search of the perfect complementary pieces. But designers and shop owners say that putting disparate items together is harder than it seems.
Anne Igelbrink, assistant vice president at Christie's East, said she sees wealthy clients mixing all kinds of styles together. "It's not uncommon to see buyers mixing midcentury-modern pieces with anything from Asian antiques to Biedermeier to Deco," she said.
And it doesn't always work. John Barman, a decorator and designer, says the trend has arisen because there are so many late-in-life couples combining households. He knows because he has seen some terrible fights between couples who, he said, "had sizable collections of English antiques or French antiques or museum-quality midcentury-modern pieces." Someone with an eye can combine those collections brilliantly, of course. But that is often the exception.
"The truth is," Mr. Barman said, "I've seen a lot of nightmare interiors out there."
Dominique Browning, editor in chief of House & Garden magazine, warns that "eclectic can be another word for a mess or an excuse for a mess." The trend may have started, she said, because people want to avoid the tyranny of the decorator and express their own style of mix and match -- which she agrees is "particularly difficult to achieve."
But it can be worth it, she said. "The line of a Louis XVI chair and a Ming table next to each other is surprising," she said. "It makes both pieces suddenly more interesting, and it really wakes you up."
Ms. Igelbrink suggests that "a decorative piece of Nouveau silver goes beautifully on a modern chest of drawers."
Michael Winters, the owner of Brand X Design Lab on East 20th Street in Manhattan, is someone with the confidence to mix away. He has a loft office with George Miller plastic stacking chairs and a 1960's feel. But it also has a 1950's Knoll desk, a Borsani Tecno chair and a pair of Christian Dell lamps from the Bauhaus era. "Oddly enough, it all comes together and works," he said. "At least in my opinion it does," he added, a bit peevishly. And who is to judge?
John Stilgoe, a professor of environmental studies at Harvard University, says homeowners were once well educated about home decor and distinctive styles. There were home decorating guides that laid down strict rules, and no one was going to confuse or mix Arts and Crafts with French provincial.
"People bought furniture in sets because the general consensus was that a room should not be visually jangling," he said. "The trend has shifted, and there are quite a few people out there in search of some sort of guidance. Eclecticism is the answer for many." Rocco Leonardis, a professor of interior design at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan, contends that interior design has been codified since as far back as the second century, making it much easier to achieve status in a society. "The eclectic look, which has become trendy, is not design," he said. "It's collecting, and there's a big difference."
But even if it's collecting, some people have trouble. Deborah Grant, an assistant at a private equity firm, is able to make snap decisions about the financial markets from her office, but finds herself facing a crisis of confidence when she shops for her home. She and her friends are trying to achieve that haphazard-but-intentional look. "None of us want to feel outdated," she said.
She maintains that stores like Pottery Barn, Crate & Barrel and Banana Republic Home are selling the same things, so it takes extra time and a sharp eye to find something unique. "I'm always looking for something a little different because it's cool," she said. "But it's not always that easy."
Greg Wooten and Becca Parrish have decorated their loft in a deliberate mix: a Paul Frankl Art Deco cabinet sits on a primitive folk art rug; a modern industrial aluminum cabinet holds a collection of ceramics from the 30's. "Mixing it up has always been happening in homes and apartments, but most of the time it's by accident," Mr. Wooten said. "Now there is a status attached if you can mix a bunch of different styles and periods." Mr. Wooten and Patrick Parrish (Becca Parrish's brother) recently mixed things up at their furniture store Mondo Cane at 143 West 22nd Street.
Yet Mr. Parrish, too, winces at the combinations some people propose. "Just because you have a beautiful 1920's table and an Eames chair doesn't mean they necessarily go together," he said. "There has to be something sympathetic about the two pieces and then the look totally works."
More and more people are thinking about design these days, says Paul Siskin, a designer based in Manhattan. With the economy still strong, a proliferation of style publications, easy access to eBay and the Internet (where connoisseurship can be cultivated) and increased travel, Americans' level of sophistication is ratcheting upward. "But access isn't analogous with taste," he said. "People need help."
And sometimes no amount of help will settle a couple's design conflict. Someone who wants Zen simplicity is probably never going to tolerate flowered wallpaper. Evan Galen, a Manhattan decorator and designer, says he often feels like a therapist to couples in conflict who think eclectic design will be their salvation. He tried telling one couple that the eclectic look was in vogue. "Unfortunately, when she admitted she hated yellow and he loved it, what she was really saying was that she hated him and he loved himself," Mr. Galen said, with a laugh.
The question remains, however: could a Hoosier cabinet, with its original crackle finish, provide the glue that would bring together a couple like this, her with her Bakelite radios and him with his framed posters from the "Star Wars" movies?

HEADLINE: Regional Trade Pacts Thrive As the Big Players Fail to Act

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The 15-country European Union dwarfs any Continental rivals, but that has not stopped the tiny European Free Trade Association, with all of four members, from plowing ahead to sign its own market access deals.
The four countries, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland, which account for less than 3 percent of world trade, are intent on expanding the trade network. The group has signed up Mexico, Yugoslavia and the four Latin American countries that make up the regional trade association Mercosur in recent weeks, and is negotiating with Canada and Chile. 
 With 16 deals in place with nations outside the European Union, the group is exploring negotiations with a number of others, including Singapore and Jordan.
The flurry of accords by the 40-year-old trading group is not a European phenomenon. Countries in Asia are also moving rapidly to pin down bilateral trade pacts. Asian-Pacific countries are accelerating efforts to make sure their companies have an equal footing in other markets, particularly with China expected to become a member of the World Trade Organization sometime in the next few months.
Underlying the new web of agreements is not only concern about the neighboring trade giant, but worry that multilateral trade progress is paralyzed.
Ever since the opening of a new global trade round flopped in Seattle last year, efforts to get new negotiations off the ground have been stymied. Medium-size and smaller countries have tired of waiting for the European Union to come up with a unified approach among its fractious members and for the new administration in the United States to set its negotiating course.
There is also concern that the continuing friction between the two biggest trading powers is creating an atmosphere that weakens the World Trade Organization's strength as the ultimate global arbiter of trade disputes.
The director general of the trade organization, Mike Moore, agrees. "Globalization is the word on everyone's lips, yet regional agreements have never been so popular," he said in a speech last month in Buenos Aires.
Statistics bear him out. In 1990, there were 50 regional trade groupings compared with 200 today.
A single regional market "can increase economic efficiency," Mr. Moore said. Such pacts can also help the poorer countries build on their competitive advantages, and increase their political commitment to an open economy, he said.
But regional accords can widen the trade divide between the industrialized and the developing countries, Mr. Moore warned. Regionalism alone "leads not towards an open world economy, but an unbalanced system of hub and spokes, with rich countries at the center, holding all the cards, and developing countries on the periphery."
The trend, however, is toward more such regional deals, with 70 such accords now under discussion.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Fall Again, Signaling Slowdown in Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators fell in November, the seventh month out of eight without an increase, the Conference Board said today. The drop could be an indication that the economy is slowing more than Federal Reserve policy makers had wanted.
The index, intended to be a predictor of economic activity over the next three to six months, fell 0.2 percent last month after declining 0.3 percent in October. The drop in November reflected falling stock prices and rising layoffs. 
 Except for a revised 0.1 percent increase in September, the index has not risen since March, adding to the likelihood Federal Reserve officials will cut interest rates next month.
"The indicators are pointing to significantly slower growth in the first half of 2001," said Ken Goldstein, an economist with the research group, based in New York. "Still, the index is only 0.4 percent lower than it was one year ago. That is not the mark of any major contraction in business conditions."
Analysts had expected a decline of 0.2 percent, the same as had been first reported for October. Previously reported economic statistics are used to compile the index.
Among the 10 components in the index, 5 had a negative effect and 3 made positive contributions. Two components -- money supply and the spread between the Treasury's 10-year note and the overnight bank lending rate -- had no effect.
Higher jobless claims, slower workweeks, faster supplier deliveries, lower orders for consumer goods and a decrease in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index pulled the index down. Increases in orders for nonmilitary goods, building permits and consumer expectations were positive contributors.
The index of coincident indicators, a gauge of current economic activity, rose 0.1 percent in November. The index of lagging indicators rose 0.3 percent.

HEADLINE: What Tax Cuts Can Buy For Health

BYLINE: By Matthew Miller; Matthew Miller is a senior fellow at the Annenberg Public Policy Center, University of Pennsylvania.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The buzz in Washington is that education offers the new administration its one early chance for bipartisanship, but that George W. Bush's stubborn pursuit of his $1.3 trillion tax cut could kill such cooperation in the cradle. But the critics of Mr. Bush's plans may be wrong in their pessimism. In fact, his big tax cut could be the basis for achieving a different and surprising bipartisan endgame in 2001 that even President Clinton would have to applaud: extending health insurance to most of the 43 million Americans who lack it.
Here's how. For starters, Mr. Bush knows that in the new divided Congress he won't be able to pass his tax cut as conceived in the campaign. Democrats and even moderate Republicans resist cuts in marginal rates and elimination of the estate tax in ways that shower most benefits on wealthy Americans, even if they pay the bulk of the taxes. 
 At the same time, Democrats are desperate to extend coverage to the uninsured, whose ranks could rise past 50 million if the economy stalls. Even liberals in Congress who have favored a Canadian-style single-payer system have become more pragmatic, saying they're open to such traditionally Republican approaches as tax subsidies for individuals for the purchase of private insurance.
The contours of a deal thus emerge. Mr. Bush puts forward his original tax plan to appease his conservative base, and it goes nowhere. But he can't afford to allow his signature initiative to go down in flames. So, sometime this spring, he orders his aides to come up with a way to salvage it with a compromise that can win public credit as a huge tax cut, but that Democrats will embrace.
The answer they should come back with is plain: Mr. Bush should put a much bigger chunk of his tax cut -- perhaps $50 billion a year -- into health coverage. He already offered small tax subsidies earmarked for the purchase of health insurance in the campaign. That plan offered up to $2,000 per family, at a cost of roughly $10 billion a year. But that plan was largely rhetorical, because decent family health policies cost closer to $5,000. Mr. Bush should make his subsidies much bigger, target them toward those with lower incomes and offer a refundable tax credit for those with incomes too low to pay taxes.
In exchange, Democrats would surely give him some of his original package, like eliminating the marriage penalty and partial estate tax reform. He'll still be passing a tax cut of Reaganesque proportions. But by enabling millions of families to buy private health insurance, he'll also be proving that "compassionate conservatism" is more than a campaign slogan.
If Mr. Bush takes this route, he won't be the first Republican president to offer such a rich health plan. The senior President George Bush, in 1992, proposed health care tax subsidies that, in today's dollars, offered up to $5,100 per family, costing $50 billion a year. That plan was in fact slightly bigger than the one Bill Bradley proposed in his primary campaign this year. Yet in 1992, Democrats, sensing that the president was vulnerable, rejected it as too little, too late. Since then, of course, the number of uninsured Americans has risen by 6 million.
The groundwork for expanding health coverage through tax subsidies has been laid. Rep. Jim McDermott of Seattle, a liberal Democrat, and Rep. Jim McCrery of Louisiana, a conservative Republican, are preparing a bill along these lines. As their cooperation suggests, a potential grand bargain on health care would require Democrats to accept subsidies in the form of tax cuts and Republicans to accept the need to make sure everyone can afford a decent policy.
If Mr. Bush is wise enough to be politically flexible, he can redeploy his tax cut in ways that Democrats and the nation will cheer later.

HEADLINE: In America;
Fragile Victories

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
In the early 1980's the producers of the made-for-TV movie "The Day After" needed a neighborhood suitable for filming scenes of the aftermath of a nuclear attack. No problem. They filmed at the intersection of Linwood and Prospect boulevards in Kansas City, Mo. Over the past several decades, few things have been easier than locating inner-city neighborhoods that had literally been reduced to rubble, destroyed as if by bombing.
The South Bronx in the mid-1970's was such a nightmare of destruction that it shocked the entire nation. Airline passengers flying over the Bronx on the approach to La Guardia Airport could look out the windows and watch the fires rage. An incredible 40,000 arson fires were set in a four-year period. 
 As spectacular fires blazed just blocks from Yankee Stadium during the 1977 World Series, Howard Cosell told a national television audience, "There it is again, ladies and gentlemen. The Bronx is burning."
That was then. In their new book, "Comeback Cities," Paul Grogan and Tony Proscio describe some of the remarkable, even miraculous improvements that have occurred in previously devastated neighborhoods in Kansas City, New York, Chicago, Cleveland and other big cities across the country.
It's not just the downtown areas of the nation's great cities that are coming back. The ghettos, the slums, the neighborhoods that seemingly had surrendered unconditionally to rot and to fear are in the early stages of a long march back to viability.
Urban issues are among the great unmentionables in American politics and media. But some good things are happening. Mr. Grogan and Mr. Proscio open their book by saying, "The American inner city is rebounding -- not just cosmetically, but fundamentally."
Referring to the area surrounding the intersection of Linwood and Prospect in Kansas City, they write: "Now, after more than 15 years of steady effort, the Community Development Corporation of Kansas City has produced two major shopping centers there, built more than 300 homes, a library, and a senior center, and in all created a bustling, thriving urban crossroad remarkable only to those who remember the wasteland that came before."
In the South Bronx, more than 10,000 new houses and apartments were built from 1988 to 1997. Crime is down dramatically. Property values and real estate tax collections have increased sharply. School attendance is up. And the widespread sense of desolation and despair, which seemed impossible to lift a quarter of a century ago, has largely given way to feelings of enthusiasm and community pride.
These are not isolated occurrences. "Essentially what has happened is that a set of trends that are usually seen as unrelated are converging to lift the fortunes of inner-city neighborhoods," said Mr. Grogan, an urban expert who is now the vice president for government, community and public affairs at Harvard.
Some of the most important factors were:
* The thousands of neighborhood-based nonprofit organizations that have worked quietly but relentlessly over the past couple of decades, in cities from coast to coast, to bring together public and private resources to rebuild neighborhoods.
* The return of legitimate commercial activity to many of these neighborhoods. This has been bolstered by the strong national economy of the last several years, and by the virtual revolution in commercial lending practices sparked by the federal Community Reinvestment Act.
* The historic declines in crime over the past several years.
This nascent revival that is taking hold in so many inner-city neighborhoods is distressingly fragile. An economic downturn, especially one that resulted in significant losses of jobs, could be devastating. Increases in crime could wipe out the painstaking gains of many years. And an erosion of political support for the Community Reinvestment Act, which was attacked by some conservative Republicans last year, would be like a death knell.
The recent improvements in the inner cities are, at best, baby steps in a long, long march. "Comeback Cities" is an optimistic book. With a new, more conservative administration gearing up in Washington, it remains to be seen if that optimism can be sustained. 
http://www.nytimes.com

TITLE: COMEBACK CITIES (BOOK)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Tennessee shop starts an apprentice program to try to draw talented young people to the field.

BYLINE: By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
IT is not a new problem, to be sure: for several years now, executives in the advertising business have been complaining about the difficulty they are having in attracting talented young people to careers on Madison Avenue.
Blame the dot-coms, their high visibility, trendiness and commercial sex appeal; blame a sophisticated 20-something population that has grown up cynical about sales pitches and the people who make them. 
 The fact remains that advertising is an industry where starting salaries, nationwide, languish at or under $30,000 annually, both on the creative and account sides, according to a survey conducted last year by the American Association of Advertising Agencies. Those kinds of numbers are not hard for novice job-seekers to beat, even today, "with a general softening of the economy," according to O. Burtch Drake, the association's president.
So, short of restructuring their wage scales, how can agencies get young people into the business? Many of them have internship programs, of course, designed to introduce advertising to college students. And there are scholarship programs, including one aimed at minority and female students sponsored by the American Association of Advertising Agencies Foundation. It provides grants to students of schools that specialize in advertising, among them the Creative Circus and the Portfolio Center, both in Atlanta, and the Miami Ad School in Florida.
The association has also produced a recruitment video, featuring Donny Deutsch, the prominent advertising executive, and young agency employees from New York shops, who all wax poetic about their jobs.
But there can only be so many scholarships. Videos are, well, just videos. And internships often degenerate into little more than discouraging, low-paying or no-paying "gofer" jobs, according to Ken Sossaman, chief executive of Sossaman & Associates, based in Tennessee. With about 40 employees and $23 million in annual business, his agency is by no means a big shop, even in Memphis, where it ranks "fourth or fifth," he said. But he is faced with the same talent issues as larger agencies.
"I've been frustrated for a long time that I can't get the people I need," he said. "I decided there had to be an answer."
And so he came up with one: the Launching Pad, an apprenticeship program for people interested in advertising careers who might nevertheless drift into other endeavors because of a lack of appropriate training or guidance. The program -- whose logo is a rocket ship -- is set to "blast off" next month with its first five participants, or "crew members," chosen from among 20 applicants from colleges in the South.
The program differs from a traditional internship in a number of ways, Mr. Sossaman said. The participants, who will be paid for working 20 to 30 hours a week, will have "real work" of their own, a project for a local charity that will be their responsibility and that will run in local print and broadcast media when completed. They will also do quick projects for current clients on short notice. And they will work independently on assignments that are similar to the work being done by regular agency employees, he said, so that "we can see what they come up with."
But the biggest difference, he said, is the supervision the participants will receive. Mr. Sossaman has hired Rikki Boyce, a former creative director for his agency and the president of the Memphis Advertising Federation, to be the Launching Pad "captain." She will run the program full time.
"I don't know of any other program like this," Ms. Boyce said, "where there is a person totally devoted to the participants, and to getting them to think differently, strategically."
Applicants for spots on the Launching Pad crew were required to answer questions about how they might conduct a certain kind of advertising campaign, Ms. Boyce said. They also had to provide proof of their creativity, not necessarily in advertising. For example, Jacqueline Daigle, 22, a successful applicant from Louisiana State University, provided a watercolor picture of a costume design she had done for a student production of Stephen Sondheim's "Into The Woods" and a poem she had written. She said she could not wait for the program to begin.
"I am really looking forward to working with creative people who are willing to give other people a chance," she said.
What will happen when the semester-long program ends? Mr. Sossaman said Launching Pad participants would not be committed to work for his agency or for any other agency, although he hopes he will be in a position "to hire the best of them." He said he is also committed to helping them get advertising jobs elsewhere, if that is what they want.
And what if the siren song of the dot-coms still proves too strong, and participants decide that advertising is not for them at all?
"There's always the next group," he said.

HEADLINE: To Bush on Russia: Forward, Not Back

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "A New Look at Russia" (Week in Review, Dec. 24): 
 As an American working with Russians to build a civil society and a market economy, I feel offended by President-elect George W. Bush's focus on cold-war security issues as the means to work with Russia.
Reversing President Clinton's focus on Russian civil society and market reform will not result in what Condoleezza Rice, Mr. Bush's choice for national security adviser, calls her hope for "a more realistic and a more fruitful relationship with Russia." The open discussions on security were possible because of the intensive contact with all sectors of Russian society.
Treating Russia as part of Europe in the State Department, abrogating the Antiballistic Missile Treaty and rattling sabers over missile defense systems will only create impossible conditions for a market economy, increased trade and the protection of civil liberties and human rights in Russia.
 
SARAH TISCH
Washington, Dec. 24, 2000
 
The writer is an economic development adviser.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Like it or not, appearance counts in the workplace.

BYLINE: By Virginia Postrel; This column appears here every Thursday. Virginia Postrel is the editor at large of Reason magazine and the author of "The Future and Its Enemies: The Growing Conflict Over Creativity, Enterprise and Progress."

 BODY:
FROM Al Gore's earth-tone suits to Katherine Harris's makeup to George W. Bush's post-election boil, the 2000 presidential race was filled with commentary on how the players looked. For the first time, the Gallup Organization even polled people on which candidate was better-looking. (Mr. Gore beat Mr. Bush, 44 percent to 24 percent.) The question was worth asking because the answer was not obvious. Both candidates were way above average.
Critics bemoan the emphasis on the way candidates look as a perverse product of media-oriented campaigns. But even in jobs where no TV time is required, the good-looking have a competitive edge. And, contrary to popular belief, the economic rewards for beauty are greater for men than for women. 
 That is what two economists -- Daniel S. Hamermesh of the University of Texas at Austin and Jeff E. Biddle of Michigan State University -- found in a 1994 analysis of data from surveys of thousands of United States and Canadian households.
Other factors being equal, the unfortunate 9 percent of working men whom interviewers classified as "below average" or downright "homely" made 9 percent less in hourly earnings than did more attractive men. By contrast, the 32 percent of men classified as "above average" or "handsome" got a wage premium of 5 percent. Women took a 5 percent hit for bad looks and earned a 4 percent premium for beauty.
This does not mean the ugly are doomed to poverty, since other factors matter a lot in determining income. The difference between the bottom and top categories, Professor Hamermesh said, "is equivalent to about a year and a half, maybe a bit less, of extra schooling; that's not small, it's not big."
What interests him is why beauty reaps rewards. Are employers just indulging their taste for good-looking associates? Or is there something about good-looking people that makes them more valuable to their companies?
To tease out more specifics about how beauty works in the labor market, in a 1998 paper Professors Hamermesh and Biddle looked at a more homogeneous group of workers: lawyers who graduated from the same law school. The school provided photos of the students, their class rank and law-review status, data on their earnings a year, 5 years and 15 years after graduating, and information about the nature of their practices. The economists then had each photo rated by a panel of four -- a man and a woman under 35 and a man and a woman over 35 -- with a score of five meaning "strikingly handsome or beautiful" and a score of one meaning "homely, far below average in attractiveness."
Again, Professors Hamermesh and Biddle found that better-looking lawyers made more money, especially as their careers progressed. Fifteen years after graduating, they noted, "better-looking midcareer attorneys were billing at higher rates, not just billing more hours."
Within this general pattern, Professors Hamermesh and Biddle looked for differences between subgroups that might indicate why better-looking lawyers earned more. If, for instance, law firm partners simply discriminated to suit their own tastes, then self-employed lawyers should be immune from the economic effects of their looks. But, the economists found, "if anything, beauty pays off more for self-employed junior attorneys than for employees."
That suggests that clients, not hiring firms, make the difference.
To test that idea, the economists looked at the difference between private-sector lawyers, who have to woo clients, and public-sector lawyers, who do not. The results were striking. The private sector not only drew more attractive lawyers to start, but the looks gap grew over time.
Good-looking government lawyers tended to switch to private firms, while less-attractive lawyers moved from law firms to government jobs.
Good-looking people "will go into fields where their beauty is more important," Professor Hamermesh said. "They'll switch to those areas where the payoff is greater." The higher payoff to good looks, he emphasizes, comes from "consumer discrimination," not employer tastes.
That payoff appears to be an international phenomenon. A 1997 study by Professors Hamermesh and Biddle and two Dutch economists, Ciska Bosman and Gerard Pfann, found that Dutch advertising agencies with good-looking executives had higher revenues and faster growth than their competitors had. So attractive executives were not just an office amenity; they were actually more economically productive.
And in a 1999 paper, Professor Hamermesh, Xin Meng of the Australian National University and Junsen Zhang of the Chinese University of Hong Kong found that in Shanghai women in the top 35 percent in terms of looks earned about 10 percent more than women with average or below average looks, other factors being equal. The Shanghai study, "Dress for Success -- Does Primping Pay?" added another element to the economics of beauty: the return on spending for clothes and cosmetics. (This unpublished paper is available at www .eco.utexas.edu/faculty/Hamermesh. Versions of the others are available at the National Bureau of Economic Research site at www.nber.org.)
The economists found that beauty spending did increase earnings slightly, but by no more than 5 percent of what women spent on clothes and cosmetics. Makeup and new clothes were not investments; they were consumption. "You're not dressing for success," Professor Hamermesh said. "You're dressing to make yourself happier."
It is tough to admit that something as superficial and preordained as personal beauty could be genuinely valuable in the marketplace. But the rewards for good looks are too pervasive to blame mean-spirited employers.
"All of our discrimination policies are based on the employer, yet the evidence we have says that there are these wage differentials, they seem persistent, they seem consistent with any kind of theory, and all the evidence points to them being caused by the way consumers feel," Professor Hamermesh said. "In other words, the problem is all of us."
Or perhaps it is no problem at all. Instead of treating beauty like race -- as a suspect category irrelevant to job performance -- maybe we should think of it more like intelligence, charm or musical aptitude. Some people are lucky enough to have it, while others have to cultivate other gifts. And we would all rather enjoy the good looks of others than do without them.

HEADLINE: Bush Could Get Tougher on Venezuela's Leader

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
After two years in which the United States has carefully avoided a feud with President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela, the administration of George W. Bush will probably take a tougher stand against the populist leader, Republican officials and foreign policy analysts say.
There is a growing belief in Republican circles that Mr. Chavez is undercutting American foreign policy by providing oil to Cuba, by opposing "Plan Colombia," which includes $1.3 billion in United States counternarcotics aid for South America, and by giving political support to guerrillas and anti-government forces in neighboring Andean nations. 
 There is also concern that Mr. Chavez, a former paratrooper who led a failed coup in 1992, is distorting the democratic free-market model advocated in Washington by consolidating institutions under his control and setting himself up as an elected dictator.
While there is no bipartisan consensus on whether Mr. Chavez is merely a nuisance or a real threat to United States interests in Latin America, Republican advisers to the Bush team say the friction is increasingly hard to overlook.
"The Venezuela issue is likely to be troubling, or a hot spot in the first three to six months" as anti-drug battalions trained by the United States begin operations in Colombia, said Georges A. Fauriol, director of the Americas Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a foreign policy research center with close ties to Republicans.
But the analysts also preach caution. The stakes are high, they note, as Venezuela holds the largest oil reserves outside the Middle East and is America's fourth largest supplier. An openly hostile stance toward Mr. Chavez could do more harm than good.
"It's been a conscious policy of trying to engage with him on a positive basis wherever possible without rising to the rhetorical bait when he pokes us in the eye," said Bernard Aronson, a former assistant secretary of state for Latin America in the previous Bush administration. "His actions are getting harder and harder to ignore. I'm not sure the incoming administration is going to be as tolerant."
Venezuela's ambassador to Washington, Toro Hardy, said that Mr. Chavez had legitimate concerns over Plan Colombia, including a fear that it will bring refugees, renewed violence and an arms race to Venezuela.
"He is a president who believes a nation, no matter its size, has the right to act in a sovereign fashion," he said. "But it in no way is a hostile posture."
Some Clinton administration officials agree. One longtime diplomat who served in Venezuela said Mr. Chavez had not jeopardized the United States priorities of fighting drugs, protecting democracy and safeguarding the oil supply. "All of our interests are pretty well taken care of," the diplomat said. However troublesome Mr. Chavez's moves to purge the judiciary and neutralize political parties and labor unions, the envoy added, "what Chavez did he did on the basis of clean elections. So far he is functioning within the democratic structure."
Republican Party foreign policy experts say they would look to Mexico to help reduce America's dependence on Venezuelan oil, which currently accounts for 13 percent of United States imports. Mr. Chavez has helped in that regard, slashing his nation's oil production to drive up prices; in the process, Venezuela slipped behind Canada, Saudi Arabia and Mexico as a United States supplier.
While governor of Texas, Mr. Bush built a comfortable relationship with Mexico's conservative new president, Vicente Fox, and he is expected to make United States-Mexican relations a cornerstone of his Latin policy.
"We need to cultivate the Mexicans on this," said a Republican foreign policy aide who served Presidents Reagan and Bush. "They could conceivably be a much more reliable supplier."
The next administration is also expected to solidify contacts within the Venezuelan military, which is increasingly uncomfortable with Mr. Chavez, the Republican experts say. Unlike Mr. Chavez, many Venezuelan officers studied and trained in the United States and do not share his suspicions, they said.
Rather than clash directly with Mr. Chavez, the Republicans say, they would favor a quiet effort to prod other Latin American nations to spurn Mr. Chavez and ignore his appeals to regional solidarity. Most of Venezuela's Andean neighbors have already voiced distress over what they say is meddling by Mr. Chavez in their internal affairs, but the most influential nation, Brazil, has taken a more benign view.
"Bush has an opportunity with Venezuela to say, I'm going to deal with the hemisphere respectfully, and to a certain extent, I'm got to let the hemisphere be the judge of Chavez's behavior," said Dan Fisk, a senior fellow at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group. "What Chavez wants is to provoke some sort of overreaction from Washington."
The incoming administration will also try to blunt regional skepticism toward Plan Colombia by providing a significant amount of development aid to Venezuela's neighbors, officials and analysts said.
Since Mr. Chavez took office in February of last year, he has seemed determined to display his independence from the United States, a posture that plays well with his nationalistic, mostly poor supporters. He spurned United States flood aid when American troops came to deliver it. He became the first head of state to break the international isolation of Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, when he visited Iraq in August.
He lavished admiration on Fidel Castro, and helped him combat the American trade ban by sending him oil in return for medical service for Venezuelans. He has fostered the greatest increase in tensions with Colombia in two decades, has reached out to Colombian rebels and has predicted that American military aid will lead to a regional conflagration. His expressions of sympathy for anti-government forces in Bolivia and Ecuador have drawn howls of protest from those countries.
He has barred American counter-narcotics pilots from flying in Venezuelan airspace, and he has led the charge in OPEC to force up prices by scaling back production. During the uncertain days after the United States presidential election, Mr. Chavez could not resist a jab at his northern neighbor. "We're willing to help out if necessary," he said.
Such positions play well at home, and some analysts say it is occasionally difficult to determine whether Mr. Chavez's appeals to class resentment and regional leadership are merely bluster.
Toro Hardy, Venezuela's ambassador to Washington, argues that Mr. Chavez has been a reliable economic partner of the United States and has taken major steps toward market reform and privatization that have benefited American investors.
"When two countries have such close economic ties you can't speak of conflicting relations," Mr. Hardy said in an interview.
He denied that Venezuela provides any material support to rebels in the Andean region, and he attributed the concern over Mr. Chavez to "misperceptions." He said Mr. Chavez's five trips to the United States prove he is not anti-American.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Share Prices Move Higher on Hopes of Easing by the Fed

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stock prices marched broadly higher yesterday even as the index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to predict the economy, fell once again, the seventh time since March it has failed to advance.
With selling to establish tax deductions now largely over, traders and investors not on vacation took some comfort from a report of a late surge of holiday shopping and what seemed a growing suspicion that the Federal Reserve will prove to be a friend to the market as it seeks to prevent an abrupt slowdown from possibly turning into a recession. 
 "Every day that goes by you get the sense that the easing will be quicker and more aggressive," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. The cut in rates the Fed has strongly signaled for its late-January policy meeting "could be a half-point," a move that would reverse the final increase in a series of six that ended in May; the first five were quarter-point moves.
Bargain hunting in technology stocks lifted the Nasdaq composite index to its third gain in four sessions after seven consecutive declines. The index climbed 45.83 points, or 1.8 percent, to 2,539.35, just a little below its best level of the day.
This left the Nasdaq, which soared nearly 86 percent in 1999, down 37.6 percent this year. It still has two sessions to help it avoid its worst annual performance, the 35.1 percent slide of 1974.
But individual stocks continued to plummet on bad news. Network Associates, a maker of antivirus software, announced late Tuesday that it would post a fourth-quarter loss and replace senior management. Its shares fell $7.25, to $4.50, and traded as low as $3.25.
"We haven't seen all the overvaluation wrung out of all the tech stocks," said George Cohen, a principal in Cohen, Klingenstein & Marks. He predicted the market would find a bottom in February or March.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Dow Jones industrial average posted lesser, but still solid, advances.
The S.& P. 500 climbed 13.73 points, or 1 percent, to 1,328.92. This narrowed its loss for the year to 9.55 percent. The biggest contributor was Wal-Mart Stores, which gained $1.94, to $52.56. Other retailers also rebounded, aided by a survey by Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi and UBS Warburg showing that same-store sales jumped 4.4 percent last week.
For the Dow, the gain was 110.72 points, or 1 percent, to 10,803.16, where it showed a loss for the year of 6.04 percent.
The Dow was paced by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, up $4.19 to $119.19; J. P. Morgan, up $2.63, to $171.63; and three stocks that gained $2.06 each -- Home Depot, Procter & Gamble and United Technologies.
One of the day's better-performing groups was transportation, including railroads. Union Pacific climbed $1.44, to $52.63.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices fell as some investors doubted the economy was slowing enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates before the end of January.
"The Treasury market has been pushed to extreme levels, with investors being fairly aggressive about how much" the Fed would cut rates, said Gary Pzegeo, who helps manage $2 billion at Evergreen Management in Boston. "We're probably due for a bit of a pullback" in prices, he said.
The price of the 10-year Treasury note fell 14/32, to 104 27/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.11 percent from 5.05 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year bond fell 14/32, to 111 20/32. Its yield rose to 5.45 percent from 5.42 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Clinton's Remarks on Foundation of Foreign Policy

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an interview of President Clinton in the Oval Office by The New York Times:
 
Q. Looking back now, are you convinced that this approach that you developed of using this web of economic engagement . . . has actually worked, and that's proved your thesis that as you engage more economically, you actually do bring countries around to democracy -- this despite the Vietnam and Chinese examples?
 
A. Well, the short answer is, yes, I think it is -- I think it will work. But I think it's a question of whether you -- whether we're prepared to pay the price of time, and what the options are. 
 I don't think there's any way for us to bring openness and freedom to China or to Vietnam more quickly than the one we've adopted. I don't think that either country -- I don't think we have any levers of pressure, for example, that would bring change more quickly. And I think the downsides of adopting a different approach are greater than the upsides.
I think the -- first, let me back up and say my whole view of this period in which we're living is that the world is becoming exponentially more interdependent, and with all kinds of new opportunities and all kinds of new dangers -- that if you want to make the most of an interdependent world, you have to let people within your country have more freedom over the basic aspects of their lives. . . .
 
Q. What kind of time frames are we talking about for China and Vietnam, do you think?
 
A. I don't know. I think, if you look at Vietnam, it was really interesting to me when I was there to see the differences in the approaches taken sort of in gradations from the mayor of Ho Chi Minh City to the prime minister to the president to the general secretary of the party. And if you -- the way they -- even the way they talked was so much a function of their responsibilities and the extent to which they are dealing with the emerging world. I was actually, on balance, quite encouraged by what I saw there and where I think it's going.
In China, I think it's really just a matter of time. If you go to -- as I've said, you've got a lot of different things going on in China. It's a vast country. But if you go to Shanghai, or just go out in those villages -- like I went to a couple of those little villages, where they elected their mayors and all -- I think there's more and more personal freedom, freedom of movement, freedom of choice of career, freedom in educational choices, things that did not exist before.
And I think that eventually the country will become more open and free if we do the right things and they do the right things.
There is always the possibility you will have people get in office in either country that will make mistakes. But I think that the policy is right, and the direction is right.
 
Q. Coming back to Vietnam from a domestic side, were there ways in which you felt your going there and the trip had brought you full circle kind of culturally and politically? . . .
 
A. Well, it was interesting. I had this encounter with the general secretary of the party, sitting there with Pete Peterson, who was a P.O.W. for six and a half years. And he is, parenthetically, not just our ambassador, but a very good personal friend of mine -- we've been close for years -- and a man who is astonishingly free of resentment and demons, given what he went through.
But -- and some of this has been reported, but basically, the general secretary was saying -- he was the most hard line of all the people I talked to -- and he said:
Well, we can talk all about the future here, but we've got to get the past straight. And we didn't invade your country, you invaded our country, and it was terrible. And I'm so glad that so many of the American people opposed it, I'm glad you opposed it, I'm glad the people were in the streets. But it happened, and we've got to somehow work this out.
And I looked at him, and I said, "If you want to talk about history, we can, but -- and it's true that we were deeply divided over the war."
I said, "Most of our division related to what the character of the conflict was, and what if any impact we could have on it."
But, I said, "Mr. Chairman, we were not France. We were not colonialists. We were not imperialists. And people like Ambassador Peterson that served six and half years in one of your prisons, they came here believing they were fighting for freedom and self-determination for the South Vietnamese."
I said: "Now your country is unified, and you are at peace. But you still have to face the age-old questions: How much of the economy should the state control? How much should be in private hands? How much personal freedom should people have, and how many decisions should be made by their families, their villages, or the state?"
And I said, "I think it would be better if we had these discussions looking to the future."

HEADLINE: Ex-Defense Secretary Seems To Be Bush Choice for C.I.A.

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
As President-elect George W. Bush prepared to name additional choices for his cabinet, former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld appeared to be the front-runner for director of central intelligence, Republican officials said today.
Mr. Bush has scheduled an afternoon news conference here on Thursday to announce what aides said could be several selections. The choices could include Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin to be secretary of health and human services; Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief campaign strategist, to be a special counselor to the president, and Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, to become chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. 
 "You'll have to just wait and see who I announce," Mr. Bush told reporters today in Boca Grande, Fla., where he was fishing with his father, former President George Bush, and his brother Jeb Bush, the governor of Florida.
On Friday, Mr. Bush made a surprise announcement of Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri to be his attorney general-designate. Mr. Ashcroft's name cropped up on early lists of possible candidates, but seemed to fade from consideration because of the strong opposition it would draw from civil rights and women's rights groups.
Aides said that over the holidays, Mr. Bush had closely conferred with Vice President-elect Dick Cheney, who is heading the transition team and has been calling and interviewing cabinet candidates in the past few days.
But even top advisers say they are not privvy to what the two men are thinking about appointments, at least not until shortly before they are announced.
"Cheney's keeping this very close to the vest," a transition aide said.
Selecting Mr. Rumsfeld, 68, a former Republican congressman from Illinois, representative to NATO and secretary of defense from 1975 to 1977, would reunite him with his star protege, Mr. Cheney. The vice president-elect was deputy White House chief of staff to Mr. Rumsfeld in the Ford administration, and later succeeded Mr. Rumsfeld as chief of staff.
Mr. Rumsfeld headed a bipartisan commission that in mid-1998 concluded that American intelligence officials had been far too relaxed about missile threats and noted that other nations could use shortcuts to develop such a weapon. Critics complained that panel's mandate was politically skewed to promote the case for antimissile defenses.
When asked in a telephone interview last week if he would consider a cabinet position under Mr. Bush, Mr. Rumsfeld said, "I'm fully engaged."
But associates say Mr. Rumsfeld, whose name has also been mentioned for defense secretary, has not ruled out an offer.
Other candidates to head the nation's intelligence agencies include George J. Tenet, the current director, appointed by President Clinton, and Paul D. Wolfowitz, a former top Pentagon official under Mr. Cheney.
Lawmakers say Mr. Tenet has lobbied to keep his job, but transition officials said that move was unlikely.
"I had hoped that they would be asking George Tenet to stay on for a while, to take the agency job out of the political cycle," Robert M. Gates, the last director of central intelligence under President Bush, said in a telephone interview.
Mr. Wolfowitz has told friends he is not interested in the intelligence job, which would take him away from his strong suit: policy making.
Mr. Bush still needs to fill the top job at the Pentagon, and Mr. Wolfowitz, along with former Senator Daniel R. Coats of Indiana, are in the running for that position.
But Mr. Coats did not quite meet Mr. Bush's expectations during a meeting here last week, and some in the Bush camp worry that Mr. Wolfowitz is not organized enough to manage the sprawling Pentagon bureaucracy.
Supporters of Mr. Wolfowitz, in particular, have rallied to his defense, noting that since he became dean of the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University, seven years ago, he has successfully managed more than 300 faculty and staff members at three campuses, and raised $77 million for the school in five years.

HEADLINE: Bushes Relax, Uncontested, in Florida

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: BOCA GRANDE, Fla., Dec. 27

 BODY:
Bill Clinton adopted Martha's Vineyard as his place to unwind, warming to its politically compatible surroundings for golf and dining.
Now George W. Bush, still 24 days from the White House, has claimed Boca Grande, a sort of Vineyard town with December sunshine. The Bush family has been coming here for years, and it is easy to see why. They fit in nicely in a town where it may well be an offense to wear socks with boat shoes, drive around in anything faster than a golf cart, or act impressed by the arrival of celebrities. 
 In fact, the people of Gasparilla Island, where the Bush family has settled into cottages that are best described as faux shabby, insist that they have hardly noticed that their town has been basically locked down by the Secret Service.
"The only people who came out to stare were the vacationers, not those of us who live here," one silver-haired woman, who declined to give her name, said this afternoon.
Then, after she thought she was safely out of sight, the woman wandered over to the split-rail fence that cordons off this island's exclusive golf club to see if she could catch a glimpse of Mr. Bush, his brother Jeb, who happens to be Florida's governor, or former President George Bush. She missed them. But she did see Barbara Bush, the president-elect's mother, stepping out of the Gasparilla Inn here to take her dog for a walk -- or, more accurately, to take her dog for a ride on a golf cart.
Despite appearances, Mr. Bush seems to have spent a good deal of his time here with a telephone in his ear: Casting about for a cabinet, after all, seems a bit more urgent than casting for this island's famous catch, the tarpon, which weigh more and fight harder than the average cabinet secretary. He is expected to announce at least one cabinet appointment on Thursday. But he came here promising to relax, and at times he was spotted doing exactly that.
At nine this morning, the president-elect, the former president and the Florida governor all appeared on a small pier, fishing rods in hand. The elder Mr. Bush was moving slowly with a cane after a recent hip-replacement operation, and he was overheard discussing his strategy for putting his best leg forward when descending stairs.
"Down to hell and up to heaven," he said, leaving reporters to debate, for much of the rest of the day, the political significance of his utterance. All three Bushes seemed delighted that the press corps was barely afloat on a tipping dock that seemed about to dump its contents into Gasparilla Sound.
A few hours later Mr. Bush's boat returned with several good-sized redfish, though it was unclear who had caught them, and under what circumstances.
Clearly the president-elect had arrived in a chad-free zone: While the presidential election ended in nearly a dead heat statewide, this wealthy corner of southwest Florida, not far from Sarasota, is Bush country. He won Lee County, where Boca Grande is located, by 18 percentage points.
"The locals must have figured out how good his presidency would be for the economy," one of Mr. Bush's aides said jokingly as he walked around the sun-splashed town.
Certainly the economy has been kind to Boca Grande: This is not the kind of town where most residents fret excessively about about prescription drug benefits or the monthly Social Security check. Houses on the water -- and the island is so narrow that most houses seem at or near the shore -- are on offer for $3.7 million. At lunchtime today at Jams, just down the block from where the Bushes are staying, the television at the bar was tuned to CNBC's constant updates of the Nasdaq -- and it seemed as if everyone grabbing a sandwich there was paying at least passing attention to the ticker.
The Gasparilla Inn has been preserved to look as if nothing much has happened since the 1920's, when celebrities began hiding out here. Coats and ties are still worn at dinner, even by children. The parlor rooms, decorated with white wicker chairs and floral prints, look like pages from a Laura Ashley catalog. Elderly couples play cards on the portico.
In short, it is the perfect place to assemble a cabinet without anyone noticing.
Except, perhaps, for John Tapley, who definitely noticed the president-elect's arrival. Mr. Tapley mixes cappuccinos at a high-end coffee shop. (There is no Starbucks or McDonald's; Boca Grande has gone to some lengths to make sure it does not look like the rest of Florida.)
Mr. Tapley emerged from his shop on Wednesday to discover that the Secret Service was about to tow away his car. "They said Bush would have to walk around it on his way out of his cottage," he said.
Mr. Tapley did not have the keys, so he sat on the hood, daring the authorities to tow both him and his car. The Secret Service backed off, he said, "until we could work it out."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Office Pool, 2001

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I got nothing right in last year's office pool except the bursting of Wall Street's high-tech bubble. Had you taken my prognostications as gospel, you would have looked foolish to your political friends but you would have saved a bunch of money.
Once more unto the breach: 
 1. The senator to emerge at year's end as most likely challenger to Al Gore for the 2004 Democratic nomination will be (a)Tom Daschle; (b) Joe Lieberman; (c) John Edwards; (d) Hillary Rodham.
2. Sovereignty issues will be resolved as (a) the traditionally Mexican Olvera Street enclave in Los Angeles is ceded to Mexico, with a mile-wide corridor to the Rio Grande border; (b) the six-block area around U.N. Headquarters in New York City wins "home rule" and is internationalized with its own tax base and police force; (c) Britain is forced by world public opinion to end its unconscionable 300-year occupation of Scotland; (d) Israelis vote to accept the Clinton plan to divide Jerusalem.
3. Bill Clinton will be (a) disbarred; (b) indicted; (c) pardoned; (d) enriched; (e) ubiquitous.
4. Nonfiction sleeper best-seller-to-be: (a) "One Scandalous Story," by Marvin Kalb; (b) "An Honorable Defeat," by William C. Davis; (c) "Seabiscuit," by Laura Hillenbrand; (d) "John Adams," by David McCullough; (e) "Staying Tuned," by Daniel Schorr.
5. A blue-ribbon Social Security panel will be appointed, headed by Bob Dole and Pat Moynihan, and will recommend that Congress and the president (a) raise taxes; (b) end the automatic cost-of-living adjustment; (c) raise retirement age; (d) permit recipients to invest in stocks.
6. Best Picture Oscar to (a) Steven Soderbergh's "Traffic"; (b) "Erin Brockovich," also by Soderbergh; (c) "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," directed by Ang Lee, the new Soderbergh.
7. First foreign policy crisis to face the new president will be (a) Israel's strike at Syrian positions supporting Hezbollah's attacks from Lebanon; (b) Haitian revolt and refugee exodus; (c) Pakistan swaps its nuclear technology with North Korea for missiles; (d) Russia moves to take over Georgia; (e) anarchy in Indonesia.
8. George W. Bush's first Supreme Court nomination will be (a) Senator Orrin Hatch; (b) Judge Laurence Silberman; (c) Judge Emilio Garza of San Antonio; (d) a female Asian-American strict constructionist, preferably from Florida, with a whole flock of children; (e) the demonstrably persuasive constitutionalist Ted Olson.
9. First Bush promise to be shot down by Congress will be (a) increased military spending; (b) steep cut in marginal tax rates; (c) a modest prescription drug benefit; (d) deployment of national missile defense.
10. Most useful fund-raising target for the opposite party will be (a) moneybags Terry McAuliffe as D.N.C. chairman and the Clinton hidden hand; (b) Attorney General John Ashcroft, to be demonized in confirmation hearings as the new Savonarola; (c) the Republican whip, Tom DeLay, the new Gingrich figure to Democrats; (d) Hillary, the $8 million royaltyist, feared by G.O.P. stalwarts to be a harbinger of the dread Counter-Reformation.
11. The continued southward direction of the economy will properly be called (a) the Bush recession; (b) the Clinton recession; (c) the long soft landing; (d) the crash of '01.
12. Bush will lose support in the political center when he (a) downmouths McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform; (b) lets banks and insurance companies get him to backtrack on consumer privacy protection; (c) oversells his faith-based intermediation thing.
13. Likely to leave the seat of power: (a) China's Jiang Zemin, his Mandate of Heaven revoked by his overreaction to the growth of religious sects, supplanted by Zhu Rongji; (b) Britain's third-wayfarer Tony Blair, upset by dispassionate Conservative William Hague; (c) Ehud (You name it, you got it) Barak, replaced by less-hardline-than expected Ariel Sharon; (d) Fidel Castro, nudged off his Havana throne by Father Time.
My picks: 1 (c), 2 (none), 3 (all), 4 (e), 5 (c), 6 (b), 7 (b), 8 (e), 9 (b), 10 (a), 11 (c), 12 (b), 13 (all). One of these years, I'll be right about Jiang and Fidel.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Gain on Sales Surge And Hope of Fed Rate Cut
Stock prices climbed broadly as traders and investors took some comfort from a report of a late surge of holiday shopping and what seemed a growing suspicion that the Federal Reserve will prove to be a friend to the market as it seeks to prevent an abrupt slowdown from possibly turning into a recession.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 45.83 points, or 1.8 percent, to 2,539.35. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 13.73 points, or 1 percent, to 1,328.92, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 110.72 points, or 1 percent, to 10,803.16. Page C4. 

China's Capital Markets Opening Up
New rules in China are allowing private companies access to the country's capital markets, which have been effectively off limits for nearly all of them. That reform could radically reshape China's economic landscape. A1.
 
Leading Indicators Decline 0.2%
The index of leading economic indicators fell 0.2 percent in November, the seventh month out of eight without an increase. The drop could be an indication that the economy is slowing more than Federal Reserve policy makers had wanted. The decline in the index, intended to be a predictor of economic activity over the next three to six months, reflected falling stock prices and rising layoffs. C4.
 
Bennett Planning an Online School
William J. Bennett, the former education secretary, announced that he was founding a for-profit school that would offer education from kindergarten through 12th grade online. The principal investor in the school is a company backed by Michael R. Milken. A14.
 
NetZero Sues Rival in Patent Case
NetZero, a provider of free Internet access, said that it had filed a lawsuit against Juno Online Services, one of its few remaining competitors, accusing it of infringing a patent on a process for displaying advertisements. C3.
 
Hearings on California Power Rates
The California Public Utilities Commission began two days of emergency hearings on whether to raise electricity rates. A14.
 
From Political to Economic Power
Three years ago, Tokyo Sexwale, who has spent his life fighting for black freedom in South Africa, quit politics and joined the very white world of South African business by starting his own investment fund. With his moves into diamonds and platinum, Mr. Sexwale has made himself perhaps the most influential black participant in metals and minerals in South Africa. World Business, Section W.
 
Borders Management Is Challenged
Stepping up its criticism of the management of the bookstore chain Borders, a shareholder has challenged the employment contracts of the chairman and vice chairman. C11.
 
Even Off Camera, Beauty Counts
Even in those jobs where no TV time is required, attractive people have an edge. And, contrary to popular belief, economic rewards for beauty are greater for men than for women. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.
