HEADLINE: Sharp Shift for China's Economy As Entrepreneurs Woo Investors

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Wang Shuxian, a former farmer who now drives a Cadillac, built his successful textile company with money from friends and family. As a private businessman, he could never sell shares on the country's state-run stock markets. Now he can, in a change signaling that China's economy is preparing to take a sudden turn.
Few entrepreneurs in this socialist country have been able to raise money from public investors without government support, as Mr. Wang was the first to do in September. But many more people like him should soon be closer to realizing the same dream. Absent a political U-turn in Beijing, new rules are allowing privately owned companies access to the country's capital markets, which so far have been effectively off limits for nearly all of them. 
 While the government will continue to play a heavy role in the market, that simple reform could ultimately reshape China's economic landscape as radically as Deng Xiaoping's breakup of the country's Maoist communes did in the late 1970's. With easier access to capital, private companies have a chance at becoming the main engine of China's economy for the first time since a brief period earlier this century and otherwise since the Song Dynasty nearly 1,000 years ago.
The change also has political implications: as China's ranks of private businesses grow in number and wealth, their owners will become an increasingly powerful constituency whose demands the government will not be able to easily ignore.
"The rule of law and access to finance are the two things that will make China's private companies independent from political power," said Andy Xie, an economist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Hong Kong.
Under the existing system, the government, not the market, decides which companies can sell stock to the public. That system puts the power over which concerns get investment money in the hands of local Communist Party bureaucrats, who are most concerned with helping state enterprises in their province survive. The system also encourages bribery and crams the markets with low-quality state companies that would otherwise never be able to list their shares.
State-owned companies get almost all the money raised on Chinese markets. Entrepreneurs remain politically isolated and financially hobbled, unable to sell stocks or bonds or get significant bank loans.
But that should begin to change, as China's securities firms decide which concerns will go public, just as securities firms do in the United States and most other places around the world.
Like most of China's entrepreneurs, Mr. Wang scraped together seed capital from family and friends when he started out 14 years ago. He bought a small textile factory in northeastern Chengde, an impoverished region once the summer playground of China's emperors, and his $6,000 initial investment has grown into the Chengde Dixian Textile Company, with assets worth $53 million and 10,000 employees. He drives a black Cadillac Brougham between rows of yarn-spinning machines to inspect his huge textile mill.
Now Mr. Wang, with about $31 million raised from the first stock offering, plans to expand production and marketing. (He still owns 43 percent of the company.)
And he is confident that he represents China's future. "In less than 10 years private companies will dominate the stock market," Mr. Wang said. "State-owned enterprises are an endangered species."
Allowing private companies to compete with the state for capital is part of a sweeping overhaul of China's economy accelerated by the country's effort to join the World Trade Organization early next year. Beijing realizes that much of the country's floundering state sector will not stand up to the global competition that W.T.O. membership is expected to bring.
Beijing grudgingly accepts that a growing private sector is the country's best chance for saving the economy from foreign domination. Strong private companies are also the quickest solution to the rising unemployment that will come as failing state enterprises throw droves of people out of work.
The transition will take some time. China's private companies disappeared along with all other private property shortly after the Communist Party came to power in 1949. They did not reappear until Deng initiated his sweeping economic reforms in the late 1970's, and they still account for only a small fraction of the overall economy.
Now, once a company has found an underwriter and meets the exchange's listing requirements, it will be free to sell its shares.
"Even private companies will be able to raise capital on the markets," said James Liu, executive vice president of the Shanghai Stock Exchange.
Mr. Liu said the opportunities for private companies will broaden further with the establishment of a Nasdaq-style market in the southern city of Shenzhen as early as next year. This "second board" will have looser listing requirements, enabling smaller, younger companies to raise capital.
China established its stock exchanges a decade ago in an attempt to shift the burden of financing state companies from the country's state banks to the public. It worked in part: about 1,000 companies have listed so far, and the combined market capitalization of the two exchanges, in Shenzhen and Shanghai, is more than $500 billion. That will make the market the third largest in Asia, behind Tokyo and Hong Kong, when China eventually merges its two exchanges as expected in the next few years.
The poorly regulated market is manipulated by the government and industry insiders, and its movement up or down has little to do with the country's economy or the quality of the listed companies. Long-term investors are rare.
Still, with roughly 50 million people trading shares -- more than in any other country except the United States -- and with personal bank deposits totaling nearly $800 million, China's markets have the potential to finance a private-sector boom.
"We wish the market were more for investment instead of speculation," said Zhang Zhuying, a retired factory clerk who spends her days staring at a market-tracking computer screen in the room of a Shanghai brokerage house reserved for people with trading accounts worth at least $60,000.
Companies now compete for the right to list their shares by lobbying the country's provincial governments, which are given quotas by China's stock market regulators limiting how many companies they can approve for listing.
But that means the money all goes to state-owned companies, and there is often corruption. When the Kangsai Group, a maker of Mao suits, wanted to go public in the mid-1990's, its managers distributed shares to any government official who could possibly make a difference.
A subsequent government investigation found that Kangsai gave more than 100,000 shares to each official crucial to approval -- 50,000 to those with an indirect role and 1,000 to any official who asked for shares and might have made trouble if turned away.
Kangsai got its market listing in 1996, selling shares to the public for about $1.33 each. The stock's price quickly surged to $3.61, and dozens of officials became rich selling their shares.
But Kangsai's outdated business ran into trouble as soon as the company had used up its cash. Today, the company is laboring under huge debt, and the stock is trading around $1.50. Several of the officials involved are in jail.
The result of such cases is a stock market larded with sluggish, barely profitable state companies, some with managers who have little idea what to do with the money they have raised. In some cases, the money has gone to pay workers' salaries or simply been lent to other cash-short enterprises at exorbitant rates of return.
Mr. Liu is pushing for the existing stock markets' listing quotas to be used up as soon as possible, so the new rules opening the market to private companies can take effect as soon as possible. "In nine months, the current quotas will be gone," he said.
Even with the expected changes, the state will have plenty of opportunities to steer the system.
China's regulators will continue to control the market in many ways. Earlier this month, they arranged the bailout of the Zhengzhou Baiwen Company, an insolvent state-owned department store operator and wholesaler of household appliances, because they feared that if the company went bankrupt it would frighten investors, set off a market rout and ruin the chances of other low-quality state-owned enterprises to sell shares.
That kind of government manipulation has led to an increasingly dangerous stock market bubble. Despite the low quality of China's listed companies and the poor performance of other Asian markets this year, China's stock market has rocketed higher the last 12 months.
More dud companies. meanwhile, will list on the stock market before the quota system expires. Imminent listings include Gansu Jiugang Group Hongxing Iron and Steel, a remote state-owned enterprise in a glutted industry, and Inner Mongolia Lantai Industrial, a salt maker.
And giving the securities industry the power to decide who has access to capital will not solve all the problems. Securities firms in China are still all state-owned and could be subject to political pressure in picking clients.
The underwriters will also have the power to price initial offerings well below prevailing market prices, as all new shares are priced now. The artificially low pricing ensures that shares surge in early trading, allowing substandard companies to raise capital by selling shares.
Nor will corruption disappear. Bribery and cronyism have allowed low-quality companies to issue shares on exchanges in countries in which there is much less government involvement, from Hong Kong to the United States.
But if underwriters do pick prospective listing candidates on the basis of economics, not politics, China's economic revolution will be under way.
Already, the quota system has expired in the so-called B-share market, where shares are denominated in foreign currencies and intended for foreign investors. (Because of China's tight exchange control rules, foreigners are not allowed to invest in the much larger A-share market, denominated in Chinese yuan.)
Mr. Wang was the first private businessman to test the new rules by issuing B shares.
"It took us about a year, but we didn't have to go through the complicated quota approval process," he said recently. "We went public on the basis of our business, not connections."

HEADLINE: Thousands of Bradlees Workers to Lose Jobs in Shutdown

BYLINE: By EUN LEE KOH 

 BODY:
As the regional discount retailer Bradlees prepares to close its doors within the next two months, 4,700 employees in 54 of its stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will soon find themselves without jobs.
Bradlees Inc. announced Tuesday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection and would sell its inventory to a group headed by Gordon Brothers Retail Partners L.L.C. of Boston. 
 The chain has 51 other stores in Massachusetts, Maine, New Hampshire and Pennsylvania, and employs 9,800 people.
Company officials said a judge in United States Bankruptcy Court had approved severance pay for its employees, who would get at least two weeks' pay. Sales employees may continue to work for up to two months, until all the stores are shut.
Retail analysts said it was likely that other discount chains, like Kmart, Wal-Mart and Target, would take over Bradlees' stores.
"The empty stores will be extremely attractive for some of those discount stores looking to expand their market," said Eric Beder, a retail analyst for Ladenburg Thalmann.
Officials of Kmart, Wal-Mart and Target declined to comment.
Bradlees had been struggling financially for the last five years. The company operated under bankruptcy protection from 1995 to early 1999.
When a regional competitor, Caldor, closed in 1999, Bradlees enjoyed a slight upswing, but company officials said it was not enough to keep the stores open. They said Bradlees could not hold out against rival stores and a slowdown in consumer spending. The company said that higher gas and heating oil prices had reduced its customers' disposable incomes.
Bradlees' demise was in part a result of the chain's inability to create its own identity, according to retail analysts. As competitors like Target employed flashy advertising campaigns and retailers like Kmart signed on Martha Stewart, the doyenne of home decor, to create her own label for the company, Bradlees lagged behind.
"Bradlees was a good discount store, but beyond that, there was not much there," said Kurt Barnard, the president of Barnard Retail Consulting Group, a company that examines and forecasts trends in the retail market. "Kmart has Martha Stewart. Wal-Mart is known for having the lowest prices. How do you beat that?"
The chain's Manhattan store, in Union Square, is considered a prime retail site.
Real estate brokers said the Bradlees store at that location had suffered from the increasing feeling that Union Square was no longer an area for bargains and discounts. As neighborhoods surrounding the area, like Chelsea and Gramercy Park, have expanded and become more upscale, full-priced retailers have slowly moved in and edged discount stores out.
"Discount stores have become more of an exception than the rule," said Benjamin Fox, the executive vice president of Newmark New Spectrum Retail L.L.C., a New York brokerage firm. "Bradlees had some trouble adapting to the rapidly changing neighborhood."
Arthur W. Strickler, the district manager of Community Board 2 in Manhattan, which encompasses Union Square, said that the area had changed and that the Bradlees store did not "really fit with the image of the neighborhood anymore."
Unlike Bradlees stores in other parts of the Northeast, the one in Union Square, on the south side of 14th Street west of Broadway, is more likely to be replaced by an office building or several smaller upscale stores rather than another discount store, Mr. Fox said.

HEADLINE: In Ice-Coated Arkansas and Oklahoma, Chaos Rules

BYLINE: BY STEVE BARNES 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 27

 BODY:
Struggling for balance after the second sweeping ice storm in as many weeks, Arkansas and Oklahoma looked to the heavens and the Weather Channel for relief today. The former offered only gray skies, but the latter suggested that Thursday could bring at least temporary sunshine and temperatures well above freezing.
Both states will need plenty of both. A Christmas night barrage of sleet and freezing rain robbed more than 500,000 people of electricity and other basic services and brought much of the region's commercial life to an abrupt halt. 
 "We've got chaos on a grand scale," said Jennifer F. Gordon of the Arkansas Department of Emergency Management.
Gov. Mike Huckabee declared 29 Arkansas counties disaster areas. The situation was much the same in neighboring Oklahoma, which Gov. Frank Keating declared a disaster area today as 120,000 people waited for power to be restored.
Slick streets and highways made driving potentially lethal throughout the region. In Arkansas, Oklahoma and Texas, the National Guard was called out to help people reach shelters and to search the highways for disabled vehicles.
In the Texas Panhandle, where Amarillo received more than a foot of snow on Tuesday, thousands of travelers were still stranded today as snow continued to fall.
The authorities estimated that 16 people had been killed in traffic accidents and other events related to the winter weather across the nation's southern midsection.
The storm shut down air travel throughout the region in one of the year's busiest travel seasons. The Little Rock airport, closed since Monday, reopened one of three runways this afternoon. American Airlines canceled 738 flights on Tuesday at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport and another 73 today.
In Texas and Louisiana, up to 156,000 people were without electricity today. The number of homes and businesses in Arkansas without power reached 400,000 at one point in the day, but by this evening the number had fallen to about 270,000.
Entergy Corporation, the largest provider of power in Arkansas, said that it had more than 6,000 repair personnel, many recruited from surrounding states, at work on repairs, but cautioned that service, especially in more rural areas, might not be restored for several days.
Power lines that had been repaired only days ago were brought down yet again by large tree limbs coated with ice, cutting the current and blocking traffic on streets and highways. Towering oaks and magnolias in the most affluent neighborhoods of Little Rock were among those falling victim to the storm. In some places, the night was pierced by the blue-white flash of exploding transformers as utility poles snapped under the burden.
Most government buildings in central and southwest Arkansas were closed today, but at least some of the grocery stores that were shuttered reopened today.
From the Ozark Mountains of northwest Arkansas to its southern timberlands and east to the Mississippi delta, residents of the state were coping as best they could, relying on hundreds of National Guardsmen and other emergency services personnel to help them reach sanctuary. More than 50 shelters were opened in Arkansas by the Red Cross and other nonprofit organizations, utilizing churches and National Guard armories.
Interstate highways through Arkansas began to clear at mid-day, although bridges and overpasses remained treacherous and authorities urged travel only if necessary.
The situation was at crisis levels in several southwest Arkansas counties that had no power for a second day today. The loss of electricity shut down water and sewage pumping stations in a number of small towns near Texarkana, and telephone service was often intermittent and in some cases nonexistent.
Hot Springs, Ark., fabled for its curative mineral water, was without it today, its pumps lifeless for want of power.
The storm was fueled in part by warm moist air rushing north into the region, where it met a layer of cold air trapped near the ground. In McAlester, Okla., this afternoon, the mixture created a rare thunderstorm of falling ice. Icy conditions were expected in the southern Appalachians today as the storm system moved east.
Governor Huckabee of Arkansas said the economic impact of the back-to-back storms would be huge.
"We're losing a lot of commerce right now and that's going to have a big impact in terms of tax revenue, although I don't think it can be measured yet," Mr. Huckabee said.
James Lee Witt, the Arkansan who is director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, was at his Yell County home for the holidays "and still is, without electricity or water," Mr. Huckabee said.
"James has promised to expedite all our requests for federal assistance," said Mr. Huckabee from the governor's mansion in Little Rock, which lacked power and telephone service for 24 hours until Wednesday afternoon.
The two spoke by cell phone.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing;
EXECUTIVES SPLIT ON 2001 OUTLOOK

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Business executives in Connecticut are divided in predicting how their own companies and others in the state will perform next year, according to a quarterly economic survey by the Connecticut Business and Industry Association. About half of the executives who responded said they expected Connecticut's economic performance to remain stable, while 16 percent said they expected it to improve and 32 percent said they expected it to worsen. When it came to their own companies, 51 percent of the executives said they expected to do better in 2001, 32 percent expected stability and 16 percent expected their firms' performance to decline, the survey found. "The outlook for the new year is the most sobering we've seen in quite some time," said Peter M. Gioia, an economist for the association. "Yet despite the newfound caution, there is positive news regarding exports and continued anticipated growth in production and sales." The survey had 342 respondents, a 17.1 percent response rate, and a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3470 words

HEADLINE: Economic Engine for Foreign Policy

SERIES: THE CLINTON LEGACY -- Last of five articles: A New World View

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
There arrived a moment in his presidency when Bill Clinton's view of America's role in the world grew up in a hurry.
It came on a frigid January day in 1995. Robert E. Rubin, who had just been sworn in as treasury secretary, followed Mr. Clinton into the Oval Office to deliver some bleak news. 
 "Bob came in and essentially told us that Mexico had 48 hours to live," recalled Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser.
Mexico was facing economic implosion, the result of a dive in the value of the peso after years of financial mismanagement and corruption. Foreign investors were fleeing, and the State Department had warned of unrest and a flood of illegal immigrants to the United States.
Someone asked how much a bailout would cost.
"We said $25 billion," recalled Lawrence H. Summers, then a senior treasury official and later Mr. Rubin's successor. "One of the political guys in the room said, 'You mean $25 million, don't you?' No, we repeated, it was billion with a 'B.' And then there was a chorus of, 'This could cost you the election.' "
It did not. Mr. Clinton sidestepped an angry Congress to raise the money. The bailout worked, and Mexico repaid the loans, plus a billion dollars in interest. Rightly or wrongly, Mr. Clinton and his aides contend, the reforms they demanded from Mexico in exchange for the money helped democracy flourish.
In retrospect, Mexico was the test for what became the signature change in American foreign policy.
To deal with a world no longer dominated by nuclear rivalries, Mr. Clinton would place a brand of economic diplomacy at the core of his foreign policy. The man who came to office criticizing President George Bush for putting commerce ahead of human rights ended up arguing, quite passionately, that the spread of American-style capitalism would eventually help spread American-style democracy. Particularly after his re-election in 1996, Mr. Clinton supported the use of economic enticements to bring about political change, including lifting cold war embargoes, signing more than 300 trade agreements and even teaching countries the basics of contract law.
Whether he was in an Irish village, a Vietnamese industrial park or at Beijing University, the message was the same: Prosperity would create choices, choices would lead to a demand for information, and that information, provided at the speed of the Internet, would bring political change. In time, perhaps, dictatorships and one-party rule would fall.
Mr. Clinton will leave office with the experiment under way but the thesis unproven. Some of the fledgling successes he has nudged along, like Poland and South Korea, were well along the path before he came to office. Others that began the trip toward democracy have since floundered. A case in point is Indonesia, where an economic collapse ousted a dictator but then plunged the country deeper and deeper into chaos.
At moments it seemed that Mr. Clinton's approach would backfire at home. For a few scary months in 1998, the financial crises in Asia and Russia seemed to put the world at risk of an economic meltdown. The danger faded, but even today, there is a sense of precariousness in the world economy, with the American economy slowing while Japan remains in a recession.
His boldest experiments at using economic incentives to achieve democratic reforms have been in China and Russia. Critics have called them failures, but the administration has argued that the verdict is still out.
In China, the market economy has flourished, and state-owned enterprises are changing or have closed. For his part, Mr. Clinton wants to be remembered as the man who pushed China toward capitalism, just as President Richard M. Nixon is remembered for opening links to China and President Jimmy Carter for normalizing relations. In 1999, Mr. Clinton first rejected, and later signed, an accord in which China agreed to open its markets to foreign imports in return for entry into the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Clinton argued that the accord would spark political openness, but in Beijing, leaders believe they can enjoy the benefits of market reform without loosening their political grip, and by some accounts, they have imprisoned more dissenters than during the Tiananmen crackdown.
In Russia, where Mr. Clinton had the most at stake and may have been the most naive, democracy came before Western-style capitalism, and the capitalism that took root -- after the Americans pressed for speedy privatization -- was of the crony kind.
Now Russia's inability to compete appeared to be causing a return to the days of central control and sporadic challenges to American power.
Mr. Clinton arrived in Washington before globalization had become a buzzword. And while he had talked about using economic levers to change the behavior of nations in the post-cold-war order -- most notably in a speech at Georgetown University in 1991 that became the template for his plan -- his initial strategy was far simpler, and more mercantile.
Job No. 1 was using diplomatic power to open markets for American goods, helping to create jobs and lift the United States out of a recession. But in his zeal for free trade, he was at odds with most of the Democratic Party.
His first struggle, winning passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993, alienated labor unions and others who had voted for him and who feared that any free-trade agreement would drain jobs from the United States.
The struggle set the stage for others: Mr. Clinton set up a war room, lobbied interest groups, cut deals with members of Congress and exaggerated the benefits for American workers.
The next year, he used the same strategy to win passage of the largest global trade deal in history, establishing the W.T.O. as the arbiter of world trade.
But the political cost was high. Mr. Clinton had further alienated the unions, and in a recent interview, he admitted that he was never able to persuade most Democrats to support his approach. Traditional Democrats struck back by denying Mr. Clinton the authority to negotiate trade accords that Congress could not alter. Labor and environmental groups got even five years later in Seattle by sinking his next major trade initiative.
Mr. Clinton also used the threat of economic retaliation to get Japan to open its markets in what proved to be partly successful. The move was a departure from the cold war stance of his predecessors, who had regarded Japan as first and foremost an ally against the Soviet Union. Many in the State Department and the National Security Council were concerned that such pressure would damage the United States' relationship with Japan, and Japanese bureaucrats fanned those fears.
"There was always a tension between mercantile diplomacy and economic diplomacy," said Mr. Summers, the treasury official.
The administration's biggest victory with Japan was an automobile accord in which Japan -- under threat that Mr. Clinton would block imports of Japanese luxury cars -- agreed to allow in American cars and parts. But Japan's sinking economy made much of the agreement worthless.
In the end, the mercantile phase petered out.
"People looked and said, 'How much are we getting for this?' " said one senior official who had been in the middle of the fray. Moreover, the American economy was taking off, easing the pressure on Mr. Clinton to reverse trade deficits.
Some administration officials said those early trade decisions were a learning experience. "If engagement is only for commerce, you will not be enhancing your interests," Mr. Berger concluded. "If we use it to press nonproliferation and human rights, then it advances our interests and reaffirms the theory."
Time and again, though, Mr. Clinton learned that economic engagement had its limits. Old trouble spots -- the Middle East, Iraq, Northern Ireland -- would not go away, and they remained immune to economic incentives.
In dealing with the Middle East, Mr. Clinton drew praise from supporters and detractors for his tenacity and his mastery of the history and politics of the region. But sometimes -- especially during the Camp David summit last summer -- it seemed that the timetable was driven more by Mr. Clinton's political agenda than by whether a deal was near. Even so, in the last hours of his administration, he was still trying to negotiate a settlement in the Middle East.
In places like Cuba, domestic politics prevented the president from gradually lifting an embargo as he had with other countries. There was the failed intervention in Haiti in 1994 and the delayed bombing of Bosnia in the summer of 1995. In between came a showdown with North Korea over nuclear site inspections, a confrontation that William J. Perry, Mr. Clinton's former defense secretary and a special envoy to North Korea, said with the safety of hindsight "took us closer to a general war" than most Americans realized. The president, said a top White House aide, referred to many of these problems as "the underbrush he had to clear away before he could launch his real agenda."
Mr. Clinton was also criticized as failing to articulate clear standards about when America should cede power and when it should use it.
Conservatives said he gave away too much sovereignty to the United Nations -- which was still waiting for Congress to pay the United States' dues -- and to other international organizations, including the World Trade Organization.
Michael Mandelbaum, a professor at Johns Hopkins University, dismissed the administration's approach to peacekeeping as "foreign policy as social work."
"Their view of the world was that they were going to right every wrong," Professor Mandelbaum said, "and use the armed forces as the diplomatic equivalent of a Swiss army knife."
But he and others concluded that Mr. Clinton's foreign policy legacy was being shaped more in the Treasury Department than in the State Department. Madeleine K. Albright was increasingly playing the role of secretary of state for the Middle East and Eastern Europe; she ceded swaths of the world to Mr. Rubin, Mr. Summers and other officials.
A former top aide to Dr. Albright said, "The State Department was simply not equipped to handle the new challenges, so it stuck to the traditional ones."
And Professor Mandelbaum noted: "It was no accident that at the end of the cold war we found ourselves in the midst of financial crises. Markets were suddenly bigger, broader, faster and encompassed more shaky economies. Nothing in the foreign policy manuals tells you how to deal with these, and it took more than a little nerve."
In the new world, leaders accustomed to setting their nations' agendas found themselves subject to the judgments of foreign investors. If a country's deficits looked too high, its ability to repay loans too dubious or if political chaos made it unsafe for new factories, money would move out with the flick of a few keys. Alliances meant little, and traditional foreign aid seemed trivial. Cash flowed to the most competitive countries; those unable to swim in the new sea found life rafts unavailable.
That was the lesson in Thailand in July 1997. The collapse of the Thai currency crippled investor confidence, which quickly caused an economic contagion throughout Southeast Asia and South Korea. Cautious because of Congressional opposition to Mexico's bailout, the Treasury Department was at first hesitant to put too much American cash on the line, so it worked through the International Monetary Fund. And for months, the fund made the situation worse for the poor, requiring cuts in social programs before it would provide loans to forestall default.
By early 1998 rioting broke out in Indonesia, and soon its dictator of three decades, Suharto, was ousted. Russia was the next to be infected, and the United States rushed to provide emergency cash for fear that in disintegrating, its old nuclear rival would lose control over its weapons.
"There were constant fights between the Treasury and the State Department over whether this was wasted money," a White House official said, "because it was clear the Russians weren't going to enact the reforms."
For a few weeks in the fall of 1998, it looked as if the contagion might hurt American markets, but the disaster was prevented with a cut in interest rates by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, a move coordinated with several major countries.
Initially, the administration blamed the global panic on the developing countries, for economic mismanagement. But opinions have shifted.
"I think that the Asian financial crisis and the Mexican crisis were as much caused by the industrial nations' financial institutions," said Mr. Rubin, who now heads one of those institutions, Citigroup. And he conceded that the United States put too much emphasis on opening countries to international investments and not enough on how to handle that money.
"With the benefit of hindsight," he said, "I would say that we should have put more of an emphasis earlier on getting the rest of it right" -- making sure countries had a regulatory structure and an understanding of what could befall them if the world picked up its money and moved it elsewhere.
In the end, intervention by the monetary fund and the United States worked, and the crisis eased. Mr. Clinton gets much of the credit. Quietly, without stirring opposition in Congress, he kept American markets open to ever-larger floods of imported goods, which helped afflicted nations export their way back to health.
But many of the long-term reforms that he talked about so passionately were never executed. Japan, Russia and South Korea made modest changes but reverted to their old habits. Indonesia continued its slow disintegration.
Rising oil prices saved Russia, but much of the force went out of American efforts to turn it into a nation of laws, where the government collected taxes and corruption did not undercut markets.
And in retrospect, Russia proved unwilling to phase out its role as arms merchant to rogue countries, an unspoken quid pro quo for economic aid. Just a few weeks ago, Russia told the White House that it was abandoning an accord signed by Vice President Al Gore and then Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin to halt conventional arms sales to Iran.
"We probably underestimated the basic difficulty of the institutional transformation of Russia," one senior official said. "Was Russia in worse shape than we recognized in '96? Probably."
But Mr. Rubin says, "Whatever money we spent, it was worth it for a world in which we are not now in a nuclear standoff."
Similarly the much-talked-about effort to build a "global financial architecture" has faded. There have been some changes -- countries now must reveal more financial information to investors, and the monetary fund has changed many of its lending practices -- but even the president has stopped talking about redesigning the world's financial system.
Eventually the backlash from the crisis came full circle, colliding with Mr. Clinton's free-market dreams.
The Asian crisis confirmed what many developing nations had suspected: globalization was a rich country's game, and the rules were rigged to favor the most competitive. The free-market system let the United States ship its goods, open its factories and move capital anywhere it wanted. But poorer nations often found that their products could not compete and that their low-tech exports were subject to tariffs and quotas that American, European and Japanese industries would not eliminate.
So when the United States proposed a further opening of world markets, developing nations struck back, starting in Seattle in late November 1999.
Trade ministers were gathering for a new round of global trade talks. Charlene Barshefsky, Mr. Clinton's trade representative and an advocate of using trade accords for political ends, peered out the window of a suite in the Westin Hotel. "Where are the barricades?" Ms. Barshefsky demanded.
For the administration, it was the start of a disastrous week. For months, unions, environmental groups, rights activists and others had been planning to grind the meeting to a halt, to make the point that their issues were being ignored. And on top of that, representatives of many poor nations were determined to stop America's agenda.
Mr. Clinton's comments only made the situation worse.
In an effort to appease the protesters and help Mr. Gore in the coming election, the president arrived in Seattle and began talking about establishing labor and environmental standards for all nations. The comments stiffened the resistance of countries like India and Egypt, which were convinced that Mr. Clinton was trying to impose American-style work rules intended to make their goods less competitive.
In an interview a few weeks ago, Mr. Clinton said: "A lot of the people in these developing countries who were marching are mad at America because we, almost alone among the advanced countries, would like to have a global trading system that has minimum labor and environmental standards. And so a lot of them thought that's my indirect way of being a protectionist, in protecting the good jobs in America and keeping them poor."
It was not the case, he said. But he lost the argument, and the talks collapsed.
Ms. Barshefsky pressed on, piecing together an agreement with Jordan meant to spur trade in the Middle East, and negotiating the deal of her political life, the one with China.
The China accord could eventually redefine the United States' relationship with Beijing. And if Mr. Clinton is right, it could result in the erosion of the Communist Party's control. He argued exactly that, as he was selling Congress on the merits of the deal, making his now-familiar pitch that "in the new century, liberty will spread by cell phone and cable modem." But even as China has opened up economically, the State Department has documented six years of intensifying crackdowns on dissent.
Elsewhere in the world, Mr. Clinton has adjusted his pitch. In the past year, he has talked far more about the fate of the poor.
"His Africa trips had a big impact," said James Steinberg, the deputy national security adviser until last summer. "He saw with his own eyes that even when governments wanted to do the right thing, their huge debt and AIDS and other impediments, made it hard to get off the ground."
The president promoted an initiative to forgive debt -- which Congress passed last year -- and he told the Indian Parliament that it was no longer acceptable that "part of the world lives in the information age" while the other "has not even reached the clean water age."
This sounded big-hearted, but it was also rooted in a new reality: The world's developing nations were gaining clout by forming coalitions.
"They are now willing to say, We are not going to do it the American way," one Clinton adviser said. "The Bush people are about to find that out."
But if there was a single moment at the end of Mr. Clinton's presidency that crystallized the successes and the limitations of his effort to use global capitalism to drag nations toward democracy, it came in Hanoi, on a Saturday afternoon last month.
To the rising alarm of Vietnam's leaders, Mr. Clinton's trip was drawing huge crowds, among them former Vietcong guerrillas who toted along their grandchildren to see the leader of the nation with which Vietnam once fought. "He will bring the Internet," one aging veteran said, and then confessed he had never sat in front of a computer.
It was just what Mr. Clinton wanted to hear. But then he met Le Kha Phieu, the Communist Party's general secretary, who had stopped many of the reforms started in the early 1990's, warning that globalization was a fancy word for surrender.
"We have seen the collapse of the U.S.S.R.," he told Mr. Clinton, and yet "we are still on our feet, we have reaffirmed socialism." They spent the next hour politely arguing whether America had imperialist designs on Vietnam in the 1960's and, by implication, whether it had them now.
The Vietnamese leader's message was clear: Just because we trade with you, don't expect us to embrace democracy. An hour later, Mr. Clinton got a much more mixed message from the mayor of Ho Chi Minh City, who asked about low-income housing and job creation.
Which side will prevail?
"I don't think there's any way for us to bring openness and freedom to China or Vietnam more quickly than the one we've adopted," Mr. Clinton said later.
But he added: "I don't think freedom is inevitable, or the triumph of democracy is inevitable. But I think it is rendered far more likely by the power of our example and the strength of our engagement."

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption and a front-page article yesterday about President Clinton's foreign policy misattributed the signing of a trade agreement with China. It was the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, not the president, who signed the agreement in 1999. (This year Mr. Clinton signed the legislation that granted permanent normal trading status to China.)
The caption also misstated the timing of Mr. Clinton's visit to Beijing. It was in 1998, not after the agreement was signed.

NOV. 20, 1993 -- Congress passes the North American Free Trade Agreement.
 
OCT. 21, 1994 -- North Korea and the United States sign an agreement requiring Pyongyang to freeze its nuclear development program.
 
DEC. 1, 1994 -- The Senate approves a sweeping global tariff-cutting trade pact, creating the World Trade Organization.
 
THE PESO RESCUE
JAN. 31, 1995 -- Mr. Clinton sidesteps Congress and uses his own emergency authority to lend up to $20 billion to Mexico to stave off imminent bankruptcy.
 
JUNE 28, 1995 -- Hours before $5.9 billion in tariffs are to go into effect, the United States and Japan reach an accord to expand American access to the Japanese automotive market.
 
AN END TO WAR IN BOSNIA
AUG. 30, 1995 -- NATO forces begin a two-week bombing campaign against Bosnian Serb targets after the shelling of marketplace in Sarajevo.
 
NOV. 21 1995 -- In Dayton, Ohio, the presidents of three Balkan states sign an agreement ending nearly three years of war in Bosnia.
 
JAN. 15, 1997 -- With the United States mediating, Israel and Palestine agree on a partial Israeli pullout from Hebron.
 
APRIL 24, 1997 -- The Senate approves a ban on chemical weapons.
 
CONTAGION IN THE GLOBAL MARKETS
 
JULY 2, 1997 -- Thailand frees its currency, the baht, from the dollar and lets it float, setting off a crisis throughout Southeast Asia.
 
OCT. 31, 1997 -- The United States contributes $3 billion to a bailout of Indonesia led by the International Monetary Fund.
 
DEC. 4, 1997 -- South Korea agrees to the conditions of a $55 billion I.M.F.-led bailout, to which the United States contributes $5 billion.
 
AUG. 17, 1998 -- Russia allows the ruble to float in value in an effort to avert financial collapse.
 
AUG. 20, 1998 -- After the bombing of its embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, the United States launches cruise missiles at Afghanistan and Sudan.
 
OCT. 23, 1998 -- Israel and Palestine sign a modest agreement in Washington.
 
WAR IN KOSOVO
 
MARCH 24, 1999 -- NATO begins attack on Serbia with bombs and cruise missiles, as Serbian troops continue to sweep through Albanian villages in Kosovo.
 
JUNE 10, 1999 -- The NATO air campaign ends after 78 days as Serb forces begin withdrawing from Kosovo.
 
NOV. 15, 1999 -- The United States and China agree to reduce tariffs and other barriers, clearing the way for China to join the World Trade Organization.

NOV. 30, 1999 -- Street protests disrupt W.T.O. talks in Seattle.
 
JULY 25, 1999 -- Mr. Clinton says that two weeks of Mideast peace talks at Camp David talks have failed to produce an agreement.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 44; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4670 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary, especially during the holiday season, and should be checked by telephone. Museum hours through New Year's Day may also vary and should be checked before visiting. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 7). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If just a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman). 

* "THE DRAFTSMAN'S ART: MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE NATIONAL GALLERY OF SCOTLAND," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Feb. 25). This beautiful exhibition of 70 master drawings from the 16th to the 19th century, many of them recently acquired, has been organized with an eye to achieving a harmonic convergence of diversity, continuity, quality, fame and obscurity. Leonardo, Raphael, Boucher and Seurat are here, in outstanding form, but so is an exquisitely detailed rendering of two Restoration gentlemen by David Paton, a Scottish miniaturist, and an almost cinematic genre scene that is considered the masterpiece of Etienne Jeaurat, a contemporary of Chardin. In between are works by Zuccaro, Pietro Testa, Pietro da Cortona, Hans Baldung Grien, Hendrick Goltzius and much more. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 * "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with handwritten words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an icebreaking introduction to an art that to anyone who doesn't know Chinese can seem unapproachable. Hours: Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students 12 and older and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
 "AN ENGAGEMENT WITH FOLK ART: CYRIL I. NELSON'S GIFTS TO THE MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FOLK ART," 2 Lincoln Square, at West 66th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through Jan. 7). This show celebrates the largess of Mr. Nelson, a book editor and folk art collector who has given 113 objects to the museum with the promise of more. The works, from the late-18th to the mid-20th centuries, cover the traditional areas of folk art -- portraits, landscapes, sculptures, painted and decorated furniture -- but the focus is on American needlework: quilts, coverlets, blankets and the like. Among the quilt spectaculars is the "Samuel Steinberger Log Cabin Quilt, Courthouse Steps Variation," by a 19th-century immigrant. Painted furniture, too, shines in this show. The painting and sculpture pieces make a more modest impression, but over all, what's on view represents a refined, solid ensemble that is very visitable. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Grace Glueck).
 
 "THE FIGURE: ANOTHER SIDE OF MODERNISM," Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art, Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Staten Island, (718) 448-2500 (through Jan. 14). This vast, uneven but enthralling grab bag of a show invites us to count the ways that artists have painted the human figure during the last 50 years. The curator, Lily Wei, selected 125 paintings by as many artists, including most of the usual suspects, from Willem de Kooning to Lisa Yuskavage. Among the best works are a huge grisaille painting of a towering giantess by Alfred Leslie; Alex Katz's radiant portrait of his wife; Catherine Murphy's intensely realistic picture of big feet; and Elliot Green's fusion of a Mondrianesque grid and a rubbery cartoon couple. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2 (Ken Johnson).
 
 * "SOL LEWITT: A RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 25). Unexpectedly, the most beautiful exhibition by a living artist in a New York museum in a long time and an antidote to the nonsense in several other museums around town. Just about every other wall is covered with wall drawings, alternately eye-popping and gossamer. Those out there (you know who you are) who run from any artist linked to Conceptualism may want to stop and re-evaluate your views after seeing what's here. The master of chaste white cubes has undergone a transformation since his last retrospective in the late 70's. Now opulence emerges from the same seemingly prosaic instructions he came up with years ago. The appeal is still to patient observation, a lesson for everyone, delivered elegantly. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 "PIERRE ET GILLES," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Jan. 7). No history of postmodern photography, fashion photography, celebrity portraiture, record album covers or the highbrow beefcake tradition would be complete without the work of the French photo team known as Pierre et Gilles, who have collaborated on over-the-top, tightly styled, hand-finished photographs since 1976 and become wildly famous in Europe in the process. In their first American museum retrospective, their work feels more than a little embalmed, existing behind a not-so-invisible shield of artistic conservatism. Certain images come to life as art objects -- most notably, one of a beautiful young sailor up to his chest in water with an iridescent night sky behind him -- but those are few. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, until 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * "POWER AND DESIRE: SOUTH ASIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE SAN DIEGO MUSEUM OF ART, EDWIN BINNEY III COLLECTION," Asia Society at Midtown, 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through Jan. 7.) The album-size paintings known as Indian miniatures, produced for an elite clientele who demanded the finest workmanship, are rightly renowned for their suave forms and brilliant colors. They also embody the moral values, political ambitions and personal aspirations of the culture that produced them. All of these ingredients come into play in this show of 67 top-of-the-line examples from the 16th to the 19th centuries. They add up to a kind of grand but intimate theater, equal parts farce, melodrama and mystery play, where men strut like gods, gods have the failings of men, and nature is a gorgeous curtain behind which infinity lies. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
* JAMES CASTLE, "The Common Place," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Jan. 13). Though deaf, speechless and illiterate, Castle (1900-77) drew with miraculous originality and steadfastness of purpose for most of his life. This exhibition presents more than 100 drawings, assemblages and small books, all created using homemade and found materials. The artist's strangely somber views of the ordinary rooms and grounds of the Idaho farm where he grew up have a haunting, deeply moving presence (Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
"FOUR NON-OBJECTIVE PAINTERS," Katharina Rich Perlow Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-7171 (through Jan. 6). Once an art world legend, the German-born painter Hilla Rebay (1890-1967) was a founder and the first director of the Museum of Non-Objective Painting, which evolved into the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. She also served as director of that institution, from 1937 to 1952. In 1939, with Guggenheim's backing, she brought her friend Rudolf Bauer, the painter, from Germany to the United States, and promoted his work. Rebay and Bauer were devotees of Non-Objective painting, defined by Kandinsky as art with no detectable reference to real-world sources. Their paintings are displayed together here, but it turns out that Bauer, a weak painter who could nevertheless create spirited Kandinskyesque collisions of form and color, makes a better showing. Also on view is "Berlin at Night," a group of mildly naughty drawings by Bauer, who before his Non-Objective career was a caricaturist for satirical German magazines. And there are several paintings from the period by the American painters Balcomb Greene and John Ferren, but not a strong enough showing to amount to much (Glueck).
 
 SOL LEWITT, PaceWildenstein, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 421-3292 (through Feb. 3), and Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-1105 (through Jan. 13). Running concurrently with Mr. LeWitt's beautiful retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art, these exhibitions present new works by the prolific muralist and sculptor. PaceWildenstein offers an explosively vibrant wall painting appropriately titled "Splat," a fiberglass sculpture in primary colors that looks like an extraterrestrial mountain range, and large, sumptuous gouache-on-paper studies. Paula Cooper features an enormous but comparatively inert concrete block work, a six-sided structure you can see into but can't enter (Johnson).
 
 GWYNN MURRILL, Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through Jan. 20). Three bronze deer rendered life-size in a smoothly simplified manner by this Los Angeles-based sculptor have a tense, remarkably animated presence. An eagle and a cheetah seem artificially stylized by comparison (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
ROBIN LOWE, "Erehwon," Bonakdar Jancou, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 414-4144 (reopens Tuesday; through Jan. 13). Mr. Lowe's large, Magic Realist paintings look like scenes from a Jungian dream. A winding road leads into the forest. A lawn gnome with a lamp guards a broken-down farmhouse. A white goat drinks from an aboveground swimming pool in a stony field. Painting in saturated colors with hallucinogenic precision, Mr. Lowe gives vivid visibility to offbeat, psychologically intriguing fantasies (Johnson).
 
 "MODERNISM DEFINED: JULIUS SHULMAN AND RICHARD NEUTRA," Yancey Richardson, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 343-1255 (reopens Tuesday; through Jan. 6). Now 90, Mr. Shulman began photographing the buildings of the modernist architect Richard Neutra in 1936. His black-and-white images of clean, airy, minimally furnished houses from the 1940's and 50's are more than just lucid documents; each glowing miniature conveys a heavenly vision of modern serenity (Johnson).
 
 "NEUTOPIA," Audiello, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 675-9082 (reopens Tuesday; through Jan. 20). Five artists playfully redesign modernity. Both Christopher Schank and Carlos Ancalmo skillfully build elaborate surrealistic, multileveled architectural structures of wood, foam, plastic and other materials. Pablo Vargas-Lugo turns cardboard boxes into works of surprising Constructivist elegance. Jay Davis's glossy pictures are like a combination of traditional Japanese landscape painting and science fiction illustration. And Anna Sew Hoy creates absurd conjunctions of child-size bicycles and giant blobs of putty (Johnson).
 
 * CINDY SHERMAN, Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, (212) 206-7100 (through Jan. 6). With her latest untitled series, Ms. Sherman is back in front of the camera again, disguised as women who, you might say, used to be somebody, maybe. They grin at the camera in clownish make-up, wobbly wigs and discount blouses, proud, valiantly oblivious to, or simply defiant of, our condescension, like the beauty pageant queen who drops her baton in the talent contest but keeps beaming. Formal devices by Ms. Sherman get overlooked because of the human element: the pattern of pigtails against plaid shirt; the purplish freckled face of a woman with purple shirt and purple cap. This formal order becomes a rational structure that gives to the work its mix of frigidity and heat, a perfectly ambiguous cocktail for an ambiguous moment and an antidote to the weary sophistication of which there is too much in art now (Kimmelman).
 
 "THRIFTING," Lombard Freid, 531 West 26th Street, (212) 967-8040 (through Jan. 6). Seven emerging Texas artists who cleverly recycle found materials. Bill Davenport makes eccentrically poetic works, like a group of blue cans bearing mounds of fake snow; Katrina Moorhead transforms a piece of plastic-foam packing material into a wonderful little swimming pool using miniature tiles and real grout; Brad Tucker produces funky conjunctions of words, materials and objects; and Francesca Fuchs merges consumer products and abstract wall painting (Johnson).
 
 FATIMAH TUGGAR, Greene Naftali, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 463-7770 (through Jan. 6). Born in Nigeria, educated at Yale, Ms. Tuggar works in a variety of mediums to sensitize viewers to the gulf between African and Western experience. In large computer-processed photomontages, she mixes and layers disconnected images -- placing Western fashion models in an open-air African meat market, for example -- to surrealistic and politically provocative effect (Johnson).
 
 MARY WEATHERFORD, Debs & Company, 525 West 26th Street, (212) 643-2070 (through Jan. 6). Since bursting on the scene at the end of the 80's with her feminist revisions of Noland, Johns and Warhol, Ms. Weatherford has followed an unpredictable path. Her new canvases, punctuated by starfish, seashells and sponges, hover uneasily between faux-naif landscape and sophisticated Color Field painting (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
"DEATH RACE 2000," Thread Waxing Space, 476 Broadway, between Grand and Broome Streets, (212) 966-9520 (through Jan. 13). Organized around a ramshackle wooden racetrack built by Andreas Schlaegel, Phillip Zaiser and Thomas Zipp, this sophomoric mess of a 30-artist exhibition means to satirize violent, addictive and otherwise excessive behaviors supposedly driving modern society to destruction. The few interesting works include a funny video by Omer Fast, who used his own voice to replace all sounds in scenes from a Mel Gibson movie, and a life-size machine-gun-toting camel built of cardboard by Alex Baggaley (Johnson).
 
 "FROM INSIDE THE BODY: CHINESE NEW PHOTOGRAPHY AND VIDEO," Ise Cultural Foundation, 555 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 925-1649 (through Jan. 6). Most of the 11 participants in this show are appearing for the first time in the United States, and together they give some idea of ways in which many young Chinese artists, with access to international art magazines, museum catalogs and the Internet, are tailoring global styles to culturally specific ends. Some cook up contemporary riffs on traditional genres; others dive straight into a hallucinatory present, with themes that sometimes dovetail with those in recent work by artists in New York (Cotter).
 
 MATT GRAY, "White Rabbit," Sandra Gering, 476 Broome Street, (212) 226-8195 (through Jan. 6). Big color photographs of two albino rabbits in a white box by this New Mexico artist. They are visually rich and dreamily weird, and they evoke a surprising range of associations, from Kasimir Malevich to Robert Ryman and Lewis Carroll to the Jefferson Airplane (Johnson).
 
 KEVIN LARMON, Curt Marcus, 578 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 226-3200 (reopens Tuesday; through Jan. 6). Mr. Larmon, who has been exhibiting regularly in New York since 1984, updates the old Surrealist-Abstract Expressionist connection. Working toward the centers of raw plywood panels, he layers grisaille glazes over loose, swirling pencil lines, creating murky depths, serpentine biomorphic forms and tension between illusory dream space and the raw immediacy of paint and wood (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
* SIAH ARMAJANI, "Glass Room," Senior & Shopmaker Gallery, 21 East 26th Street, (212) 213-6767 (reopens Tuesday; through Jan. 6). You couldn't live in this endearingly homespun "glass room," but then, it's not meant for that. Made of glass and plastic bricks and set on wagon wheels like a prairie schooner, it is packed with fanciful allusions and tributes: to country carpentry, old-style American farm life, vernacular rural architecture and at the same time the futuristic visions that glass seems to offer. Despite its transparency, it has a more private aspect than the long roster of bridges, houses, reading rooms, gardens and other structures -- some functional, some purely aesthetic -- with which Mr. Armajani has adorned the built world. Enigmatic yet accessible, sturdily constructed but for contemplation only, "Glass Room" is a sparkling addition (Glueck).
 
 ANDREW FORGE, New York Studio School, 8 West Eighth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 673-6466 (through Jan. 6). A Pointillist-derived system of colored dots has for years been the lyrical basis of painting by Andrew Forge, an English-born painter, critic and teacher. Worked on the canvas in dense but nuanced arrangements made from close observation of "places, seasons, times of day, conditions of light," the dots usually can't be read as specific imagery. But sometimes they hover on the edge of representation, evoking trees, a pond and other aspects of nature. To be savored rather than looked at hurriedly, they resonate in the mind (Glueck).
 
 PAUL PFEIFFER, the Project, 427 West 126th Street, Harlem (212) 662-8610 (reopens Wednesday; through Jan. 7). The emotional, almost religious intensity that infuses Mr. Pfeiffer's tiny wall-mounted video tapes, and created such a buzz around the artist last spring, is all but absent in this show. The power of his work stems from intimate encounters with small, moving images lifted from existing film and ingeniously Pfeifferized. Thus a large installation and some manipulated photographs founder on the seas of one-liner cerebralness. Only "The Long Count (I Shook Up the World)," based on the 1964 Clay-Liston fight, reflects Mr. Pfeiffer's poetic understanding of the meanings to be found at the nexus of the body, the camera and American life (Smith).
 
Last Chance
 
"A NEW YORK CIRCLE," Susan Teller, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 941-7335 (through tomorrow). Selected by a veteran New York modernist painter, Fannie Hillsmith, this exhibition of works by friends and acquaintances evokes a midcentury period when the progressive art world was far smaller and more intimate than today and the common language was Cubism. Besides Ms. Hillsmith's own robust Cubist still lifes, the show includes fine small works by luminaries of American art like Louise Nevelson, Suzy Frelinghuysen, A. E. Gallatin, Alice Trumbull Mason and Charles Shaw (Johnson).
 
 "HIP-HOP NATION: ROOTS, RHYMES AND RAGE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Sunday). The complex cultural amalgam of music, poetry, break dancing, art and fashion that is hip-hop poses a serious challenge to any art museum, but with the proper resources and curatorial expertise, it could have been met. Instead this show offers a partial outline of hip-hop history, conveyed by photographs, posters, magazine and album covers, memorabilia and monotonous expanses of clothes that make the show nearly indistinguishable from the gift shop. Garnished with graffiti art, it bypasses many other equally interesting connections to contemporary art. Because the show omits music videos, it manages to be virtually devoid of the sounds, words and moving bodies that are the essence of hip-hop. The results are a cross between a mall and a mausoleum. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 * "THE IMPERIAL GAZE," Sepia International, 148 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 645-9444 (through tomorrow). The British photographer Samuel Bourne was in India for only seven years (1863-70), but he took thousands of pictures, established a lucrative business and became well known for his cityscapes and pictures of architectural monuments. Like many quest-driven travelers, though, he wanted, even needed, something from India: in his case, an experience of the Sublime in nature. In Kashmir, he encountered an earthly Eden, and on arduous treks to the Himalayas he discovered the meaning of hugeness. The pictures that resulted are part of one of the richest bodies of photographic work to emerge from British India (Cotter).
 
 "IN THE PRESENCE OF SPIRITS: AFRICAN ART FROM THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF ETHNOLOGY IN LISBON," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Sunday). The more than 140 objects on view relate to the secular and the supernatural in African culture: masks, power figures, dolls, decorated stools and chairs, pipes, posts and other artifacts. Outstanding is a group of initiation masks made from wood and more fragile materials like feathers, fabrics and barkcloth fibers. Ranging from fierce to benign in expression, they are giddily imaginative. Impressive, too, is a selection of dolls from the Ambo people of southwestern Angola. The objects in the show were chosen for their high aesthetic value, and it doesn't disappoint. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for children, students and the elderly; free on Sundays (Glueck).
 
 ARNOLD MESCHES, "Echoes, a Century Survey," Donahue/Sosinski Art, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 226-1111 (through tomorrow). An impassioned Expressionist painter, Mr. Mesches, now 77, has stayed with figuration through all the art world "isms" of his time. His work combines his interest in 20th-century history -- wars, strikes, the Holocaust, class and economic struggles -- with his own immigrant family saga. He gets it down with the energy, bold colors and lively humor (if not great painting) that keep you looking. An old-fashioned show about feelings in an era of art world ironies, it nevertheless works. The painting helps: its rough, guileless, straight-from-the-tube abruptness strikes just the right note (Glueck).
 
 * RICHARD NONAS, "A Ghost in Every Kayak," Five Myles, 558 St. Johns Place, Crown Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 783-4438 (through Jan. 31). Established by the theater director and performer Hanne Tierney in memory of her son Myles, a news photographer killed in Sierra Leone in 1998, this maverick gallery has an entrancing show put together by Mr. Nonas. Examples of his floor-hugging post-minimalist work run down the center of the gray-painted space. Walls are hung with an extraordinary collection of boats, full-scale replicas and near-abstract models fashioned by the artist (Cotter).
 
 * "OPEN ENDS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9480 (closing in stages, beginning on Tuesday). The third and final cycle of "MOMA 2000" covers 1960 to the present and fills nearly the entire museum with almost a dozen different theme shows. "White" is one theme. Memorial art is another. Childhood and lost innocence is yet another. Like previous installments in this year-and-a-half-long navel-gazing reconsideration by the museum of how to present its permanent collection in anticipation of its future home, the show has the effect of being clever and a little too solipsistic: it's about smart curators' making occasionally vivid and previously unseen connections among disparate works without making particularly fresh sense of the period as a whole. It's artistic game playing, highly pleasurable up to a point. The themes are always arguable, which is part of the game. This also becomes an occasion for the museum to parade acquisitions of the last decade, which include Gerhard Richter's series of paintings based on the Baader-Meinhof gang, occupying an entire room and probably the exhibition's high point. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * "PAINTERS IN PARIS: 1895-1950," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). This show of more than 100 paintings celebrates the Met's acquisitions of works by School of Paris painters, going back to 1946 when Gertrude Stein bequeathed her portrait, done by Picasso in 1906. That portrait served as a cornerstone for later acquisitions in the field, particularly over the last 20 years. The museum's increasing interest and diligent wooing of collectors have brought not only single works but also groups and entire holdings, like the 18 major objects bequeathed by Florene M. Schoenborn in 1995 and the Jacques and Natasha Gelman trove of 85 masterpieces accessioned in 1998. The treasures on view include works by some of the 20th century's greatest: Bonnard, Braque, Chagall, de Chirico, Derain, Gris, Leger, Matisse, Miro, Modigliani and Picasso, in an animated arrangement that should beguile the most jaded Met-goer. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).
 
 "RAVE REVIEWS: AMERICAN ART AND ITS CRITICS, 1826-1925," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Sunday). A year after the Academy opened as a school for art instruction, it organized its first annual show, 170 contemporary portraits, landscapes and historical sagas. This entertaining hodgepodge of a show, described as "the first comprehensive historical examination of American art criticism," brings together more than 70 paintings and sculptures that first appeared in these shows, with the reviews they got at the time. One immediate and large success was Winslow Homer's "Prisoners From the Front" (1866), which portrayed a lineup of scraggly Confederate soldiers with their leader confronting a smartly uniformed young Union officer. The contrast made by Homer between the two sides was seen by the painting's most perceptive reviewers as a comment on why the South lost the Civil War. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $4.50, students and the elderly (Glueck).
