HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

In a Brutal Year for Stocks, Nasdaq, Dow and S.&P. Fall
The stock market stumbled as it wound up a brutal year that began with euphoria but ended with thousands of devastated investors and the worst returns in more than two decades.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq fell the hardest and had its worst year since its founding in 1971, plunging 39.3 percent, to 2,470.52. Leading the dive were technology, media, telecommunications and Internet shares. Old-economy companies bolstered the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell only 6.2 percent, to 10,786.85. And the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finished the year down 10.1 percent, to 1,320.28. Page A1. 

Midwest Manufacturing Up Slightly
The Purchasing Management Association of Chicago reported that its closely watched survey of manufacturing activity in the Midwest had found that manufacturing contracted in December for a third consecutive month, as inventories and order backlogs shrunk. C2.
 
Flatiron Leads Kozmo Investment
At a time when many venture capital firms have allowed their dot-coms to die, Flatiron Partners is raising $30 million for Kozmo.com. The investment is expected to keep Kozmo, an online delivery company, afloat. B3.
 
Santander to Buy Rest of Banespa
Banco Santander Central Hispano plans to buy the rest of Banco do Estado de Sao Paulo for $1.2 billion. Banco Santander won control of the former state bank in a November auction, paying $3.6 billion for a 33 percent stake. C2.
 
IBP Considers Tyson's Latest Bid
The beef processor, IBP, said it would evaluate a sweetened $2.8 billion takeover offer from Tyson, the poultry processor. C3.
 
No-Frills Airline Starts in Brazil
A new airline offering discount service on domestic routes, Gol Transportes Aereos, said it would serve seven Brazilian cities. C2.
 
Minnesota Sues Fleet Mortgage
The State of Minnesota has sued Fleet Mortgage, a unit of FleetBoston Financial, accusing the unit of illegally sharing confidential information about consumers with telemarketers and adding unrelated charges for services to consumers' mortgage bills. C14.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
STOCKS ARE LOWER ON THE FINAL DAY OF A BRUTAL YEAR

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The stock market stumbled hard once more yesterday as it wound up a brutal year that began with euphoria but ended with thousands of devastated investors and the worst returns in more than two decades.
Leading the dive from highs established early in the year were technology, media, telecommunications and Internet shares, which sent the Nasdaq composite index down 39.3 percent, its worst annual loss ever. 
 The prices of some popular Internet stocks now hover dangerously close to zero. More than two-thirds of stocks in the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index were down 30 percent or more for the year, while a third of those traded on the New York Stock Exchange were off that much. In total, about $2.7 trillion in shareholder value evaporated in the course of 2000.
For the first time since 1984, investors did better in the Treasury market, where notes and bonds returned just over 13 percent.
"Investors thought it was easy, that you could buy technology companies and they went up every day," said Frederick B. Taylor, chief investment officer at the United States Trust Company. "Now we have learned that is not the case."
Even if, as many strategists expect, the second half of 2001 will bring a revival of the market, the beginning of the year could continue to be rough. Forecasts of corporate earnings are being reeled in, and investors are waiting anxiously for the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates.
"We are shaking off the bottlenecks and excesses of the last run," said William Rhodes, chief investment strategist at the Williams Capital Group, "and you have to do that to get ready for the next run."
It was also a year of embarrassment for the many Wall Street analysts who persisted in promoting the new economy and technology companies long after the stocks began crumbling -- and then ended the year talking about how the technology bubble had burst.
Perhaps the only comfort in this year's decline is the recognition that it followed a remarkable record of gains. All three major indexes had double-digit returns in each of the previous five years. And the Nasdaq, which fell the hardest this year, had double-digit returns in 8 of the last 10 years, including an astounding 85.6 percent jump in 1999.
Moreover, outside of technology and e-commerce companies, the market did not do nearly so badly. Without such stocks, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index would have been up about 3 percent this year, reflecting the relatively strong performance of the old economy, as utilities, energy, tobacco, health care, bank and brokerage house stocks all had good years.
The Nasdaq had its worst year since its founding in 1971, after plunging 51 percent from its record high in March. Stalwarts of the technology bull market led the collapse, with Dell Computer plunging 66 percent and Microsoft, 63 percent.
The Street.com's index of Internet stocks rose 177.7 percent in the seven months leading to its March high, then plunged 77.5 percent by the end of the year. Among its components, Priceline.com dropped 97.2 percent; Yahoo, 86.1 percent; and Amazon.com, 77 percent for the year.
The S.& P. 500, denied a positive return by the technology drag, finished the year down 10.1 percent, its worst year since an 11.5 percent decline in 1977. Among the most widely held stocks, Lucent Technologies plunged 81 percent; Xerox, 80 percent; and AT&T, 67 percent.
The best performers from the old economy -- like Philip Morris, which surged 91.3 percent as fears abated about the damage from tobacco litigation -- helped limit the decline in the Dow Jones industrial average to 6.2 percent for the year. But that was still the Dow's worst year since 1981, when it fell 9.2 percent.
In preholiday trading yesterday, the Nasdaq was unable to end the year quietly. The index plunged 87.24 points, or 3.4 percent, to 2,470.52. It was the 94th trading day of the year in which the Nasdaq fell 2 percent or more. The Dow fell 81.91 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,786.75. The S.& P. 500 dropped 13.94 points, or 1 percent, to 1,330.28. The losses came amid relatively high trading volume, with slightly more than a billion shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange.
Have investors learned from this down year? Will they again chase after technology stocks -- or the next hot sector -- for their promise rather than their profits?
"If the market turned on a dime today and headed up for the next several months, it would be a lesson soon forgotten," Mr. Taylor said. "But I don't think that is going to happen."
Market strategists are also keen to learn whether investors have lost their habit of recent years of buying on the dips, a practice that helped the stock market recover from previous sharp slides during its long bull run.
For now, at least, caution seems to be trumping hope. "Investor expectations clearly have been wound down, and they are not buying on the dips," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Credit Suisse First Boston.
As the New Year begins, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries may add itself to the list of other problems that the market and investors face. It is planning to try to stem the recent decline in oil prices with production cuts early next year, a move that if successful would just cut further into consumer spending and economic growth. The price of oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange finished the year at $26.80 a barrel, down from the $37.20 high in September, and up just 4.7 percent for the year.
A further decline in the dollar, which has dropped 12 percent against the euro since October, might also worry investors, as it signals that foreigners are less attracted to the American market. But for the year, the euro was still down 6.3 percent against the dollar, its second year of decline since its inception in January 1999.
As the new year begins, investors also face a further round of earnings warnings for the fourth quarter of 2000. On Oct. 1, analysts were expecting 15.6 percent earnings growth for the S.& P. 500 in the quarter, according to First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks corporate earnings.
That projection already has dropped to 4.8 percent. "We don't have any reasonable sense of when the bottom is going to be and how deep it is going to be," said Chuck Hill, director of research at First Call.
Many factors contributed to the bursting of the dot-com bubble last spring and the subsequent tumble in the shares of companies like Lucent and Cisco Systems whose products form the backbones of the Internet.
The mad rush for any stock with a technology handle drove valuations to the moon. So it was easy, once extravagant expectations for sales growth and earnings began to be disappointed, for investors to find a reason to flee. Such disappointments abounded, as six interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve finally began to slow economic growth and tighten credit and, in turn, consumer spending began to slow.
So since September, investors have heard little but company after company warning that earnings and sales will be lower than expected.
Many of the factors that sent stocks lower helped the Treasury market rally. The prospect of slowing growth, combined with investors looking for a haven in the Treasury market, helped push prices higher and yields lower. Government budget surpluses, which led the Treasury to curtail the issuance of new debt and begin buying back existing long-term debt, made Treasuries more attractive, adding to the downward pressure on interest rates.
And as economic data began to confirm in November that the economy was slowing, the rally in the bond market gained momentum.
This month, when Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, signaled that growth had slowed so much that the central bank was ready to cut interest rates if there was a hint of a recession, rates fell even further. Investors are signaling that they are expecting the Fed to cut its short-term interest rate benchmark very soon, possibly before the next policy meeting at the end of January.
In trading yesterday, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was at 5.10 percent, down from 5.11 percent Thursday and from 6.44 at the end of 1999. The yield on the 30-year bond was at 5.46 percent, up from 5.44 percent Thursday but down from 6.48 percent a year ago.
With interest rates where they are now, it would not take much of a decline next year to push long-term rates down to their lowest levels in more than 30 years. And such a decline could eventually give the economy and the stock market the jump- start they need to make 2001 turn out fine by the end of the year.

LENGTH: 1114 words

HEADLINE: For Defeated Incumbents, Shock and an Interest in Want Ads

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
The spacious storefront office of Assemblyman Nelson Antonio Denis in East Harlem bustled with activity just a few short weeks ago. Now, it is nearly empty. The phone lines were disconnected a week ago, and callers are given no forwarding information. A moving company, courtesy of the State of New York, came in a day later to take back all of the office furniture and computers.
Mr. Denis, a 46-year-old lawyer completing his fourth year in the Assembly, lost in this year's Democratic primary to former City Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th. And Mr. Denis is learning some of the cruelties that come with the end of a politician's tenure in elective office. "The difficult thing," he said, sitting on a folding chair in a barren vestibule warmed by a portable space heater, "is that I never expected to lose. It still doesn't seem real." 
 For any politician, losing an election is a difficult emotional experience. But for an incumbent, a loss is apparently steeped in indignity. It is the bitter feeling of losing despite the exposure and power garnered by incumbency, the free mailings to constituents and the experience of having been successful in past elections.
In fact, more than 90 percent of all incumbents in the State Legislature are re-elected, according to a study by the New York Public Interest Research Group.
For the five incumbent members of the Legislature who lost re-election races this year, this was their last week in public office, with the victors taking over Jan 1. Four of the five were defeated in primary elections in September, and another lost in the general election in November. And while they all said that they had had time to adjust to their new unemployed status, the final days, they said, were particularly difficult.
While their losses are weeks or months old, they said they could still felt the sting of defeat.
"Sometimes, I think about what I could have done differently," Mr. Denis said. "You sometimes can't help retrace your footsteps.Sometimes, I wonder if things would have turned out differently if I had taken a more negative tone in the campaign," he added. "But that's not the way I do things. Plus, you can't go back and do things over again."
David Rosado, a two-term state senator from the Bronx, said he, too, was haunted by his defeat in the September primary and often rethought the campaign to consider where it might have gone wrong.
"This is the first time I ever lost an election, and it's tough for me," said Mr. Rosado, 58, who served in the City Council and the Assembly before running for the Senate in 1996. "I often spend time looking back and thinking about the mistakes I made this time.
"Normally, I run a very hands-on campaign," Mr. Rosado said. "But in this race, I let other people run my campaign. When I think about the campaign these days, I know I would have done a lot of things differently, if I could do it over again."
Mr. Rosado lost a particularly bruising battle -- in a case of political musical chairs -- to Pedro Espada Jr., the former state senator whom Mr. Rosado had unseated four years before. Their rivalry had been high-pitched ever since, adding to the sting of Mr. Rosado's defeat. But Mr. Rosado said that despite feeling wounded by the loss, he harbored no ill feeling toward Mr. Espada.
"I wish him the best of luck, I really do," Mr. Rosado said, before offering a commentary on the race.
"He deserves to be congratulated," the senator continued, sounding something short of magnanimous. "After all, he spent a lot of money on his campaign -- a lot more than we did. He spent money like he was running a campaign for governor instead of the State Senate.
"I didn't have that kind of money for mailings and ads on cable television. I couldn't even defend myself from his attacks. But I wish him the best. Really."
Assemblyman Robert A. Daly, a Republican from Niagara Falls, said he was not surprised that he lost after one term in office representing a heavily Democratic district. "But it's still tough," he said.
Mr. Daly, 40, lost in the November election to Francine DelMonte, a Democrat and a longtime aide to former Assemblyman Joseph T. Pillittere, Mr. Daly's predecessor.
"You are so focused during the campaign, so thoroughly focused," Mr. Daly said in a recent interview. "I put so much of my time and energy into this campaign. And then, it's over and you realize that you won't have that job anymore. And you have to ask yourself, what is the next step for me going to be?"
For Mr. Daly, who with his wife is raising four sons, the next step has been hard to define. Like other defeated incumbents, he has been confronting the prospect of finding employment at a time in life when many people are settled in their careers.
A salesman for an office products company before running for the Assembly, Mr. Daly will take a job as a special adviser for the New York Power Authority, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
For the defeated incumbents, what comes next remains an unresolved issue, even as they pack their belongings and move out of their government offices.
"I haven't quite figured that out," said Edward Griffith, a Democratic assemblyman from Brooklyn who was defeated in the September primary after 28 years in office. "I have looked into a number of things. But nothing is certain."
Alfred T. Coppola, 58, a state senator from Buffalo who lost in the September primary, said that his financial situation necessitated his working.
"I don't have any idea what I will do," said Mr. Coppola, who lost to a Buffalo city councilman, Byron W. Brown. "I've been working in government as a city councilman for 17 years before coming to the Senate, so I'm not eligible to collect on the 20-year pension. As it stands now, I would be getting just $10,000 a year. And I cannot collect Social Security because I'm just 58."
When asked about the future, he said, "Nothing has come up at this point in time, but I will have to do something."
Similarly, Mr. Rosado said he would receive a monthly pension of about $900 -- half of what it would have been had he served another two-year term.
"So, I've got to work now," he said. "I've got to look for a job. I don't think I will have too much of a problem finding one. But I've still got to go out and find one."
Mr. Denis said he would practice law full time, explaining that he wanted to maintain a presence in the neighborhood he represented for the last four years. He said he had no particular plans to run for office again, but he added that he had not ruled it out, either.
"You never know what the future holds," he said. "I just might do it again one day."

HEADLINE: Germany's Financial Heart Is Open but Wary

SERIES: CROSSING BORDERS: Testing Tolerance

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Dec. 28

 BODY:
With its cluster of high-rises known as the "Frankfurter Manhattan," its big banks and its bustling airport, this is a town with pretensions. Petra Roth, the mayor, sees it as a "global city providing hub functions for the continent," a place that should be "as cosmopolitan as New York."
On one level, such ambitions seem droll. The first reaction of Jeffery H. Perkins, an American banker, to the city was, "You can't be serious -- where is it?" The compact downtown area evokes Des Moines more than Manhattan. But on another level, the mayor has a point: Frankfurt is a city of foreigners. 
 Not just dapper corporate types like Mr. Perkins. Frankfurt is home to 80,000 Muslims, most of them Turks of modest means. Foreigners, including a large contingent from the former Yugoslavia, make up 30 percent of the population, one of the highest ratios for any town in a Europe troubled by immigration. But there is no blood on the streets. Quietly flows the Main River beneath that mock-New-World skyline.
As Germany goes these days, so goes Europe. And if Frankfurt, the headquarters for Europe's new Central Bank and so the capital of Europe's nascent shared currency, the euro, is comfortable being a part-Muslim city with 27 discreet mosques, perhaps the so-called "New Europe" of one money and blurred borders can be a more tolerant place.
"Xenophobia is very unusual in Frankfurt," said Francesco Rinaldi, an Italian banker. "Perhaps it's the 300 foreign banks, or the vast airport, or the long American presence." Not until 1994 did 30,000 American troops pack up and go home -- the cold war won and, so people here say, the city shaped in the soldiers' open, can-do spirit.
But even here, at the heart of American-influenced Europe, far from the traumatized psyche of a former East German city like Dessau, where rightists this year killed one African immigrant (whose wife was German), the ghost of xenophobia is not entirely absent. For Frankfurt -- like Germany, like Europe -- is struggling to define a shifting identity.
As the departed American soldiers suggest, this city is no longer part of a cold war country living what Zafer Senocak, a German intellectual of Turkish descent, has called a "quasi a-national existence under the umbrella of the West." Far from it: this is now the financial center of a strong Germany seeking to define and express a new national pride.
But Frankfurt is also the capital of a unique experiment in dismantling the nation state through the voluntary abandonment of sovereignty involved in giving up national control of monetary policy and adopting a common currency.
So the continent's largest state, one reborn only in 1990, yet also one in dismantlement, veers this way and that in its mood, one minute nostalgic for a "proud Fatherland," the next in the vanguard of what Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, himself a child of Frankfurt, calls the postnational era.
Its unease about national identity -- and the anti-immigrant outbursts that sometimes accompany it -- is often evident, as it is in other nations of the 15-member European Union, a bloc integrating ever more without putting the experiment directly to the vote of its 360 million citizens.
Recent surveys suggest that a conservative-nationalist mood may be ascendant in Germany. Over the past year, the number of Germans who believe defense of the nation state is important has risen to 56 percent from 48 percent, according to surveys conducted for the European Union. Other polls suggest that as many as 67 percent of Germans feel there are too many foreigners in the country.
But Frankfurt has not experienced the xenophobic attacks of some other smaller German towns, suggesting that anti-immigrant violence may often exist in inverse proportion to the number of foreigners actually present.
"We have few problems in Frankfurt and many in Dessau, where immigrants are 1 percent of the population," Otto Schily, Germany's interior minister, said in an interview. "Fears of foreigners are often wild fantasies."
Frankfurt has been trying to open minds to foreigners for a long time. A decade ago, prodded by Daniel Cohn-Bendit, the French-German hero of the May 1968 student uprising in Paris, now a Green politician who makes Frankfurt his home, this city opened a "Multicultural Office" -- a department committed to furthering and recognizing the cultural diversity of the population.
Today, however, multiculturalism is out of fashion at a city hall under Christian Democratic control. Mr. Cohn-Bendit's office has been placed within a new "Integration Department." The two names -- the former a celebration of cultural diversity, the latter an invitation to cultural conformity -- reflect Frankfurt's shifts.
"A measure of national pride and a desire that immigrants adapt to national customs is normal," said Albrecht Magen, 71, the Christian Democrat who heads Frankfurt's new drive to "integrate" immigrants. "You cannot always remind us of our history in order to deny Germany any national sentiment. If you remind somebody constantly that he was a bad boy at school, he will probably be a bad boy."
For this retired lawyer, the move away from the "ungovernable parallel worlds of multiculturalism" is salutary. Integration, he adds, "does not mean we want to baptize the Muslims"; it means they should adapt to Germany, learn its language, know its laws.
These conflicting currents are familiar to Petra Bayam, 35, a Frankfurt corporate lawyer. Now, at the end of the holy month of Ramadan, she finds herself sitting without shoes at a table set for a Turkish feast.
Around her sit a dozen relatives, mostly young Turkish-Germans, fluent in German but not -- yet, at least -- German citizens. A nephew, Behadir Bayam, 15, says: "When I'm in Turkey, people say, 'Come here, you German.' When I'm here, people say, 'Come here, you Turk.' So I'm not sure who I am."
So it goes among Europe's immigrants, often seen, seldom understood, elusive shadows on the landscape. Across the continent, residents seem to have caught a collective bout of cold feet about integrating immigrants, and perhaps nowhere more so than in Germany, which has the largest number of foreigners -- 7.2 million -- although the highest percentage is in Switzerland.
In countries from Austria to Belgium, European societies with uncertain identities in the cold war's aftermath have been looking for another external enemy against which to define themselves -- and often seem unable to find a better target than the migrant.
Four decades have passed since Germany, which unlike France and Britain had no former empire to turn to for laborers, signed an agreement with Turkey to bring in "guest workers." Recruitment officially stopped in 1973, but the "guests" stayed and multiplied -- and today number more than 2.1 million, many in the Frankfurt area.
Their presence troubles a lot of Germans, who feel exploited by the Turks, or deceived by such eternal "guests," or wary of Islam, or threatened in a German national culture now being rediscovered.
The "Turkengefahr," or Turkish danger, is a still potent ghost in the history of Germany and especially Austria, where many battles were fought against the invading infidel. Martin Luther called the Turk a "cunning, cruel, devious, impetuous murderer"; such stereotypes are not easily overcome.
But Ms. Bayam overcame them. Born Petra Fuchs, the only child of a Catholic mother and Protestant father, she this year married her longtime boyfriend, Hulisi Bayam, another lawyer, the son of Turkish immigrants from Antalya. Such mixed marriages, while growing in number, remain rare.
They started dating at university. Her parents, professionals, were "a bit surprised." His parents, construction-site and factory laborers, were a "bit worried." She went to Turkey and discovered her prejudices: "I had thought all the women covered their heads and all the men were machos," she says. "But Turkey was not like that."
Hulisi Bayam had already defied the stock images. He arrived in Germany in 1973 at age 9, speaking not a word of German. Today, his German is of an almost stylized perfection, his urbane manner exudes sophistication, and his consulting company, Bayam AG, is an important bridge between the German and Turkish business worlds.
They were married on Feb. 12 in a Frankfurt church. The priest, a broad-minded man, was amenable -- to the point of allowing an Islamic prayer to be spoken by a Muslim cleric. It was the first time such an eclectic ceremony had been permitted in the church.
The one small problem involved the photographs. The photographer, a German, was troubled by the fact that Hulisi is shorter than Petra. So he placed the groom above the bride on a staircase. When some of Petra's German friends saw the pictures, they perceived in Hulisi's positioning a sign that "he's a Turkish macho."
So it goes with stereotypes; they endure. Islam equals fundamentalism. Turks often run fruit and vegetable stores in Germany: proof that at heart they are peasant farmers. They speak poor German after many years: evidence of their ignorance.
But in the couple's families, familiarity brought rapid conciliation. "Of course, Hulisi's family had always thought in terms of a Turkish wife, but they accepted me quickly," Ms. Bayam said. "And my own had always taught me that nationality or religion should play no divisive role. They were open to Hulisi."
Indeed, Ms. Bayam's mother, Marritta Fuchs, knows what it is like to be a stranger. After World War II, her family, wealthy landowners, were given one hour to leave the Sudetenland as Czech forces drove out ethnic Germans in revenge for Hitler's war. She eventually settled in Frankfurt, and the lesson she gave her daughter was not one of rancor; it was one of the folly of ethnic hatred.
The lesson was taken to heart. Ms. Bayam -- widely traveled, wary of any national sentiment, an internationalist -- is representative of a broad swath of young Germans who, prodded by horrific history, have perhaps moved further beyond patriotic feeling than any other people in Europe. These Germans find it natural to reach out to and embrace other cultures -- sometimes as an escape from their own.
But another broad swath of Germans, in the east of the country but not only there, are reacting against the likes of Ms. Bayam. They cling to a homogeneous image of a German "Volk" determined by bloodlines; they want to wave German flags and sing the German anthem without feeling Hitler forever precluded such "normal" expressions of patriotism; they seek to reinforce a renascent German identity.
Many in this group are no more than conservative patriots. But others are the rabid nationalists who, in 1992 and 1993, set fire to Turkish homes in Molln and Solingen -- killing eight Turks in all. In a community that is now the largest minority of another faith in Germany since the prewar Jews, these memories live on.
Mr. Bayam, a thoughtful man, is at home in Germany -- more so than in Turkey, he says. Like other immigrants, he has benefited from the very things -- free university education, free health care -- that tend to breed resentful talk of foreigners "exploiting" European welfare systems. But he is troubled by the direction taken now by many Germans -- indeed, by conservatives across Europe -- who are essentially telling immigrants: conform, or go home.
It is still a battle, he says, to convince Germans that Islam can also mean tolerance, and that Turks are part of this society, here to stay. More than 25,000 Turks are now enrolled in Germany's universities, more than 50,000 own businesses, and, in 1999, 84,000 were granted German citizenship -- by far the largest group of foreigners.
Citizenship laws were somewhat liberalized in 1999, breaking with old German notion that bloodlines define the nation, but not as much as many Turks wanted. And over the past year, the conditions of that citizenship seem to have become ever more exacting.
"The buzz word in Frankfurt is integration," Mr. Bayam said. "But does integration mean I have to give up my Turkish identity? Then I say, no. Does it mean Christianity? Then I say, no. Or does it mean that I learn other things and Germans help me do so and we talk and reach out to each other? Then I say, yes."
At his feast table, Mr. Bayam's 72-year-old mother, Fatma, sits to his left, and his sister-in-law, Makbule Bayam, on the other side. Fatma wears a head scarf; Makbule does not; both speak broken German.
Makbule has worked for 18 years in an old people's home. She started out cleaning, then cooking. Then she was asked to help with the old Germans: cleaning, feeding and changing often helpless people.
At first she declined. Then, she agreed, but only to wash the women. After five years, she said all right, she'd wash the naked old men, too. She earns good money, close to $2,000 a month, and like the other immigrants there -- Turks, Portuguese, Indians, Yugoslavs -- she is ready to do work that Germans are reluctant to do.
This is a glimpse of Germany's -- and Europe's -- future: a fast-aging, generally prosperous population, dependent on immigrants. Of the Turks in Germany, 70 percent are under 35.
Mr. Bayam's mother is bright-eyed and vigorous, the matriarch. When she arrived in Germany three decades ago, she worked first in a bread factory. Later she moved to a loudspeaker company, where, on arrival, her colleagues told her to remove her head scarf. The manager was called, and after some discussion decided that, with or without a head scarf, she worked well, and could do as she wanted.
At the feast, Fatma's head scarf is gold and black, similar in color to the stylish silk scarf her German daughter-in-law wears around her neck. They embrace: an image of barriers broken.
Frankfurt has worked hard to cut through divisions. The city avoided ghettos by scattering foreigners in various districts and has tried to contain conflicts through social workers trained to defuse tensions over loud foreign music or pungent lamb. Thirty percent of marriages in the city are now mixed -- between Germans and Italians, for example -- although very few cross the Christian-Islamic divide.
The Integration Office, headed by Mr. Magen, has had its successes -- notably with a program called "Mamma speaks German," an attempt to teach the language to immigrants like Makbule Bayam, whose German-born children are fluent.
Over all, however, Mr. Magen feels integration is becoming ever more difficult. He complains about a backlash, among Turks, to resurgent German national pride; he says the several Turkish satellite television stations now available here reinforce divisions, and help keep Turks Turkish.
Like Ms. Bayam, this apparently well-meaning man has his own private history of German integration. His father, he confides, was a Jew -- baptized and entirely assimilated, but still a Jew by Hitler's definition -- and had to hide during the war. "After the war," he says, "We just became Germans."
And why are Germans, his countrymen and women, afraid of Islam? Because, he says, they are no longer real Christians and are bewildered by the intensity of many Muslims' attachment to their religion. Because they have "Uberfremdungsangst" -- a fear of an "overforeignerization" that will destroy their culture.
But what is this culture, exactly, in the land of Goethe and Auschwitz, a place where Turkish kebabs are as popular as wurst, and 9 percent of the population is foreign? That is hard to say. "Look," says Mr. Magen, finally and enigmatically, "Life is not black and white. It is gray."
The view from his window is gray, out across an old bridge over the Main to a church spire on the other side, and behind the church the high-rises of Frankfurt's little Manhattan (with 15 more skyscrapers planned), and along the river bank the Jewish Museum, everywhere the impression of a shattered history.
Germany is not black and white. It is gray. But the hues of east and west, of Islamic culture and what some now call Judeo-Christian values, of Bayams and Magens, have yet to blend comfortably -- even in a city like Frankfurt where they co-exist in peace.
 
Crossing Borders
 
Articles in this series have examined the ways in which migration is changing the face of Europe. Previous articles dealt with criminal groups smuggling asylum seekers into a Europe that needs but does not welcome them; how East European women are tempted west, then sold into the sex trade; and the travails of "new Europeans" living the clash between the cultures of their parents and those of their adopted homelands.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 862 words

HEADLINE: Uneven Choices for the Cabinet

 BODY:
President-elect George W. Bush continued to build his cabinet team yesterday, mixing interesting choices for the departments of Education and Health and Human Services with an unsettling pick for the Interior Department. Both Tommy Thompson, the Wisconsin governor, who will run H.H.S., and Rod Paige, the Houston public school superintendent, who will run Education, will bring experience and a reputation for flexibility to their jobs. Gale Norton, the former Colorado attorney general, chosen for Interior, brings considerable familiarity with environmental issues but also a reputation as a dedicated property rights advocate with deep reservations about the Clinton administration's aggressive efforts to enlarge federal protections for wilderness and wildlife.
Mr. Thompson is the architect of one of the country's most innovative welfare reform policies. As such, he promises to bring creativity to the federal agency that oversees welfare, Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security. When he became governor in 1987, about 100,000 Wisconsin families collected welfare benefits. As he prepares to leave, the number is down, by one measure, to about 20,000. Wisconsin's robust economy has been one big reason for this decline. Another has been Mr. Thompson's innovative policies. Like others in his party, he preaches individual responsibility and work. Wisconsin's program puts everyone in some type of job, including community service for those unable to find employment in the private sector. 
 But Mr. Thompson also insists on spending government money to provide the working poor with ample medical insurance, child care assistance and other support services. When the new welfare law comes up for reauthorization in 2002, some Republicans will argue for cutting back federal money because welfare rolls have shriveled. Mr. Thompson can be expected to pull hard in the opposite direction, calling on Congress to keep funding flowing so that states can make sure that people who have left the welfare rolls stay off.
The biggest question mark about Mr. Thompson is his record on abortion. He is adamantly pro-life, and signed some of the nation's harshest anti-abortion laws. One, blocked by the Supreme Court, would have imposed sentences up to life on doctors who perform so-called partial birth abortions. Mr. Thompson cannot change the basic laws governing a woman's right to choose, but his department is enormously important to women's reproductive freedoms. For example, under President Clinton officials at the department fought hard to make available the "morning-after" pill, whose use is opposed by many right-to-life groups. The fear among women's groups is that Mr. Thompson will reverse this and other enlightened policies.
Mr. Paige, the education secretary-designate, is credited with greatly improving Houston's school system, including a significant increase in test scores. A Republican and longtime Bush family friend, he would be the second African-American in the cabinet alongside Colin Powell. Based on his public record, Mr. Paige seems a wise choice to help Mr. Bush carry out his campaign pledge to bring innovative solutions to educational problems.
Of the three designees, Ms. Norton is clearly the most controversial. Both she and Mr. Bush sounded the right notes in their remarks yesterday. Ms. Norton spoke of the "awesome responsibility" of managing the public lands and of her wish to "preserve our wonderful national treasures, restore endangered species, and help Americans enjoy the great outdoors."
Nevertheless, her political pedigree is deeply disturbing. She has been associated with two of the worst Interior secretaries in the department's history, James Watt and Donald Hodel, both appointed by Ronald Reagan. As a young attorney she was hired by Mr. Watt for a staff position at the Mountain States Legal Foundation, a sort of right-wing answer to the Sierra Club that favors traditional Western economic interests like ranching, mining and forestry, and has litigated vigorously against the Endangered Species Act and other basic federal statutes that the Interior Department is sworn to uphold. In the mid-1980's Ms. Norton served as associate solicitor at Interior, where she helped craft the legal basis for Mr. Hodel's efforts to open the coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration. Mr. Bush promised during his campaign to ask Congress to open the plain for drilling, and in Ms. Norton he has an enthusiastic ally.
As attorney general, Ms. Norton was a strong advocate of Colorado's "self-audit" law, which grants companies amnesty from enforcement of federal air and water pollution laws if they police themselves. This law angered the Environmental Protection Agency in Washington but was much favored by Colorado businesses.
Ms. Norton's task is to rise above the policy of reckless commercial exploitation espoused by old patrons like Mr. Hodel and honor her department's broader mandate to protect the nation's natural resources. Even a cursory inspection of the opinion surveys will tell her that Americans in overwhelming numbers will want her to do exactly that.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Jackson's Teammates Saw Only a Captain

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

 BODY:
THE vote was held in secret, in a room in Ray Tompkins House beside the Yale gym in New Haven in late November 1948. It was to determine the captain for the 1949 Eli football team. A school sports ethic held that no one was to discuss whose name he was going to write on the paper ballot.
As one of the guards on the team, Lenny Fasano -- now Dr. Fasano, an internist in New Haven -- recalls, the vote was 49 to 1 for a fullback and punter named Levi Jackson. 
 "Levi was so adored and beloved by the rest of us, and he was such a good player, that I couldn't believe anyone voted for someone else," Fasano said. "After the vote was announced, and we followed the traditional drinking a glass of Champagne to our new captain and then throwing the glasses against the wall, I said to Levi, 'I've got to find out who voted for the other guy.' He said: 'I did, Lenny. I wouldn't vote for myself.' "
The election made national news, for Levi Jackson was black, the first of his race to be chosen for the prestigious honor in the history of Yale football. Editorials praised the so-called "broad-mindedness" of the electors as being "wonderful." Two, however, saw it a bit differently.
"What the hell's so wonderful about it? This is America, isn't it?" asked Bill Corum, sports columnist for The New York Journal-American. And Red Smith replied to the rhetorical questions in his column the following day in The New York Herald Tribune: "A small echo answers, 'Hooray!' Look, what the Yale kids did wasn't anything wonderful. . . . It's what decent people expect of decent people." He added: "When you say the Yale football players have struck a blow for tolerance, then you are condescending to Levi Jackson. . . . Do you tolerate right guys?"
Of course, Corum and Smith knew the significance of such acceptance of a black, 19 months after Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier in major league baseball. And what they were saying in their bitter irony was: Why should something like this have taken so long, at Yale and elsewhere in America? Where were the masses of decent people? Why should there even be a need for "racial progress," which Jackson's election supposedly symbolized?
Jackson, who set 13 modern Yale football records, died earlier this month at age 74. He graduated from Yale with majors in sociology, psychology and economics, had served in the Army, became an executive with Ford, rising to become one of its top executives before retiring in 1983 as a vice president. He was active in community affairs in Detroit, his adopted hometown -- he was reared in Branford, Conn. -- and was appointed to the National Selective Service Appeal Board, which settled disputes over eligibility for the military draft.
"Levi and I talked often about the black athlete in America," said Fasano, who went to grade school, high school, college and served in the Army with Jackson, a lifelong friend. "He wasn't happy with black athletes leaving college early, or even going straight to the pros."
Fasano said Jackson believed black athletes "had to take advantage of an education, otherwise you won't be able to rise."
"With no education, you go from being a star in sports back to the ghetto."
Jackson lived what he believed. "I remember even in high school that Levi would stay up to 1 or 2 in the morning, studying," Fasano recalled. Jackson, whose father was a steward in the Yale dining halls, was the youngest of six children and the only one to get a college education -- helped by the G.I. Bill of Rights, after he served in the Army during World War II.
"It upset him when some black athletes acted inappropriately," Fasano said, "but he said he comprehended where some of that came from. Having been so discriminated against by whites, these athletes had so much hatred in them that it blinded their judgment. Levi said, 'They have to learn that they will not be able to compete in this world with that attitude.' "
Denyse Jackson, one of Jackson's two daughters, recalled that her father "never said a mean thing about anyone."
"He always tried to understand," she said. "And he always wanted to be known first, not for football, but for having got his education."
About that vote for the Yale captaincy, Fasano recalled: "You know, it didn't dawn on us that we were voting for someone of a different color. And when he was carrying the ball, we would have killed ourselves for him. We didn't tolerate Levi Jackson, we loved him."

LENGTH: 620 words

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Saints to Play It Again, With a Focus on Faulk

BYLINE: By CHARLIE NOBLES 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29

 BODY:
Jim Haslett is acutely aware that his New Orleans Saints have a 7-1 road record, best in the National Football League, while they have won only three of eight games at the Superdome. That is where they will meet the St. Louis Rams on Saturday in a National Football Conference first-round playoff game.
"We've thought about busing them to the airport and flying around the city a couple times and landing," Haslett said with an impish smile. 
 Short of doing that, Haslett hopes he has at least devised a way to slow down Rams running back Marshall Faulk, who was named the league's most valuable player on Wednesday. This past Sunday, at the Superdome, Faulk punctured the Saints for 220 rushing yards and 2 rushing touchdowns, and added 7 receptions for 41 yards and another touchdown in a 26-21 St. Louis victory that forced Saturday's rematch.
"The films showed that we freelanced too much in the last game," Haslett said. "Some of it was just the frustration of playing a back of such quality. But it's correctable. We'll try to play disciplined football, like we have for the last couple of months. We'll be trying to take away what he does best."
In the next breath, though, Haslett wondered aloud whether the Rams have too many offensive weapons for any defense to contain, with quarterback Kurt Warner -- the league's most valuable player last season -- and two of the N.F.C.'s top receivers in Isaac Bruce and Torry Holt to complement Faulk.
St. Louis, which will be playing its third game against the Saints in 35 days (they split the first two), is the league's dominant offensive team this season. The Rams set N.F.L. records for offensive yards (7,335) and passing yards (5,492), eclipsing the 1984 Dan Marino-led Miami Dolphins.
Moreover, they led the league in yards per game (458.4), points per game (33.8), rushing touchdowns (26), passing touchdowns (37) and they had an incredible 47.5 percent third-down conversion rate.
Haslett said that even if the Saints had "15 or 16 guys" on the field defending the Rams, they would still have a hard time.
The Saints have a double challenge in attempting to eliminate the Rams, last season's Super Bowl champions. Besides St. Louis, they have their own demons to address: they have never won a playoff game.
The Saints' playoff history requires 3 pages of a 278-page media guide. It includes four games -- all losses, with the last coming in 1993. This is the tale of woe for a franchise that joined the N.F.L. in 1967.
Haslett, however, has made significant inroads in doing the seemingly impossible. The Saints are 10-6, same as St. Louis, despite one of the league's worst run of injuries. Strikingly, they begin their run in the playoffs with an inexperienced quarterback in Aaron Brooks and a veteran running back in Terry Allen, who was unemployed barely a month ago.
Brooks replaced Jeff Blake, who went out with a broken foot on Nov. 19, and Allen took over for the 1998 Heisman Trophy winner, Ricky Williams, who broke an ankle on Nov. 12.
Saturday's game did not sell out until today. It is as if Saints partisans are sensing they might be let down yet again.
"People still look at us and think: 'When's it going to happen? When are we going to see the same old Saints?' " guard-center Tom Ackerman said. "Well, these are not the same old Saints. It's not even close."
If the Saints figure out a way to stymie Faulk, the spotlight will surely fall on Warner. The 18 interceptions he threw this season are the most by any quarterback in the playoffs, and 12 of them have come on the road. He was out with an injury on Nov. 26, when New Orleans defeated the Rams, a 31-24 victory that some call the biggest in Saints history.

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
Murky Responses to Plan As Mideast Violence Flares
Israelis and Palestinians continued to wrangle over an 11th-hour compromise proposed by the Clinton administration, as new violence left a Palestinian policeman dead. Prime Minister Ehud Barak declared that he would never cede sovereignty over the Temple Mount, while the Palestinian Authority said it was ready to negotiate "under international sponsorship" but said nothing about accepting the American initiative. A5 

Pilots Fight Off Attacker
An apparently deranged passenger tried to seize control of a British Airways jet carrying nearly 400 people from London to Kenya and plunged the plane into a dive that the pilots managed to recover from only after subduing the man in a cockpit struggle. The man was taken to a Nairobi hospital, where he was sedated and placed under police guard. A4
 
Ghana Opposition Leader Wins
John Agyekum Kufuor was declared the winner in the presidential runoff election when his rival, Vice President John Atta Mills, conceded. Mr. Kufuor will succeed the longtime president, Jerry Rawlings. A4
 
6 Killed in Colombian Ambush
Diego Turbay, the head of a government commission that tries to foster dialogue between the government and rebel groups, was killed along with his mother and four other people in an ambush. The police blamed Colombia's biggest rebel group, FARC. The episode was expected to deal a blow to the unsteady peace process. A7
 
Election Overturned in Mexico
A court overturned the election of the governor of Tabasco, who is from the Institutional Revolutionary Party, the nation's former ruling party. The tribunal found enough evidence of impropriety in the October voting to annul the results, stripping the party of its only significant victory since July, when it lost the presidency after 71 years in office. A7
 
New Candidate in Peru
A former prime minister, Federico Salas, said he would run for president in April, though a congressional commission has recommended that corruption charges be brought against him. Mr. Salas worked for former President Alberto Fujimori in the final months of his scandal-ridden term. (Reuters)
 
World Briefing A4
 
NATIONAL A8-13, 16
 
Bush Fills Four Posts; Still Seeking a Democrat
President-elect George W. Bush chose Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin to lead the Department of Health and Human Services. Gale A. Norton, the former attorney general of Colorado and an advocate of limiting federal regulation of land use, was picked for interior secretary. Rod Paige, who overhauled the Houston schools as superintendent during Mr. Bush's term as Texas governor, was chosen for education secretary. Anthony Principi, who served as acting secretary of veterans affairs under Mr. Bush's father, was chosen to run that department again. A1
 
With only three cabinet posts left to be filled, Mr. Bush has yet to name a Democrat to a cabinet post. He said he had tried to recruit Democrats, but had so far had no success. A11
 
Gore's Tally Grows, to No Avail
Al Gore's popular vote lead over George W. Bush has grown to more than half a million, according to a state-by-state survey of final certified results by The Associated Press. The totals were: 50,996,116 for Mr. Gore and 50,456,169 for Mr. Bush. A11
 
A House After the White House
President Clinton and Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton signed a contract to buy a five-bedroom, brick colonial house near Embassy Row in Washington for $2.85 million. A13
 
Winter Storms Grind On
Utility workers and snow and ice removal crews were digging out from an icy storm that claimed 41 lives in the Southern Plains this week. The Midwest was grappling with a separate storm that was moving toward the Northeast, where it was expected to converge with an off-shore system today. Forecasters said the combined storm could deliver high winds and up to 16 inches of snow. A8
 
Mass Slaying in Philadelphia
The police were searching for four gunmen who shot 10 people made to lie face-down in a boarded-up row house on Thursday, killing 7 and wounding 3. The authorities said drugs might have been involved. A8
 
Seattle Strike Partly Settled
A dispute over the terms of possible layoffs cut short a contract vote by members of the Newspaper Guild at The Seattle Times, on the 38th day of a strike. But striking workers at The Post-Intelligencer approved their contract offer, 88 to 29. A13
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
City Braces for Icy Blast; Snow Emergency Declared
Mayor Giuliani assured residents that the city was ready for the powerful snowstorm barreling east. As a precaution, he declared a snow emergency effective at midnight last night and deployed a fleet of tow trucks to remove cars parked on snow routes. Forecasters said 8 to 16 inches of snow could fall on the region. Several airlines warned travelers to expect flight cancellations. A1
 
Nuclear Plant Firing Up Again
Con Edison is set to restart its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant in Westchester, anticipating that by tomorrow it will begin producing electricity for the first time since it was closed in February after a radioactive leak. B1
 
Man Run Over by Subway
Aris Gil, 20, lost three fingers when he fell to the tracks trying to escape three robbers on an E train in Queens and the train ran over his hand, the police said. B3
 
New Life for a Dot-Com
The online delivery company Kozmo.com is running low on cash, but its balance sheet is improving in New York City and some other markets, prompting the venture capital firm Flatiron Partners to lead a $30 million investment in Kozmo. B3

A Manhattan judge froze $537,000 from the failed Senate campaign of Representative Rick Lazio, after a political fund raiser, Laura Van Hove, sued Lazio 2000, saying she was owed at least that amount for her work. B5

Stocks Close Out a Dismal Year
The Nasdaq plunged 87.24 points, or 3.4 percent, to 2,470.52, to end the year down 39.3 percent, its worst annual loss ever. The Dow fell 81.91 points, to 10,786.75, off 6.2 percent for the year. The S.& P. 500 dropped 13.94 points, or 1 percent, to 1,330.28, down 10.1 percent for 2000. A1
 
Companies raised $393 billion from American investors in the last quarter, down 2.5 percent from the fourth quarter of 1999 and less than in any quarter since spring 1997. C1
